movie_review_blurb: The Last Jedi is not just a bold, fresh and humorous new addition to the franchise -- it's the one that will change it forever.
There is no beauty; instead, an oppressive emotional intensity which shuts out the spectator.
movie_title: Scenes from a Marriage (Scener ur ett äktenskap) (1974)

movie_review_blurb: Very convincingly photographed.
Take the kids for once.
movie_title: Jumping Over Puddles (Uz zase skácu pres kaluze) (1971)

movie_review_blurb: This is Fassbinder's first public showing in this country and it will not be the last; [he's] a highly skilled German director not yet thirty who also wrote the screenplay and indeed the theme music.
movie_title: Angst Essen Seele auf (Ali: Fear Eats the Soul) (1974)

movie_review_blurb: Ash Wednesday is a woman's film of a particularly bogus kind.
A tragi-comedy in which our modern beasts of burden ultimately exact revenge with horrific panache.
The film is interesting for what it shows of San Francisco's undertown but its psychology is lame [and] the plot an illogical mess.
Without a doubt Orient Express is a vastly entertaining film.
Lo and Behold makes sure to inextricably tie utopian goals to darker, more deadly possible outcomes. But the paradox is that the film is strangely inspiring even in its more alarming moments.
movie_title: Lo and Behold, Reveries of the Connected World (2016)

movie_review_blurb: How you'll feel about The Post is more or less preordained by how you feel about Hollywood, Spielberg, the yearly tradition of Oscar bait, and the boogeyman of a "liberal media"...
Moonlight is a drama that can be separated from representational politics, but shouldn't be.

Gillespie's insistence on comedy in place of what's largely missing from the film - perspective, pathos - falsely energizes the story. It's sped up but feels hollow. A spinning compass whose needle is about to snap.
While the film doesn't entirely deliver on its start, the overall mood remains pricked by a similar sense of doom and shivering unease.
A riveting, impossible-to-shake masterwork that leaves the audience spooked, not by its telling but by its commitment to abstract themes of grief, solitude and coming of age.

It's an astonishing, often challenging and sharp examination of race in the United States, confronting how the country's history repeats and how Baldwin insisted we must remember, relentlessly question, remain conscientious and resist.
Daughters' impressionistic look at the Great Migration (who will go, who will stay, and at what cost?) combines a corporeal sense of history with poetic, often indirect and allegorical underpinnings.
A cathartic experience of sorts, 12 Years A Slave achieves something few other films do. It makes you uncomfortable.
Even when the film tarries perilously close to Fight Club "what is reality?" territory, it works to ultimately benefit the whole.
Chasing Trane gets off to a passable, if unimaginative, start telling John Coltrane's story, but it fails to finish the job with any kind of grace or equanimity.
movie_title: Chasing Trane: The John Coltrane Documentary (2017)

movie_review_blurb: An imperfect portrait, then, but hardly an unworthy one.
Kuso is gross. ... I'm not terrifically excited to revisit it, at least until my stomach settles a little from the first go.
There's a ton of increasingly focused talent on display here.
A classic of both queer cinema and experimental film, and it's a real boon to cinephiles everywhere that it's being made widely available again.
It's in that lengthy middle where the film gets lost.

Ridiculous, but gleefully so.
Shallow, meandering, predictable, padded, and jam-packed with one unfunny, hoarily conceived slapstick bit or pratfall after the next.
Delightful and inventively savvy. The year's last animated film is also its best.

A lavish, high-octane epic. King Kong has a welcome heart to go along with its razzle-dazzle, but it is a heart that alternates between hot and cold.
Profound. Transcendent. Heartbreaking. Brokeback Mountain is a cinematic triumph of incendiary depth and poeticism.
An occasionally incomprehensible work that still manages to be captivating and consistently watchable.
A grandly successful fantasy. Practically flawless casting, bewitching storytelling and impressive visual effects bring the beautiful, troubled land of Narnia to life.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: The Lion, The Witch and The Wardrobe (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Won't be winning any awards for originality or visionary achievement, but in its own small, sweet way, the filmand Felicity Huffmanwin you over.
The waste of talent and money thrown into this cheesy, haphazard production should be a criminal offense the world over.
The Ice Harvest has talent to spare in front of the camera, but isn't nearly as smart or sharp as it would like to be.

There are funny moments--a few even hilarious--but the majority of jokes try so hard and go so far over-the-top that they splat on the ground before takeoff.
An emotional, exhilarating experience, Rent is alive with such boundless energy and joy that it is one of the year's most purely entertaining cinematic efforts.
The powerhouse performances from Joaquin Phoenix and Reese Witherspoon sell even the mustier of moments.
Marvelously directed and artistically without fault, it's the series' most complete and satisfying entry to date on all counts.

movie_review_blurb: A bland sitcom posing as a star-studded feature film.

When The Ringer was over, my world hadn't changed, but there was a smile that remained on my face.
Emotionally satisfying and rings exceedingly true.
An effective, wise, and frequently amusing entertainment that fondly sticks in the viewer's memory after the end credits have finished rolling.

Gentle-hearted and surprisingly sweet.

Shallow and utterly irrelevant.

About as derivative and forgettable as this genre comes.

Allen's strongest and most self-assured dramatic feature in over a decade. Welcome back, Woody! You've been missed.

The season's first unadulterated disappointment.

Consistently too dumb in its plotting to elicit the sort of enchantment and whimsy it strives for.

Doesn't run out of steam as quickly as the first one did. The Transporter 2 barrels right along, embracing its over-the-top stupidity in the process.
A warm and honest gem of a movie, frequently laugh-out-loud funny in surprising and genuine ways, and quietly touching without forcing obvious emotions on the viewer.

A realistic, emotionally resonant film made for grown-up audiences in a time when most theatrical releases are aimed at the teen demographic.

Save for Dakota Fanning (who is marvelous no matter the role), there isn't a whole lot to enjoy or get involved in.

An overblown, frantic, giddily exciting, eye-popping exercise in visual artistry over internal three-dimensionality.

A beautiful, layered, uplifting, dizzyingly romantic motion picture. This is one of the year's very best films, and one of its most unexpected cinematic treasures.

Sharp-witted and fairly consistently hilarious, rustling up some affectionate, but mostly disturbing, flashbacks to my own restaurant days.

movie_review_blurb: A smart and surprisingly rewarding gem with resonating themes and ideas, In Her Shoes is episodic mainstream filmmaking done right.

A horror buff's wet dream.
Falls smack-dab in the middle of terminal disposability.
When the stars aren't charming the viewer, the film is busy shooting itself in the foot.

Slow-moving and limited in scope...Seems more suited for cable than theatrical exhibition

Spry, whimsical and frequently laugh-out-loud funny.
Pleasant, but not dynamic, it's old-fashioned feel and narrative deficiencies bound to leave most audiences cold.

Forgettable, completely harmless, sporadically amusing, and not at all ready to go up against the real masters at Pixar and Disney.
Akin to David Lynch on an off day.
A complete cinematic joke.

This film couldn't have come at a more opportune time.

A winning and suitably uplifting way to spend a couple hours.

movie_review_blurb: The Garfield in these shoddy movies is nothing but an impostor of the once-beloved real thing.

movie_review_blurb: Supposed to be sweeping and romantic, but instead takes on an uncomfortable and creepy undercurrent.

Absorbing, charming, and even touching.

Faithfully derivative of the low-grade, entertainingly bad slasher items of two decades ago.

A rousing, slam-bang, no-frills action extravaganza.
Boggles the mind with how many things it gets wrong.
Audiences searching for nothing more than popcorn entertainment will get their money's worth.
A mesmerizing triumph of both pitch-perfect minimalism and devastating existentialism, painting a bleak, uncompromising portrait of desolation personified.
Dark Water proves that the horrors of the human condition are just as frightening, if not more so, than all things that go drip in the night.
Will please non-discriminating action hounds while leaving everyone else in search of a little meat unfulfilled. It's as fun as it is instantly forgettable.
Its often low-key study of human interactions and bonding is quietly truthful and erudite.

Strictly of the take-it-or-leave-it variety, not romantic or involving or memorable enough to warrant more than an ultra-brief passing glance.
A one-of-a-kind original. Those courageous enough to give it a try will find their efforts rewarded, at times in the most unexpected of ways.
An utterly mesmerizing, boundlessly imaginative achievement, perhaps -- and I do not use such terms lightly -- the most visually astounding motion picture ever made.
movie_title: Sky Captain and the World of Tomorrow (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A solid, affectionately told drama, at times wavering the line of excellent, that only disappoints when it doesn't add up to the fully-realized catharsis it is aiming for.
Creatively bankrupt trash made by a committee of hacks who don't know the first thing about generating suspense, frights, or cohesive storytelling.
A taut, crowd-pleasing thriller in which the improbable, if canny, premise is overlooked in exchange for what is an exceedingly fun ride.
Frightening and enthralling, and quite often, but the film's consummate thematic missteps cripple the project beyond repair.
Not the customary disposable cinematic fare released on the always-slow Labor Day weekend, but an intriguing, original film of ideas and human feeling.
The Cookout holds a smug, mean-spirited undercurrent, made all the more rotten by an attempted sincerity as false as a set of dentures.
What might work powerfully on the page comes off on the screen as not terribly interesting.
For the not-easily-offended, this is certainly one of the most deliriously ballsy comedies to hit screens in years.
Doesn't even fall into the 'so bad it's entertaining' category. As unscary, threadbare, and downright dull as these kinds of movies come.
movie_title: Anacondas: The Hunt for the Blood Orchid (2004)

movie_review_blurb: While the plotting doesn't exactly reinvent the wheel, it does skew conventions enough to leave the viewer edgy and wondering what will unfold with each progressive scene.
A highly charged, poignant study of the imperfections within human nature and the frailty of otherwise powerful love relationships.
A faux-sentimental comedy that not only isn't funny, but half the time appears to have forgotten to insert the joke.
A sincereand sincerely problematicfilm that may have been shot twice, but deserved a third try to get things right.
A hit-and-miss affair, commendable for its intricate, unpredictable storytelling but frustrating that it all adds up to a poof of smoke and a wink at the viewer.
At no time does it work, providing cheap thrills, bad writing, and a particularly nasty side that tries to pass itself off as popcorn entertainment.
Charmless and confoundingly amateurish, a trifle of bankrupt non-ideas that will be forgotten about long before the November election even gets here.

Oddly lacking a heart. In its place is misguided material decidedly unsavory for most of its target audience, and a string of inappropriate ethnic and racial stereotypes.
One sequel where a pressing need to find out what happened to the protagonist is absent, replaced by an attempt to cash in on the financial success of the first picture.
movie_title: Bridget Jones: The Edge of Reason (2004)

movie_review_blurb: An endlessly magical experience. One couldn't ask for a movie more pure and genuine. In a single word, The Polar Express is a masterpiece.
A long slog through a pretty sea of thankless twaddle.
Boundlessly enjoyable, extravagant to look at, and a frequent adrenaline rush.
The frequent steps from reality into fantasy are gorgeous to behold and humanely relevant rather than cloying and cute.
Saw simply doesn't cut it.
Stylishly grim and nervously intriguing for most of its running length, but concludes with an underwhelming, derivative whimper.
A disappointingly unoriginal and one-note biography of a man and his life that were anything but.
Evoking Stanley Kubrick in its slowly spellbinding pacing and meticulous, always unpredictable technical attributes, Birth is a visually sumptuous work.
A gratifying early surprise of the autumn movie season, an intelligent and wise film that finds vast entertainment value in one man's own existential crises.
Has its respective merits, but this is one festive occasion that desperately needed another rewrite.

Genuinely surprises because one is never quite sure where it is headed next, all the while involving the viewer in freakish, unforgettably nightmarish imagery.
There are some hearty laughs to be had, but they don't come frequently enough.
A largely appealing drama, the kind of sports movie that anyone, even non-fans of football (like myself), can get wrapped up in and care about.
So pure at heart that, even with its over-the-top moments and cliches, one is willing to forgive the flaws and admire all that it achieves.
A spiffy-looking ride on a road to nowhere.
It's like going on an invaluable 8,000 mile vacation for the affordable price of a movie ticket--well worth the ten dollars.
A film that loves and respects the country's firefighters, but makes the mistake of not getting to know them in a meaningful or substantial way.

May be the most intellectually demanding motion picture of the year. Some will find their mind satiated. Others will leave angry. In one way or another, all will be baffled.
Intelligently wicked and bloodily appealing in an agile sort of way.

Has been rendered impotent by the insane demands of a studio obsessed with the PG-13 rating. An attractive but empty horror-lite version.

A thankless visual spectacle, marvelous to look at but woefully empty where its heart should be.
A welcome new spin, a brash style, and more big laughs than expected on an old tale that still holds quite a bit of relevance.
Bankrupt of imagination and will be nearly forgotten the instant the viewer exits the theater, but it's harmless - the sole reason why it is difficult to out-and-out hate it.
A quirky, one-of-a-kind comedic gem. Even when you aren't laughing out loud, you won't be able to stop from smiling.
Soul Plane will likely inspire viewers to immediately rewatch Airplane! to wash out the bad taste this new movie pollutes into their mouths.
Content to parade out an endless, ever-wearying line of cliches, ludicrous plotting and dialogue, and paper-thin stock characters whom the viewer forms no relationship with.
Assured, visually triumphant filmmaking that isn't simply a joy to look at, but also bewitches with its tightly conceived plotting.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Prisoner of Azkaban (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A film that not only works as a documentary but as an endlessly intriguing and grin-inducing narrative.
The film is a head-on collision of spare parts from different genres, none of which work separately or as a collective whole.
Blazes across the screen with mature, rapid-fire wit; genuine warmth; and rainbow-colored visual beauty.
How is Breakin' All the Rules different from all the countless other romantic comedies specializing in misunderstandings and mistaken identities? It isn't.
Reminiscent of a cheesy Harlequin romance that just so happens to have lots of big battles and expensive effects.
Too trite and uninteresting to service the wonderfully affecting performance from Lili Taylor.
One of the most thought-provoking and important films of the last few years.
Disposable eye candy that entertains while it plays itself out but isn't worth much once it's over.
A terminally lame teen comedy with a grade-school mentality.
Wants to be dark and scathing, but lacks the courage of its convictions.
Opts to waste its potential in favor of a barrage of cheap jump scares and clumsy plotting.
Successfully manages the tricky balancing act of being sharply satirical without making fun of its characters.
Yes, there are some bigeven giantlaugh-inducing moments, but this is one ribald cinematic effort that could have used another extensive rewrite.
It's never scaryand doesn't try to bebut it sure does have a pitch-black, smile-inducing charm.
A quality, albeit frothy, teen flick destined to charm its target audience, and maybe even some grown-ups, as well.
An important documentary and a spellbinding entertainment. Laugh-aloud funny, razor sharp, informative, humane, enraging, and powerful, oftentimes all of the above at once.
A frightening journey into the heart of human darkness and morality. Sure to endure as a watermark of the coming-of-age genre for years to come.
[Director] Joshua Marston's meticulous eye for cold, hard facts on his subject matter raises Maria Full of Grace above the level of mere docudrama.
Offers the ultimate conundrum. A complex motion picture that demands a second viewing, yet doesn't offer enough that's scary or emotionally resounding to be worth the first.
If there is a reason to see it, it's the effortlessly enchanting Murphy, but that isn't quite reason enough. This is one Book that should have remained closed.
Collateral is an arrestingly written and acted dramatic thriller that refuses to cut easy corners for the majority of its running time. An enthralling experience.
Sloppy, boring, dumbed-down and heinous. By the end, you may find yourself experiencing a fantasy of finding all the copies of the picture and burning the negatives.
Attempts to cram too much information into a 95-minute feature. Fortunately, there is enough that is exquisitely good to make up for many of its narrative downfalls.
movie_title: A Home at the End of the World (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A jittery, unapologetic experience worth a look for those who prefer psychological horror over broad slasher cliches.
A cold, calculating virtual redux of The Bourne Identity that leaves a bitter aftertaste in its wake. Audiences have seen this all before, many times over.
Overtly bad (and unintentionally funny) enough to become a camp classic.
Absolutely riveting entertainment, a chilling portrait of human paranoia also posing as an engrossing and visually vibrant political thriller. This is one arresting film.
The Door in the Floor is unfocused beyond repair.
Some of the most convincing and lifelike visual effects in movie history. This is a wide-scope sci-fi thriller done right.
Does justice to its well-known source material while putting a pleasant spin on it. It's better than one may be lead to expect, which is perhaps the best compliment of all.
Garden State is a beaming, unforgettable little masterpiece, creatively alive and emotionally intimate at the same time.
Its unforced mixture of the crass with the sweet may not be the likeliest of combinations, but it is a decidedly beguiling one, all the same.
movie_title: Harold & Kumar Go to White Castle (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A marginal entertainment with some greatly funny scenes definitely worth seeing, but is the rest of the movie worth wading through to get to them? Probably not.
movie_title: Anchorman - The Legend Of Ron Burgundy (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Strives to be more than just a predictable, by-the-numbers kidnapping drama, but that, ultimately, is all that it ends up being.
One of the season's must-see efforts. All of the studio-produced, mass-marketed romances out there, take note: this is precisely what a love story should be.
This is some of [Kline and Judd's] most astonishing respective work in memory. De-Lovely is unremittingly romantic.
Real-life love stories rarely work out quite so faultlessly, but for two hours it's nice to believe that they could.
A visually dazzling spectacle and a technically creative triumph. Spider-Man 2 is a significant and grandly entertaining cinematic work.
A black hole of a movie without anything original to do or interesting to say. That it isn't outright terrible only makes its utter pointlessness all the more glaring.
This is one screenplay that would have excelled had all the dialogue been excised or retooled.
A vile, morally repugnant lump of coal. One of the worst, most disingenuous Christmas movies in memory.
A worn-out Goodwill version of Rocky that either deserved a less-banal filmmaking approach or didn't need to be made at all.
A warm-hearted, enjoyable diversion. A possible contender for one of the sleeper hits of the summer.
movie_title: The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Mysterious Skin, for all of its depictions of atrocities and human sadness, is a rarified thing of vulnerable beauty.
One of the most lackluster of the modern, big-budget CG-animated releases.
Sexist, homophobic, pointless and overloaded with brain-crushing bigotry...has an evil and putrid secret agenda that couldn't have less to do with football if it tried.
A slam-bang summer blockbuster. Completes, deepens, and enriches the series beyond the pop-cultural phenomenon it has long-since made for itself.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode III - Revenge of the Sith (2005)

movie_review_blurb: There is no necessary tension, no memorable characters, and no sense of fun. Instead, Renny Harlin just lines up his cast and knocks off their boring asses one at a time.
The intentionally over-the-top, at times cheerfully wicked, streak is greatly harmed by a cop-out conclusion that pushes the tone toward falsely uplifting mawkishness.
Will Ferrell is always entertaining, even in lesser roles like this one. Painless to sit through once, but offers nothing of value to be worth ever seeing again.
Entertaining in its joy and energy, and perceptive in depicting a specific, one-of-a-kind era.
Thrilling, bone-crunching, gloriously choreographed fight scenes, but they're in between the more enduring core of the film, which is a character-centric family drama.
An absolutely riveting, highly charged drama, Crash is an important motion picture that demands viewing in high schools across the country.
Scary, scream-and-squirm-inducing, and suspenseful, it's the first unequivocally good--and often downright great--popcorn entertainment of the still-early summer movie season.
Hitching a ride, even one in space, has never been less exciting and adventurous.
movie_title: The Hitchhiker's Guide to the Galaxy (2005)

movie_review_blurb: Plain, old, rancid trash, as careless as it is despicably wasteful. If Xander Cage had to die, the XXX series should have keeled over with him.
Unobtrusive and virtually painless as an occasionally witty laugher, but lacks the courage of its convictions to follow through with its less commercial ambitions.
A gem of a love storyhonest, funny in an unforced way, sometimes painful and, ultimately, winsomely romantic. One of the nicer surprises of 2005, thus far.
Looks good, sounds good, and is a motion picture that the actors make worth seeing.
Palindromes is Todd Solondz's first significant cinematic failure, a pitch-black fable twice as shallow and trite as it is intriguing.
Why bother ratcheting up suspense with unseen forces and horrors of the psyche when you can just show actors in makeup instructed to look spooooooky?
A dreary, uninformative, emotionless disaster. At least Alexander had the comical benefit of Angelina Jolie hamming it up with reptiles.
Who could have guessed that a so-called slasher movie could be as psychologically haunting as this one manages to be? A new classic of the horror genre has been born.
Has a rushed, thrown-together feel to it made all the more glaring by cheesy 3-D that is ugly and doesn't work in any way, shape or form.
movie_title: The Adventures of Sharkboy and Lavagirl in 3-D (2005)

movie_review_blurb: So bewitching as a romantic, charged & aesthetically slick star vehicle that it's easy to overlook its shakier aspects. Has adult summer blockbuster written all over it.
Lacks the requisite passion and urgency to make the experience anything more than a periodically pleasant waste of time.
A brightly entertaining teenage comedy as frothy and predictable as cotton candy, but also just as sweet.
The most in-depth study of a single joke that has likely ever been attempted on film.
The first act holds such promise, but by the end, Bay deflates all rooting interest and throws logic out the window in favor of shootouts and been-there-done-that car chases.
Delights in its unashamed vulgarity and spiritedly laugh-inducing wickedness.
The Devil's Rejects is meanspirited, graphic, and bubbling over in ultra-realistic viscera, but it isn't without sociological merit.
Happy Endings, like its characters, is an ambitious, if flawed, work, but there is also a touching soulful quality that cannot be denied and cannot be faked.
Good enough to stand on its own, but the film doesn't even begin to hold a candle next to 1971's version.
Headed straight for divorce court.
Boring, empty, anticlimactic, uninspired and bankrupt of humanity.
A painful, sluggish black hole of simultaneous bad ideas and no ideas at all.
The sparks of brilliance littered throughout Miranda July's debut feature are just thatsparks.
movie_title: Me and You and Everyone We Know (2005)

movie_review_blurb: A loving portrait of a gorgeous, awkward creature that, in some ways, is remarkably similar to human beings, and in other ways couldn't be further from us.
The worst family feature so far this year...Rebound stinks like a rancid pair of sweaty old gym sneakers.
Overlooking a disappointing conclusion, War of the Worlds is a marvelous entertainment of imagination, edge-of-your-seat suspense, and surprising thoughtfulness.
Feels unfinished, like a rough cut still awaiting a much-needed polish. Fleetingly amusing? Yes. Full-out magical? Not so much.
Gritty, dark and unapologetically violent, Land of the Dead is a solid, serious zombie movie.
Zippy, brightly-colored fun. The film flies right by at such a stylish clip that the viewer hardly has time to realize how very slight the whole thing is.
Amidst the troubled waters are some bright spots that lift the picture above being a painful experience; as is, it is merely disposable.
Batman Begins is involving and skillful, more so as a drama than as an action film.
This isn't the worst movie of the yearit isn't even the worst comedy of the yearbut it may be one of the blandest.
Travels down been-there-done-that territory, afraid to take chances and unaware of its own tedious mediocrity.
The most consistently funny motion picture of the year so far, and also its sweetest. Once over, audiences won't so much walk out of the theater as they will float out.
Breathtaking to look at, but its core is without a pulse.
Although not a chore to sit through, the whole thing seems rather clunkily thought out and offers precious little worth remembering once the end credits have rolled.
Damn that Satchel Paige bobblehead doll and double-damn director Brian Levant for thinking it was a good idea.
An utterly abysmal wannabe-horror film. Never even remotely frighteningthe trailer is worlds above this lame finished product in terms of a visceral response.
Having seen it all before, and in a superior, more charming fashion, the most likely response from viewers will be lackadaisical indifference.
An understated drama simmering just underneath the surface with explosive emotions and occasionally breathless intensity.
So dimly lit and its plot so threadbare that the viewing experience is not much more gratifying than sitting in a pitch-black room for 95 minutes.
The epilogue is poignant and truthful in a way that the rest of the film, with its inept storytelling and strictly unfunny humor, does not earn or deserve.
A frantic, pointless sequel, funny in clumps, but mostly contrived and empty.
Better in sections than as a whole, and those sections don't arrive at a steady enough pace to undo its failings.
movie_title: A Love Song for Bobby Long (2004)

movie_review_blurb: A biopic that is all shiny surface and no substance, washing over hard details in favor of a lot of stage performances that come off surprisingly flat.
The picture is a beautifully foreboding storybook sprung to life, mixing guffaw-inducing comedy, frightful fantasy, and resonating drama without missing a beat.
movie_title: Lemony Snicket's A Series of Unfortunate Events (2004)

movie_review_blurb: So full of shameless vanity that each ticket stub should come with a mirror, a make-up case, and a high-priced plastic surgeon.
Wishes to be full of good will, but it is hampered by an unnecessarily extreme mean streak that the picture refuses to be accountable for.
Absolutely riveting entertainment. Takes a formulaic blueprint, tramples it to the floor, and comes up with something altogether more penetrating, touching, and real.
Takes the 'everything-but-the-kitchen-sink' approach. Leaves no sports cliche unturned and no chance for inspirational feel-good moments unvisited.
This is one dreary, listless film. The sooner it is forgotten and the once-promising director restakes his claim in being someone to watch, the better off we all will be.
movie_title: The Life Aquatic with Steve Zissou (2004)

movie_review_blurb: One of the most entertaining motion pictures of the year, The Phantom of the Opera is a cinematic gift for the ages that finds profundity in its thematic innocence.
Harmless but shallow, cinematic junk food that goes down with ease but has no nutritional value and will be forgotten about almost immediately after devouring it.
A solid, albeit flawed, effort. Stellar work by Leonardo DiCaprio, but Cate Blanchett's masterful, Oscar-worthy performance steals the film.
The sumptuous performances and tantalizing dialogue make even the most detestable of human behavior uncontrollably fascinating.
An enormous cinematic mess. Alexander is not so much mind-numbingly boring as it is intriguingly nonsensical.
As a dramatization of non-fiction events, a film that, more than anything, sets out to evoke distinct emotions within the viewer, Hotel Rwanda is certainly effective.
Elektra would have been far better off staying dead.
These daffy sea creatures pale enormously next to the infinitely superior joys of The Incredibles and The Polar Express.
Graphically violent and merciless...refreshingly unpretentious in its goal to entertain and put a jolt in any non-squeamish viewer sick to death of cookie-cutter genre movies.
This is jaw-dropping, awe-inspiring, 'I-can't- believe-someone- made-this-crap' badness we're dealing with.
As the title suggests, Melinda and Melinda features two renditions of the same person. Woody Allen would have been smart to scrap them both and start from scratch.
When so few comedies these days are actually funny, Guess Who is an entertaining and diverting way to spend 105 minutes for audiences starved for laughs.
Gracie Hart may still be armed, but her sheer fabulousness has come to a rather abrupt and unfortunate end.
Ice Princess sticks closely to the mold of other sports flicks, but there is a tenderness and refreshing lack of compromise assembled from its spare parts.
Moves fast and isn't without its freakish images-but it becomes obvious the film was rushed into production without much thought or faithfulness into the first picture's lore.
A valiantly flawed effort boosted by noteworthy star turns that make the two-hour running time a rewarding filmgoing experience.
Doesn't contain a whole lot to grasp onto and take away with you, but it's pleasurable and bright and inoffensive while it lasts.
Hostage is a hit-and-miss action-thriller. When it is good, it crackles and pops with literally breathless, grip-your-armrest-style intensity.
Warm, funny, weighty, wholly original, and even occasionally quite tense, Millions will open up the minds of both adults and children without talking down to them.
A lame-as-lame-can-be bust.
The ambitions of the film are diffused by a nagging sensation that we've seen it all before, and done with a surer hand.
Hip, zippy, and oh-so-cool.
A consistently unoriginal comedy that plays like an abandoned 97-minute sitcom pilot without the laugh track or hardly any laughs.
As a PG-13, Cursed is a lesser, more cowardly effort, but one that still has enough giddy buoyancy and slick thrills to lift above its last-minute studio tinkering.
There is no reason to make a trip to the theater for what amounts to a loud and frenzied day at Chuck E. Cheese's.
The sum of its parts could have added up to much more than it does. Then again, let's be thankful for small victories. It could have been Are We There Yet?
Too many false endings and time issues aside, Hitch is difficult to discount when it handles the rom-com formula better than most of its insufferably dumbed-down ilk.
Good-looking, but decidedly hollow. Misses the opportunity to explore its evocative central conceits by attempting to do too many other things at once, and failing.
A chill-free, suspense-deficient thriller that is not only an enormous waste of time and film stock, but also insanely empty and heavy-handed.
Elicits a handful of smiles but not many laughs as it approaches a finale that comes as a foregone conclusion.
An absorbing mystery-thriller for its first hour ... until it races off the tracks toward a dumb, albeit predictable, twist ending.
A slice-of-life so purely amiable and astute in its portrayal of the cutthroat corporate world that it is easy to overlook a great many flaws in its design.
The comedy is drab and predictable. The satirical flourishes are so soft that they are hardly worth mentioning. The thrills are diffused by tonal shifts working against them.
Thought-provoking long after its haunting final frame, Babel is a weighty and complex spellbinder.
It is only once the end credits have begun to roll that you step back, process what you have seen, and leave dissatisfied.
Is Never Back Down so bad it's good, or just plain bad? Really, it's a little bit of both.
A small-scale family drama that walks the walk, but doesn't seem to know where it's going half the time.
Difficult to like and yet impossible to deny, Funny Games is a coldly efficient, spectacularly acted and unremittingly bleak thriller.
Yet another accomplished, stylistically courageous work from a filmmaker whose willingness to take chances and pull them off is his finest attribute.
10,000 B.C. is a load of crap dressed up with pretty background vistas. The film is terminally lifeless, something that a so-called 'event' picture should never be.

Worth a recommendation for adult audiences in search of something that won't insult their intelligence. Granted, The Bank Job won't enhance anyone's IQ, either, but sometimes a pulpy slice of crime thriller theatrics is all you need.
In it's painfully accurate portrayal of characters struggling to make their way in a world that oftentimes seems cruelly unfair and confusing, Snow Angels rings resoundingly true.
Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day is terminally pleasant. Granted, pleasant isn't a bad thing, but the film calls for a looser, more wild side that never quite comes.
movie_title: Miss Pettigrew Lives for a Day (2008)

movie_review_blurb: This shrill, chaotic, mass-market drivel is the kind of absent-minded family film that gives thoughtful, worthwhile family films a bad name.
What could be translated into a wonderful and even educational thirty-minute short is stretched and padded to the brink when forced to fill out a feature-length running time.
movie_title: Dr. Seuss' Horton Hears a Who! (2008)

movie_review_blurb: With some fine-tuning, Penelope might have been transformed into a winning little fable about accepting and loving oneself. As is, it only serves to remind of what could have been.
Stay home and watch any of Ferrell's past films, all of which are more worthwhile than this monotonously unfunny tripe.
Less would have definitely been more in this case; if viewers squint their eyes hard enough, they might just be able to locate a kitchen sink lurking somewhere in the background.
An inspired low-budget horror item with a rough and tumble guerilla filmmaking flair. What it lacks is a steady focal point to rattle the viewer's interest and emotions for an hour and a half.
A non-flashy but uncommonly savvy film about teenage life that one can only hope finds its rightful audience.
Cute but a little empty, Be Kind Remind boasts an original premise without the clarity of writing and character dimension to back it up.
Never scary but frequently cartoonish in its sour humor, Diary of the Dead can't even figure out if it wants to be taken seriously or as a poor, unfunny spoof.
With no one to root for, no adequate story development, and action scenes that are the epitome of underwhelming, Jumper is a lost cause.
Its simplistic and occasionally juvenile plot is at odds with its more mature subject matter. The Spiderwick Chronicles is flashy and diverting, but also ultimately insubstantial.
It's all been done before, and better. Furthermore, the nearly two full hours it takes to reach its foregone conclusion begins to pry on one's nerves.

Fascinating in its depiction of a troubled relationship between sisters that is anything but black and white. This emotionally ripe angle to a tragic story that could have been told any number of ways is where the film gets its potency.

Soulless, impersonal and shamelessly derivative, this dime-a-dozen sci-fi garbage is such a depressing step down for Neil Marshall that one can hardly believe it was made by the same guy responsible for the rightfully acclaimed The Descent.
Drillbit Taylor goes down with ease when it isn't trying too hard. This may not be a great teen comedy, but it is a warm and smart one.
Ultimately becomes little more than a series of derivative, predictable genre conventions without the necessary skill to back them up.
A phantasmagoric, candy-colored treat for the senses.
A slight but infectious British comedy, Son of Rambow charms in spite of a slim plot and sketchy character development. The first ninety minutes may not be, but the last five are just about perfect.
Not good, not bad, just there, the film faithfully crosses off one timeworn cliché after the next.
Not quite memorable enough to live up to the top superhero films but proficient enough to be satisfying, Iron Man suggests with a clever ending that better things are yet to come.
Can a movie title be so unthinkably bad that it single-handedly ruins the viewing experience? As it turns out, yes.
Far from a complete failure, but in trying so hard to up the ante the filmmakers have made a lesser, more rambling finished product. Simply isn't as satisfying this time around.
movie_title: Harold & Kumar Escape from Guantanamo Bay (2008)

movie_review_blurb: There are a handful of solid laughs, but there are more than a few duds in the mix. One suspects that had Tina Fey penned the film herself, it wouldn't have been half as conventional and plodding.
Paints a compelling and thought-provoking picture of not only school violence, but violence in general, and the trickle-down effect that a single moment in time can have on one's whole future.
Was the movie entertaining? Yes. Did it quite consistently earn some big laughs and small chuckles? Yes. Was the audience's intelligence insulted? Thankfully, no.
A drab exercise in poor storytelling, empty-headed characters, low-grade aesthetics, and forgettable action sequences. This isn't 'so-bad-it's-good' we're talking about; it's 'so-bad-it's-bad.'
Could have used more innovation and less strained obviousness as it worked its way toward an underwhelming conclusion.
A stalk-and-slash horror movie with precious few slashes, the PG-13-rated Prom Night is a tame, by-the-numbers affair without surprises or a point of any kind.
It's a story that has been played out more times than can be counted and is none too fresh on this go-round. Street Kings simply brings nothing new to the 'bad cop' subgenre.

A smart film about smart people, as the title promises, but they are also humanely flawed. Like all of us, they don't hold the key to life's questions and dilemmas, and all the intelligence in the world isn't going to change that.

Because the film works so splendidly for so long, the sole misstep that The Ruins takes is a major one, ending on a note of disappointment. What comes before this is superbly crafted and as tight as a vise grip, worth seeing for that alone.
Despite its heart being in the right place, Nim's Island is a strikingly far-fetched and cloying picture that tries way too hard to be alternately juvenile and bittersweet.
Not bad but also so frivolous that there's nothing to grab onto and take away from it all. Leatherheads is a good-looking but misguided waste of time and effort.
Amiable. Bland. Cute. Formulaic. Inconsequential. Run Fatboy Run goes down with ease, but it's awfully slight.
About five good laughs stretched over a 70-minute running time (not counting the ludicrously padded 15-minute end credits).
A pulse-poundingly high-spirited and extremely well-directed drama. If 21 is only one thing, it's intoxicating.
Acted with aplomb and occasionally compelling, Stop-Loss nevertheless fails to impress.
At the risk of going against the obvious 'it's-cool-to-hate-Hilton' popular majority, it should be stated up front that The Hottie & the Nottie isn't half-bad.
Welcome Home Roscoe Jenkins is a happy surprise of a movie, a heartfelt comedy that probably shouldn't work, but does. (Would it have hurt to add a comma to the title?)
A bravura, genre-twisting gem. This is one picture that packs a wallop.
The fools, it turns out, are audience members who get duped into thinking this will be a fun, energetic romp.
Children may laugh at the broad humor, but what's lurking underneath the comedy is dark and disheartening.
About as appetizing as a candy cane laced with arsenic.
An auspicious and grandiose entertainment. Thoroughly immersive and genuinely wondrous.
Profundity is never achieved because the would-be encompassing love story at its center isn't given enough time to build and breathe.
Light on plot but plentiful in moments of keen human observation, Juno is authentic and, oh, so winning.
So screechingly obvious by the 15-minute mark that all the viewer is left to do for the remainder of the running time is wait around for the slow-witted machinations of the script to catch up.
A wise, low-key drama where the characters' humane, accurately written interactions take precedence over all else.
Would be right at home as a movie made for television. As a feature film, it is a forgettable, humdrum sapfest.
Simply put, to spend time with these people is unpleasant and without a payoff (or an emotional release) to reward the audience's efforts.
Abysmal in the extreme, Hitman is 100 minutes of soul-crushing nothingness.
Takes a terrifying plot and then somehow manages to miss the mark and the scares.
Slight, uneven and not very memorable. Just as the viewer's heart is intended to soar, mine was left lukewarm and wishing that it cared more.
Enchanted proves that a motion picture can be light and frothy and yet still be intelligent and emotionally rewarding. As unlikely as it may seem, this is one of the year's best and brightest films.
Not without its flaws, Mr. Magorium's Wonder Emporium is a minor but honorable effort that kids and adults will be able to enjoy together or apart.

There is a place for staunchly political cinema like Redacted, just as there is a place for any genre or personal perspective. In this case, it is the crude treatment of the material that spells its undoing.

Because the picture's technical side is so extraordinary, it is truly saddening to have to write that Beowulf isn't a very good movie. Take away the visuals, and what is left is a talky, subdued, lifeless affair.

In a world of mediocre, formulaic fare that is like everything else that has come before it, Southland Tales stands invigoratingly apart from the crowd. It's ballsy, fascinatingly different and thoroughly commendable.
Doesn't quite have what it takes to be low-key and reserved and still hold more than cursory interest.
Rough around the edges, but it is also frequently funny in its adherence to clichés and does boast an energetic tone.
A well-acted, professionally lensed post-apocalyptic thriller.
With hyper-active editing and camerawork that doesn't stay still for longer than a second at a time, Mulberry Street is too frenetic to always be comprehensible.
The decidedly small-scale finished product doesn't quite measure up to the epic scope of its story. Fortunately, the film's heart remains very much intact.
So moronic it almost makes the recent mediocre Made of Honor seem sophisticated by comparison.
I Am Legend is a frightening film. What gets under your skin, though, has nothing to do with the conventional horror elements.
It is rare for a film to achieve a feeling of unequivocal, breathtaking transcendence, but Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street does just that.
movie_title: Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A nearly plotless and always asinine stoner comedy that is so inconsequential it begins to evaporate from the memory before it is even over.
Quite faithful until the dumbed-down Americanized ending, yet time and again the treatment is inferior.
Thoroughly unoriginal and screams of desperation. Over Her Dead Body is a fitting title; this is a DOA dud.
Meet the Spartans is a downtrodden cinematic vacuuma sickening, derivative, shallow, condescending, utterly worthless piece of ....
Hollow, hopeless, horridly written and wholly unpleasant. One would be hard-pressed to imagine a conventional narrative being any thinner than the one in Rambo.
A run-of-the-mill thriller that lacks the substance to be anything more than forgettable.
Cassandra's Dream is like a dream, all righta bad one, made by an aging filmmaker who, sadly, simply doesn't have the same magic he once did.
Adds up to more of a whimper than a banga thinly drawn female-empowerment lark without the spine to be as ruthless as it wants to be and without the smarts to be half as memorable as it should.
Strictly junk food for rom-com lovers who will devour anything of its ilk that comes their way. All other potential audience members needn't bother.
Alarming and nothing short of terrifying. Cloverfield is the year's first unadulterated masterpiece. There has never been anything quite like it.
In the Name of the King would be irredeemable if not for its near-brilliant ability to give the viewer douche chills for 127 solid minutes.
movie_title: In the Name of the King: A Dungeon Siege Tale (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Comedies don't have to be high in class as long as they are funny, entertaining and do not treat their audience like imbeciles. First Sunday fails all three of these qualifications.
Puerile and low-rent, piggybacking on the fad of updating foreign horror films by dumbing them down for us American simpletons.
If Day-Lewis' Oscar-bound turn is one of the strongest of the year, it only calls more attention to the weaknesses around him.

The Orphanage is first and foremost a weighty, at times heartbreaking, existential study of the frailty of life, the mysteries of death, and the knowledge of one's own mortality. It is also very, very scary.

Scares are few and far between. Suspense is in short supply. As for the battle sequences pitting the slimy aliens against the metal-geared predator, they are plentiful but forgettable, nondescript freneticism shot in murky lighting.
Nicholson and Freeman are a dynamite onscreen team, the power of their characters' friendship lending appropriate weight and gravitas to the proceedings.

When The Great Debaters ends, expect to be uplifted despite the inherent schmaltz. Think about the film for any length of time afterwards, and the wheels of its storytelling undeniably begin to deflate.

Shifts between earnest melodrama and zany comedy without making much of an imprint as either...In all of her frequently breathtaking talent and depth, Hilary Swank deserves better than what P.S. I Love You has to offer.
A bawdy, rib-tickling, anything-goes spoof of such recent music biopics as Ray and Walk the Line, and here's the kicker--it's actually a better movie than both of those.
movie_title: Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A forgettable and too-glossy piffle posing ridiculously as Oscar bait, Charlie Wilson's War tells a true story that warrants more respect than this lifeless, frivolous drudge of a final product.
National Treasure: Book of Secrets has the same director as National Treasure, the same writers, and nearly all of the same lead actors. This is no surprise, since it is basically the same movie.
An all-in-fun slasher flickshallow as can be, never scary, unevenly acted, but wickedly comic.
What once felt both magical and foreboding now seems rather dreary and perfunctory.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian (2008)

movie_review_blurb: An immensely creepy thriller, one that plays fair with the audience, treats its characters with unusual intelligence for the genre, and is all the more effective because the minimalist plot is kept spare and straightforward.
A serious-minded, true-in-spirit redux.
movie_title: Nosferatu: Phantom der Nacht (Nosferatu the Vampyre) (1979)

movie_review_blurb: A landmark motion picture.
movie_title: Nosferatu, a Symphony of Horror (Nosferatu, eine Symphonie des Grauens) (Nosferatu the Vampire) (1922)

movie_review_blurb: A facetious yet sincere documentary that makes the case for why all of the world's organized religions are not only, well, ridiculous, but also detrimental and downright dangerous.
While it is the liberals of America who receive the brunt of abuse, it is the conservatives, portrayed as hypocritical, narrow-minded hicks and heathens, that unintentionally look like fools.
An unnerving, disorienting fable of the darkest order.
A painfully unfunny, virtually charmless talking-animals pic. What did the lovely Jamie Lee Curtis see in this project that she felt warranted coming out of semi-retirement for?
With minimal saccharine emotions and a reliance on low-key realism, Flash of Genius is a formulaic underdog tale carried out with decided intelligence.
For viewers who can get past the turn-off of a title, they will find a film as entertaining and easy to like as it is shrewd about its subject matter.
movie_title: How to Lose Friends & Alienate People (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Like a movie that '80s-era John Hughes never made, Nick and Norah's Infinite Playlist is candid, thoughtful, touching and hugely entertaining.
Lisa and the Devil is the real deal, a masterfully poetic journey into darkness and dislocation that is long overdue in finding the audience it so desperately deserves.
movie_title: Lisa And The Devil (Lisa e il diavolo) (The Devil in the House of Exorcism) (1973)

movie_review_blurb: These days, westerns are a dying breed, uncommonly found in multiplexes. Appaloosa is the latest reason why.
By the time Jerry and Rachel are riding around on airport conveyer belts while Agent Morgan, in hot pursuit, stumbles over luggage behind them, the film has lost all semblance of sanity and focus.
A peculiar black comedy without a detectable point.
Isn't bad by any means, but it is so low-key that it's rarely funny and difficult to get excited about.
A blind children's chorus singing 'I Can See Clearly Now' is among the highlights of this otherwise forgettable animated feature.
A light smattering of funny moments can't save this misogynistic, feel-bad romantic comedy.
What begins as a button-pushing think piece concludes by pushing all the wrong buttons and losing sight of the bigger picture.
A strong, forthright motion picture that accurately offers few cut-and-dry answers and blessedly doesn't shy away from its socially demanding subject matter.
The picture's 14-year path to fruition should have taken a fifteenth in order to get the kinks in the script worked out.
A minor work on the Coen brothers' résumé is still better than, or as good as, most other filmmakers' best.
One of this year's most stirring romances, adroitly manipulative, yes, but never condescending.
Bava displays how ahead of the curve he was in tackling the slasher genre.
movie_title: Reazione a catena (A Bay of Blood) (Twitch of the Death Nerve) (1972)

movie_review_blurb: A skillful, if by-the-numbers, horror pic.
A solid first sequel and the truly chilling jump scare at the end gives the original's a run for its money.
When Dark Ride goes for the throat, it has some fun. The rest of the time it's rather insulting.
An underrated gem, a mini-masterpiece of frights and atmosphere.
Fits the '80s slasher blueprint to the letter. It's only adequately made, but it happens to feature a handful of scenes so knee-slappingly bad that the film ranks as a party favorite.
One of the more inspired early-'80s slasher pics.
If a remake must be made in lieu of original thoughts and ideas, one could do far, far worse. Quarantine is the real deal--a primal, uncompromising vision of insanity run amok.
A Cliffs' Notes version of Ernie Davis' life that turns everything he worked for into a Hallmark card.
Stagnant, lugubrious and very, very slow. Besides being plodding, the fatal error of City of Ember is its lack of heart.
So many like-minded films have beat it to the punch that there's nothing new to offer audiences. The talents of all involved have been wasted, and so has our time.
A well-made funhouse ride of pure terror and near-breathless dread.
It's a mixed bag, to be sure, but in the right frame of mind it gets the (limited) job done.
For the devious bad guy's creative and unsettling garb alone, Girls Nite Out earns more points than it otherwise probably warrants.
A spookily good time.
Playing to a classier tune, the film is one that is immersive even in its understatedness, weaving a tale that is all the more effective because of how believable it is.
Freddy Krueger is now a full-blown cartoonish caricature of his initially dread-induced former self.
movie_title: A Nightmare on Elm Street 5: The Dream Child (1989)

movie_review_blurb: Not counting 1994's Wes Craven's New Nightmare, it's superior to all the other later sequels in the series.
movie_title: A Nightmare on Elm Street 4: The Dream Master (1988)

movie_review_blurb: The burn-faced night stalker simply doesn't make the impression here as he did in the former two installments
movie_title: A Nightmare on Elm Street 3: Dream Warriors (1987)

movie_review_blurb: As is the prevalent case with most sequels, the film is inferior to its predecessor. It is still very, very good, however, more so than most viewers give it credit for.
movie_title: A Nightmare on Elm Street 2: Freddy's Revenge (1985)

movie_review_blurb: Terrifically spooky and original, the film continues to feel completely modern despite being almost a quarter-century old.
Exceedingly stupid and convoluted, leading to a big 'huh?' ending. April Fool's, indeed.
Even today, it holds up as a spooky, flirty entertainment, doing justice to the folly and mirth of its namesake holiday.
As a tried-and-true slasher film, it has its moments, but ... it grows tedious by the end.
One of the most patently imbecilic thrillers to come down the pike in many a moon.

Pretty junky stuff, but it is notable for one oddball thing: the end credits attribute someone as 'Personal Chef of Nicolas Cage' and someone else as 'Assistant to Personal Chef of Nicolas Cage'. Yikes.

Whether the fault lies with a script crying out for further drafts before shooting, or a cheap studio shutting off its director's creativity in order to save a buck, the dubious result remains the same. Babylon A.D. is a mess.

Zippy, lightweight, raucously silly, and embracing of its well-earned R rating, College doesn't pretend to be deep or anything more than it is: a you-are-there portrayal of three high schoolers let loose on a hard-partying university campus.
There is a fine line between something that is so bad it's good, and something that's genuinely good, and Mamma Mia! straddles it throughout.

A sexual metaphor about penises and a scene where a character is eaten by a creature and escapes death by exiting its anus is so inappropriate that the MPAA must have been asleep when they rated this G.
Nihilistic, imaginative and emotionally gratifying, The Dark Knight is in many ways a groundbreaking triumph, and perhaps the best superhero film to date.
It's not every day Eddie Murphy releases something that doesn't make you want to rip your eyes out. In its own way, it is a fun movie.
Briskly paced but soulless where it counts, the film acts as empty spectacle that, when it all comes down to it, isn't particularly spectacular.
movie_title: Journey to the Center of the Earth (2008)

movie_review_blurb: If the premise isn't exactly air-tight and the pacing is uneven, the visual panache and central character work helps to make up for some of its deficiencies.
Paved with such good intentions that it's a shame to have to criticize it. Alas, said good intentions cannot stop the picture from being a decidedly dull and eventless experience.

The story itself isn't a complex one, but the characters are, and the journey they endeavor upon from the month of June to the dog days of August is one that is emotionally satisfying, easily relatable and well worth taking.
Hancock is a giant mess of a movie. It's not just misguided, it's insulting.
A resoundingly affecting and emotionally cathartic family drama. Lingers and stirs in the memory long after the end credits have rolled.
Alive with stylistic innovation and impressively clean storytelling. The experience is close to exhilarating.
An original, mature and borderline-artsy family film that makes a name for itself. Like the rest of Pixar's titles, it is destined to endure for years to come.
A pleasing antidote to audiences tired of the summer movie blockbuster season, Kabluey is an affecting, noble-hearted charmer.
Plays like nothing more than a marathon viewing of an entire seventh season that should have never been made.
While far from a complete misfire, Forces of Nature remains simply too by-the-numbers to be particularly gratifying or worthwhile.

A fairly pedestrian, slap-dash piece of work but the tone is so light and goofy that it's difficult to imagine anyone getting offended by its onslaught of bathroom humor, penis gags, midget jokes, elephant sex, and Hindu-flavored satire.
A spy comedy that isn't clever enough to get many chuckles and isn't over-the-top enough to work as prime lampoonery. It's dull, forgettable and uninspired.

Were the first 45 minutes of The Happening not as rattlingly effective as they are, one could chalk the film up as mediocre. There is such untapped potential, though, that the dishonest places Shyamalan chooses to take his audience are maddening.
What is so disappointing about the film is how much of a lesser experience it is than Ang Lee's Hulk.
A desperate, miserable experience.
movie_title: You Don't Mess With the Zohan (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A snappy, amusingly witty family comedy. Kids will undoubtedly love the film, while adults won't feel talked down to.
With a few tweaks, the picture could have actually been about 12-year-old step-brothers, and been better for it.
An entertaining and inventive ride tailor-made for the summer movie season.
movie_title: Indiana Jones and the Kingdom of the Crystal Skull (2008)

movie_review_blurb: If American Teen isn't a particularly deep documentary, it is an entertaining one.

Tonally and thematically all over the place. It's a political satire that is too soft and yet too cynical. It's a familial drama that wishes to tug at the heartstrings, but is done in by cloying prefabrication.
As depressing and empty a cinematic experience as any other picture this year or last (or maybe the whole decade). To label it as simply unfunny or vacuous or ugly or boring would be a compliment.

By only partially broaching the film's underlying themes concerning terrorism, religion, and international relations, Traitor becomes little more than a disposable thriller in need of a sharper focus.
A more slapdash affair than its predecessor, but writer-director Todd Stephens has retained enough sunshine, sweetness, and bravely go-for-broke showmanship to keep things moving at an amiable pace.
movie_title: Another Gay Sequel: Gays Gone Wild! (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Alternately hilarious, subtly sinister, and finally poignant, Baghead is not quite like any other film in memory.

A trippy, unsettling experience with a clear eye for mesmerizing visuals. Genre fans grown weary by today's mainstream spate owe it to themselves to seek out this grim, creatively sumptuous, unapologetically chilling indie effort.
A feel-good family sports drama more likely to make the viewer feel sick from sugar overload.

Like a modern-day Lucille Ball, Anna Faris is a pure and utter natural, brilliant at getting a laugh and just as adept at finding the pathos in the unexpected. This is the brightest comedy so far this year.
Low-rent, boring, brazenly mindless garbage.
This is an uproariously crowd-pleasing satire, one that embraces its R-rated subversiveness without ever feeling dirty or mean-spirited.
Makes up for a lack of gut-busting moments simply by being genial and smartly written. The Rocker is a minor, feel-good entertainment. It's not rocket science, but its heart is in the right place.

That the film is ultimately not about whether the guy gets the girl, but about whether the guy will be able to make peace with his past and go on to live the life he deserves, is pretty remarkable in itself.
Mirrors isn't a total wash of a horror film, but it is not unreasonable to expect more from a filmmaker who has delivered stronger, more confident works in the past.
A comparatively minor success on Woody Allen's directorial resume, but its reflective depiction of post-collegiate confusion and yearning rings true.
George Lucas' desire to suck a few more dollars out of the consumers' pockets has led to a roaring creative misstep.
An immersive experience, perhaps the most impressive and least flawed use of the 3-D format, to date.
A smug comedy so blatantly pleased with itself that the finished product isn't nearly as much fun to watch as it probably was to make.
Not to be confused with the more famous grindhouse biker flicks of a bygone era, Hell Ride misses out on that critical sense of freedom on the open road.
A curiously languid, emotionally detached experience.

Begins as a been-there-done-that stoner romp before turning into an outlandishly silly and graphically violent action-thriller. The tone may be schizophrenic, but the sheer, unabashed showmanship of the whole thing warrants praising.
A solid if not wholly necessary sequel, but Carmen, Tibby, Lena and Bridget are so pleasant to spend a couple hours with that it hardly matters.
movie_title: The Sisterhood of the Traveling Pants 2 (2008)

movie_review_blurb: There is no excuse for an action feature to not hold a single thrilling moment. That's not just bad luck, that's bad filmmaking.
movie_title: The Mummy: Tomb of the Dragon Emperor (2008)

movie_review_blurb: As a genre effort, it's strictly forgettable, but as an emotional addendum into the ongoing lives of Fox Mulder and Dana Scully, it is satisfying and bittersweet.
movie_title: The X-Files: I Want to Believe (The X Files 2) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: For legitimate frights that don't rely on gore, Grudge 2 fits the bill. Just don't go in expecting to make sense out of the convoluted story, because there isn't any.
An unnerving, ruthless, borderline-mesmerizing thriller.
A mind-bending supernatural horror film with more promise than it delivers.
A big-screen adaptation of Men's Health and Fitness magazine, 300 is about as involving as sitting in front of a video game demo at Best Buy.
A blasé road comedy with less than five funny moments in total but plenty of tired gay jokes to pass around.
Black Snake Moan is an odd little number. It tries to be a lot of things at different times, but isn't particularly successful in any genre.
An absorbing, hugely ambitious, richly textured entertainment, and one of the better releases of a still-early year.
One of the last lines uttered in The Number 23 is, 'It may not be the happiest of endings, but it's the right one'. Try the wrong one.
Has its crude little charms, but for a movie based upon such a cutting and acerbic series there is no excuse for how forgettable it ultimately is.
A well-meaning but insufferably corny yarn.

When Ghost Rider ended, infectious widespread laughter and comments of ridicule broke out in the theater. That is probably not the reaction director Mark Steven Johnson was aiming for, but it was well-warranted.
Enchanting, transcendent and profoundly moving, Bridge to Terabithia is a masterpiece.
Retains a quirky charm that cannot be discounted. Recommended not just for what it achieves, but for what it attempts to.
A beguiling, witty and truly romantic date flick.
Blemished but undeniably enthralling as dark entertainment, Hannibal Rising is one of the good ones.
Murphy may be at the top of his game, but Norbit is stuck on autopilot.
Yet another supernatural thriller about ghostly apparitions and corpsy children, The Messengers doesn't deliver.
The only good use for Because I Said So would be as a step-by-step handbook on how not to make a romantic comedy.
What was the last studio picture this bad? Maybe 2002's The Adventures of Pluto Nash. I've seen more talent in my cat's last dump.
All things considered, a more appropriate title would have been Oil and Water.
A 180-degree switch in tone and a ridiculous last-minute "twist" botch the outcome.
Neither here nor there, neither offensively bad nor anything special, Catch and Release inspires little more than a shrug.
Has a truly cruel streak and disturbing disregard for life that puts a damper on what otherwise could have been a lean, taut and well-made B-movie.
Plays by its own rules and hopes prospective audiences are patient enough to follow characters whose lives are more rewarding to watch than the ho-hum plot surrounding them.
Considering that nothing adds up in the end, it is difficult to understand why a star of Sandra Bullock's caliber would agree to get involved.
Hidden from critics for a reason.
Sandler is uneven, but Reign Over Me is affecting in its own right.
A poignant study in empathy and, ultimately, rebirth.
Just the ticket for genre fans starved for a movie that actually thrills.
Hot Fuzz is rare in that it builds character development just as much as it aims for a punchline, and this is one aspect that is most appreciated.
The talent in front of the camera is too good to be wasted on something this trivial.
Doesn't quite rise above being a common "issues" movie, but it at least handles said issues with intelligence and tough realism.
If nothing else, it can lay claim to being the only film in memory that had me in tears of hysterical laughter before the studio logos came up.
movie_title: Aqua Teen Hunger Force Colon Movie Film for Theaters (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A charming slice-of-life...Molly Shannon gives a multifaceted Oscar-caliber performance of insight and subtlety.
John Hughes meets Alfred Hitchcock meets the 21st century in Disturbia, an adeptly crafted if not terribly original horror-thriller.
Straddles the line between intrigue and blandness until it decides it's had enough and just sort of peters out.
For the one-of-a-kind experience all by itself, it is not to be missed. Narrowing in one's focus on the quality of what is offered, it is more of a mixed bag.
Ungodly awful.
A quality dramedy that knows how to satisfy its target audience. Rexxx is talented in tricks and stunts, but this is Josh Hutcherson's film all the way.
Grammatically incorrect though it is, Are We Done Yet? is precisely what audiences will be pleading by the ten-minute mark.
A skillful and compelling character study under the guise of a heist movie.
An acerbic, satirical and richly comic escapade--or should that be ice capade?
Strikes the right notes as a fast-paced comedy, a touching but not saccharine slice-of-life, and a valuable learning tool for children.
If The Hills Have Eyes II is to gain notoriety for anything, it is the invention of one of the most laughable methods of murder ever captured on film: death by leather wallet.
Strictly generic junk that could very well deaden the brain cells of children everywhere.
As a formidable A-list action pic, the film is an unexciting throwaway. As an R-rated exploitationer, it doesn't understand that such a thing should actually be fun to watch.
Pride is a generic title for a generic movie.
A tad unorthodox in today's times of fast and furious entertainment for kids, but those who take a chance on it will be pleasantly satiated.
Better than expected, if not quite good enough to recommend outside of maybe a late-night cable airing or a spin on DVD.
Alpha Dog isn't a total wash, but it is unfocused, overstuffed and routine.
Too transparent and unintentionally silly to accept all of its faux-sincere message-making.
Watching Code Name: The Cleaner is like staring into a dark, uneventful abyss.
When so many movies are predictable cookie-cutter affairs, it makes one appreciate the flawed Déjà Vu for the risks it takes and the heady imagination it implores.
Next time around, it wouldn't be a terrible idea for Aronofsky to allow his characters the chance to smile.
Craig is the best thing about Casino Royale, which for all of its positive steps in the right direction could still use some more dusting off.
A clueless, pointless, unfunny dud. The kind of movie where one can tell that the actors already know they're making a piece of crap.
Bobby doesn't get everything right but when Estevez allows his images and the reality of his characters do the talking, the film works with indelible cogency.
Decidedly spineless and not exactly all that eye-opening.
The most original and valuable animated feature since 2004's The Polar Express.
For Your Consideration is Christopher Guest's most comedically sharp feature since the marvelous Waiting for Guffman.
A Good Year is a bad movie.
Hopelessly convoluted and vague.
A darkly whimsical dramedy that manages to walk the line between mainstream and unconventional.
An acrimoniously cookie-cutter affair without an honest bone in its body.
An ugly, dispiriting, prefabricated lump of coal. With any luck, The Santa Clause 3 will be but a distant memory by the time December 25 arrives.
movie_title: The Santa Clause 3: The Escape Clause (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Flushed Away deserves to be just that.
A comedic masterpiece and possibly the funniest movie in years.
movie_title: Borat: Cultural Learnings of America for Make Benefit Glorious Nation of Kazakhstan (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Quite a nifty and superb thriller ... thought out with precision and executed with irresistible macabre flair.
Perceptive, sad and witty.
Not a bad motion picture, but it is a missed opportunity that sheds fleeting light on what could have been an important historical epic.
Never met a cliché it didn't like.
A complex revenge drama and an intriguing mystery that, like the old magic act standby, attempts to pull a rabbit or two out of its hat by the end.
The music is heavenly in its use and perfect for the tone, rustling up an emotional response far greater than anything brought about from the characters themselves.
A one-part mean-spirited, one-part saccharine, all-parts forgettable piece of fluff.
A laughably heavy-handed sermon railing against the modern-day media's greedy thirst for exploitation as a means of entertainment.
The first ten minutes are brilliant and then, for the most part, the fun (and music) screech to a halt.
movie_title: Tenacious D in The Pick of Destiny (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Perhaps a special appearance from Old St. Nick might not have been such a bad idea.
Dangerously close to scraping the bottom of the barrel when it comes to theatrically released animated movies.
Proof-positive that a formulaic plot done to death can still work if enough effort and passion is put into it.
Difficult to resist even when its allure is only surface-deep.
movie_title: Perfume: The Story of a Murderer (2006)

movie_review_blurb: Is (1) a victim of its own hype, and (2) nothing like what it's being marketed as, but there is an audience involvement writer-director Guillermo del Toro manages to work up all the same.
Just to see Cate Blanchett bitchslap Judi Dench is worth the price of admission.
Dumbed-down, unscary hokum without a clue how to ratchet up a person's heartbeat.
A consistently tense, demanding and altogether exhilarating experience, an instant new classic of the sci-fi genre.
Night at the Museum isn't an utter disaster but it is a dreary special effects-laden fantasy adventure with zero thrills and only intermittent heart.
Syrupy, vapid, unfocused.
A movie musical that certainly knows how to carry a tune, but is missing a heart.
In every way possible, Letters from Iwo Jima is the superior effort and precisely the kind of film Flags of Our Fathers should have been.
Inland Empire isn't just a brilliant motion picture; it's a work of staggering art.
To say the movie is merely 'boring' doesn't seem fitting or epic enough of a word to describe what an excruciating endurance test its 108-minute running time is.
Stop me if you've heard this one before...
A moving and heartfelt character-based drama with an unsentimental tone that makes the machinations of the plot all the more urgent and effective.
This story could be used as a wonderful learning tool for children dealing with loss.
By the end, there's nothing to grab onto except spare limbs and innards.
There hasn't been a more entertaining and satisfying drama released to theaters in months.
Sputters to the end credits on autopilot.
Epic love stories are one thing, but this one is intended only to be cute, fluffy and at least a half-hour shorter.
I have had knee-shaking, äss-skewering hemorrhoids that were funnier than this so-called comedy.
movie_title: Van Wilder: The Rise of Taj (Van Wilder 2) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: One long setup that ends up being much ado about nothing.
A desert-set Aliens rip-off with no-budget creature effects that look like H.R. Giger by way of "South Park," Unearthed is a dismal failure on every level.
Slickly produced but much ado about nothing, Next keeps one's interest, only to laugh in your face for caring.
An instant contender as the best film not screened in advance for critics. The lack of support Hollywood Pictures afforded this thoughtful sleeper gem is frankly inexcusable.
When a film has as much going for it as Good Luck Chuck did at the onset, and the magic is flying, it is positively heartbreaking to watch it all deteriorate by way of such glaring condescension.
Sydney White might not physically resemble Snow White, but the classic character's value system thankfully has not been lost in translation.
A heartrending slice of Americana both inspiring and foreboding in its view of a world that will exist long after we are all gone.
An absorbing, gentle slice-of-life, light on plot but heavy on smaller moments of keen human interaction and observation.
A penetrating, lacerating, angry-as-hell condemnation against the incalculably devastating cost of war as it pertains to both those fighting in it and those consequently affected by it back home.
An ambitious failure, but a failure nonetheless. For a film celebrating life and love, Across the Universe ironically and unforgivably leaves the viewer feeling cold.
Destined to go down in history as one of cinema's most blunderingly, catastrophically bad big-budget films of the last few decades.
Enjoyable enough while it lasts, but also instantly disposable.
An ultimately satisfying venture with a few spot-on acting turns, but it is a tad too ordinary for a director who thrives when he is anything but.
The good news is that Resident Evil: Extinction is about twice as good as its predecessors. That's not saying much.
Riddled with illogical plot contrivances, pat irony, half-formed subplots, and a climax that stretches the boundaries of what can be swallowed.
The film as a whole encounters some bumps in the road, but it is also better than most will be expecting.

Ridiculously violent, comically bloody and so over-the-top that one can only view it as a cartoon that just so happens to be live-action. As for the says-it-all title, it is truth in advertising taken to the extreme.
There is nothing overwhelmingly bad about the finished product, but there is also nothing, save for a performance or two, that inspires the viewer to sit up and take notice.
As entertainment, the film is equally unpleasant and captivating. As a more serious drama, it alternates between heartbreaking and heavy-handed.

This so-called reinvention doesn't cut it by a long shot. It is a foul-mouthed, soulless, low-rent slasher flick that mistakes graphic violence for genuine thrills and sex scenes for character development.
Balls of Fury is precisely the kind of dud that gives a bad name to films opening over the lazy Labor Day weekend.
Acerbic and cutthroat in all the right places, along with truthful, savvy, and consistently entertaining.
War is largely a yawner.

Blessedly shrewd where it counts and deserves notice. The lessons develop naturally and aren't jammed down the viewer's throat like the hypocritical sermonizing in I Now Pronounce You Chuck and Larry.
For any self-respecting horror fan, Hatchet is an amusing, spooky, visceral, smartly-crafted breath of fresh air.
An example of middle-of-the-road insignificance.
A film that resonates in spite of its shortcomings...Feast of Love is a frothy, whimsical title--too frothy and too whimsical for a film that might have been more accurately named Woe Is Love.
A message movie without a soul or a solid cinematic framework to make the impact it intends.
Joins the unsavory ranks of holiday entertainment that isn't entertaining and has little holiday cheer. This is a sinful missed opportunity for all involved.
Lions for Lambs will not change anything. It probably won't even put a dent in the the U.S.'s consciousness. Regrettably, it's more of the same with only cursory signs of a soul.
A masterpiece of a thriller, as merciless as a livestock stun gun to the head, as sharp as a razor blade, and as confidently written as any genre classic one can think of (take your pick).
Routine but skillful, P2 takes a bare-bones premise and uses it to string up a series of escalatingly tense situations.
A snazzy-looking mixed bag. Kids will be diverted, adults will tolerate it, and all involved will be expecting something more imaginative than what Jerry Seinfeld has whittled together.
