Strictly paint-by-numbers filmmaking any way you slice it, and not even the individually riveting performances from Washington and Crowe can save it.
Heartfelt, but uninspired, the film follows a plodding, predictable path that does not deviate for a second from what the viewer expects.
Easily the worst entry in the series, and the first one that undeniably feels like a sloppily thrown-together rush job.
Comfortable and enjoyable in an unpushy sort of way.
For a horror picture being released only weeks before Halloween, 30 Days of Night doesn't thrill and it definitely doesn't spook.
The provocatively-titled Gone Baby Gone peels itself one layer at a time, revealing unpredicted and mesmeric sides to a story that could never be guessed from the initial setup.
The film demands to be taken as a prestigious Oscar hopeful, but the material just doesn't have that level of potency; it's more akin to a slick but forgettable made-for-TV effort.
Light on plot, which wouldn't be a problem if the mildly rote characters held more depth than they do.
movie_title: Things We Lost in the Fire (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A stale, murky drama so oversimplified that its politics boil down to a single tidy, elementary-level message: torture is bad.

Characters speak in dime-store odes to the sacred game of baseball. The emotions are of the maudlin, heart-on-your-sleeve variety. The music score swells even when the scene doesn't call for it. The climax is set at the big game. You get the picture.
Taut, intelligent and confidently unpretentious about what it sets out to, and does, achieve within the crime-thriller mold.
Once the narrative edges toward meeting up with where it began, Michael Clayton becomes riveting stuff all the way until the gratifyingly acidic ending.
A dreary, frequently nonsensical ordeal.
movie_title: The Seeker: The Dark Is Rising (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The Heartbreak Kid is not the romantic comedy it is selling itself as, but a horror story about a selfish guy getting exactly what he wants and not earning any of it. There is no fun in that, only misery.
The Darjeeling Limited is a pleasant trifle, and that's it. Individual moments shine but they do not make a satisfying whole.
One of the most cinematically assured works of the year. Blows most tried-and-true westerns out of the water.
movie_title: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The movie's pure good will can only carry it so far, and by the third act it has already exhausted all avenues of amusement.
More concerned with emotionally manipulating the audience than breaking any new ground on the subject matter.
A well-crafted jack-in-the-box toy that is more frightening in its ratcheted apprehension of what is to come than in the ultimate outcome.
Cooks up a preposterously tacked-on and ill-advised ending that ruins the integrity of what has come before.
The film spins its wheels as Winterbottom loses sight of the human element in exchange for a stab at mounting tension that simply isn't there.
Underneath the atmosphere and pizzazz is an intimate and thoughtful portrait of one man's return from an abyss infinitely more haunting than any old, evil hotel room.
By all accounts, Evan Almighty shouldn't work, but it kind of does.
Superficial, unimaginative and inert. The so-called heroes are pompous, one-note caricatures who have the depth of gnats, and are just as irritating.
movie_title: Fantastic Four: Rise of the Silver Surfer (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The sleuthing is where the fun is at, and Nancy Drew is enjoyable enough for one to hope there are more onscreen mysteries for her to solve in the near future.

Whereas the first film began as a college kid's wet dream and ended as a nightmare, Hostel: Part II is cloaked in a pall of dread and darkness from frame one. Even the lighter moments in the first act seem like taunting harbingers of doom.
Danny Ocean and company ought to seriously consider retirement.
Takes a swell idea and then wastes it on a forgettable plot and one-dimensional characters.
A fascinating and thoroughly unsettling exploration into the mind of a serial killer, Mr. Brooks could well be the smartest, most astute thriller of its kind in several years.
In the annals of sports flicks of the twenty-first century, Gracie eclipses practically all of them.
Knocked Up is a good film. Lurking beneath the surface is a great one just dying to break free.
Dishonestly marketed but fascinatingly macabre...Bug is about creepy-crawlies as much as Magnolia is about frogs and The Squid and the Whale is about sea creatures.
Bloated beyond comprehension, overplotted to the point of aggravation, and about as soulless as a ship captain specter, [the film] is a total mess.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: At Worlds End (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Like a lesser '80s slasher movie, Severance is fine while it lasts, and forgettable once it's over.
The big, green ogre and his ragtag pals are still an amiable lot to spend ninety minutes with, but a creative overhaul might be in the cards if the series is to continue to a part four.
28 Days Later had its moments, to be sure, but 28 Weeks Later is the real deal--scarier, darker, uncompromising, and more emotionally complex.
Even when the lack of forward motion in the narrative shines through, Georgia Rule is worth watching for Lindsay Lohan alone.
Plays like a network sitcom with a few four-letter words thrown in that wouldn't make it past the censors.
There is a good motion picture hiding somewhere beneath the surface of Lucky You, but it hasn't found its way to the screen.
As is a rule with most sequels, Spider-Man 3 is bigger and vaster in scope than its predecessors. Where it bucks the trend is in its decided superiority over them.
Genial and appealing...Keri Russell essays a heroine that is worth rooting for and caring about.
A gloriously unpretentious gem just waiting to be discovered. That the film hasn't yet received the full respect it deserves only adds to its charm.
The climax set at the dancing competition drags on so long one wonders if the film wasn't originally meant to be a miniseries event.
Suspenseful and rousing and rarely stopping long enough to wear out its welcome. As crowd-pleasing spectacle, Live Free or Die Hard fits the bill.
Overly simplistic and not terribly hard-hitting, but worth recommending for the unflattering mirror it dares to place before the government in charge.
Superbad is a successful laugher, no doubt about it, but what lingers afterwards is the poignancy of childhoods reaching an end.
Why make a serious, no-holds-barred horror film about werewolves when you can make a PG-13 kiddie show free of all the elements an audience goes to see this kind of movie for?

Stardust isn't just a one-note movie with a lot of pizzazz and zero substance, but a more thoughtful motion picture that ponders many of the mysteries of life in a way that is accessible and emotionally satisfying.
More of the same, only better.
A lazy, juvenile, starkly unfunny and consistently unrelatable family film.
A big-hearted movie that delights in playing with the conventions of superhero pictures. In the same week when the insulting Bratz is also opening, it's a comparative godsend.

There isn't a moment of truth or perception in its miserable 98 minutes; this film's view of high school is so skewed from reality and so insulting in its contempt that it's almost scary to think preteen girls would fall for it.
An oddball comedy that only seems to be funny for the people who made it. The audience, unfortunately, is left out on the joke.
Solid but not overwhelming. If another sequel does happen to be made in the future, Jason could afford to be given a little more meat and complexity.
The images, flooded in deep blues and reds, are vibrant and just plain gorgeous, turning even empty moments into chances to aesthetically wow the viewer.
Feels like yesterday's news. For fans of the television show, wait a few months for the DVD. For everyone else, don't even bother.

Might have been worth recommending had the film cut to end credits during a key sequence set to Liz Phair's "Count on My Love." Unfortunately, director Scott Hicks trudges forward with plotting that gets dumber by the minute.
A moody, classy, skin-deep sci-fi piece"Sunshine" gets enough right to please genre buffs.
So much of it hinges on depicting a person's gay lifestyle as a punchline that the third act's aim for political correctness feels hypocritical and dishonest.
movie_title: I Now Pronounce You Chuck & Larry (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Less focused than John Waters' subversive and satirical original, but nonetheless brings a smile to your face and is destined to get your feet tapping.
Some inventive individual moments aside, Captivity is off-puttingly derivative and clumsily written.
A haunting and evocative motion picture that stays with you.
An entertaining marvel of invention and storytelling. The series' reigning achievement and one of this summer's smartest and most invigorating releases.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (2007)

movie_review_blurb: License to Wed is set on a plane of existence not inhabited by intelligent life, but by widespread nincompoops.

A melting pot of astonishing ineptitude. Amazing, how hundreds of millions of dollars can go into making a finished product that doesn't offer one solitary second of wonder, momentum, tension, or authentic emotion.
For a movie that begins on such shaky footing, Evening packs an impassioned wallop by the end.
Pixar's weakest film in almost a decade.
The time spent watching this hackneyed waste is interminable, frustrating, and quite boring.
The ending, plain and simple, cheapens all that has come before.
Uncompromising and plausibly compelling.
I doubt I would be able to find ten things I hate about 10 Things I Hate About You, but the positive aspects of the film far out-number ten.
One of those dumb, corny concoctions that attempts to be a heartwarming family film, but is too muddled in its own cliches and predictability to be the least bit touching.
A rather cartoonish biopic of struggling-actress-turned-trashy-writer Jacqueline Susann.
One of the most consistently disturbing, surprising, and visually beautiful motion pictures I have seen this decade.
One of the most genuinely sweet love stories to come along in quite some time.
The clear potential that The Muse possesses only makes the final product even more of a disappointment.
Scorsese's most impressive, dramatically sound piece of celluloid in at least the last seven years.
One of the most misguided big-screen diversions to come along in some time, considering the clear potential it has.
I'll take Disney's superior animated entertainment, Tarzan, over this any day of the week.
The ending of the film inevitably leaves the door wide open for a third part, but judging from this amazingly lackluster first sequel, everyone involved should have quit while they were still ahead.
movie_title: I Still Know What You Did Last Summer (1998)

movie_review_blurb: If you hate movies where people with low-IQs are chased around and killed by demented bozos, avoid it at all costs!
A spinetinglingly good horror film.
While not what one would exactly call 'action-packed,' there are several scenes that are edited and directed with such energy, it's a shame the rest of the movie is so very bad.
A sleek, impressively well-made movie, a lyrical flower in a bed of January thorns, if you will. It is simply too admirable a film on too many levels to be thrown to the wayside.

While one can walk away from a theater appreciating that the film actually has more than a few fleeting thoughts in its mind, there is rarely, if ever, a clear attempt to develop the wide array of characters from being anything more than symbolic figures
So concerned about its plot that it doesn't pay much attention at all to its characters, and therefore, the film only comes off feeling even more empty-headed.
Stylish, suspenseful, and unusually intelligent for a genre movie, Cherry Falls is an excellent example of how to make a horror movie right.
Too many problems detract from Bowfinger to make it be considered a 'great' comedy, but it is a good one.
Unsure what it wants to be, and never firmly finds its footing.
It could have been much worse. Now how's that for being positive?
A flawed motion picture, and yet it works despite its many problems.
I found myself often shrinking down in my seat, afraid to see what was going to happen next, but not daring to take my eyes off the screen, either.
A heaping piece of rancid garbage.
Strictly a wild comedy, and it works surprisingly well, sure to attract wide audiences that break out from the teenage crowd.
Payback is not, in any way, an entertaining film.
A depressing, lugubrious film experience.
What's the worst that could happen, you say? Well, for starters, getting locked in a theater showing this movie on a continuous, 24-hour loop.
movie_title: What's the Worst That Could Happen? (2001)

movie_review_blurb: What an ingenious concept.
Taking every scene on an individual basis, it is often madly brilliant, but put it all together, and it is a pretentious, incoherent mess.
Has promise, and it has occasional flare, but for the most part, it is a string of missed opportunities.
So misguided in so many ways that it makes you wonder how such talented and high-profile actors would even get involved in an embarrassing clap-trap like this one.
The most delightfully morbid film of the year, a movie that goes so far over the deep end with its outrageousness and violence that I couldn't help but be won over by the material.
Boosting a smart, savvy screenplay and a bright, young cast, Amy Heckerling succeeds in telling an oft-told story by writing characters who may be flawed, but are good-hearted inside and often out.
Allen's first motion picture of the 21st-century, and, no doubt, one of his brightest and sunny in years.
A respectable family drama, but is all the more disappointing since it is obvious that it could have been so much more.
movie_title: The Deep End of the Ocean (1999)

movie_review_blurb: Comes this close to overcoming its problems and succeeding as a thriller, but doesn't quite make it.
The film is a magical experience.
You can either get angry at having part of your night wasted, or you can heartily laugh and make fun of it on the drive home from the theater.

Having seen the film several times in the years since, my rating would now stand at a mildly positive 2.5 stars. Yes, the movie is too short, but it is also stylish and suspenseful enough to recommend.
Random Hearts has one half of terrific material, and then resorts to the ultimate betrayal: formulaic filmmaking.
Truly spellbinding and powerful.
An earnest, emotionally accurate, but seriously flawed drama.
A thinking-person's film.
Too often wanders into unnecessary silliness, and the ending leaves something to be desired.
A few subtle, quiet moments sneak in every once and a while, but the asinine screenplay destroys all signs of cinematic promise.
Babe: Pig in the City is mostly a joyless sequel to the joyful original.
Slowly but surely wrapped around me and put me under its rapturous spell.
An offbeat and occasionally quirky little movie that, like all successful ensembles, gradually builds upon its energy, depth, and momentum the further we get into it.
A deliberately paced, but endlessly creepy, horrifying motion picture.
Basically, what you see in the trailer is what you get, and nothing more.
An intelligent, impassioned adult romance that has a lot to say, and doesn't feel the need to let a rock soundtrack full of love ballads explain it.
A quirky, smart gem of a movie that is not only fun to watch, but has quite a few meaningful things to say about life, love, and death.
Tries to desperately cloak itself so its viewers don't realize how very little worthwhile material is actually present.

It's akin to cotton candy; you consume it with interest for its duration, but there is nothing that is particularly filling about it, and you're left either wanting more or nearly forgetting that you even ate it.
They probably should have completely thrown the script out. That way, they could have come up with a story that at least had a sign of intelligence and freshness.
Plays as an instructional guide on making your sex life better, rather than one that has a thorough story and characters.
A peculiar mixture of several different film genres.
A one-of-a-kind film that takes a lot of courageous chances.
A documentary not nearly intimate enough in its portrait of the people the film inhabits. For webaholics, at least its never boring, even at a prolonged 102 minutes.
So muddled and frustrating in its storytelling that I felt like giving up on the film halfway through.
One of the most involving and well-made space-set thrillers since Ridley Scott's 1979 opus, Alien.
A powerfully articulated and subtle drama from famous Iranian director Dariush Mehrjui.
Capsule Review
Through the performances and screenplay, we often do get some extremely well-written and intelligent scenes.
A triumph of both style and substance.
Not completely agreeable, but nonetheless, it manages to somehow remain a strong entertainment.
So very good in so many scenes that it almost makes you angry the movie is hampered by an uneven, flawed screenplay.
The biggest laugh I've had at the movies all year.
Solondz is one of the masters of flawlessly intermingling both pitch-black comedy and heartbreaking drama, sometimes at the very same moment.
Inept on every possible filmmaking level.
Banderas proves that you can successfully make a film that doesn't relate directly to you, simply if the underlying themes are felt deeply enough.
Let me make things clear: I still like the Muppets, but an increase in quality is in serious need.
A little too conventional and predictable for my taste. However, when the ending came, the whole effect of the movie was pretty much ruined.
Thoroughly entertains in the context of this genre, but it also stands as being the most uplifting and romantic love story of the year.
The sort of romance that doesn't come around too oftenintelligent without being saccharine, heartfelt without being condescending.
The underwhelming finale simply proved what I had increasingly been realizing throughout, which is that there was no reason for Gone in 60 Seconds to be made at all.
movie_title: Gone in 60 Seconds (Gone in Sixty Seconds) (2000)

movie_review_blurb: Such a well-meaning drama that you almost feel guilty criticizing it.
A veritable winner.
Flawed, to be sure, but its heart sure is in the right place.
An ambitious animated film that at least attempts to aim for something different, but is impaired by its hackneyed plot.
The Siege is constantly heavy-handed, not entertaining or insightful, and just goes to prove that not even the best actors can save a film that lacks a satisfactory screenplay.
One of the more enjoyable and lively motion pictures to come along this summer, and demonstrates how a successful comedy should be carried out.
American Beauty is a devastating motion picture of unconceivable power.
May be a so-called 'feel-good' comedy-drama, but it is rarely funny, and its emotions neglect to exude much tangible feeling.
One of the very few comic book adaptations that has been successfully translated to the big screen.
What the picture lacks in freshness, it more than makes up for it in the outstanding performances across the board.
DOA from the start.
A ridiculous and just plain goofy romantic fantasy that's as flimsy as a slice of bologna.
While never an inherently terrible movie, Bait digs itself a deep grave early on, simply by its own sheer mediocrity in every aspect.
Scream 3 has arrived, and to say it was well worth the wait would be an understatement.
Has two good scenes amidst the creative dead zone that surrounds them.
If there is a bright spot to be found beyond the unbearable filmmaking stench of desperation, it is Janeane Garofalo.
Rests solely on the presumed charm of the cast, and half of the actors are not charming at all. Now, what does that tell you?
A new animated classic has been born.
A respectable, intelligent film, but one, to be sure, that prospers more while in the individual moments, rather than one that remains deeply ingrained in your long-term memory.
Best of all about Mission: Impossible 2 is that its story is actually easy to follow, and therefore what happens means more to the viewer.

Gladiator is a flawed motion picture, and one that, for all its flashiness, comes off as a mild disappointment. It is still a good film, but only marginally so, and easily could have been a great one.
A highly entertaining, funny, exciting, no-holds-barred, bubblegum triumph of the way to make a great action-comedy, as well as a rambunctious female empowerment fantasy.
A mediocre 'man-on-the-run' crime drama without any twists or likable three-dimensional characters to keep your interest.
Had Say It Isn't So abandoned its lewd, naughty roots and tried to just be a sweet romance, it might have worked better.
A modern-day slasher pic that is a step above most in the genre.
A lighthearted, frothy entertainment that goes down with ease.
The picture feels rushed and rather pointless -- a nice enough diversion, but one that fails to go that extra mile to become anything other than such.
It may not be an earthshaking cinematic experience, but it does have its heart in the right place, here on earth.

An awe-inspiring, amazing achievement that not only is refreshingly more serious and realistic than the usual dull recent Disney movies, but enraptured me in its spell from the first powerful sequence to the last.
One of the most original, invigorating films I've ever seen.
If the movie is a disaster on the writing and directing levels, at least most of the performances are strong and effective, and on a technical level, it is often impressive.
Has a genuinely goofy premise, and is far more original than the other sequels. But if you look at it as a horror film, which it is, that is where the film fails.
Had Say It Isn't So abandoned its lewd, naughty roots and tried to just be a sweet romance, it might have worked better.
Like all of the films Ed Wood directed, this new movie is a pure and simple dud.
movie_title: I Woke Up Early the Day I Died (1998)

movie_review_blurb: The rare, quintessential Hollywood romancesmart, affectionate, realistic, and thoroughly likable.
A film with a truly fascinating and clever premise that nevertheless collapses under the weight of everything that surrounds the central storyline.
Talent can certainly help any film out, but when the written material isn't up to their level, what we are virtually left with is a vacuum of thin air.
Screams out for that special, gentle touch, and the filmmakers sadly never realize it. Or maybe they just didn't care.
It's just too bad, then, that the finale could not have been stronger. It downgrades a potentially great film to being, at most, a very good one.
A sort of half-hearted fantasy that is rarely ever involving.
Is this film better than the original? The answer is no, not quite, but to my shock, it is just about as good of a remake as could have possibly been expected.
Capsule Review
A virtually unknown gem, and is one of the sweetest, most touching romances of the decade.
I was never exactly bored while I was watching it, but I hasten to add that I was rarely ever entertained.
A sparkling comedy.
Woefully unfunny.
A rollicking good show that dazzles each and every time writer-director Helgeland treats the audience to another classic rock song.
Lazy storytelling at its worst, so disposable it is likely to be forgotten before it even reaches the end.
Bar none, the funniest film of the summer.
A romance without passion, urgency, depth, or even a slight modicum of believability...easily one of the worst films of 2001.
When it comes to sheer, unadulterated laughs, one couldn't hope for much better...Alyson Hannigan is absolutely charming.
A disquieting, classy, superbly realized horror tale.
The jokes are about as fresh as moldy bread run over by a dump truck.
Practically a carbon copy of [its] predecessor.
One of the best films of the year, a movie that takes a painstakingly realistic look at the difficulties of growing up...Thora Birch is a revelation.
Entertaining, light-hearted, and maybe even a little wise.
Features moments of sheer power and earnestness, and others that are so misdirected and ludicrously written, they have to be seen to be believed.
The most uneven motion picture Tim Burton has ever made.
If it wants to be a romance between [Cusack and Roberts], I've seen more sparks fly between ostriches.
An almost non-stop parade of snazzy, state-of-the-art visual effects and fast-paced, breathtaking action set pieces.
A missed opportunity, one that will undoubtedly go down as little more than a footnote in these fine performers' respective careers.
A sunny, hip confection.
Filled with endless imagination and wonder...sure to go down, in time, as one of the brilliant achievements in modern moviemaking.
Flounders in desperately overwrought dialogue and one of the most incomprehensible plots since 2000's 'Battlefield Earth.'
Choppily edited and obviously rushed into theaters to make a quick, tidy profit.
A surprisingly ill-advised misfire that surely won't be garnering many devoted fans above the age of single-digits.
A gorgeous, surprisingly meditative look at the beauty of life and the mysteries of death.
A playful throwback to the slasher flicks of the '80s, the film wisely does not try to copy or steal from its predecessors, but comes up with a style and tone all its own.
One of the very best of the recent slasher offerings because it mixes its laughs and chills with more smoothness and grace than usual.
Simply isn't tightly enough written or plotted to be satisfying, despite some notable performances.
A terminally thin, virtually motionless action film.
Never rises above being merely skin-deep.
While Return to Me plays out, you are not bored, but you also are not as satisfied as you could be.
Magnolia is a mind-blowing masterpiece of a movie--heavy in drama, intense emotional material, characters, and underlying themes.
Kaminski may not hold a firm grip on the picture the whole way through, but he does conclude on an unexpectedly high note that questions life, faith, and one's mortality.
If the movie is never necessarily boring, it also is rarely interesting.
Clumsy and self-important.
This low-rent, convoluted follow-up gives the great original a bad name.
An unheralded gem of a motion picture, and one of the more vibrant and authentic depictions of teenage life in memory.
Been there, done that.
Remains an uneasy, uncomfortable balance between a comedic romp and something remarkably darker.
An exceptional motion picture. A true-to-life examination of the bond between a mother and a daughter, and has universal appeal for anyone who has ever had a parent.
Strictly cut-and-paste filmmaking, and it doesn't even do a respectable job at that, either.
Has the ability to both surprise and frightentwo things that are rarely found in today's horror films. It's safe to say you will never ever look at flying in airplanes the same way again.
Nowhere near perfect, and in the confines of staying true to Andy's life, it probably could never be.
A well-made thriller, to be sure, but just about as banal as they come.
One's tolerance for strictly juvenile humor will decide what other age frame might enjoy such fodder.
An intellectually vacant and pointless excursion to a town that is almost frightening in its artificiality.
Perfectly cast from top to bottom, with many fine performances shining through.
I was in constant enjoyment as I watched it.
A sly, extremely potent political satire, aided by a first-rate cast that hungrily dig into their respective roles with a vengeance.
Plays well as both a romance and a portrait of a lonely man coming to terms with the mistakes in his life.
movie_title: My Name Is Joe (Mein Name ist Joe) (1999)

movie_review_blurb: It simply sits there, motionless, without any notable attributes to recommend, or that are even worth mentioning. It's unfortunate, but it's the truth.
What is most surprising is how touching much of the film is without ever taking the easy route, and going for obviousness or predictable, maudlin melodrama.
A rollicking adventure yarn of thrills, humor and daring close calls, albeit one liberally borrowing its style and tone from the "Indiana Jones" series.
Baby Boy is not a great movie, and lacks the overall realism and intensity of Boyz N the Hood, but it is a good one.
An electric drama.
Convoluted as some of the developments may be, the movie never loses its interest or atmosphere within the swampy, backwater Georgia town, and as summer popcorn-fare, it is unusually intelligent.
The whole movie, ambitious as it may be, relentlessly flaps there like a fish suddenly pulled out of the water, gasping for its last few breaths.
Isn't a bad movie by any means; it's just a reasonably silly one that, in one form or the other, has been overdone to death.
A worthwhile entry into the 80's mad-slasher wave.
A perfectly good way to waste an hour-and-a-half for those seeking a 'dumb' horror movie. It's no more than that, but sometimes, that's enough for any fan of this genre.
An assured first feature from Merendino, a filmmaker whom I look forward to his next film from.
One of the most joyless family films in a long time.
A serious-minded motion picture on the trials, tribulations, and (good and bad) experiences of young adults, is not to be missed.
A brutal, oft-unpleasant thriller, punctuated by quick cutting and a loud late-'90s alternative soundtrack.
Aside from the premise, the film is not likely to become a perennial Christmas mainstay, due to its uneven tone and flawed.
You almost certainly couldn't find a funnier, or (disregarding its mediocre finale) more entertaining, movie out in theaters right now.
Almost always convinces and involves the viewer.
One of those small, deliberately paced, but charming foreign films in which not much happens plot wise, but a lot happens to the characters emotionally.
Although far from perfect, johns is an edgy and powerful motion picture.
Five times better than Bruckheimer's previous embarrassment, Armageddon. Of course, that isn't to say that it's actually good. It's just saying that it isn't terrible.
Such an angry and bitter motion picture that you can almost physically feel the emotional coldness that is brewing under the surface.
A blatantly gimmicky action-thriller with the sole purpose of consistently fooling the audience.
Capsule Review
A delicate drama, short on plot but rich in memorable characters.
Flawed as it is, The Phantom Menace captured my imagination and I enjoyed it.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode I - The Phantom Menace (1999)

movie_review_blurb: Watching House on Haunted Hill is like going to a restaurant where the food looks delectable, but tastes awful.

Go in expecting a masterpiece of modern cinema, and you are surely setting yourself up for a disappointment. But go in expecting to be genuinely entertained, and you'll have yourself a rollicking time.
The movie is so conventional that it ends up being just as cliched as the Hollywood filmmaking system it sends up.
movie_title: Jay and Silent Bob Strike Back (2001)

movie_review_blurb: A respectable, smartly-scripted slasher film that firmly proved good horror movies were once again being made.
movie_title: I Know What You Did Last Summer (1997)

movie_review_blurb: The film itself, unfortunately, is a lifeless, unamusing contraption without any of the flair or excitement of, Toy Story.
An already-flawed motion picture that could have added up to so much more than it ultimately does.
There are moments within the film that are full of such unblinking reality and intelligence that there is no way it could be a 'mainstream' American picture.
The film itself is simply lifeless, with only an occasional laugh popping up here and there so that it isn't completely unbearable to watch.
Amazing, too, how the ending has the sheer power to completely blindside you when the final, ultimate twist occurs.
A jewel of a film.
Piles on the cheese and corn and honey-sap so thickly that the film, at times, seems to be in danger of being smothered to death, which would have been fine with me.
Entertaining and charming, the film is one of the better, more accurate, 'coming-of-age' films to be released in awhile.
Simply not enough substance left for the film to be particularly worthwhile.
I just wanted them to leave me alone.
The film, if you can call it that, actually goes beyond the state of bad taste into a shameful, meaningless, extreme realm all its own.
A low-rent version of Men in Black.
Everything a quality animated feature should be: intelligent, accessible to both kids and adults, and most important, genuinely fun.
Aspires to be something more than it actually is.
What finally decides the fate of Keeping the Faith is its utter likability.
Attempts to be moving, it left me cold.
A masterful human comedy and a sincere drama, as imaginative as it is unpredictable.
A bubbly, little comedic gem, and unexpectedly sharp-witted, to boot.
A stunner through-and-through, and can safely stand as one of the very best motion pictures of the season.
Not at all a bad filmsimply a misguided one that is ruined by an amateurish screenplay that is missing three important elements: a heart, a brain, and the nerve to be courageous in its storytelling.
A striking triumph!
Little more than a shallow retread of many, many movies gone by.
Pearl Harbor is a difficult movie to review. It is in no way a great movie, but it also is far from bad.
You're obviously supposed to root for Dudley to triumph, but his character remains nothing more than a clumsy, accident-prone doofus.
One of the most underrated motion pictures ever made.
movie_title: I Spit on Your Grave (Day of the Woman) (1978)

movie_review_blurb: Unfortunately falls into Altman's pile of disappointments.
Although you could certainly do much worse, there is only one really distinctive quality about the film, and that is Charlize Theron's charismatic performance.
Leaves us with such striking moments of stark, raw terror, that it puts many less serious horror films to shame.
Has what it takes to act as a blueprint on how to make the quintessential romantic comedy.
Saying it is a waste of time is an understatement of epic proportions.
If I had to rate it today, it would shoot up from two to three stars.
The whole cast of Scary Movie keep straight faces throughout, which is the right way to go. By making everything seem serious and real, it only proves more funny for the audience watching it.
Will delight adult viewers who are in the mood for a feel-good comedy that turns out to not only be about the punchline of jokes, but also takes its characters and their situations seriously.
If anything, the movie is funny, plain and simple, and due to the several noted performances that are far above this slight material, I found I was enjoying Big Daddy quite a lot.
A very bad movie, and amazingly so.
Hooper's sophomore effort, which had a bigger budget but is lesser-known, repeats the same basic formula.
A wonderful film from beginning to end, one that is honest, genuinely funny, and poignant.
Dull and oddly outdated, only the lush photography by Hurlbut, accentuating its gorgeous Toronto-based setting, saves the picture from being a surefire cure for insomniacs.
For every good performance and delightful, well-written scene, there would be a large amount of off-the-wall material that did not work at all.
A fun and completely amiable precursor to the upcoming onslaught of Summer movies.
Marks the superior feature film debut of Cholodenko, as well as Sheedy's strongest, and best, role to date.
A disaster of epic proportions!

A worthwhile venture that may not go down as a modern animated classic, but it does expose Disney as a studio more than willing to break free of tradition and try something a little different, for once. It's about time.
A thought-provoking and poignant ode to Jackie du Pre's life.
Has a tendency to be marginally entertaining one minute, and then brain-numbingly dull and misguided the next.
An astute, thought-provoking film, but the ending left me just as dissatisfied as Lisa is throughout the movie, in her journey to not follow by the rules of today's superficial society.
It boggles the mind why New Line actually had the nerve to waste millions of dollars on a piece of wretched trash like this.

To see "The Blair Witch Project" is not to simply watch it, but to experience it. In the annals of films that can intoxicate, terrify, and leave one's spirits distinctly rattled, only the best of the best can match it.
The story is simple -- almost painfully so -- but it still could have worked had the screenplay been more focused and innovative, and the characters dealt with more satisfyingly.
I liked most of what I saw, but it was also difficult not to acknowledge how much stronger it might have been with just one more screenplay rewrite.
It is simply a very funny comedyno more, no lessand sometimes, that is enough.
For all of its potential, [the film] never breaks away from being merely skin-deep.
A pulse-pounding paranoia thriller.
A brave and adult motion picture that is far more mature and honest about its subject matter than the usual film.
Although imperfect, Three Kings has enough vigor and intelligence to satisfy both audiences that prefer action, and those that enjoy more thought-provoking fare.
A well-made romance that may not always work, but is appreciatively overambitious in its ideas about relationships and the opposite sex.
Episodic, uneven screenplay.
Masterfully written and memorably performed.
A mostly spellbinding drama that may not be the spectacular achievement of Shyamalan's last film, but why does it  or should it  have to be?
An amazing triumph that proves what a master Terrence Malick is at his craft.
By the time the tiresome, surprisingly violent climax began, the last nail had already been hammered in this unfortunate film's coffin.
What could have been a courageous, unsettling character study of an emotionally disturbed young boy, only manages to be an ineffective, uninvolving bore.
A bloody, gripping, gruesome, big-budget, popcorn-munching horror movieand it works. Scientific logic, be damned!

[Benigni] somehow succeeds at such a genre-bending convention (or unconvention, if you think about it), finding just the right balance between humor and drama so that the film in no way is condescending to the subject matter.
movie_title: Life Is Beautiful (La Vita è bella) (1997)

movie_review_blurb: Are you, more or less, setting yourself up for disappointment if you go to see a film adaptation of one of the most powerfully written novels you can recall reading?
Turns into a sort of poetry, flowing gently from one scene to the next.
This a stunner of a thriller, both mature in its writing, also by Minghella, and provocative in its inclinations and plot twists.
A heartfelt and intelligent motion picture.
So much care has been contributed to the soundtrack that director Frears has forgotten about the importance of the film itself.
A winning and often hilarious comedy that delves into the lives of the rich, the famous and the struggling.
Resembles a direct-to-video movie at almost every ill-advised turn because of its overall air of moronic silliness.
Everything collapses under its own weight.
In its depiction of a marriage on the rocks, The Story of Us is successful in its ideas, but not necessarily in its treatment.
One of those rare breedsa live-action family film that relies on intelligence and adventure to tell its story.
A provocative morality tale, The Pledge is not only the first great motion picture of 2001, but also a film that exposes Sean Penn as being every bit as talented a director as he is an actor.
A respectable film, particularly in its unequivocal details involving the characters and genuinely unpredictable outcome.
A very bad movie.
A nightmarish puzzle. It's aged very well.
It is ultimately in the exact performances and writing that are the primary reasons October Sky works so well.
Staring at a blank screen would be at least fifty times more entertaining and visually stimulating than all of Wing Commander combined.
A grand entertainment. One of the best Hollywood productions to come out of the pipeline in years.
An exceptional, if not perfect, Australian drama that gets farther into the inner workings of a child's mind than any other film I've ever seen.
As a horror film, it is a horrifying study in terror, and as film in general, it is a brilliant study in style and mood, as well as the darkest regions of a person's psyche.
Another smart and pop-culturally hip film from Williamson.
When a film's story stops dead in its tracks simply to show somebody nude for no apparent reason, you basically can sense that you're in for the long haul.
Didn't seem to add up to much when it was all over.
A distressingly lifeless concoction.
A distressingly lifeless romantic comedy.
The film is little more than adequate, not a total washout, but nothing that hasn't been recycled a thousand times before, and done more ambitiously.
Unredeemably bad, and shockingly so.
An entertaining, if flawed, film all the way up until the disastrous final 5 minutes, which turn up the self-appreciation and cheeseball meters so high that it becomes sickening.
After seeing his second adventure, you have to wonder how many times the same jokes can be played out before they start to overstay their welcome.
movie_title: Austin Powers: The Spy Who Shagged Me (1999)

movie_review_blurb: The writing is congruously witty and smart, and the successful humor really is worth the price of admission.
A remarkable triumph -- alive with creativity and wonder, proving that the medium of film can take us anywhere, and act upon us in any way possible.
Innocent, light-hearted, and charming.
Nothing that occurred in it was earthshaking or shocking or particularly inventive, but it was well-done, all the same, and I really did like it.
'Magic' was the one thing this movie desperately needed.
A respectable enough love story that holds so much promise, yet doesn't seem to have had the screenplay kinks worked out before shooting commenced.
So precise, so hilarious, so biting, so smart, so perfect, in every one of its minute details that it comes as a sort of godsend.
A fast-paced, entertaining drama that, little-by-little, grows problematic when you stop to think long enough about its specifics.
The film is often overwrought, even if it is well-meaning...The ending is especially unconvincing, as it seems to switch to the end credits while still in midstream.
A devastating, haunting motion picture of inconceivable power.
A comedy without the laughs, and an action film with a non-existent level of excitement, Blue Streak is an obvious and misguided effort.
A wonderfully original and entertaining comedythe rarest of breeds.
Unmistakably feels like a rough cut of a possibly good movie.
Fails miserably at every turn.
This film is like no other I have ever seen for one major reason: it plays exactly, and I mean exactly like real life.
Like a loaf of stale bread. From afar, it may look fresh and mildly engaging, but get closer, and its appeal sours.
Take Dumb & Dumber, add a wrestling angle to the storyline, and strip the proceedings of all signs of wit, interest, and laughs.
An often remarkably exhilarating and surprisingly insightful dance drama, perhaps the most impressionable and well-made in its genre since 1987's Dirty Dancing.
Watching the picture, it felt more like a cerebral experience, than a normal film.
It may not be a great movie, but it's one of the most amusing times I've had at the multiplex this whole year.
Stuck on auto-pilot, and therefore, comes off as a tiresome excursion into terrain that has been covered too many times to count.
It proves to be a detached experience that isn't much fun at all.
It is a film experience like no other, a movie for which the word original was clearly invented for.
Stupefyingly horrendous.
[It] could have certainly benefited from a little more of that mischievous nature.
movie_title: Dr. Seuss' How the Grinch Stole Christmas (2000)

movie_review_blurb: An example of how not to make a courtroom drama, and it certainly did not do justice to the very serious subject matter the film deals with.
A mindnumbingly brainless comedy.
Low-rent horror garbage, and one of those rare theatrical outings that actually deserves to be relegated to the junk bin at video stores across the world.
Weak and sloppily-written.
A cinematic triumph, a motion picture so rich with honest emotions and ideas that it comes as a relative surprise that this is a big-budget, star vehicle.

A disturbing, evocative journey into the human mind, the film recalls your spookiest dreams, most forbidden fantasies, and darkest past memories, strung together in an unforgettably bold visual palette.
Capsule Review.
Isn't exactly a dull experience, but it is a monotonous one, because the capabilities it so obviously holds is put to zero good use.
As an 'in-the-moment' popcorn entertainment, it works wonders.
Twin Falls Idaho is flawed in many ways but its virtues also cannot be denied.
Manages to fail on almost every possible level.
Especially heartfelt and truthful.
The film's aspirations were higher in the planning stages than what was translated to film.
While watching Beloved, I could easily see one of the best films of the year within, but it ultimately let me down in its penultimate moments.
A quality-butchering remake.
A sleek, good-looking, and entertaining romance.
So good throughout that the film easily had the potential to be great.
Individual moments and ideas come off as far more powerful, and memorable, than the overall whole.
The performances, direction, screenplay, and impressive technical aspects work together as a solid unit to make the exciting journey to nowhere a great deal of fun.
Fast-paced and enjoyable enough, aided by the dynamite duo of Steve Martin and Goldie Hawn.
Clever, entertaining, and thought-provoking, a purely original thriller that is able to stand on its own two feet.
By no means an earth-shattering, important film, but it is quiet and entertaining.
No better than anyone should have expected, which is to say that it isn't any good at all.
A glossy Hollywoodization of a serious subject that is as far from the bright lights of Hollywood as could possibly be.
It should have read, 'Memo to screenwriters: Use you brain!'
At least the Wachowski's attempted to do something different than what had been seen before, even if the finished product isn't quite the success they obviously yearned for.
Renfro and McKellen are nothing short of spectacular, but with all things considered, Apt Pupil just isn't a very well thought-out picture.
A film that has a snappy pace, clever writing, and is condescending to neither kids nor adult viewers.

A consistently dull, meandering motion picture that is never anything more than difficult to sit through and cannot be salvaged by the relatively unextraordinary performances of Gooding Jr. and Hopkins.
An enjoyable dramedy that is fairly obvious in where it is headed right from the start, but in getting there, it surprises in how moving and wise it becomes.
A horror-fantasy that all involved should be wholeheartedly proud to be a part of.
Follows a rather predictable, well-worn path, but the sheer joy of performing on the actors' parts sells the film as a whole.
If anything, the action leaves a cursory adrenaline rush. When the movie is over, though, don't expect to think about it again -- because you won't.
An entertaining and smart film.
You've Got Mail, is a sleek, well-photographed romantic comedy that actually compliments the beauty of NYC more than the actual stars of the film...
Wants to be a horror movie, and Polanski apparently is attempting to recapture the acclaim he received from Rosemary's Baby but he has no such luck.
Has something to say, and it says it remarkably well.
Has many intriguing elements that might have equaled up to more in a tighter screenplay, but it ultimately doesn't satisfy once the end credits have begun to roll.
A preposterous, asinine horror movie (also, in more ways than one) that is about as subtle as a freight train crashing into your house.
Cursorily enjoyable, but almost instantly forgettable.
Not only a thoroughly enjoyable and satisfying piece of work, but one of the better, more thought-provoking movies [Altman] has made.
Rushmore, as in life, is a mixture of comedy and drama, of surprises and inevitability, and most importantly, is purely human.
A relatively classy horror picture, and director John Ottman has proven that he can successfully cross over from being, not only a gifted composer, but also a respectable filmmaker.
Whatever It Takes is light, fluffy, fast-paced, and through the sludge of overdone ideas are a couple original moments.
"Back to the Beach" is, by no means, a deep and thought-provoking motion picture, [but] when you're dealing with Frankie and Annette, what more could you ask for?
A nice, respective try, but Detroit Rock City just misses the mark.
A wildly inventive creation that is just about as adult as an animated film can get, and at times, I even started to forget that it was, in fact, animated.
A thoroughly disposable psycho-thriller aimed at the teen demographic, and one of the very worst theatrical films of its type in recent memory.
An always-entertaining and fairly thoughtful film on the subject of love, and how everyone hopes for it in one way or another.
It is a sad state of affairs when John Carpenter can make something as misguided and flatly written and filmed as Vampires.
Constant sequences of drug taking, one after the other, does not a good film make.

That rarest of thrillers that actually thrills, and offers up a fair share of chills, too. It may not be groundbreakingly original, but it sure is an entertaining ride for the duration of its running time.
Since January is usually the time of year that is known as the dumping ground from bad movies, At First Sight comes as a refreshing and sophisticated change of pace.
Archive Review -- I'd probably rate it much higher now.
An often funny, always engaging romantic comedy filmed in a documentary format.
A toss-up between wonderful moments and weak moments. This is one of the brightest vignettes of the film, thanks fully to Plimpton's stand-out, high-energy, hilarious performance.
A sumptuous, meticulously poetic motion picture that refreshingly tells much of its story through strikingly beautiful visual images, rather than a lot of dialogue.
Assembles an astonishing cast of gifted actors and then, alas, chose to do very little with them.
The most realistic and horrifying storm ever put to celluloid.
It may also even have the power to make you think twice the next time you run through the drive-thru at your local KFC.

Leave it up to director Oliver Parker's An Ideal Husband, based loosely on famed 19th-century writer Oscar Wilde's play, to prove that all a period film needs to jump vibrantly to life is a remarkable cast.
A pointless sequel to the 1998 hit, is superior to its hideously misguided predecessor, and yet it's still pretty bad.
A divergence for the eyes and little else, the movie has the ability to stay with you for about as long as its slim 84-minute running time, and then exits from your memory.
A well-meaning, yet derivative, film of this sort is basically made or broken by the writing and portrayals of the characters, and both aspects are unsatisfactorily handled.
Dogma is not supposed to be taken seriously, which is as it should be.
A huge comic winner, and one of the best times at the movies I've had all year.
An assured, well-made piece of work that shows just how smart a studio picture can be.
An ambitious film on many different levels, and I can appreciate that, but it rarely succeeds on any of them.
One of the most daring and attentive films of the year.
The film works a gentle spell around its viewer, and ends up leaving an unexpected lasting impression.
Has neither the laughs of Roxbury nor the heart of Superstar, exposing itself as merely a very shallow and forgettable comedy.
A mature, emotionally resounding film that could have easily been released in December and garnered several Oscar nominations.
The type of film that must have been made for 8-year-olds.
Moving at a brisk pace and highly entertaining for the genre, Nobody ultimately falls apart in its last five seconds.
An enjoyable enough way to spend an hour and a half, but doesn't end up having much to offer in the way of substance.
Capsule Review.
A sunny, good-natured romantic comedy that is as light as air, but almost always charming.
The premise is admittedly pretty crafty, but other than that two-minute distraction, Return to Horror High is certainly no great shake.
A carbon-copy of most other 'dog & boy' movies.
Could be a new classic of the teen genre.
Rarely funny, mildly entertaining in a morbid sort of way, and almost always terrible.
A glossily filmed, well-acted comedic drama that gets buried in one scene and the next of worn-out material.
Harrison Ford and Josh Hartnett are...a veritably delightful and likable duo that mesh surprisingly well with each other.
A summer movie that offers sporadic thrills and spills with nothing but dead air surrounding them.
Takes itself and the horrific situation it puts its characters in seriously...A tense and frightful good time.
Finding Nemo is superlative family entertainment, joyous and alive in a way few films are.
A rare mature film about free-thinking adults, and one that treats its characters with an open mind and a big heart.
If there has to be more heist pictures in Hollywood, The Italian Job...gets the formula right. Straight-forward, fast-paced, and very hip, the movie goes down with ease as an early summer diversion.
Based on its wasted potential, something tells me the cinema gods wouldn't be nearly as forgiving.
Luscious, inventive, and always dreamy.

The Matrix Reloaded is no better or worse than its predecessor, improving upon certain aspects (the characters and action scenes) while lacking some of the stronger elements of the first film (the overall imagination and ingenuity).
Nothing more than a cheap-looking, desperate attempt by New Line Cinema to ruthlessly suck the pockets dry of every fan of its infinitely superior predecessor.
movie_title: Dumb and Dumberer: When Harry Met Lloyd (2003)

movie_review_blurb: The In-Laws is unredeemable filmmaking, an unfunny, egotistical, idiotic dead-zone of a movie with nary a glimpse of energy or genuine heart.
By the very nature that it is more appealing than a lobotomy, Daddy Day Care is a superior [Eddie] Murphy venture.
Has a lot going for it, and is most certainly worth seeing for enthusiasts of Faircloth, horror movies, and high school-set stories.
As much as I like Hilary Duff and Lizzie McGuire, they both deserved better than this underwhelming big screen outing.
Stands as a worthy enough follow-up, but just a notch less successful...lacks the faultless pacing and focused storytelling of the original.
May be more at home on a television screen once it goes to DVD, but it is admittedly a lot of fun all the same.
Has a handful of understated moments of truth, but most of it is hokey, unoriginal, and amazingly smug.
A surprisingly challenging and rewarding motion picture experience, as ruminous and unforgettable as it is thrillingly spooky and suspenseful.
A tedious and twisting slog that, by the end, closes its fist on thin air. There is not a moment of true depth--character, narrative, or otherwise--in a single frame of this 98-minute waste of time.
Every step of the way, Malibu's Most Wanted reminds of a rough cut, rather than a completed motion picture.
A motion picture not easy to shake...grim in its look at what one person is capable of doing to another, but it is not heartless.
An unconventional, ballsy winner.

The scenes between Alex and Emma offer a handful of nice laughs and winning moments, but because the majority of them are set within a dank-looking Boston loft, they feel more suited for an off-Broadway stage.

The choreography is flat and lifeless; the pop songs are thoroughly disposable, mass-produced trash; and the lip-synching and sound mix have to be some of the worst ever for a big studio motion picture.
There is more to [Lisa] Kudrow-and "Marci X" proves it-than Phoebe Buffay...An unexpectedly sharp-nailed satire.
Chan may still have what it takes to perform difficult stunts, but...he is surrounded by a cesspool of ludicrous plotting, incomprehensible storytelling, and characters about as sturdy as wet cement.
Something a good deal more remarkable than it otherwise might have been without the music...Well-intentioned, full of amiable energy, and exceedingly entertaining with each passing minute.
Open Range is far from the worst film of the year, but it does test one's endurance like no other.
Brittany Murphy and Dakota Fanning make for a winning combination, and their characters' sometimes dark journeys do not always take the most obvious route to the inevitable happy ending.
The story is bad and the writing even worse, but one would at least expect a skateboarding movie to feature some noteworthy stunts. Not so.

A far-better-than-expected, late summer thrill ride...Better than any of the other ten Friday the 13th movies, and places in the upper half of the previous seven-parted Nightmare on Elm Street series.

Why Gigli is getting so widely lambasted from other critics, I do not know. [It] may not be a life-changing motion picture, but it is always likable. Most of all, and most importantly, it has a good heart.
It doesn't take a rocket scientist (or a pie fornicator) to tell that American Wedding is easily the weakest in a once-promising series.
A painless diversion, but also an undeniable rush job that makes enough misguided storytelling decisions to place it as the worst of the three Spy Kids flicks.
Ultimately, the highlight of Seabiscuit is its memorable performances, superior to the merely passable screenplay they must support.
While there are more moments with flair than in the original fiasco, Lara Croft: Tomb Raider -- The Cradle of Life remains a one-dimensional and suspiciously lifeless affair.
movie_title: Lara Croft Tomb Raider - The Cradle of Life (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Attempting to cram two books' worth of plot material into a 100-minute movie is not a very good idea, but How to Deal squeaks by with astute writing and effectively well-rounded performances from its ensemble.
Every last bone in its body is hateful, offensive, and sickening.
Freaky Friday is warm-hearted without being treacly, and a comic delight without delving into cloying theatrics. It also happens to be one of the summer's most refreshing cinematic delights.
While Atkinson is at his offbeat best, the film he has been placed within is sorely routine and more often blase than not, its every joke telegraphed far in advance of its ultimate appearance.

The film is decidedly more involving than [most of the other summer movie extravaganzas], holds more intriguingly original conceits, and--here's a refreshing change of pace--keeps its running time well below the two-hour mark.
Not only one of the most auspicious and original independent features in years--particularly for a first-time filmmaker--but it is one of the best films of 2003...Genuinely disturbing.
By the end, the film has gone from being a cheesy delight to an aimless, tired smorgasbord of empty action scenes.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: The Curse of the Black Pearl (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Unmemorable and mostly generic.
movie_title: Sinbad: Legend of the Seven Seas (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Charlie's Angels: Full Throttle is a great time at the movies, to be sure, but it stands in the shadow of [a predecessor] that was more original, more satisfying, and somehow more complete.
If Christopher Guest didn't exactly hit the ball out of the park with A Mighty Wind, however, he has still made a film good enough to make any of his supporters anxiously await his next effort.
Not exactly conventional kiddie fare, but it nonetheless captures their imaginations.
Strictly vacuous and insulting.
A dazzling, spooky visual masterpiece...One of the year's best.
Has a none-too-subtle racist agenda that is thoroughly unfunny and repellent.
A charmer when it wants to be, if only because the characters on display are ones we enjoy spending time with.
Indelibly works its way underneath the skin.
High-spirited and even endearing...Kangaroo Jack is far better than it has any right to be.
An astonishing piece of work and an actors' dream, about lives that feel real and characters that are anything but superficial in their wants.
Lacks the momentum or care needed to make it genuinely romantic, consistently humorous, or an insightful portrait of just-marrieds.

Endlessly enlightening, always fascinating, and nothing short of miraculous, to see Adaptation is to live, see, breathe, and feel in an entirely different way than any other motion picture released this year has offered.
That a film such as About Schmidt can be so dark and yet so funny, so poignant and yet so uplifting, is something of a miracle.
A terrifically engaging film with a plot that would be utterly ludicrous if not based on fact.
This is [Sandra] Bullock and [Hugh] Grant's show all the way, and they make the most out of a tried-and-true formula.
Gangs of New York is flawed and has several slow patches, and that is the bad news. The good news is that, on every other account, it is a remarkably ambitious and deeply powerful masterwork.
Takes off with one mesmerizing song after the next, interspersed between exposition sequences that are mere filler for the main attraction.

Maybe The Two Towers will stand as a more respectable and meaningful bridge between the crucial first and last entries. On its own, however, it is a crushing disappointment of ill-advised missteps and misplaced opportunities.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Two Towers (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Better than it has any right to be, yet remains an uneven affair not good enough to be worth running out and seeing.
Clear proof that the series has long since surpassed its days of glory.
Succeeds where many others have failed (Sweet Home Alabama being a recent example) by actually being romantic and side-stepping tedium.
An admittedly by-the-numbers affair, but garners some hearty and unexpected laughs through the machinations of its premise.
A nicely-drawn, humanistic character study and a genuinely romantic romance.
Empire has its visual and character attributes, but the culmination of its 90 minutes is akin to reaching out for something substantial, and coming away with nothing but thin air.
Analyze That is more of the same--a near-carbon copy of its predecessor--meaning that it has a handful of funny moments surrounded by a boatload of unfunny ones.

Delia, Greta, and Paula rank as three of the most multilayered and sympathetic female characters of the year. As each of them searches for their place in the world, Miller digs into their very minds to find an unblinking, flawed humanity.

As amateurish as first-time director Jonathan Liebesman is with handling his performers and their roles, he is a clear technical expert, heightening a distinguishable, foreboding atmosphere while delivering thrills and chills at a clip rate.
This 90-minute diversion won't be sweeping any award shows anytime soon, but it is utterly painless and actually quite sweet.
An entertaining trifle to a point...but it doesn't treat the character's or the audience's intelligence with the respect they deserve. By the end, you just don't care anymore.
movie_title: How to Lose a Guy in 10 Days (2003)

movie_review_blurb: If my mini-anxiety attack driving home following the film is any indication, Final Destination 2 if nothing else, may just give you nightmares for days afterward at the mere thought of getting onto the highway.
One of [Adam] Sandler's weaker, more slapdash efforts.
As fluffy and innocuous as the first two acts are, the overlong and schmaltzy last thirty minutes become an endurance test.
A revenge tale that tries to act smarter than it really is, and ends up embarrassing itself in the process.
More of a stunt than a fully-developed motion picture, but it is nonetheless pulled off with an engrossing flair.
[Chris Rock] knows what is funny and how to get a laugh, and there is enough energy in the proceedings to carry him through this lightweight entertainment.
Preposterously dumb and often more dull than not.
The film seemingly exists for only one solid reason: to cruelly play with, and jerk the chain of, every audience member foolish enough to be swindled into a theater showing this pompous joke.
The first hour [is] so freakishly intriguing and well-crafted that the derailed second half can't completely bring it down.
Suspenseful and competently made...[but] one cannot help but walk away sensing that more could have been done with the premise.
Crispin Glover is pitch-perfect...but as a horror film, the movie is extremely dated.
A wasteful, if painless, diversion.
The first truly great motion picture of 2003...seamlessly interweav[ing] its complicated characters and their even more complicated lives into a wholly original and vibrant tapestry.
One part unconvincing, jingoistic war picture and one part melodramatic, preachy hogwash.
In six words, Cradle 2 the Grave is hackneyed, preposterous, disposable, undemanding, diverting, and energetic.
There are enough genuine laughs to keep things fun and undemanding...Queen Latifah steals the film.
A riveting mystery-drama filled with absorbing writing and even better acting.
Effectively gritty when need be, but for most of its running time meanders as it tries to find its central story arc.
[Colin] Farrell may only have about fifteen minutes of screen time, but he is easily the star of the movie, creating one of the best screen villains in quite some time.
Neither funny nor likable nor charming nor particularly entertaining, Old School is a big-screen comedic bust that flunks out in every department.
Runs smoothly and likably until a maddeningly dumbed-down and cloying finale that sinks the entire film.
Its intense storyline and engaging characters gradually manage to enthrall you up until the clumsily orchestrated climax.

Is so muddled in melodramatic theatrics that it dulls down the action setpieces, while the action setpieces are so subdued on their own that the melodrama is just the final nail in the coffin of a movie with little to redeem it.
The film's highlight is definitely its screenplay, both for the rhapsodic dialogue that jumps off the page, and for the memorable character creations.

An uncompromising and beautifully told slice-of-life about the human condition of transitioning from a child to an adult...Evan Rachel Wood delivers one of the most courageous and emotionally raw performances in years.
A severely muddled, lethargically paced religion-based thriller without any thrills or even vague signs of entertainment value.
How do you write a review for a movie that unashamedly craps on the memory of its deservedly famed and beloved predecessor? The answer: with venom.
How anyone could call Gibson's filmic account anti-Semitic is mindboggling in its confused narrow-mindedness.
Akin to a feather--weightless.
movie_title: Confessions of a Teenage Drama Queen (2004)

movie_review_blurb: It's a fast, enjoyable 92 minutes, funnier than the trailers might suggest. Nothing more, and nothing less.
The best motion picture about teenage life since Donnie Darko...Has the power to become the defining teen picture for Generation Y.
It doesn't have that extra spark required to make it anything but instantly forgettable.
A soft, undernourished biography that plays things too safe.
Crammed with indelible images and scenes of sheer beauty and impact.
Nowhere near as good as The Wedding Singer...but what Adam Sandler and Drew Barrymore share on film is most certainly no flash in the pan.
The downright wackiest, most laughable thriller to come down the pike so far this millennium.
Amicably gets the job done while never wavering far from its often cliched path.
Falls into the trap of so many other family pictures by alternately pandering and condescending to its pint-sized target audience.
88 minutes of pretty pictures in search of a plot and a point.
In the fleeting third act, The Perfect Score hints at what could have been. Unfortunately, its improvements arrive too little, too late.
The first great motion picture of 2004, and certain to be one of the best of the whole year.
A purely formulaic romantic comedy not fresh or memorable enough to garner an identity of its own.
It's cotton-candy junk food that, for once, actually knows what it's doing...Entertaining all the way.
Sparks of interest are few and far between and the only thing worth looking at is the pretty European scenery.
There is no good reason to make a trip to see My Baby's Daddy, but at least it goes down painlessly enough and isn't a complete wash.
The film, and its cumulative emotional effect, is something of a brilliant, passionate, unflinching tour de force.
Successful only in sullying the memory of a superior movie that didn't warrant a sequel, particularly one so glaringly lacking in imagination and purpose.
A pretty creative conceit and often quite funny and creepy, to boot.
Bogs itself down with overplotting and a languid pace.
The majority of the humor falls flat, the pacing holds no true momentum, and passing entertainment value turns to frustration before the first hour is up.
Plays like a watchable sitcom, sporadically amusing but without enough material to warrant being feature-length.
By the time The Punisher reaches its depressing conclusion, one is more likely to feel unclean about the whole experience than to walk away with an adrenaline rush.
Congratulations, Quentin Tarantino and Miramax. With Kill Bill, you single-handedly turned a brilliant motion picture into two lesser one's.
One of the most embarrassingly unfunny comedies to crawl down the pike in some time.
Ella Enchanted is a pleasurable surprise, a superior family film that is destined to entertain both children and adults.
Truth be told, for most of its running time The Alamo plays like a vague, badly written history lesson aimed at grade schoolers.
Unapologetically cynical, miraculously imaginative, and sumptuously beautiful, Dogville is a thought-provoking time at the movies.
Appallingly unfunny...About as stimulating as an actual 300-mile drive across the desert wastelands of Arizona and New Mexico.
Meanspirited, empty, pointless, and absurdly condescending.
Dolls is as warm and sincere as it is dastardly and spooky.
A shattering glimpse of the way a community reacts when the erratic killing of an innocent suddenly hits close to home...Deserverdly stands as one of the best films of 2004.
With all pro's and con's tallied, Hellboy stands as a durable popcorn entertainment with definite potential to become a franchise.
There are a number of enormous, laugh-out-loud moments throughout, enough to mark it as one of the better comedies in recent memory.
[Kevin Smith] has mistaken maturity for old Hollywood cliches and conventions.
Corrects many of the problems that plagued its predecessor and returns to the general feel and campy creativity of the animated series.
[Jim] Carrey and [Kate] Winslet exude just the right chemistry--a destined connection--to make the love story between them ring with emotion and vitality.
movie_title: Eternal Sunshine Of The Spotless Mind (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Dawn of the Dead is creepy, smart, classy moviemaking. The film takes no prisoners in its sole goal to scare you silly.
Tediously conventional and ho-hum.
A taut, spine-tingling thriller, the most assured and classy adaptation of Stephen King's horror-themed work since 1990's Misery.
A junky, creatively bankrupt rush job of a sequel that has no connection to the original outside of the title character.
Spartan is a technical achievement, impressive for the things it does well and unfortunate that so much more might have been improved.
Kate Bosworth and Topher Grace ignite light, but palpable sparks as the romantic leads, and the movie that surrounds them is well-paced and never less than entertaining.
movie_title: Win a Date With Tad Hamilton! (2004)

movie_review_blurb: While the tautly paced Paycheck succeeds at keeping your attention, it offers nothing at all to think about or even remember once its two hours have run their course.
Big Fish has heart and it has originality, but its greatest attribute of all is its pure honesty.
For viewers courageous enough to withstand the bleakest of stories and the most cynical of outcomes, House of Sand and Fog is a challenging motion picture.
Plays like a sitcom that just so happens to feature characters infinitely more real and complex than the genre usually permits...[Katie Holmes] is a joy to watch.
A magical slice-of-life whose small-scale nature is part of its effervescent charm.
This updated version strikes a glaringly inferior note from beginning to end...However, judging it on its own merits exposes it to be a pretty good, stylishly crafted slasher flick.
Pales when placed next to all the similar movies it is shamelessly derivative of.
It's cheesy, lame, embarrassingly acted, sloppily written, and totally unscary.
Intolerable Cruelty is a shallow and instantly forgettable non-romantic comedy, a new cinematic low point for Joel and Ethan Coen.
A marvel of strikingly original action setpieces and tight plotting, surrounded by a visual lyricism difficult to translate into words.
A melodramatic murder-mystery that is as uneven as its outcome is anticlimactic.
Casa de los Babys has a grander scope than Sayles was either able to afford or invest enough time in developing.
The film never digs beyond its skin-deep roots.
A joyfully simple and exceedingly entertaining motion picture that is about as much unadulterated fun as you are likely to have at the movies all year.
A black hole of nothingness that is not only hackneyed, but also mindnumbingly boring.
Wickedly funny and full of energy.
A first-class travelogue of sights and scenes; its whole, ultimately, is less than the sum of its parts.
Underworld is one of the most visually stunning motion pictures of the year. Everything else...is ready for the scriptwriter's junkyard.
A well-meaning trifle, earnestly performed but way too bland and vanilla to elicit much in the way of rooting interest or lasting memorability.
Instead of replaying the same storylines and characters,...Allen should refocus his attention on originality.
Almost astonishing in its thinly plotted, shamelessly derivative amateurishness.
For the sheer promise it held for so long, and its jarring plunge into maddening mediocrity by the end credits roll, Matchstick Men may just rank as the most disappointing film of the year.
As faithful as any 21st-century effort has come to matching the look and feel of a 1970's "backwoods" splatter flick...I smell a cult following in the making.
While most of the physical comedy is lazy and predictable...what surrounds it is a surprisingly charming diversion with a rather clever premise.
If your idea of a good time is trying not to roll in the aisles with laughter and risk making a fool of yourself, then Scary Movie 3 surprisingly fits the bills.
Lyrical and deeply touching...as intimate, humane, and heartfelt as any love story this year.
A major cinematic achievement--simultaneously heartbreaking, frightening, unpredictable, sexy, grim, provocative and eerily plausible.
Filled to bursting with joy, creativity, and good cheer, Elf is one early Christmas gift that does not disappoint.
If it's family fare you're seeking, see this and skip the dreadful, condescending Cheaper by the Dozen. You can thank me later.
Cold Mountain is a technical triumph, to be sure, but it is just as lacking in pure soul.
Turns its every character into a cliche and its every plot development into an easy preconception.
To say that The Return of the King is this already-classic trilogy's paramount achievement is to understate things.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Rotten to the core and misogynistic in the extreme.
Something's Gotta Give is witty, smart, and charismatically electric-three vital elements rare to find in most of today's romantic comedies.
An engaging and affectionate motion picture that may have its fair share of problems, but treats its subject matter with surprising adeptness.
Snappy and charming enough to overcome its predictability and shopworn cliches.
[A]n imaginative, heartbreaking film -- one of 2003's best -- that you won't easily forget.
The Last Samurai is so built on common Hollywood movie cliches and superficial, jingoistic messages that it achieves no identity of its own.
The Missing may not be a standout western for modern day audiences, but it is undoubtedly a step in the right direction.
Syrupy, dumb, and desperately unfunny...Cheaper by the Dozen is the worst family film of the year, a sub-sitcom-level failure as abhorrent as it is half-baked.
The kind of rare perverse treat that John Waters would undoubtedly go crazy for...Billy Bob Thornton is genuinely perfect.
Trying to make sense of it and still stay involved through the duration of its 116 minutes is about as meaningless and unrewarding as...well, Timeline itself.
Becomes too cute for its own good, relying so heavily on symbolism to get its points across that it becomes more ridiculous than lyrical.
A thoroughly fascinating examination of a shameful footnote in journalistic history that many people probably wish to forget.
Gothika is a classy, dread-filled production populated with an above-average cast and plenty of namesake atmospherics...One of the stronger horror entries of the year.
A spirited fantasy that doesn't slow down long enough for the viewer to think about its flaws.
movie_title: Dr. Seuss' The Cat in the Hat (2003)

movie_review_blurb: The performances save the day in The Human Stain, bringing humanity to a worthwhile film that could have ultimately been much better.
The film's languid pacing quickly grows tedious, and the movie itself, unfortunately, becomes a bore.
movie_title: Master and Commander: The Far Side of the World (2003)

movie_review_blurb: A movie bursting with energy and sheer creativity.
A woeful, sloppy, misbegotten load of crap. In other words, it makes its two predecessors look like examples of modern cinematic masterpieces in comparison.
Woody Allen's weakest [film] since 1992's "Shadows and Fog."
movie_title: The Curse of the Jade Scorpion (2001)

movie_review_blurb: Max has 'first-time director' written all over it, and the arresting, contemplative subject matter demands a more experienced filmmaker to do it justice.
The kind of film one cannot simply walk away from and not think about. It is not only powerful, but the lasting impression it makes is nearly unshakable.
Uses a thick undercurrent of atmospheric dread and truly creepy sound effects to keep the tension high.
