The various plot elements could have been tighter and the various twists given more emphasis. Despite these flaws, though, it's a good indie horror anthology and we hope to see more.
To give this film a decent score would be an insult to the many low-budget features out there that scrape every penny they can find together to produce something good.
What could have been a darker version of Home Alone may have saved the entire thing, but the obvious lack of budget means it doesn't really go anywhere.
The Last Scout is, alas, a bit of a lost cause. Leave the woggle at home and rewatch Silent Running instead.
It's filled with interesting ideas, but we wouldn't recommend it other than to examine a case study in failure.
Ignore this and catch a couple of episodes of Star Trek The Next Generation on Netflix instead.
This is a perfect beer and pretzels movie (or pasta and meatballs, if you prefer).
This is an urgent, persuasive, if cloyingly conventional history lesson with a story that Hollywood's barely touched on before.
[It] heralds the director as a master of a deeply personal magic-realist genre, effortlessly moving as it is psychologically and artistically rich.
A frenetic, kinetic, but largely insipid speed through the lives of ostensibly random people in modern day Warsaw.
[An] absorbing, menacing debut.
It isn't quite an Israeli version of JFK, but Rabin, the Last Day rivals Oliver Stone's film in seeking to pose questions that official studies have refused to explore.
Bryan Cranston is irresistible as Dalton Trumbo in this sparkling period drama surrounding the Hollywood Ten.
A luscious, strangely enchanting watch and terrific fun for those who'll launch themselves into it.
Guatemala's first-ever Oscar entry is an absorbing, beautifully-shot drama of cultural ritual and the drive of one young woman to escape a rudimentary social system.
Burnett finds nuggets of comedy in the blindspots in your typical accounts of degenerative diseases.
Michael Shannon and Imogen Poots ... excel as lovers in this tightly-wound psychosexual love story that has elements of the best of Eyes Wide Shut.
It's appreciated how banker males here were numbskulls and showoffs, while women played the same game by being sophisticated and smart-talking.
Despite its tendency to fall into familiar characterizations, there's much to like in its playful storytelling, not least from a winning performance by Jesse Plemons.
Post-apocalyptic thrillers don't come much leaner or meaner than Northern Irish director Stephen Fingleton's gripping debut feature The Survivalist.
The moments in which Okazaki reflects on Mifune's choices through the actor's own experiences are the best parts of the film.
A partial return to form for director Atom Egoyan ... Nazi hunting for the Best Exotic Marigold Hotel generation, if you will.
A campy, nasty, tremendously fun horror experience in which death proves not the ending we might expect.
A messy, scattered drama that, for all its visual resplendence, is too narratively slippery to reach much in the way of profundity.
Zhao's combination of the visual palette of Malick, the social backbone of Reichardt, and the spontaneity of Cassavetes creates cinema verité in the American plains.
Garrel has the touch of a wiser man not taking judgment on his characters' youthful foibles, where setbacks are to be embraced and learned from rather than experiences discarded from memory.
movie_title: Lover For A Day (L'amant d'un jour) (2018)

movie_review_blurb: A sophisticated, idiosyncratic, thoroughly modern interpretation of a French romantic farce, perceptive if not laugh-out-loud funny.
movie_title: Let the Sun Shine In (Un beau soleil intérieur) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: There's much to interest the Lynch fan here, but it also might be an unparalleled assessment of the artistic learning of a great American filmmaker.
A bolder, brasher film, fiery in comparison with Gloria's relatively tenderness, but anchored once more by a stellar central performance.

Despite offerings of the open landscapes of North Africa, if there's a wild west in Mimosas, it's internal and spiritual, the quest being for meaning in a world that, like the film, doesn't give easy answers.
Anchored by three great performances, but it feels rather distinctly average - and it's hard to make Isabelle Huppert look average.
Reda Kateb is given his meatiest role to date as one of jazz's foremost artists.
The melancholy here is truthful and painful, but T2: Trainspotting rarely shows insight into what that failure brings about.
Kika Magalhaes lends a vampiric presence to the central role, ready to suck her victims into a life of servitude inhabited only by nightmares. Indeed, this chilling film may just occupy yours.
Much of the directness in the film's attitude to difficult issues is surely down to Sciamma, whose own projects Girlhood and Water Lilies didn't shy away from the conflicts of growing up.
movie_title: My Life as a Zucchini (Ma vie de courgette) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A bold and brilliant drama rightfully garnering Brokeback Mountain comparisons.
Richard Linklater's darkly funny mock doc is full of surprises, not least one star's terrific return to form.
It's a testosterone feast for fan boys, as it currently stands, and not without its laughs. But it could so easily go so much further.
There's something seriously wrong with life in our schools. And Hirsch clearly believes the world must be shown the harsh realities of it.
A mischievous sense of fun permeates throughout Carax's fifth feature, which proved welcome relief at this year's Cannes Film Festival.
Beautifully bonkers. Lavant lurches from one extreme to another, with the limousines themselves having their own say on proceedings. Cannes loved it.
The film's downfall lies in its inability to do anything more than titillate with a continuous series of chase sequences.
Wiseman loves a chase - the film is littered with them - but forgets the rest. The author Philip K Dick would not be impressed, although Farrell emerges unscathed.
Despite its one-gag premise, this quirky indie rom-com delivers in heart and aesthetic.
The rom-com twists don't always work, but it's easy to fall for stars who clearly love acting together - particularly Blunt, who could make a paper bag dazzle.
This little-green-men mash-up shows that in space, no one can hear you laugh.
Fast, fun and glowing with neon delight, this third effort in the franchise is enough to encourage kids to seek out their own animal sanctuary.
For a timely comment on today's political world - where everything is seemingly caught on camera - it's entertaining, light-hearted and nicely played by a great comedic cast.
An Aboriginal girl group's journey from the outback to stardom is an energetic, feel-good triumph.
While it may feel familiar to some, such awkward home truths do not a great viewing experience make. Jones is bereft of charm, while Streep seems misplaced as his loyal wife.
If you can survive the first hour's complexities - you'll need to focus hard on the narrative to keep up - a pay-off, of sorts, awaits.
This is French farce in its most straightforward form, rather than the radical, cutting satire some would wish for.
Although the film dodges earlier personal issues - notably, the breakdown of her relationship with US rapper Travis McCoy - it does show the star as human.
Hermanus's Cannes-feted feature serves as a bold statement on the stereotypical Afrikaans male, now struggling to remain relevant in a post-apartheid South Africa.
The finale may leave some unfulfilled, but this is an intuitive visual essay that begs to be experienced.
Donzelli's film is an incredibly brave one, given its subject matter and biographical nature, and is presented in a creative yet digestible way.
Whether there's an agenda underpinning the film or not, Gibson is clearly back in his element here, with plenty of wind still in his sails.
A lively, noir-flavoured thriller with classic narrative ingredients and an A-grade Aussie cast in tow.
Israeli filmmaker Dover Kosashvili approaches the Russian writer's novella with a mix of kid gloves and assured know-how, by way of screenwriter Mary Bing.
For all its grand designs and sweeping vistas, Prometheus could simply do with a bit more story.
An 18th-century epic that harks back to the great Amadeus with its sumptuous detail and vision, A Royal Affair is one of the finest, most refreshing period dramas to emerge in a long time.
Pattinson ditches the fangs but keeps the brooding, in a thoughtful essay on a man fighting for meaning within hollow surrounds. Riveting, poetic and thoroughly Cronenberg.
A thoroughly modern twist on the classic noir, framed for our modern times in contemporary Moscow, where the gap between the haves and the have nots is stark.
As with last year's joyful Rio, Ice Age still looks more like a classic cartoon than its competitors. And that, at least, is impressive.
Given recent developments in Egypt, the questions posed by this Arab Spring-themed musical comedy-drama from Lebanon could not feel more apt.
Lurching from picket-fence sweetness to road-trip screwball comedy, it's a hit-and-miss affair that's largely forgettable, save for its pairing of Shepherd and Bell.
This fresh take on the Marvel phenomenon - with its unabashed love match front and centre - opts to delve deeper into Parker's troubled past.
Performances are impressive - particularly Snook, who seems destined for greatness - with screenwriter Michael Lucas serving a suitably gentle helping of humour throughout.
We're left with the deflated feeling that we've witnessed something initially promising that proves wholly inconsequential.
Despite some curiously scathing comment on the Occupy movement, Nolan's third and last Batman is an exhilarating, epic finale, with a series-best performance from Bale.
An urgent, fly-on-the-wall affair that plays out like a grittier big-screen take on its more famous, US TV-related cousins.
It boasts solid performances from Gere and Sarandon, yet feels overly familiar, even predictable, at times.
In lesser hands, The Possession would simply feel like a blatant rip-off from horror days of yore. Yet Bornedal's well-crafted feature proves far better than expected.
Although typically loud, brash and flat-footed, the Oscar-winning filmmaker oddly opts for hokey romance over stinging critique.
Wearing its influences proudly on its sleeve, fans are likely to lap it up with glee.
movie_title: The Man With the Iron Fists (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Miller and Watson are in their element here, helping to shore up Chbosky's sophomore effort, which is likely to offer a pivotal moment in time for its leads.
movie_title: The Perks of Being a Wallflower (2012)

movie_review_blurb: With its superior cast all delivering like their lives depend on it, Daniels' camp, trashy tragicomedy seems destined for cult status. Kidman, especially, is a revelation.
Anna Kendrick's assured lead performance elevates this Glee-type musical affair from its modest confines.
Crowe has a blast - and has never been better - in this oversteamed paean to chop-socky classics. With its severe edit, though, the narrative proves almost incomprehensible.
movie_title: The Man With the Iron Fists (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Pitt's best work in years. His final, show-stopping speech is phenomenal.
It's pure Nickelodeon stuff: bubblegum high jinks that's short on laughs but also, mercifully, shy on offending, too.
For all its grand, overblown designs, there are some genuinely engaging surprises. Helena Bonham Carter and Sacha Baron Cohen are a riot.
A deceptively light-hearted romp that blends English and Danish with a touch of Italiano, for a lively, likeable view of the complexities of life and love.
As light and airy as a soufflé, but not without charm. Taglioni and Bruel are both convincing as the reluctant lovers who just might embrace the inevitable.
Director Juan Antonio Bayona's instincts are spot on for the first act with Watts, less successful when it switches to a more mawkish tone.
Connolly stands out as the up-to-no-good Scot with a wandering eye, while Smith is in her element as the would-be ma'am.
A work of inspired comic genius that shows Lowe and Oram as faces to watch. It also confirms, again, why Wheatley is one of the most fascinating talents working in film today.
Flawed it may be, but at its core lies an epic journey that shows Lee reborn as a creative force.
A gothic horror tale that studiously avoids any modern gimmicks in favour of classically themed motifs, with a neat twist to Hammer its point home.
Delpy is unlikely to set the world on fire with these farcical outings of the absurd, but it's a pleasure to see her back onscreen, doing what she loves.
A delight, a revelation of imaginative storytelling. Willis delivers his most assured performance in years.
Loach brings a warm-hearted poignancy to this feel-good tale of the more disadvantaged in society who, miraculously, find redemption.
Whitney Houston's vibrant, final performance adds poignancy to this likeable, breezy remake of a familiar tale.
For those familiar with the story of Rodriguez, this engaging documentary on his substantial success in South Africa will prove both illuminating and bemusing.
A dreadful misfire, particularly for Cooper, who is otherwise pursuing an interesting career trajectory away from The Hangover series.
John Hillcoat's tale of Prohibition bootleggers boasts excellent performances, but doesn't feel as focused or nuanced as The Proposition (his last collaboration with Cave).
Riseborough once again astounds with her ability to inhabit a character, with Owen also on cracking form as the agent under fire from all sides.
A largely forgettable letdown that could have, should have been a contender.
Oscar-nominated, lauded at festivals overseas and now, one of the most successful French pictures of all time, The Intouchables is simply irresistible.
What Dredd lacks in satirical insight - a bizarre oversight, given its dystopian view of America's east coast - it makes up for in sheer brute force and meat-head violence.
Nothing terribly new, but great fun, all the same. Morgan has assembled a hugely enjoyable, tightly edited journey through the Stones' creative heyday.
Bearing more than a passing resemblance to TV phenomenon Glee, this would-be college version largely succeeds thanks to a standout performance from Anna Kendrick.
Unpleasant, repellent viewing that, surprisingly, offers only repugnant characters and toxic protagonists, nothing more.
There's hardly a serious message being made about the plight of America's education system here, which makes one wonder what the point of it is.
Late-night TV fodder for insomniacs, perhaps, nothing more.
A terrifyingly real, surprisingly moving buddy-cop action-thriller that doesn't let up. Informed and open, Gyllenhaal and Peña are both magnificent.
It can't hope to match its predecessor for charm and accessibility. Where In Bruges felt droll and gentler in tone, Seven Psychopaths is unwieldy, ramshackle and gory.
Boasts a rare, inherent understanding of its subject, with Lewin now facing the prospect of becoming seriously hot property, as awards season beckons.
A subtle, good-natured ride with a gentle bite. Langella gives an exquisite performance as the wily ex-con.
A trifle of a romp, strictly for Pattinson obsessives who can't hold out until November (when Twilight takes its final bow).
Despite the hoopla surrounding its premiere at this year's Toronto International Film Festival, this fact-based baseball drama remains a rather dry, if serviceable, affair.
Despite some typical visual flair, and an affecting soundtrack to boot, Trishna lacks the emotional punch of Hardy's novel, with Pinto and Ahmed's pairing feeling contrived.
Inevitably, the 90-minute film has a lot to live up to. And, by and large, it succeeds in its mandate.
We may have seen this stuff before but it could have been so much worse.
Does this need to be in 3D? Of course not. And neither did it really need to be remade. But it has -- and it's fun. Fang-tastic fun, in fact.
Rossi gains unprecedented access. Crucially, we witness the workings of a newsroom: the skill required to generate stories, the jockeying between staffers, and so on.
movie_title: Page One: Inside the New York Times (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The source material is Anne Marie du Preez Bezdrob's biography, and the period detail is spot on. Yet Winnie: the movie opts to wear its heart openly on its sleeve, and play it absurdly safe.
A father-son family yarn that shares the same sweet sentiment as the recent Crazy, Stupid, Love: that the best things in life are far from free - or easy - to obtain.
For those who believe self-styled indie filmmaker Kevin Smith to be a one-trick pony - and there are many - this curious horror-thriller will come as something of a shock.
A fascinating look inside a sport that remains open to anyone, should they dare to try their hand at it
Drive, above all else, reminds us why Gosling has been hailed as the new Sean Penn, or even a 21st-century Brando. He is outstanding.
A wonderfully understated delight.
Depending on whether you love or loathe such stuff, you're likely to either applaud with Lloyd Webber-esque glee, or plan to flee at the nearest opportunity.
A highly imaginative, deeply moving and incredibly brave film, boosted by a lead performance so intense, you'd swear the man's from another planet.
With a tighter grip on proceedings, one imagines Restless would have Van Sant troubling the Academy all over again. As it stands, it's a sweet, gentle film.
Hastily assembled, uneven and severely lacking in charm and laughs, Jack and Jill is one of Sandler's weakest outings to date. Which is saying something.
It manages to spectacularly abandon all its small-screen smarts and charm.
A respectable (if unnecessary) reboot that's brutal, well acted and not overly serious.
Melancholia clearly showcases Kirsten Dunst as a bona fide force of nature: something that's been hitherto overlooked or ignored. For that alone, it gets my vote.
The film is foul-mouthed and not without its flourishes of violence but it's irresistibly likeable (and unpredictable).
This is documentary filmmaking quite unlike any other: a tale of triumph over adversity, of victory and tragedy, visually presented as riveting, explosive drama. Senna is essential viewing.
Tyson is presented via multiple split screen, with relentlessly frank and rhythmic sentences overlapping one another. The effect is mesmerising.
Dives straight into whiz-bang gizmoland, opting for "pause, rewind" flourishes. Cute and enjoyable family fare, then, if a little forced.
movie_title: Shorts: The Adventures of the Wishing Rock (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Playful, light-hearted and fun, with an impressive cast of Aussie stars and some fine stop-motion animation. As it stands, at 74 minutes, it's not quite as smart (or rewarding) as one would hope.
The real gold lies in the separate, personal journeys of Messrs Edge, Page and White, explored in their own vastly different locales.
An authentic, overdue biopic that explains Lennon's torment and fire.
Cassel is at the very top of his game -- and Richet has raised the bar a dozen notches for those brave enough to now attempt a crime film of any kind.
Self-conscious, uneven and confusing at times -- but Sidibe's fine performance has to be seen, regardless. She is, quite simply, astonishing.
movie_title: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Some great moments of comic timing provide for a pleasant, if flawed, bittersweet comedy of errors.
Outstanding. Never before has a tale of crime and punishment been so exquisitely handled by one of our own. This is a towering achievement.
A bloated mess that's not remotely funny -- or suspenseful.
The Trip works surprisingly well on the big screen as one continuous tale. That's down to its two leading men, who clearly relish sharing screen time with one another.

Bridesmaids turns the gross-out comedy genre on its head and emerges bigger and better than its predecessors. It boasts unforgettable breakout performances and is the most important comedy of the year. And the best.
For a grand finale to a truly epic, good-natured franchise, this is a perfect goodbye that's very hard to beat.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: No clever messages here, just bang-on romance and action, with another fresh twist on 20th-century history woven in for the kids to dive into after the credits have rolled.
This is a wholly wasted opportunity for Gibson -- and a disappointing misfire from Foster.

There is nothing that fascinating about Favreau's treatment, nor his source material, but compared with similar blockbuster fare of recent months, this curious exercise in genre bending is very watchable.
If Burton had ever worried that his celebrated brand of eccentricity might one day feel dated or even irrelevant, that unthinkable day may indeed have come.
A wonderfully adroit comedy for grown-ups, and those with a zest for the good things in life.
movie_title: Gianni e le donne (The Salt of Life) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: In this rehash of the 1981 smash - which featured fellow English comic Dudley Moore in the title role - Brand looks and sounds comparatively bland.
It's the party you've only dreamed about, the tagline says. And if you were 17 years old again, you might be inclined to agree.
Smart, sharp and dark, J C Chandor's ensemble drama - eliciting defined, defiant performances from an A-grade cast - summons the spirit of David Mamet's Glengarry Glen Ross.
While hardly raising the bar in action-comedy, it's still a fun, irreverent, laugh-out-loud take on the beloved, small-screen original.
The Best Exotic will come as a welcome surprise. A sunny but shrewd musing, it offers an oft-ignored section of the cinema-going audience a delightful hit all their own.
As a dark, grimy journey deep into the belly of the underworld, The Raid is breathtaking and terrifying.
Given its inevitable merchandise tie-ins, this animated eco-preachy affair carries with it more than a whiff of questionable intent.
Restraint is not something we've come to expect from David Cronenberg. Yet here, the Canadian sticks with his more measured tone of late.
A modern-day take on the classic Hollywood romance, delivered with the kind of panache long thought lost to the sands of time, that proves essentially timeless.
The film seems to be aiming for a whimsical flourish on an otherwise unpleasant subject. Its premiere at Cannes met with a mixed response. I remain underwhelmed.
For those who prefer their otherwise bitter politics lightly coated with sugar, this should suffice. A bolder remit wouldn't have hurt, though, given the source material.
Sparks's books are more Mills & Boon than The Deer Hunter, with his characters little more than mere sketches. Only the women even vaguely register dramatically here.
Vanessa Paradis is superb, playing the tough, single mother struggling in a prejudiced and very un-swinging '60s Paris as if her life depended on it.
A hugely entertaining coming-of-age tale, grounded in realism. Sivan's note-perfect portrayal of the diminutive hero is matched by a razor-sharp Cleese.
Joss Whedon marshals matters effectively throughout, without losing sight of that other key demographic: those who dispensed with their comic books long ago.
The production values are extraordinary. Yet for all its chutzpah, matters begin to go awry once the Nazi army descends on Earth, where they lose their sense of comedic power.
There's little to recommend this B-grade, formulaic affair. The plot is tosh, the dialogue hackneyed at best.
You'd be the world's biggest grinch not to get a kick out of this feather fest.
Polanski hasn't had this much fun in years and neither, by the looks of things, has his cast. A wickedly dark delight.
With yet another ho-hum run at the multiplexes, Katherine Heigl's big-screen resumé is fast looking like an insider's gag.
Were it supremely confident of knowing when to show its trump card, the film could have gone even further.
As with the wicked witch, there's something inherently untrustworthy, even slapdash, about this whole affair.
Jim Loach's feature debut presents the horrific injustice of forced child migration in a calm, measured manner.
A bold, epic exercise that Malick comes close to pulling off. It may not stack up against his best, but it doesn't fail to incite feelings of awe in its audience, either.
After all the expectation, this Tintin feels strangely flat and lifeless. A War Horse it is not.
Infinitely more watchable than its predecessor, with Downey, Law and, now, Fry all on top form. Yet McAdams is sorely missed.
movie_title: Sherlock Holmes: A Game of Shadows (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The master of modern America cinema is indeed back, with a suitably understated bang.
As a gloriously dark ode to the decade that gave us grunge and scrunchies, it's a wickedly guilty pleasure. For Theron, it's her most daring performance yet.
The title of this teen disaster-by-numbers affair could not be more apt - as a collective omen for all those involved
Its appeal lies in its innate ability of tapping into that sense of joy that lies within us all. It is irresistibly charming. It is unmissable.
McQueen's film is breathtaking in its execution. Fassbender delivers his finest performance yet. Why he hasn't received the expected Oscar rubs remains a mystery.
The man whose biggest claim to fame remains the fun but frothy Charlie's Angels pushes all the requisite buttons, while never straying too far from the party line.
The Vow never veers far from its heart-on-sleeve leanings, particularly with Tatum's overbearing voice-over, but McAdams is typically reliable.
Madonna, for all her faults, cast this self-funded feature with uncharacteristic cinematic poise. Otherwise, though, it's a disappointment
Fond nods to Wahlberg's cinematic past ("It's like the size of a Mini Cooper") are thrown in, and it's imaginatively shot, yet it all feels rather too familiar.
McG's film ticks the expected action boxes easily enough but, as per usual, is not designed to be taken remotely seriously.
Disappointingly flat. Hitchcock the man feels best left where he himself enjoyed being most: behind the camera.
A super-slick thriller that doesn't let up, with exceptional performances all round. Make sure you catch it before the inevitable US remake rears its head.
Allen's mixed experiences with London stand in sharp contrast with his love affair with the French capital (the setting for last year's return to form, Midnight in Paris).
movie_title: You Will Meet a Tall Dark Stranger (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Painfully funny and rather moving, as well. Seems destined for cult status.
An ill-fitting, occasionally awkward yarn that crackles at times (thanks to its charming leads), but struggles to fire.
This critic's eyebrows were raised more for the inclusion of Rolf Harris' Tie Me Kangaroo Down Sport than for any would-be chills, which bizarrely fail to materialise.
Christian Bale still makes this rather run-of-the-mill proposition appealing, regardless of how oddly unfashionable he may currently be.
This second feature is very watchable, but it lacks a sense of purpose (so prevalent in its predecessor), and any emotional punch or, indeed, pay-off.
Only when the protagonists' lives are at stake - and bombs drop - does the piece truly come alive, with a sense of much-needed urgency.
For all the film's shortcomings, White's story does ultimately shine through.
The ability to survive no matter the odds has rarely felt more immediate and watchable.
Finding Fela! doesn't shy away from the uglier side of Kuti's life, but it does lack the analysis one is craving, and expecting.
Armed with a legitimacy as startling as its content, it is a superbly executed document of a pivotal, inevitable era in 20th-century history.
A worthy, thought-provoking follow-up to Another Earth, in which fact and faith square off with increasing complexity and consequences.
A lively document of a revolutionary band on tour in Canada - and a stark reminder of what a music documentary should do.
movie_title: The White Stripes Under Great White Northern Lights (2010)

movie_review_blurb: A convincing, evocative drama that captures a key moment in history with aplomb.
An enjoyable (if rather one-note) ride through one of Hollywood's more bizarre eras.
movie_title: Electric Boogaloo: The Wild, Untold Story of Cannon Films (2012)

movie_review_blurb: High-school students have plenty of growing pains to offload, and Gomez-Rejon clearly knows what makes them tick. His film is at once buzzy, fun and confronting.
movie_title: Me and Earl and the Dying Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A loving ode to the American wheat belt, told with lashings of candour and wit.
It is a striking and powerful film, and certainly one of Broomfield's best for quite some time.
Former heart-throb turned indie king, Matthew McConaughey goes for broke with what could well be his most affecting on-screen turn yet.
In the wake of Mandela's recent passing, this well-intentioned adaptation of the great man's best-selling autobiography inevitably takes on a greater poignancy and stature.
Unpredictable yet utterly dependable, thrilling yet stoic, Katniss Everdeen is a force of nature on screen, and a role that Jennifer Lawrence appears born to play.
One might wistfully wish for something more earthy in tone (that is, more Brassed Off than The Full Monty). It's great fun, though.
Ender's Game certainly looks and feels serviceable, but lacks the sting to emerge as a serious contender in a crowded market.
Alves has served up a loveably authentic romp, that manages to speak to a broad audience, while also echoing the experiences of millions of emigrés around the world.
A modern twist on a classic Disney formula with lashings of dry wit and old-school romance.
A deliriously barmy, laugh-out-loud sequel that manages to top the much-loved original, with fond nods to Australia in tow.
The Rocket is a thoroughly infectious yarn set among the jungles of Laos.
Remarkably, given the very serious subject matter, the film exhibits an infectious comedic flair that never goes too far.
A huge improvement on its predecessor. Jackson and his collaborators have opted to broaden and modernise the franchise's appeal.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013)

movie_review_blurb: As far as family entertainment goes, there's very little to fault with this rather delightful and moving picture.
Given this costly ($US175 million) and largely pointless dirge, shrewd filmgoers may feel compelled to instead explore the original, in all its noble glory.
A flawless piece of classic Coen brothers cinema, exquisitely timed and told by all. Quite possibly their finest work yet.
An outrageously black comedy about white-collar crime, unapologetic in delivery and unashamedly graphic in its intensity.
This latest instalment in the found-footage, domestic-horror franchise opts for far greater supernatural silliness than its predecessors.
Although it seeks to send up their greatest on-screen achievements, this half-baked farce merely reinforces the idea that De Niro and Stallone have seen better days.
Jon Turteltaub's ''old men behaving badly'' romp does more than merely pander to expectation. Beyond the noise of the strip lies a buddy comedy with heart.
A hit on the festival circuit, affectionately told, Twenty Feet from Stardom is a treat.
This intelligent examination of our fascination with science is impeccably realised, despite a modest budget.
A laughably absurd fantasy that goes nowhere fast.
Struggles to convey its passions, despite considerable effort from its two leads, an intuitive soundtrack and handsome photography.
Jason Segel and Rooney Mara are an unlikely central pairing in this low-key sci-fi about the discovery of an afterlife that's both fascinating and frustrating.
There's shades of Straw Dogs and Deliverance in this effective Aussie backwoods horror, an intelligently restrained work that manages to remain authentic and tense throughout.
Lowery's film may take an eternity getting there, but by the end it transforms into a powerful, sobering work of contemplation and grief.
Despite its premise - and promise of unparalleled access - the film feels constrained by what it can or can't show (presumably, so as not to incriminate certain officers).
While it falls short on detail in some areas, the essence of Lynch the artist -- or at least, what he's willing to share with his audience -- is fascinating to observe, leaving you wanting more.
John Lydon's post-Sex Pistols career is examined in this intimate doc that proves as frustrating as it is fascinating.
Alexander Payne's gentle satire has a point to make about the state of the union - and the future of planet Earth.
William Friedkin revisits his Exorcist franchise with a curious companion piece for fans, which throws up more questions than it answers.
Andrew Haigh's beautifully crafted film follows one boy's journey of self-discovery.
The racial elements, added by Clooney and co-writer Grant Heslov, flesh out what would otherwise feel like familiar Coen territory.
Avoid watching around mealtimes, and keep your loved ones close. This brawl is one hell of a blast.
McDormand kicks against convention and expectation, with an out-of-the-box performance that delivers what one would hope for, and so much more.
A heartbreaking and powerful film.
A shrewdly timed reminder of Pixar's early, heady days, when the animation powerhouse could do no wrong.
A fresh, thoughtful look at the world's favourite quartet.
movie_title: The Beatles: Eight Days a Week - The Touring Years (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Multi-layered complexities and stand-out performances make this a rich experience, with Kristen Stewart surprising the most.
Andrew Dominik's documentary about Nick Cave's new album offers a gentle, haunting portrait of a family consumed with grief.
This darkly comic factual drama hits all the right notes, thanks to inspired turns from Christian Slater and James Franco.
The pains of ageing, and the chasms that divide generations, are mined with witty precision in this latest comic outing from Noah Baumbach.
More akin to leaving your cares (and possibly keys) at the door, and diving in for some quick thrills. Undemanding, reasonably entertaining fun.
Unlike the recent Ex-Machina, which tackled the reality of robots entering our lives with style and poise, this glossy affair fails to convince beyond its overheated melodrama.
A fascinating, exhilarating, immensely satisfying experience.
While it isn't anywhere near the game-changer it might have been, it's entertaining enough, with some memorable sequences (and ideas) that are worth exploring on VOD.
Philip Ridley's acclaimed tale of childhood, vampires and the prairie is as beautiful and menacing as ever.
A bold and brassy classic that challenges social and political norms in a magnificent manner.
The film seeks to offer an abstract essay on the isolated youth of the US - which it does, in a breathtakingly fearless and measured manner.
The African-American icon's richly textured and often traumatic story is unpacked in this near-definitive documentary for PBS.
movie_title: Maya Angelou: And Still I Rise (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Watching a Solondz film has never been a particularly easy experience, yet Weiner Dog offers a droll playfulness not seen since Welcome to the Dollhouse.
Spike Lee's follow-up to Bad 25 shines a light on the King of Pop's indisputable talents, but is otherwise alarmingly lightweight.
movie_title: Michael Jackson's Journey From Motown to Off the Wall (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Parker's resolve with the project (made without studio backing) should act as a clarion call to independent filmmakers everywhere.
Pam Grier's third outing as a tough 1970s Blaxploitation action lady is fun, although not as exhilarating as Coffy and Foxy Brown.
Despite a sense of déjà vu and an unconvincing ending, David Farr's London-set pregnancy chiller conjures up a claustrophobic atmosphere.
Katie Holmes puts in a memorable shift as a struggling single mom in her impressive directorial debut.
This Australian chiller about a rash of grisly murders makes a play to be the new Snowtown.
Viewed again, far from the madding crowd and general hoo-ha of Sundance, it stands up much better than expected.
Confidently fulfils its ambitious intent with ease.
Riveting, emotionally charged drama, with powerhouse performances to match. Jordan is a revelation.
Bizarrely, its biggest flaw lies with casting. Carrell is too familiar to convince as a Lothario, Buscemi looks vaguely lost, while Carrey is too long in the tooth.
The issue of FDR's fidelity remains a thorny topic for traditionalists and historians, never mind the light, fluffy - and ultimately disposable - version of events.
Scoring a popular hit on the film festival circuit, director Julia Loktev elicits superb performances from a minimal cast.
A heartbreaking, brilliantly executed exposé, in which four deaf victims bring the church to account. Their testimonies are chilling.
movie_title: Mea Maxima Culpa: Silence In The House Of God (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A hugely entertaining but dreadfully convoluted crime romp, in which logic flies out the door as wandering illusions of the mind take hold.
A respectable swansong for the late Claude Miller, who passed away just weeks before it premiered at Cannes.
An occasionally funny romantic zombie comedy (or rom-zom-com) that offers a fresh twist on Shakespeare's Romeo and Juliet.
Joseph Kosinski's ode to classic 1970s sci-fi lacks serious tension, but does offer visual flair and elegance, with a typically arresting performance from Andrea Riseborough.
A whimsical view of the woman who fuelled the corridors of power in France with culinary common sense.
Terence Stamp is terrific as the grumpy Arthur, while Vanessa Redgrave embodies the ailing figure of Marion with a gravitas one would expect.
An outrageously entertaining, CGI-soaked tale of foreboding that transforms into a good-natured send-up of everything that proceeded it, replete with gags galore.
Parents will look on with dismay; others will leave feeling bemused but thoroughly entertained.
Gosling delivers his most assured performance yet, in an ambitious, near-operatic drama-thriller that boldly unfolds across two distinctly different hours.
A tense psychological chiller that ratchets up the tension before collapsing with a predictable finale.
As odd as the title suggests, this is a strange and dreadfully overwrought family yarn.
movie_title: The Odd Life of Timothy Green (2012)

movie_review_blurb: A fresh rendering of the Dickens classic, designed to mark the 200th anniversary of the writer's birth, plays it far too safe to ever challenge Lean's definitive take.
Surprisingly, it is singer Ronan Keating who provides the sole saving grace, in a film that otherwise chokes and splutters with cliches and tired routines.
Aside from feeling bemused and confused by the end, the web of deceit that's presented is not even vaguely believable.
A think piece linking past, present and future that's surprisingly haunting and moving in its delivery.
Bill Murray proves a sound choice as the president who quietly battled polio. So too does Samuel West, as the stammering King George VI.
A well-acted but uneven take on recent events that feels strangely superfluous.
Faithfully and tastefully performed, without ever threatening the legacy of David Lean's definitive 1946 version.
Proudly doffing its cap to Sergios Corbucci and Leone, this latest, sprawling exercise in film lore dares to tread where most other white American filmmakers would not.
Interior. Leather Bar ultimately rings hollow in its diatribe and agenda because its chief instigator refuses to open up.
David O. Russell's latest buzz film straddles a fine line between farce and kitchen-sink drama before settling into a groove that gets under one's skin.
Denzel Washington single-handedly steers director Robert Zemeckis's lesson in substance-led evasion with stunning precision and depth.
A sweet tale of love, loss and life with solid performances from a first-rate cast.
This is far from the bomb some would have envisaged, but neither is it the character illumination one would wish for.
This is easily Spielberg's best picture since Schindler's List. Having a two-term black president now in the White House can't hurt its chances, either.
Wright's staged version tries desperately to gain one's attention (which it does) and engage one's affection (which it doesn't).
Fans of the original 1970s TV show will not be amused. Casual observers may simply shrug with indifference.
Haneke's startling film stands in stark contrast with other recent, comedic fare that seemingly addresses similar issues.
LaGravenese elicits some wonderfully hammy turns, particularly from Irons and Thompson, although a tighter edit wouldn't have gone amiss
Hits a six at every turn. The humour may be gentle, but it's always sharp. Tellingly, not a single gag falls flat. A wonderfully unexpected delight.
Nicole Kidman is enthralling in this swampy, deranged neo-noir set in the American south.
Stu Zicherman's amusing but formulaic man-in-crisis comedy has neither a fully realised protagonist nor a clear message.
Luhrmann understandably wants his Gatsby to be great, but he has inadvertently reminded us that the Great American Novel belongs precisely where it was born: on the page.
Young adulthood is rarely portrayed with such conviction, in a manner that connects with both its core teen audience and a wider adult demographic.
A painfully unfunny, overly familiar send-up of recent horror franchises.
Her elder co-stars may lead this psychological mind dance with ease, but it is Mia Wasikowska who astounds the most.
This boardroom blackmail romp feels as contrived and silly as anything Luketic has helmed in recent years.
A surrealist pastiche that's too clever (or enthusiastic) for its own good.
Foxx and Tatum offer an effective buddy pairing lacking from the similarly preposterous Olympus Has Fallen.
The setting acts as a bland backdrop without substance or thought. Worst of all, the dialogue feels horribly contrived, even lazy. A misguided misfire.
Neither as dreadful as some would claim nor as poignant as it would like to be, Diana skirts the surface of a complex figure while trying to keep all parties at bay.
A tighter adaptation of Winton's book, helmed by one, possibly two filmmakers, would have sufficed. As a collective, it feels weighed down by its own remit.
As good as it is, Lovelace oddly avoids further illuminating Boreman, beyond what we already know.
A thrilling, adrenalin-fuelled ride that recreates 1970s track-side action with aplomb.
Not since Erskineville Kings, in 1999, has Hugh Jackman appeared so emotionally exposed on screen. It is an exceptional, Oscar-worthy performance.
An absolute delight: a thrillingly unpredictable romp that entertains with joyful and mischievous abandon.
It's all done with far more heart than one would expect. Perhaps Coogan, like Partridge, is now mellowing with age. Whatever next: grandkids?
Evidently, the film's raison d'etre proves to be its spectacular undoing. McCarthy's script is awful: bogged down with leaden dialogue that prolongs scenes for no reason.
Hawke brings a gravitas to the role of parent and home protector that is of far greater interest than the film itself.
A self-conscious, would-be historical drama that's too distracted by star cameos and domestic strife to be truly effective.
Sharni Vinson kicks some serious butt, in this very watchable horror romp from Adam Wingard.
A hugely enjoyable, thoroughly infectious feature debut.
Kormakur and his merry cast blast their way through an absurdly silly and very funny comedy of errors, as one defence service inadvertently wages war on another.
The film, which premiered at Robert De Niro's Tribeca Film Festival in New York, proves remarkably enlightening.
Damon is, as ever, thoroughly watchable but given its predecessor's smarts, Elysium fails to capture District 9's spirit or sense of originality and wonder.
McKenzie does well to emphasise the cultural impact of modern Australia on the lives of its original settlers, while wisely avoiding political grandstanding.
Far from the swinging '60s or sleazy '70s so often portrayed with glee on screen, the London of Paul Raymond's world feels grim, dark and, ultimately, devoid of passion.
Terrence Malick's vague, sweeping ode to love lost and found is anything but wondrous.
Garrone has confounded expectations with this light, Fellini-esque send-up of reality television and the celebrity it has spawned.
A self-contained, astutely executed project, with Whedon's old guard giving their all for the sheer joy of performance. Great fun.
Outrageous and shocking to its core, the film, perhaps aptly, feels like some wayward younger sibling to its more accessible and commercial predecessor.
Alex Gibney's film is an absorbing examination of the world's most infamous information portal.
movie_title: We Steal Secrets: The Story Of Wikileaks (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Aside from Carell's limited turn at doing nasty, it all feels terribly familiar, in a half-baked, Little Miss Sunshine-lite sort of way.
Wilson elicits a stronger turn from Vaughn than we've seen for some time. The results are surprisingly engaging and endearing.
Mungiu has crafted an alarming and engaging real-life horror story, based on a 2005 case of exorcism.
Its raison d'etre is a terrifically spirited performance from Hollywood's most heterosexual of Lotharios, Michael Douglas, aided and abetted by Damon and Lowe.
The Bling Ring suggests Coppola still has the nose for a good story, but not the depth to sufficiently explore it.
A fascinating yarn that could have provided for stunning story fodder. Thanks to spirited turns from his three leads, Michael Bay just about gets away with it. But only just.
The Pixar themes may be present and correct, but its values are sorely lacking.
A wickedly funny romp that heralds the arrival of some seriously fiendish talent.
After she walks off, Daddy tells his son, "Whack your own spider!"
Big Fish is love and death, Burton style.
Blood in. Blood out. Eye roll.
Peter Webber's gorgeous Girl With a Pearl Earring is a work of lightweight conjecture.
More or less plays out as a home-on-the-range knock-off of Nicolas Ray's brilliant Rebel Without a Cause.
Shattered Glass speaks simultaneously to our humanity and sense of moral outrage.
Showgirls without the flying French Fries; Hardball on the dance floor; Flashdance with less grease and elbow.
More goose-pimply epic swirl and top-notch Uruk-hai smackdowns, but there's also more of the dreamy Christian allegory that highlighted the first film.
movie_title: The Lord of the Rings: The Return of the King (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Is Nicole Kidman contractually obligated to interact with birds in all her films?
Everyone in Dead Girls Society, err, Mona Lisa Smile wears their one character trait like a placard.
Jacques Rivette's spry and intoxicating 1974 comedy Celine and Julie Go Boating observes the way women look at each other, themselves, and the world around them.
movie_title: Céline et Julie Vont en Bateau (Celine and Julie Go Boating) (1974)

movie_review_blurb: The Director's Cut of the film hauntingly amplifies Ripley's disconnect from her dead daughter and her relationship to the young Newt.
The war between America and the Middle East is in full metaphoric force in Vadim Perelman's ridiculous eviction melodrama House of Sand and Fog.
The film should easily appeal to anyone who's never met an Asian person in their life.
The much-maligned last part in the Alien quadrilogy should be approached as the comic book actioneer that it is.
The oppressive power of Carpenter's Scope framing is matched only by his ability to speak to contemporary affairs.
Girls Will Be Girls is every bit as dull and offensive as it is frequently hysterical.
The film is an ethereal, opiate-induced chronicle of a young girl (a flower of Shanghai if you will) whose life is preciously unexamined.
Emir Kusturica's tragic-farce Underground may be the most important film of the last 25 years.
Is Affleck in it for the salvation of the world or Uma Thurman's booty?
Kid-friendly, market-researched drivel, from the rudimentary conflicts to the pinup adolescent cast.
A master stylist, Woo is similarly brilliant at examining the moral and social hierarchies of his patriarchal crime worlds.
Not only does Paul's battle with Madeleine represent a war between the sexes, but a clash between disparate philosophical and moral beliefs.
A disastrously misconceived confection that should easily neuter a few childhood memories.
movie_title: Dr. Seuss' The Cat in the Hat (2003)

movie_review_blurb: The film's simple beauty lies in the way that Lopes-Curval effortlessly equates life to a passing season.
Puppy Love 101 for the MTV generation, an inoffensive but painfully routine look at Teen Beat personalities looking for love in all the wrong places.
movie_title: Win a Date With Tad Hamilton! (2004)

movie_review_blurb: The only reality here is that truth is slippery, and that's something Broomfield understands more than most documentary filmmakers working today.
movie_title: Aileen: Life and Death of a Serial Killer (2004)

movie_review_blurb: The soulless Alien is essentially an amalgam of power shots.
Bless Penelope Cruz's Spanish little heart (not to mention her right tear duct) that she can wail a line like "He opened me like a flower of pain" without busting a gut.

Caro seems less concerned with evoking the economic or socio-political baggage bringing the film's characters down than she is with telling the same sappy tale of patriarchal perseverance we've seen so many times before.
Some notable clips are missing, but this is a pretty comprehensive overview of music video auteur Michel Gondry's work, from 1987 to 2003.
movie_title: The Work of Director Michel Gondry (2003)

movie_review_blurb: Pornography is D.H. Lawrence without the penetration, Diary of a Chambermaid with none of the bite and philosophical imagination.
The film's awful sound design is trumped only by a shrill Chaturani's sadistic desire to add vocal contractions to her line deliveries.
If you refuse to buy Mackey and Aaron as Simpson and Yates, there's no mistaking the authenticity of the film's non-human entity.
Proves once again that Bellocchio is not so much a filmmaker than he is an unenthusiastic debater.
Kill Bill: Volume 1 is essentially a pop culture wanker's failed multimedia experiment, a vacuous junk heap of dorky gags and riffs, violent anime and offensive slapstick.
The entire film is stitched together from a collection of long shots that stress the expansive emotional distance between the film's characters.
Not only is this useless "revision" ignorant of history, it panders to its modern audience with look-Ma visual brouhaha.
Barbara Albert's contemptuous Free Radicals unravels like an Austrian Short Cuts, except there's no humanity buried beneath the life-is-bleak passages of the film.
Since Otar Left is meant to play out like a fable, but Bertuccelli's direction isn't nimble enough to carry it off.
Ostensibly about an epic betrayal, Bright Leaves spirals beautifully in a hundred different directions.
Tsai's elegy to a now-departed Taipei theater is also a beautiful love poem to the movies.
Padilha sheds light on numerous social catastrophes and hypocrisies plaguing Rio de Janeiro and the incestuous, complex relationship between real life and reality television.

Privileged audiences that swooned for Decline of the American Empire should expect more of the same oh-so-witty jibber-jabber and specious political "noise" exchanged between Arcand's motley intellectuals.
Ostensibly about our fascination with fame, the film actually has very little to say about the subject that hasn't been covered a million times on VH1's "Behind the Music."
Once you remove all the economic and cultural baggage that frustrates the couple's attempts to hook-up, Raja is really just about the thrill of the chase.
This elegant movement in still life unravels as a profound metaphor for both the filmmaking process and life itself.
The embarrassing Earth Mother chants by Phil Collins further remove us from the world of the sacred past and straight into a Disney marketeer's cubicle.
Like the carol the film proudly blares during Christmas season: "Joy to the World! The Savior Reigns!"
Robert Benton's The Human Stain should be a lesson to us all: it is possible to make a film creakier than Guess Who's Coming To Dinner.
Why save the world when Angelina Jolie can do it for you and get laid at the same time?
Browning uses the film's famous "Wedding Feast" sequence and its rhythmic use of montage to fantastically blur the lines between the normal and the abnormal.
It shouldn't come as a surprise that Ferrell's insane performance almost saves the show.
The Wachowskis lay on the spiritual allegory thick, but the film's fragile, better-than-here hopefulness is genuinely unsettling.
How "numb" do you have to be in order not to know that you've seriously injured yourself?
Nigel Cole's feature-length sitcom Calendar Girls reimagines The Full Monty with boobies.
The film's raw, sensual realism and social consciousness brings to mind Frears's My Beautiful Laundrette.
Juicily satiric of the typical self-indulgence that motivates Queer as Folk.
Reminds us of how easily our adult sexual identities are encoded in our seemingly innocent childhood behaviors.
This beautiful, deceptively simple coming-out story martyrs one of its titular characters in order to free the other from his closet.
Wayne Kramer's misogynistic The Cooler is not for the Mamet faint-of-heart.
If not as dense as Godard's Masculin, Féminin, Wolfgang Becker's Good Bye, Lenin! is an equally playful look at the effects of American globalization abroad.
Happily and ridiculously over the top, Secret Things is a war of anarchic, sexual primitisim.
Keys seems to understand that the global appeal of Cuban music is directly proportional to its multiculturality.
Loved the discovery, but hated the man's forcing of himself on the project.
I was not prepared for the moment when The Tween Who Cried Wolf became The Lindsay Lohan Movie.
movie_title: Confessions of a Teenage Drama Queen (2004)

It's to Sky Blue's credit that it's able to say more in one image than sub-par anime like Appleseed can convey in a thousand meaningless words.
Marchand uses the death of Bambi's mother as a point of departure for a study on postmodern violence in cinema.
movie_title: Qui a tué Bambi? (Who Killed Bambi?) (2004)

movie_review_blurb: An elaborate equation consisting entirely of bad horror tropes and trashy psychological symbolism.
An exhausting soap opera of doom that cuts back and forth between what seems like 100 speaking parts and conveys a chilling vision of rats being slowly flushed down a toilet.
A work of Jarmuschian deadpan, Fernando Eimbcke's Duck Season is independent in the purest and most literal sense of the word.
Like the overpraised Affliction, it strains to trace the sins of the father in the sins the son.
Considerably less miserable than Free Radicals, but it's also more schematic.
Primo Amore is as moody as Matteo Garrone's previous feature, The Embalmer, from which it seems to have pilfered much of its metaphoric import.
There's a great short film in here somewhere.
It looks and feels like Session 9 but it rattles the soul like The Gate of the Sun.
Fever Pitch is not just some comedy about two people meeting each other halfway, but something greater: a statement about the wheeling and dealing of a tradition.
If you manage to stick around for joy, it's probably because -- like me --you dig the original score by Graham Massey.
State Property 2's daisy wheel of violence represents a reckless glorification of thug life.
Moodysson doesn't use this borrowed aesthetic to study what's on his plate; he's just out to cause a scene.
movie_title: Hål i mitt hjärta, Ett (A Hole In My Heart) (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Where was Radley Metzger when you needed him?
Every plot point follows a soapy and well-worn path, but the characters speak to each other as if they've known each other their entire lives.
The attention Kim pays to the spirit world is obsessive and alluring, but his view of flesh-and-blood women and victimhood is still a problem.
L'Esquive consistently teeters on the brink of tragedy but dares to end on a chipper note.
Never lives up to the pleasures of its first half, but the filmmakers remain as lovestruck by the story as its characters are with each other.
Evokes a period in time before Ritalin and common sense.
Just as the characters are underthought, the storylines are incongruently pieced together.
True to the film's idealized spirit, directors Mike Gabriel and Eric Goldberg similarly fend off history.
The central relationship is tenderly conveyed but the plot soon takes a predictable antagonistic path.
A remarkable synthesis of proto-feminist ideals and visionary aesthetics.
Hey, Toby, I know what you did last summer: you went gay!
Fails to summon a compelling parallel between Merchant's anti-Semitic baggage and the Jewish Maurice's own struggles as an actor.
Feels like a lecture you'd expect to hear at a liberal arts college.
Pop iconography typically signifies the alienation of Araki's characters from the world, but in Mysterious Skin it ushers in their salvation.
The film's tapestry of snarky sights and sounds doesn't exactly shed a complex light on the social and emotional problems and behaviors of people who lived in '50s.
That's hot.
Popov himself emerges as the story's villain, a schmuck with the personality of a TV anchorman and the common sense of Troy Duffy.
More than 40 years after its original release, Viridiana remains one of the most shocking films ever made.
Possibly the closet American relation to an Italian giallo.
A compelling and obsessive humanization of American eccentricity.
The non-stop swirl of anecdotes from which the film is assembled lacks sociological resonance.
movie_title: Lipstick & Dynamite: The First Ladies of Wrestling (2004)

movie_review_blurb: Certi Bambini is all show.

Some films are ripped from the headlines, others are ripped from the pages of Cosmopolitan.
If, according to the film, everyone has their hands on India, direcctor Gurinder Chadha similarly has her hands on the American box office.
Though convinced it's helping people to rediscover their roots, the film succeeds only in planting corn.
This isn't Spirited Away, and while critics are bound to call the film innocuous (it is, I suppose), this is precisely what's so endearing about it: its innocence.
The birth of Parinya's gender struggle is Freudian to the nth degree, but the confusion is evoked as a magical-realist pageantry of clashing cultural and sexual signifiers.
Long on visual affections and unexamined smut but short on insight, the film's view of human behavior is as offensive as it is preposterously simpleminded.
Like Shaolin Soccer, the film is positively insane, a genre-defying spectacle of postmodern signs colliding at rates seemingly faster than the speed of light.
10 Reasons Why You Should (Or Shouldn't) See Raise Your Voice...
It's like one half of a Willa Cather novel: The moral backbone is there but its social spine has been ripped out.
A daisy wheel of revenge-fueled gore speciously intercut with delusions of social commentary.
Howl's Moving Castle is a Hayao Miyazaki film through and through, but the film's meta momentum is bound to disappoint fans of the director's more conventional work.
This high profile anthology of shorts by Fruit Chan, Park Chan-wook, and Takashi Miike is related by their chilling structuralist rigor.
To Be or Not to Be's wit continues to be overshadowed by its touchy plot.
movie_title: To Be or Not to Be (1942)

movie_review_blurb: Off the Map evokes cave paintings coming to life.

Shapeless but its objective stance is powerful.
Robots more or less confirms that production studio Blue Sky is likely to be remembered as the Jan to Pixar's Marcia and PDI's Cindy.
The Hero is unassuming and confidently directed for a first feature.
True to its metaphysical fixation with the art of embroidery, characters often feel like strands undone from an uncompromising human tapestry.
A film that seems to have been made under the influence of illicit drugs, you may need to be in a K-hole to remotely enjoy it.
Maggio clogs his story with all sorts of serendipitous events but seems uninterested in looking at these chance encounters on any kind of existential or spiritual terms.
A triumph of internal horror.
Old man good, young man bad -- I get it already!
A horrifying vision of globalization gone terribly amuck.
At the very least, it's more sensitive than more Lucky Charmed productions of its kind like Waking Ned Devine and Calendar Girls
Brown weaves a fast-flying tapestry but makes the mistake of having Nathan Furst score the thing to within an inch of its life.
Rent Pootie Tang instead.
It knows how to cover its bases, but its tidy structure doesn't exactly gel with the rough-and-tumble nature of the sport at its center.
An unusual mix of Leigh-for-Dummies social realism and fairy-tale wish-fulfillment.
Strictly for anyone who ever wanted to know what it would be like if Chris Columbus directed El Topo.
When the director fails to conflate the film's sexual unease with larger social issues, Or (My Treasure's sexual paranoia begins to reek of exploitation.
For his feature film debut, director Yann Samuell mainlines into Amelie for inspiration but can scarcely muster a contact high.
Critical of the suburban milieu as a petri dish where regressive sexist fantasies are cultivated.
Infernal Affairs could be the syllabus for "The Effects of Michael Mann, Tony Scott, and the American Police Procedural on Asian Cinema."
Ricci, a largely inconsistent and limited actress, is splendid when the atomic bomb inside her character's head goes off.
Every character trajectory is painfully schematic, and the filmmakers evoke cause-and-effect in the simplest terms possible.
Queens living on Castro and Christopher streets will lap this up, but isn't this kind of we-are-family minstrel comedy getting kind of old?
Auto-critique or ego trip? Sex Is Comedy is a little bit of both-sadly more of the latter.

Michael Haussman's over-directed conspiracy thriller takes place in a small desert town in New Mexico and recalls a bad episode of The X-Files.
Plays out like an antidote to films like Napoleon Dynamite that seem to exist for no other reason than to make audiences feel superior to lower-class buffoons.
In the end, what is the film's drag act but an excuse for the Wayans to learn how to respect women's feelings?
Essentially a moving Abercrombie and Fitch catalog, Riding Giants is a boy's club chronicle of surfing that, while gnarly to look at, feels like too much homework.
Unevenly pitched somewhere between a straight-faced Mr. Smith Goes to Washington and a magical realist Big Fish.
If corporations are protected under the law as living, breathing people, then this enthralling Canadian documentary sets out to tell us what kind of people they are.
Deceptivily simple and wickedly funny.
An under-thought formula linking sex, youth, and violence.
A single-minded ode to international camaraderie and American perseverance.
Some Kind of Monster is a first: a film that's intimate to a fault.
There's a certain multi-cultural conflict that distinguishes the Lewton-Tourneurs.
Despite the breathtaking locales, Warriors of Heaven and Earth is impossibly cheesy.

movie_review_blurb: Curiously, watching the unseemly-looking and self-obsessed Second Best is not unlike being trapped in an abusive relationship.

The Incredibles may fight to save the world, but they teach us to know thyself.

Spectacularly irrelevant, Bright Young Things is well-performed and frequently hysterical but its political resistance is frustrating.

A disturbingly lurid, sometimes riveting (dare I say fun?), but often offensive spectacle of violence.
In 13 Going on 30, women are allowed happiness, but only if they choose the right man.
Not unlike My Big Fat Greek Wedding, Connie and Carla allows Nia Vardalos to showcase her abject desire to mug the camera.
This is a film that sees only in black-and-white.
Strictly for those who didn't want to crawl into the fetal position and die when Shaggy grew breasts in Monsters Unleashed.
Basically an excuse to give Jackie Chan a hundred different places to beat people up.

The biggest cinematic human rights violation since Bad Boys II.

A deeply humanistic proclamation of the power of faith.
movie_title: Un condamné à mort s'est échappé ou Le vent souffle où il veut (A Man Escaped) (1957)

movie_review_blurb: A laconic portrait of a remote Chinese city in arrested development.

Ozpetek's "fairy tale" hopes to get by on the good looks of its actors alone.
Unlike Ichi the Killer and the considerably shorter Visitor Q, Gozu's random acts of hysteria don't seem to add up to anything.

A rhythmic ode to togetherness, non-cynical communication, and the power of mother's milk.
movie_title: The Story of the Weeping Camel (2004)

movie_review_blurb: For those who think there'e nothing funnier than yokels acting like idiots for 90 minutes straight.
A smutty, bargain-basement version of In the Bedroom.

movie_review_blurb: One could say that Innocence thinks so much that it ultimately has very little to say.

More or less a neutered version of Robert Altman's sexy beast The Player.

movie_review_blurb: The anxieties suffered by Tina throughout the film are well thought-out by the franchise's typically one-dimensional standards.
movie_title: Friday the 13th Part VII - The New Blood (1988)

movie_review_blurb: Director Rob Hedden may have been onto something: From Crystal Lake to Manhattan, the series itself was always drowning in ****.
movie_title: Friday the 13th Part VIII - Jason Takes Manhattan (1989)

When Susan wonders if it's scarier seeing or not seeing the sharks around them, she may as well be talking to the audience.

movie_review_blurb: It's amazing what people will swallow when guys in suits and ties are cracking the whip.

Bloodless and impersonal.

movie_review_blurb: Quiet and unpretentious, the film's humanism isn't confrontational exactly but it's unmistakable nonetheless.

An apocalyptic sweat chamber nervously situated between complacency and heartbreaking could-have-been hopefulness.

movie_title: L'uccello dalle piume di cristallo (The Bird With the Crystal Plumage) (1970)

movie_review_blurb: Monsters Inc. is a humbling reminder of what it's like to fear, imagine and hope.

As far as stuffy Oxford dramas go, Harry Potter has them all beat.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Sorcerer's Stone (2001)

movie_review_blurb: Black Knight's first half is a consistent hoot.
Tony Scott always knows how to put on a good show.
Soderbergh is so cool he can make anything go down like fine wine.
A masturbatory pop culture thriller that only services Cameron Crowe's fondness for rock n' roll.
Now here's a sadistic bike flick that would have made Vittorio De Sica proud.
You might forget Disturbance ever existed, but it's a fun ride while it lasts.
This sliced and diced curio (think Manchevski's Before the Rain as directed by Godard) tackles entirely too much to ever really be about anything.
movie_title: Code Unknown (Code inconnu: Récit incomplet de divers voyages) (2000)

movie_review_blurb: No Man's Land may end with an honest blip yet its history is remiss.

The idle David relishes his freedom though he is wholly unaware of the moral responsibility expected of him.

A stunning deconstruction of bourgeois complacency in the face of pastoral decay.
Noble yet vague, Hearts in Atlantis is slight yet beautiful to look at.

movie_title: The Devil's Backbone (El Espinazo del diablo) (2001)

movie_review_blurb: A thriller-chiller that is as shamelessly predictable as it is memorably grim.

movie_title: Akai Hashi No Shita Noo Nurui Mizu (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Bruce Weber's filmic journey becomes a series of libidinal ups and humbling downs.

A charming study of language as the way to another's heart.

movie_review_blurb: It's Hemingway meets Kustom Kar Kommandos as Alain Guiraudie sets latent homosexual lust against greasy metallic parts.

Comforted by the deaths of so many Jews, the Nazis became oblivious to the possibility of a Jewish revolt.

A rock-solid Hollywood thriller that showcases a corrupt cop's twisted abuse of innocence.

movie_review_blurb: Voyage, like 8 1/2 to Fellini, is Scorsese's pure expression of love for a constantly evolving cinema.

movie_review_blurb: A film's always in trouble when it has more screenwriters than cast members.
Joe Nobody becomes Joe Somebody after he gives it to the man.

movie_review_blurb: Touching Home strenuously aspires to the same sort of greatness that has alluded many a film before it, like the heavy-handed, Gone with the Wind-grubbing Raintree Country.
