Under Sverak's shrewdly unforced direction, other thesps are natural and appealing.
At once scabrously funny and uncomfortably poignant...
A resolute Bosnian mother grows determined to find the daughter taken from her and given to German foster parents a decade earlier in finely played drama Warchild.
Toronto fest opener crudely welds the grisly verisimilitude of Saving Private Ryan to the contempo cultural revisionism of Pearl Harbor but can't forge the disparate tones into a powerful whole.
The kind of movie where only some of the characters have last names, this essentially sweet-natured enterprise feels slightly rushed and distracted.

Large cast is uniformly fine with tongue-twisting, pulpy dialogue, though pic presents only brief flashes of what look to be fully realized characterizations jettisoned at some point during production or post.
A deliberately coarse character style that's more Gumby than Gromit.
Taxidermia sets a benchmark for body horror in the cinema.
A focused, absorbing meditation on race, class, history and sex.
A sprightly pace and a fatalistic sense of humor propel the proceedings over a generous amount of drinking jokes and other cliches of Irish life and culture.
A modern genre classic, reinterpreting a familiar story with emotional delicacy and visual force.
Love The Beast has the mellow glow of affectionate nostalgia for the kind of solid construction and steadfast mateship increasingly hard to come by in these prefab times.
Glossy yet ultimately shallow, this platitudinous, unconvincing drama makes The Colour Purple look like Mississippi Burning.
As frustrating as the story's shallowness is, this shortcoming is very nearly negated by the sheer physical pleasure of the production.
TV scribe Kundo Koyama's first bigscreen script peppers the proceedings with rich character detail and near-screwball interludes that shouldn't fit but somehow do.
Though director Olivier Megaton exhibits a good bit of that annoyingly jagged editing that's become all the rage in action films, he has the good sense to never cut away from Statham's pecs.
Though the script is flat and the acting perhaps intentionally stilted, Lussier's trump card is a distinctive blend of new technology and old-fashioned prosthetic effects.
When he is at the top of his game, as he is here, Cruise's charisma is blinding.
A so-so pic on an incendiary subject.
The numerous action sequences, while imaginative, lack a visual cohesion that allows them to be fully appreciated.
movie_title: Underworld: The Rise of the Lycans (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Who better than Rourke to sell the idea of a battered, yet proud pugilist in search of redemption?
An intimate, lacerating, absorbing visual diary of the three-year onset of terminal disease Amyotrophic Lateral Sclerosis (ALS) in aspiring filmmaker Ben Byer.
A beautifully atmospheric vessel that will seem infinitely deep to some and chafingly dry to others.
A tastefully reverent, fundamentally sincere treatment of Margaret Laurence's 1964 Manitoba-based novel, a staple for Canada's 12th graders.
[The film] understands that emotional authenticity is just as important as entertainment value.
A precisely modulated yet cumulatively forceful story of a rural family feud turned deadly.
A bracingly old-fashioned, lushly visualized showbiz meller set against pre-World War II Gallic political unrest.

This Bond is also a bit of a jerk, taking what he wants when he wants it and acting on an instinct that leaves little room for moral debate. Seen in this light, Craig is the perfect storm of Bondian class and mayhem.
While it may lack a certain amount of bite, there's plenty of bark to recommend this winning animated adventure.
The most even-keeled, pleasant and mainstream movie Jim Carrey has made in many a moon.
Igor celebrates a defiantly adolescent and suitably caricatured vision of mortality with the potential to have adults and special young malcontents in stitches.
There's a good deal of potential squandered in this strained comedy, which suffers from lazy writing, miscalculated acting, perfunctory directing and general bad timing.
"Club Life" is a flat, disjointed drama that's buoyed by a couple of good performances. Your mileage may vary depending on your interest in dance montages.
The dullest entry in an atrocious trilogy.
It doesn't reinvent the wheel, but Poltergeist is a solid, surprisingly effective chiller that's respectful towards its 1982 predecessor while acquitting itself as a proficient update.

Wilson is an engaging actor, but he's stuck treading water in a movie with little action. Heigl, on the other hand, seems bored and aloof. She's playing against type, but she's stiff and doesn't make a fun villain here.
"Dawn Patrol" has a lot on its plate and manages to drop it all.
"Growing Up and Other Lies" tells you right in the title it's not going to take maturing seriously, so it's not a surprise that the movie is unfocused and ineffective.
There's not much new for Farley fans, but they'll enjoy the admiring and amiable tribute.
It's like "Memento," except that movie was fantastic.
Even if this movie isn't fresh, it's often amusing.
It's a lazy, by-the-numbers bore. It almost jumps through hoops to not be different in any way. In fact, you could sleep through the movie and still recite what happened.
How did the guy who made "Gremlins" and "The Howling" direct this cheap-looking, sophomoric, unfunny dreck?
A fictional slice of Americana which creates a dreamlike atmosphere around a traditional story of love, crime and redemption.
You're Next is far too derivative to appear to anyone but hardcore slasher-movie fans with low-standards.
The serious subject of child abduction and murder isn't well served by the way Anderson's film veers into a comic book/vigilante drama, ultimately making this a call worth avoiding.
Blue Jasmine marks a high-water mark for Blanchett, and for Allen, who demonstrates both the craftsmanship and the unique gift for balancing comedy and pathos which has eluded him for so long.
Considerably less grounded in any kind of recognizable reality than the first chapter.
Helgeland has crafted a decent sport movie, but one that feels too sanitized and feels too educationally minded to prove any genuine thought.
With a bright production design enlivened by strong 3D, and a simple, likeable story about self-actualisation, it's a slow but sure winner.
Not funny enough to be a comedy, not weighty enough to be a real B-movie thriller ...
Far too reverent to the source material, po-faced, literal and without raising much intensity.
Audiences who appreciated the first film will enjoy the silliness, but uninitiated viewers may find a second serving of Meatballs is hard to swallow.
movie_title: Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs 2 (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Long, ponderous, but undeniably entertaining, The Butler is a ritzy crash-course in US political change.
A lively premise and darkly humorous tone give way to predictable action and a dull finale.
Ellis proves that the slow-burning thriller can still work as both an entertainment and as a penetrating social critique.
Coogan's gift for making Partridge a believably awful everyman makes Alpha Papa a welcome slice of accomplished British character comedy.

Aside from a toned-down finale that thankfully doesn't attempt to re-create the exhausting multiple climaxes of the original's Central Park finale, The Smurfs 2 is as bald a retread as the unimaginative title might suggest.
Adults looking for undemanding fare for their kids may find Top Cat's brand of sass, irreverence and cheeky charm offer a persuasive alternative to today's crasser children's entertainments.
Originally conceived as one single portmanteau film, the Paradise trilogy doesn't have enough meat on its bones to justify four hours of anyone's life.
Red 2 seems stifled by the weight of its own detailed exposition, and only Hopkins seems to be enjoying himself in the same gleeful way that Mirren did in the previous film.

The sincerity and sentiment of this film are there to be basked in. Yet audiences outside Japan may find the subject too serious and yet too slight; there's a reason why films about potential incest aren't often as cute as this.
Eden surprises by managing to paint a vivid and disturbing picture of the trafficking experience within the context of a conventional thriller.

The synopsis promises to put the Wolverine, a blue-collar superhero, into an appropriately realistic criminal environment, but in practice it all adds up to Wolverine fighting the usual big robot in a volcano-sized laboratory.
Lellouche does herself no favours by wearing such influences on her sleeve, yet her cast are game, the locations look great, and the whole enterprise has an agreeably frothy touch.
Play isn't much fun, but it does skewer the way in which modern selfishness creates social division.
Killer footage never emerges, just guys goofing off ...
For those prepared to go with the abstraction, Upstream Color is a rewarding and mind-blowing experience.
The Deep is a spare and reasonably compelling drama for the first hour, mainly thanks to Ólafsson's star-making turn.
This Haunted House needs a KEEP OUT sign nailed to the door.

Writer/director Ed Gass-Donnelly's film offers little ironic edge or incisive imagery, pushing far too hard with an unpleasant emphasis on sexuality, and ending up as a by-the-numbers rehash of the original film's weakest elements.
Despite Butler's considerable charm and undeniably buff appearance, Chasing Mavericks sinks in choppy water.
Elaborate backstories have more meaning when the characters are known and loved; Percy Jackson's endless exposition only demonstrates why he's nobody's favourite boy-wizard.
Free Birds lacks the humour, pathos or narrative skill of a proper children's film.
It may be old-fashioned, but it's also as close to an instant classic as family films get.
Those keen to see four princes of 80s cinema going through the motions will find their Last Vegas gamble pays off in minor ways.
Makes up in razzle-dazzle what it lacks in intelligence.
An authentically awkward, ordinary life, scrupulously observed.
While little more than an update on an ongoing dispute, The Fake Case is a welcome chance to catch up with the quirky artist's heroic struggle for freedom.
Joe may be too bleak and unsparing for some tastes, but it's an adult, accomplished drama that elevates an ordinary story to near-operatic heights.
Snowpiercer is leaden and confused, an all-star disaster of a movie, of interest only to connoisseurs of expensively botched sci-fi money-pits.

A film which says little of consequence beyond fictionalizing its target; only Bisset's Lady Macbeth-like presence hits an appropriately hysterical note for this tabloid-trashy film which quickly chokes on its pretensions.

Lange at least has an angle on her character; the rest of the cast simply hit their marks and spout dialogue like robots, delivering lines which should evoke erotic fervour, but are exchanged without urgency, conviction or belief.
A cynical cash-grab riding on the coat-tails of far better productions.
There's not quite enough compelling visual material to justify feature length.
movie_title: Pantani: The Accidental Death Of A Cyclist (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Like the character he plays, Turturro clearly wants his film to be adored, but Fading Gigolo's decidedly male fantasy doesn't offer enough laughs or heart to be more than a passing diversion.
Much like Anderson's The Three Musketeers, the details are highly dubious, but the effect is strangely pleasing in its daft, anything-goes showmanship.
Few directors would dare to put the dilemmas inherent in military aircraft design to the fore, but Miyazaki's film deals sensitively with the notion that good work may be used for bad ends.
Blue Ruin is a simple story well told; it marks promising work from both Saulnier and Blair, and delivers on its promises of a tightly-wound descent into hell.

The last hour of The Raid 2 is all-action, delivering several astonishing set-pieces, one involving a hammer-whirling girl on a packed commuter train, the other a series of fights in and around cars careering through busy city streets.
Stranded in a dull-looking house, and with little action, Pogue's film gets bogged down in conversation and cod-scientific mumbo jumbo.
Compellingly weird and occasionally wonderful to behold.
Rio 2 is an amiable enough cartoon, as forgettable as its predecessor but certainly colourful and incident packed enough to be marked as passable family entertainment.
The Double is a clever film, but despite its downtrodden hero, not a particularly empathetic experience.
The Stag is an inoffensive debut for Butler, but a film on this subject needs a bit more cojones than this meek knockabout.
Tavernier's adaptation of the cult comic strip, Quai d'Orsay, is episodic, insular and hard work for non-Francophiles.
Both the character and the film blossom as Ida discovers the joys of nightclubs, John Coltrane and sex.
Before the Winter Chill is a rather odd film: excellent performances, a convincing milieu, and then a final twist that seems so improbable that all Claudel's careful work seems undone.
Considerable tension is elicited, but the characters are well enough drawn that the outcome of Grand Central is never clear.
There's a delicate romance buried within, but Gondry's endless stop motion tomfoolery and visual jokes prove overwhelming in all the wrong ways.

If you're familiar with the historical specifics, Stalingrad is a reasonably engrossing war drama in the style of Days of Glory, well-played and with moments of vivid patriotic spectacle that look like an army recruiting poster come to life.
A well executed minor drama that casts a careful life on the inner lives of military personnel, and promises good things to come in terms of the young cast, and Tom Petch's future career.
Affleck, Dafoe and Harrelson all do their very best to whip up a storm, but Cooper is guilty of wasting A-list talent on a B-movie revenge scenario.
The lazy structure, lack of narrative drive or visual stimulus quickly reveal the reasons that Boyd's life hasn't been tackled cinematically before.
As a major filmmaker, it's about time Scorsese found some material that stretched his ideas, rather than his audience's patience.
Filmed on the cheap in Bulgaria, it makes up for what it lacks in originality with a plethora of well-staged car-stunts, and puts action firmly at the centre of its limited appeal.
Linklater makes use of unshowy direction and natural improvisation from his leads, who both get co-writing credits, creating a remarkably unforced picture of love kindled and rekindled.
The Raid is short, tough, and offers exactly the kind of pumped-up kicks that die-hard action fans adore.
While it's nice to see talents like Keaton and Sarandon in The Big Wedding, it's ultimately frustrating seeing their talents wasted in Zackham's paper-thin excuse for a rom-com.
Looking more prepared for a walk down a Milan catwalk than the grizzled sea-salt she's supposed to be, Berry provides a dull filling for Stockwell's risible shark sandwich.
[It] sports such a puppy-ish desire to be liked, but for a really good time, you'd be better off just watching Bridesmaids again.
Madagascar's animals parody human characteristics to enjoyably madcap effect.
It will be alarming to many to see how easily hatred is stirred up by local media, but also rewarding to see that Kato's fight for his own human rights has been ably captured for posterity.
Soon gives way to silliness, with the poltergeist fiddling with Sally's Buckeroo and Slinky toys.
Fanning's transformation into a sickly Brighton girl is the one notable factor in an otherwise annoyingly shallow look at terminal illness.
By dint of its underplayed acting and serious tone, The Possession is one of the better efforts of its type ...
[A] mean-spirited, one-gag time waster.
Circumstance bravely depicts the political plight of independent young women in Iran, a timely and worthwhile subject somewhat let down by two-dimensional storytelling.
While not a game-changer, Jackpot is the kind of sprightly low-budget import which is likely to reward fans of the Nordic crime genre.
Batmanglij and Marling have crafted a neat chiller, a no-frills B movie that explores the central conceit with intelligence and wit...
Strong British independent cinema deserves an audience, but The Man Inside never lands a punch.
The real stars turn out to be the audience, whose natural, unguarded reactions to Abramovic give this film a transcendent, luminous and ultimately life-affirming quality.
movie_title: Marina Abramovic: The Artist Is Present (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Kosmos shows plenty of evidence of a rare visual talent at work.
Milburn's debut is a slight, unpolished micro-budget, yet the grasp of storytelling displayed here marks him as a promising talent.
The attempt to capture the minutiae of everyday life is brave, but the activity Sanders actually portrays turns out to be disappointingly mundane.
Segel and Blunt are charming as ever, and an accomplished supporting cast includes Chris Pratt as Tom's incidental bromance Alex and Rhys Ifans as Violet's lecherous mentor.
Visual effect supervisor-turned first time director Bradley Parker quickly runs out of creative ideas, making this disaster-tourism trip well worth avoiding.
What To Expect When You're Expecting is the kind of witless schmatz-fest that gives women's pictures a bad name...
movie_title: What to Expect When You're Expecting (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Next time Ferrell ventures south of the border, he might want to take a gag-writer with him.
It's a promising, efficient debut for McCarthy, but any kind of originality isn't part of the deal.

A Royal Affair is a welcome break from the current plethora of morbid Scandinavian thrillers; instead, Rasmus Heisterberg and Nikolaj Arcel have co-adapted an unfamiliar but well documented true story of 18th century Danish royalty.
Lucas' dream project crashes and burns due to thin characterization, hoary clichés and crude simplifications...
Whatever the title says, this is most definitely not Irvine Welsh's Ecstasy, but an agonisingly watered-down imitation, a long, languid come-down after the frenetic buzz of Trainspotting.
While not as offensively tawdry as recent release The Devil Inside, Bousman's film is strictly by-the-numbers horror fare.
The Nut Job feels like an archly contrived excuse to justify the groaning pun of the title.
Far too ponderously slow to maintain the tension, despite Olsen's undoubted effectiveness as a scream-queen.

Act of Valour might work as a recruiting poster for impressionable teenagers, but those who bravely serve in the armed forces deserve a better tribute that the naïve, sub-Team America nonsense served up here.
All the sentiments about 'being all you can be' fall somewhat flat against the cynically commercial feel of StreetDance 2's enterprise, which credits the audience with one brain-cell each.

It won't be to many people's taste, but for those with strong stomachs, Excision presents a strain of horror that's grounded in real life, and one with more potency that most conventional slasher/torture fare.
Teenagers deserve bigger portions of entertainment than these meagre morsels.
As an undemanding time-passer, Here Comes The Boom just about goes the distance.
Banks makes a feisty soccer-mom, Wilde has nothing to do but look frostily on, and Pine smoulders pointlessly at everyone he meets, completely failing to suggest anything but complete vapidity.
A big, brash but ultimately somewhat boring fairy story that relies too heavily on celebrity casting for appeal.
Luhrmann's gaudy approach is appropriate to the material; as proved by his best novella The Diamond as Big as The Ritz, Fitzgerald understood the distinct allure of grand scale and opulence.
Grim displays of guilt and remorse are on show from all concerned, but the seriously glum expressions of a high-calibre cast can't inject any meaning into such a contrived story.
Serious-minded, literate dramas are few and far between outside Oscar season, and until a tired third act, The Eye of the Storm just about manages to live up to its illustrious pedigree.
The final suggestion that people on medication are just a mood-swing from being a danger to the community consigns Norris's dull-looking film to the lowest echelons of stigmatizing thought.
Lacks wit, genuine laughs, or any real sense of wonder, just a couple of misfiring comics in fright-wigs going through the motions.
Identity Thief isn't a great comedy in the class of McCarthy's Bridesmaids, but it's still a decent one ...
Zobel's film shocks, but leaves the viewer to uncover the real story for themselves.

The result is an oddly broken-backed narrative, with three distinct chapters and no central character to carry the narrative. The ambition, to tell a complex story over two generations, is laudable, but the result isn't entirely satisfying.
Despite the odds, both stars strike a few sparks in Anne Fletcher's slight comedy.
Kashyap's film is lightning paced, well-acted and breathlessly observes a complex story about a snake-pit of casual killers.

Thérèse Desqueyroux works best as a character study, with Tautou impressive as a shrewish, unhappy woman who, despite her extreme actions, finds that her fate remains frustratingly beyond her control.
Neighbouring Sounds is a clever, original drama of social concern, with trivial incidents barely masking deep social fissures.
The slow pace and choppy technicalities will deter all but the most hardcore genre fans, although the more determined zombie-philes will find something to sink their teeth into.
Stand Up Guys is very much an old man's film, but Stevens just about delivers the performances that its ageing audience demands.
Rather than aping Hollywood dramas, Living Apart Together aims for the unforced sophistication of French cinema, and the mix with pawky Glasgow humour makes for a beguiling blast from the past.

Safe Haven is a blandly 'vanilla' film; attractively shot in picturesque locations, peppered with recognizable if unexciting faces, and delivering a simplistic homily about love conquering all that only a teenage girl could love.
There's little about Chao-Bin's other work to suggest the splendidly choreographed ballets of swordplay that feature here, with Woo's dexterous hand obvious in the fight scenes.
Sammy's Painfully Long Incarceration would be a better title for this sequel to 2010's A Turtle's Tale: Sammy's Adventures.
A small film with humble ambitions, I Wish is a gentle piece that children may find dull, but tearful adults will recognize that Koreeda captures the essence of childhood dreams.
'Dumbing down' a film about educational reform defeats any point; while proficiently made, Won't Back Down's glib feel-good message deserves to fall on deaf ears.
Apatow seems to be offering autobiography as entertainment, but while aiming for blunt honesty, This is 40 is simply dull.
A welcome return from one of the genre's acknowledged masters.
There's little actual humour in May I Kill U?, just a grim view of police-work, deprivation, social media and modern life generally.
It might not be offering anything new to the lore of the horror film, but Midnight Son is a confident, minor work that hardcore admirers of the True Blood/Twilight cycle will want to seek out.
Wright doesn't take the time to create any real tension, which means that the comedy relief doesn't have a chance of raising laughs.
As a vehicle for Cruise, Jack Reacher isn't an entirely comfortable fit, but makes for an undemanding slice of thick-ear mainstream entertainment.
Kendrick and Wilson have the right kind of sass to entertain; they may not be as glamorous as the kids in Glee, but in Pitch Perfect, they seem like the girls who are having all the fun.
It's professionally crafted fluff, disposable as chewing gum, but likely to hit the spot for the specific female primary-school age-group the film is aimed squarely at.
Collette anchors the film with a selfless, let-it-all-hang-out performance that sets an agreeably anarchic tone.
Neither dealing with the supernatural nor particularly violent, Stoker might not appeal to horror fans, but manages to create something fresh in the thriller genre.
The Purge: Anarchy is a welcome expansion of the first film's concept, and shrewdly fills a void as one of the few adult-orientated action films in the family-friendly summer schedule.
There's nothing to distinguish TV director Sam Miller's pedestrian effort from scores of straight-to-download thrillers.
As with the first film, children will be drawn to the bright colours and simple morals, which makes some of the sexual and racial stereotyping on the sidelines rather regrettable.
The Age of Shadows has a steely verve and baroque style that recalls the classic Warners gangster movies of the 1930s, even if the microscopic detail often threatens to derail the narrative.
Mullan's partial fabrication of Laing's well-documented story robs Mad to Be Normal of authority at every turn.
Pits a white and black colleague against each other in a film light on social commentary and heavy on crude humour.
The turbulent story presented here inevitably becomes a cautionary rather than celebratory tale.
It's smattered with gore and overacting, and ultimately good for nothing.
A deliberate rebuke to the short shrift that LGBT issues were given in the classic 1980s Brat Pack movies, offering just enough heart to overcome what it lacks in depth.
While Dornan merely pouts and smoulders, Johnson is again the major selling point, making something likable and human out of the cipher that is Anastasia.
It's a genuinely experimental film, intermittently successful despite a punishing lack of depth in the characterisations.
F Javier Gutiérrez's 'threequel' arrives a decade late to the party with little new to offer.
There's not much visually for Jackson to focus on other than the wigs and talking heads - the best of which belong to Wilkinson and Scott, managing to imbue proceedings with energy and character.
iBoy has an original-enough concept, taken from a book by Kevin Brooks, but any freshness is muffled by the dated gangster movie clichés peppered throughout the script.
It would take a cold heart not to feel some uplift from Aisholpan's game-changing triumph against the odds.

The Edge of Seventeen may not revolutionise the sub-genre, but it's more articulate than most and harks back visually and thematically to the seriousness of John Hughes's The Breakfast Club, still the mother lode of disturbed teen movies.
Zappa and his music may rarely have been fashionable, but this documentary provides a valuable and permanent record of the man himself; his musical canon can be enjoyed elsewhere.
movie_title: Eat That Question: Frank Zappa in His Own Words (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Sullenberger's heroics made for a great news story, now, in the capable hands of director and star, they are the foundations for a riveting, cinematic drama.
Your Name offers audiences intellect, wonder and tears in equal measure.
The refinement of Schamus's storytelling is up to the task of evoking the novel's honest, yet complex notions, making this the best Roth adaptation in decades.
'Do you think the internet can dream of itself?' is the kind of gnarly enquiry Herzog puts to his experts, and their detailed answers are recorded with friendly gravitas.
movie_title: Lo and Behold, Reveries of the Connected World (2016)

movie_review_blurb: While not for everyone, this old-fashioned adventure with a fresh twist may gain a cult following of those interested in how two French directors challenge the cookie-cutter narrative of most animations.
Small children might just find the film's energy enough to please, but the plot-holes stop Storks from taking flight.
Theroux has created an amusing documentary, but one which rarely lands a meaningful punch on its easily demonised subject.
Ross manages the similarly rustic set-pieces with considerable visceral style, helped by McConaughey's haunted, intense presence.
Sausage Party is rude, funny and unexpectedly profound in places, with the juvenile humour leavened by some thoughtful commentary on modern life.
Popstar: Never Stop Never Stopping fails to generate any genuine laughs.
Bad Moms is actually pretty good when it comes to raising a smile to two.
Nine Lives is a real cat-astrophe for all concerned.

Never attempting to scale the more ambitious heights of a Pixar, Collision Course is a brisk, innocuous entry in a series that places silliness and colour before narrative drive, character or originality.
If some of the jokes drag a little (the jibes at Clarence's George Michael fixation go on way too long), it's hard to complain when there are so many funny flights of fancy.
Neill and Dennison's chemistry ensures this unusual survival story is so knee-deep in charm that even moments of gloopy pathos feel thoroughly earned.
Professionally mounted, but too familiar to provide anything other than routine jump-scares.
As a movie, The Boss Baby just doesn't have the kind of lovable concept that makes for a great family animation, although Baldwin's vocal performance raises a few indulgent smiles.

By the Law is essentially a three hander, played in the familiar silent style of wide-eyes and grand gestures; by stripping Edith's backstory out of London's story, Kuleshov's characters seem to have been fashioned to carry an obvious political message.
What makes this work as cinema is that Burden's creations have such visual power. The artist may be gone but, on the screen, he lives forever.

Wilson and Helms are the right leads for this odd couple tale of friction between a laidback bum and his uptight sibling, but the central conceit (that women enjoying sexual freedom is funny) no longer passes for a joke.
The climax, when it comes, is yet more of the fumbled plotting that has made the Fifty Shades films a trial to watch.
The Tad franchise has the sense to steal from the best, even if such copy-cat strategies deprive the hero of any unique character of his own.
movie_title: Tad the Lost Explorer and the Secret of King Midas (Tadeo Jones 2: El secreto del Rey Midas) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Comes up fresh due to a strong cast, large-scale production, and a narrative scope that dodges difficult political questions.
If you're prepared to do a little philosophical heavy-lifting for yourself, it's a thoughtful and persuasive invitation to a world of meditation.
As a film, Brigsby Bear is as lovable as the title character himself.

This is a bible-based, animated adventure for children, with the emphasis on cute comedy and familiar pious tropes; it's somewhat dry and bland, but simplicity and an over-qualified voice cast help see it through.
This powerful film is an absolute must for anyone looking to gain a better understanding of the issues involved.
The trademark irreverence keeps proceedings likeable, and in the face of such an onslaught of swearing, casual drug-use and cheerful excess, it seems churlish to complain.
An espionage-flavoured take on the Sasquatch myth, with directors Ben Stassen and Jeremy Degruson hitting the right, child-centric tone.

Byun delivers a taut and visceral slice of machismo; a tough, gaudy entry in the Korean crime cycle that's likely to expand the ever-growing fanbase for this kind of blood-drenched, bare-knuckle fare.
Bombastic and noisy, yet minuscule in emotional heft, it's a geostorm in a teacup.
It's cute, simple and surefooted enough to deliver a dog-and-pony show that the target audience, at least, are likely to adore.
By tapping into the innate power of great art, Kobiela and Welchman's drama adds up to more than the novelty of its sumptuous parts.

As with Bill Forsyth's best work, the film's bonhomie might just have universal appeal; such gentle humour may be lost on some, but Whisky Galore! offers a true taste of Scotland that's well worth acquiring.
While the franchise needs a rest, the film's slapstick sense of fun should satisfy even the most hyperactive imagination.
Audiences who like to imagine that they could make a better film themselves may well, in this instance, be correct.
With the titular beast onscreen for just a fraction of the two-hour runtime, those outside Japan may feel that this latest incarnation of Godzilla is a lot less fun than it should be.
Motor-racing may still be a man's world, but this account of a strong woman's triumph reveals a very personal and affecting hidden story.
The metaphor of superpowers equalling sober potential is good, but the careless development would barely fill a ten-minute short, making American Hero something of a slog.
Recent interviews with most of the protagonists weave a complex narrative of fame, failure and fatigue, narrated in a very un-Scottish drawl by Kim Deal from The Breeders / Pixies.
Gill's debut offers nothing but incessant needle-drops instead of drama; modern life may be rubbish, but there's no need for modern romances to be so utterly naff.
Huston has conjured up a tough but rewarding story of real-life pain and hard-won healing.
It's basically one long training montage, from about ten minutes in until ten minutes from the end.
Morals about moving on from the past and embracing new friends might have seemed pat if Holm's film were not so deft in the pithy observations it makes about life's random, too-often cruel nature.
movie_title: A Man Called Ove (En man som heter Ove) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A weird and not particularly wonderful animation for children.
Although director Stuart Hazeldine's drama preaches to the converted, it retains the simple strengths which made the book so widely read.

It's to Harrelson's credit that Wilson's occasional charm just about outweighs the unpleasant aspects of his character for most of the 94-minute runtime, as he staggers through one excruciatingly painful situation after another.
A breathtaking debut feature, simply drawn, rich in texture, and warm of heart.
The veteran director gives a professional gloss to A Dog's Purpose, but all the skill in the world can't make this dog's dinner palatable.
Offers a cheap, but sufficiently cheerful rumble in the jungle.
movie_title: The Jungle Bunch (Les as de la jungle) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: As an extended sketch about the meeting of two remarkable figures, Elvis & Nixon manages to capture why the public retain such curiosity for these influential, eccentric men.
Overdrive provides just enough crash-and-burn stunt action to satisfy undemanding thrill-seekers, but not much else.
Although likely to be remembered as a misfire, there's lots of entertainment to be derived from the oddball mixture of lofty ambition and barrel-scraping comedy.
A minor pleasure for undemanding B movie fans.
Rock's scattershot film may not be for the ages, but at least developing a personal angle has allowed him to get his groove back.
Fans of the first film will note the problematic lack of balance; without Cusack's notably sour contribution, Hot Tub Time Machine 2 sinks in a sea of its own bodily fluids.
A sombre, intelligent tale of readjustment and personal healing.
Enjoyable hokum.
The Signal might seem like just another entry for the ongoing pile of lo-fi, stargazing fare, but a few unexpected virtues help it resonate more than most.
Likely to be received with delight by the kids and stoic grimness by restless adults.
Home's infantilism is a regressive step for DreamWorks, offering a sour rather than sweet experience for audiences.
Part political exposé, part character study, Kill the Messenger feels too much like a polemic, and too little like a human drama, failing to entertain as well as it informs.
While its intentions were probably high-minded, the only reaction Stonehearst Asylum is likely to induce is hoots of derisive laughter.
A small-scale but heartfelt drama that delivers a simple and effective message about the importance of political freedom.

It's a film swamped with the worst kind of glitzy Hollywood distraction, while the problem at the centre of the story - Doug's lack of genuine friends - is a subject that The Wedding Ringer's mirthless razzamatazz completely fails to address.
The humour is mostly crotch-level and initial bonhomie gives way to tiresome violence in a largely joke-free finale.
The Gambler is a remake that effectively updates a subtle yet nihilistic story; Wyatt and Monahan stick to their mean-spirited guns and offer up a sour view of addiction and the havoc it wreaks.
Eastwood's infectious sympathy for Kyle and ease with the actors and action ultimately triumphs over the film's lack of engagement with either marital or wider political issues.
Recaptures the magic intermittently.
Penguins of Madagascar passes the time pleasantly without expanding the franchise's universe in a particularly imaginative or challenging way.
Changing golfing traditions may be an unexpectedly hot topic in 2016, but Tommy's Honour offers misty-eyed melodrama rather than any real insight into sporting history.
Diplomacy is a tiny film that hits a big target.
Such lameness is all the more disappointing considering how much more tightly Donaldson once pulled together a similar package in the 1987 Kevin Costner spy drama No Way Out.
While deeply unfashionable, Night Train to Lisbon's old-school, historically aware melodrama seduces during some compelling stretches, and reasserts August as a filmmaker of real ability.
Dolphin Tale 2 plays out in a fairly tedious way; there's a brief period in a child's development when they will actively seek new and serious drama, yet might still accept fare as bland as this.
It's the work of intelligent filmmakers with a welcome willingness to shoot for the big questions of life, the universe and everything.
Despite laudably aiming for originality much of Braff's second film plays out as self-pitying Hollywood schmaltz.

By adding spurious action and making the characters older than in the novel, the makers of The Giver sell-out the story; a project which prizes individuality shouldn't so slavishly adhere to the Divergent-school of teenage drama.
The Boxtrolls is impressively nasty fare for gothic fantasists of all ages.
Sex Tape is brisk but annoyingly light on laughs, a slight fumbling of an idea that deserved a more rigorous exploration.
Hamm's charm works well playing a debonair scoundrel on television but in this bland, family friendly offering, it's a resource that's quickly drained.

Alleluia is an unpleasantly perverse psychodrama that certainly delivers on the nastiness of the premise; Dueñas and Lucas both give intense performances, and the result is enough to make both sexes think twice about online romance.
The tonal shifts of a Bollywood blockbuster sit uneasily in Arrambam.
There's a lot for genre fans to like, from Dujardin's winning central performance to an eclectic soundtrack that sets a montage of street crime to Al Wilson's classic song 'The Snake'.
Robot Overlords feels like yet another busted franchise pilot in search of an audience. It's too brash for families, too babyish and obvious for teens.
It's a sympathetic portrait of a tortured genius battling introversion, medication and hangers-on.
It's a proficient but forgettable comedy well-suited to the raucous nature of its star.

Parents will at least recognise their old favourites in Top Cat Begins - with it replicating the kind of silly, simple knockabout routines that should be right up the alley of the cat's original fans.

movie_review_blurb: Viewers will be mystified by the existence of this copy of a copy of a British TV show that passed its sell-by date more than three decades ago.

Blandly photographed and unexceptionally acted, The Longest Ride is a typically generic love story from the Sparks production line.

As simple and well-meaning as Charlie himself, it's an old-fashioned delight.

movie_review_blurb: It's harmless, albeit cliché riddled, fun for youngsters, and it doesn't make grown-ups wish they had two hours of their life back.
Ryan's Kallen is painfully two-dimensional.
It's an engaging story about how overwhelming greed can turn a silk purse into a sow's ear.
Completely lacks the nobility, statue, and credibility due such an amazing story, even if it is an old man's folly.
The spectre of Alzheimer's disease hovers abstrusely over this South Korean remake of the 2008 Hollywood film Lovely, Still.
A tomb-raiding adventure film that entertains sporadically with supernatural elements, but bores you to sleep whenever anyone starts talking.
The pleasure of this belated sequel [to 2006's Marriage with a Fool] stems as much from [the protagonists'] deepening insight about marriage as it does from the impressive supporting cast.
movie_title: Anniversary (Fen shou zai shuo wo ai ni) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A respectable action drama that doesn't try to replicate the pleasure of its predecessors, instead admirably turning to contemplate Ip's priorities in life.
Speaking candidly to both heart and mind, Ten Years realises some of Hong Kong natives' greatest apprehensions at a time when the city's social landscape is fast becoming unrecognisable.
A slow-burning true crime story that only indulges its sensationalistic premise in brief doses, the film weaves a complex web of psychological turmoil around [its] characters.
This is solid proof that dynamic sports footage does not make an effective crime thriller.
A full-on homage to the best of Hong Kong pop culture from the 1980s and '90s.
A deceptively tranquil drama about grief and moving on. Zinnia Flower is both visceral and contemplative and will likely leave an indelible impression on the more patient viewers.
Johnnie To's consummate flair as a visual stylist is on full display in [this] 3D musical adapted for the screen by actress-scriptwriter Sylvia Chang from her first written play, Design for Living.
The beloved characters from the hit TVB drama Return of the Cuckoo (2000) make a wholly avoidable comeback in this exploitative big-screen sequel.
Based on the real-life story of a cancer patient who blogged about her last months ... the film's infectiously optimistic outlook should win over the casual viewers.
[The film] doles out its stories of lost ideals and ephemeral friendships with all their bittersweet repercussions -- before losing its plot to absurd coincidences and banal revelations.
Anchored by a quietly devastating turn by Zhao, the film is at its most poignant when it observes the palpable feelings ... that are running through her character.
movie_title: Mountains May Depart (Shan he gu ren) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A startlingly immersive film that gives the illusion -- at once inspiring and heartbreaking -- that you're in the presence of the late great American novelist David Foster Wallace.
Graceful and elegiac, Mr. Holmes is a poignant meditation on mortality that just so happens to feature the world's greatest detective in the lead.
[A] surprisingly witty big-screen adaptation. Even the old-fashioned aura of the stories ... finds an excellent balance between nostalgia and bracing self-reflection.
The viewer is advised to simply surrender to the wave of sentimentality.
Here's a space travel epic that digs deep into technicalities and still manages to be tremendously thrilling and fun.
Gyllenhaal continues his streak of idiosyncratic roles ... and lends the film the strong emotions it fails to conjure with its feeble script.
Our Little Sister is an uneventful, if also overwhelmingly life-affirming, family portrait that once again establishes Koreeda as one of today's pre-eminent humanist filmmakers.
This blend of abduction thriller and police procedural ... is an entertaining genre exercise that methodically reshuffles its timeline to fend off predictability.
Nothing hurts more than being friend-zoned. Or, at least, that's the conclusion likely to be drawn ... in this alternately heart-warming and disheartening tale about learning to let go.
movie_title: A Journey Through Time With Antony (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A mildly pleasant ride thanks to its amiable leading duo, a gently observant script and some witty little commentaries on America's cultural diversity.
[A] gentle story about making the most of one's confined existence, it culminates in a simple yet enchanting fable about life's infinite small pleasures.
The genius of It Follows lies in the simplicity of its set-up. ... In Mitchell's intensely creepy movie, the dread only keeps on building until the end.
Soi Cheang's second contribution to the franchise is a vastly improved production that marks the finest attempt yet at adapting Journey to the West for an effects-driven blockbuster.
movie_title: The Monkey King 2 (San Da Bai Gu Jing) (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Allen's suspenseful movie is so cynically narrated, it soon morphs into an existential comedy of an improbably high order.
At long last a disaster movie that doesn't upset the randomness of suffering by compelling the heroes to save the world or the obnoxious side characters to meet their ironic comeuppance.
The Tag-Along has become one of Taiwan's highest grossing horror flicks in living memory -- without even the benefit of being especially original or memorable.
Alternately exhilarating and terrifying, The Jungle Book offers a hyper-realistic view of the forest as a place of natural hierarchy, unpredictable menace, and cross-species camaraderie.

The subtle differences between stage and film acting are amplified to often enthralling and sometimes painfully contrived effects in this part-adaptation, part-reimagination of French Kiss, Candace Chong's hit 2005 play.

Nicholas Stoller's film throws up surprises in the way it tackles gay marriage and female empowerment without irony and extracts poignancy from Seth Rogen and Zac Efron's returning man-child characters.
Chongqing Hot Pot is an awkward blend of friendship drama and heist thriller that unwittingly trades all its narrative intrigue for senseless violence in the final third.
Even if you are allergic to the manipulative tactics of tear-jerking cancer dramas, there's still a lot to savour [here] ... Patrons of the sniffle are in for more than they usually bargain for.

An ordinary citizen is turned into a mutant fish-man during a faulty genetic experiment in [this] mildly intriguing, if also rather predictable, satire on the South Korean society's self-serving tendencies.
For all its sexually charged sequences, In the Room is really more about the lingering sadness that results from the transient encounters it depicts.

A social allegory of sorts, this gratuitously gory hostage drama ... could have packed a stronger punch if it didn't indulge in plot turns so incredulous, that they could only fit into a supernatural fantasy.
It is a truth universally acknowledged, that a single Chinese woman in their late 20s or beyond, must be in desperate want of a husband. ... Dime-a-dozen leftover-stigma clichés.
movie_title: The Last Women Standing (Sheng zhe wei wang) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A perceptive film that has the self-awareness to make innocuous fun of the much stereotyped expat experience. ... It's sure to enchant with its lavish display of the city's alluring night lights.
This 1930s-set drama chronicling events leading to the deportation of a little-known, real-life Irish political activist is a graceful digest of Loach's signature motifs.
An exemplary showcase of gritty, no-holds-barred action filmmaking.
Family discord takes a maddening turn in Wonder Mama, a humanistic drama beset by unbearable histrionics.
There is so much goodwill in Danny Collins that even its characters' struggles are made to feel frothy.
If Jafar Panahi was still looking to show the power of artistic expression over the filmmaking ban placed on him ... he has found an ideal approach with his new film - in good humour.
Pitch Perfect 2 offers just what its audience wants: catchy musical numbers, celebrity cameos and sometimes very un-PC jokes.
The film offers a resounding experience for anyone remotely interested in the way we watch movies.
Kill Time is a frustratingly fragmented film that doesn't always convince with its sprawling, decades-spanning saga of illegitimate desire and unconsummated love.
movie_title: Kill Time (Mou sha si shui nian hua) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: This casually xenophobic action thriller would require fantastical conviction in American supremacy, if not a perverted desire for excessive, racist brutality to [truly enjoy].
While it's also adapted from Wang Dulu's five-part Crane-Iron novel series, the new film ... feels like a slapdash piece of fan fiction.
movie_title: Crouching Tiger, Hidden Dragon: Sword of Destiny (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The Lunar New Year comedy comes across as a C-movie that's been mistakenly bestowed the budget of a tent-pole production.
movie_title: From Vegas To Macau 3 (From Vegas To Macau Iii) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: With its breathtaking photography and a still-unparalleled sense of wonder, the film demonstrated Kubrick's single-minded focus to inspire awe in his audience.
Should any pop star wish to stroke his own ego by leaping into the film director's seat, he could at least handle it more subtly than Richie Jen does with this fawning debut.
movie_title: All You Need Is Love (Luo pao ba ai qing) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The second installment of Hong Kong actor-director Stephen Fung's steampunk martial arts trilogy shows an encouraging restraint in its stylistic approach and finds a much sharper focus on its storytelling.

The heartening story of a young girl realising her singing talent is tempered by the borderline offensive portrayal of her deaf and mute farming parents ... as a pair of clowns that serve as the butt of most jokes.
Irrespective of its slapdash plotting, Full Strike is still very much a showcase of Cantonese comedy at its irreverent best.
As much as it resembles a conspiracy thriller in which data encryption is a survival tactic, Citizenfour must be considered, above all, a journalistic achievement.
Murmur of the Hearts is a quiet and sometimes strangely moving story about the search for closure; it is also one of Chang's best directorial efforts to date.
This behind-the-scenes documentary ... has at least proven its worth in capturing a pivotal moment in the Paris fashion house's legacy.
Helios ultimately plays like a political farce relying on deafening shoot-outs to temper its overwhelming silliness.
Hardy and Rapace provide a solid emotional anchor as a couple brought together by fear and tightened by survival instinct.
The preposterousness of [the story] is offset by Crowe's powerful depiction of the horrors of war for both the Australians and Turks.
Xue Xiaolu's Seattle- and New York-set romantic comedy is nothing you haven't seen before -- although it's also pleasant enough to disarm you with its sweetness.
movie_title: Bei Jing yu shang Xi Ya Tu (2013)

movie_review_blurb: [Son of Saul] has moulded the Nazi death camp testimony into a first-person narrative experiment unlike any other fiction film before it.
Stephen Chow's Journey To The West: Conquering The Demons is a thoroughly entertaining action comedy that suggests, a la Woody Allen, a promising new life behind the screen for the actor-director.
The slapstick humour in Lost In Thailand is hardly vicious but occasionally very effective.
Despite its run-of-the-mill characterisation, this second feature by director Boo Ji-young largely engages with its sincere attempt at social critique.

A frenetic kids' film that is chock-full of madcap energy, throwaway sight gags and very silly puns, Angry Birds should most please those who are willing to relinquish their cynicism and go with the flow.
A sumptuously realised detective mystery that merges Holmesian deductions with shootouts, explosions and action sequences -- some of which are shown with slow-motion bravado.
Having spent much of his career filtering good humour through very bad taste, writer-director Pang Ho-cheung delivers arguably his naughtiest picture to date with a pitch-black comedy.
Visually inventive yet dramatically lacking.
movie_title: The Flying Swords of Dragon Gate (2012)

movie_review_blurb: Takashi Miike's live-action adaptation of the long-running anime series Nintama Rantaro is a hilarious family movie that will handsomely reward younger viewers and fans of the original, but might inevitably alienate the uninitiated.
Sadly, the film also seems to be in a race with its ensemble cast to see which will first lose its sanity completely -- and the film wins by a fraction.
movie_title: Hi, Fidelity (Cheut gwai dik nui yan) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: A relentlessly sweet and entertaining urban rom-com.
movie_title: Don't Go Breaking My Heart (Daan gyun naam yu) (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Yu's increasingly sombre portrait of loyalty and violent revenge is partly let down by his story's uniformly superficial characterisation.
Sufficiently diverting yet predictable enough to be just the perfect fodder for genre cinema enthusiasts.
The soul of this movie is really in its tireless references to the historical and social conditions of 1950s and 60s Hong Kong, whose street views are recreated in vibrant, saturated colours.
It is at once loyal to the Hong Kong director's aesthetic sensibilities and the myriad of martial arts traditions that he's gone to exhaustive length to pay homage to.
A relentlessly entertaining romancer.
A solid if unremarkable take on the final years of the famed warlord Cao Cao.
In Tsui's hands, the communist propaganda classic becomes a handy platform to showcase his craftsmanship.
An absorbing tale of crime and non-punishment set after the bursting of Japan's bubble economy.
A San Francisco-set fantasy in which [Blake Lively] plays out a Benjamin Button-like existence through some truly awkward romantic situations.
This poor man's Whiplash never quite conveys the depths of its protagonists' struggles.
This rom-com ... is so hackneyed it might be more fun counting the cliches than cheering for its male lead, now stranded light years away from his former James Bond glow.
This entertaining Bollywood musical is so relentlessly buoyant in its charge to ask the big questions it comes close to reaching an epiphany.
Considering the star power of its two leads, it is a pity that this film wasn't conceived as more of a two-hander.
movie_title: A Tale of Three Cities (San cheng ji) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: While Wu's pop cultural spoofs are largely hit-and-miss ... his creativity fades as Undercover Duet gradually ditches its Hong Kong setting to become a mediocre Shanghai-set action thriller.
As strands of storyline feverishly tie themselves up through twists and coincidences, the double and triple crosses fade in impact next to the poise of Choi's all-star cast.
The fight scenes ... are staged in the filmmaker's typically professional fashion, and the thrilling car chases in populated areas flaunt a blissful ignorance of civilian casualties.
The importance of ageing gracefully is examined with both humour and pain in the sharply observed While We're Young, a satire that's more brutally honest than it is impertinent.
This existentialist meditation on free will and murderous impulses may be worthy of Kafka or Camus ... One of the most perversely original fantasy movies in recent memory.
movie_title: Attack on Titan: Part 1 (Shingeki no kyojin) (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The Assassin summons a strangely rapturous experience from its ostensibly bewildering narrative, which only adds to the air of mystique. An instant classic.
A hot-blooded movie with a sophisticated view of the high-pressure pursuits of pro riders.
This vampire parody transcends its one-joke nature to yield extended hilarity.
movie_title: What We Do In The Shadows (2015)

movie_review_blurb: This spirited movie is a tour de force in bringing enchanting form to abstract ideas.
Paris is where broken hearts go to heal - or so this insipid travel commercial of a film would like us to infer from its sporadically amusing, though never remotely credible, romantic story.
Monster Hunt is far more engaging as cultural commentary than as entertainment.
The second English-language feature by Amélie's Jean-Pierre Jeunet is a road movie that has captured its visually striking journey in glorious 3D.
movie_title: The Young And Prodigious T.S. Spivet (2015)

movie_review_blurb: A stately backstage drama that gradually morphs into a full-blown supernatural horror movie, [this is] a synthetic experience that sporadically intrigues but never fully engages.
Despite its origin as a shoujo manga (for teenage girls), this abridged version is incongruously at its weakest when it deals with matters of the heart.
Although screenwriter David Nicholls' seriously rushed, trimmed and modified adaptation has created large discrepancies with the book, this ... remains a strangely engrossing film.
Infinitely Polar Bear features an endearing turn by Mark Ruffalo and will bring a smile to your face.
It feels like a music video that refuses to end.
This gay-themed romance will likely break a few hearts with its devastating tale about finding one's place in the world.
This fourth instalment does well to supplement the 3D spectacle with lively characters and good humour.
A heartfelt production that should find its place in Hong Kong's stagnant prison movie tradition.
movie_title: Imprisoned: Survival Guide for Rich and Prodigal (2015)

movie_review_blurb: You don't want to be in Adam Sandler's shoes right now.
Essentially a dusk-till-dawn party film with a paper-thin plot and an open invitation to the audience to exult along.
It is ironic that Criminal - which features a maverick neuroscientist character and spins its nutty story around a pioneering brain operation - should prove to be such a brainless genre exercise.
A convoluted tale of capricious human relationships and questionable moral conduct, the film is anchored by the unassuming charisma of Haru Kuroki.
movie_title: A Bride for Rip Van Winkle (Rippu van winkuru no hanayome) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: An artfully presented film about two lovers who can't stop torturing themselves with their self-serving tendency and inexplicable aloofness.
Aside from its allegory about power, Wu Kong as an effects-driven action fantasy is just not very entertaining.
Ozon has at least scored on one count: L'Amant Double is so gloriously and unpredictably kinky that it manages to make Fifty Shades of Grey look like child's play.

The best way to screen this might well be as an infomercial at sake conventions, where viewers are free to sample minutes-long clips set against an incessant soundtrack of bland, easy-listening music.
movie_title: Kampai! For the Love of Sake (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A wacky family comedy imbued with a touch of lazily scripted sci-fi fantasy that suggests it's pitched at pre-teens.
Hui makes the most of her cast - boasting a notable number of Hong Kong Film Awards winners - to fashion an unapologetically human drama.
Made in Hong Kong forms the first part of Fruit Chan Gor's "1997 Trilogy", and is shot with a rawness and urgency that would in time become the writer-director's signature.
Mad World is not quite the profound reflection of reality its makers intended it to be, but despite its flaws this is a brave film.

77 Heartbreaks, despite its peculiar premise, has nothing interesting to say about contemporary mating mores, although I was surprised -- and occasionally amused -- by its long line of supporting stars.
A respectable period action drama that frequently loses its steam to redundant scenes.

Shunning the crowd-pleasing, life-affirming tendencies of mainstream dance movies, Polina instead offers a lyrical and introspective look at the intricate process of finding one's true artistic calling.
A sensual and uncompromisingly heartbreaking account of a one-night stand that fizzles out into two lives of lingering regrets.
This CGI spectacle largely transcends its genre clichés with its relentlessly earnest desire to please.
movie_title: Legend Of The Naga Pearls (Jiao Zhu Chuan) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: With Prisoners offers a nightmarish account of institutional depravity, one said by its makers to be based on real events.
A quirky yet predictable film made special by its reverence for inspired cooking, the directorial debut of Hong Kong editor Derek Hui is more food porn than romantic comedy.
movie_title: This Is Not What I Expected (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's fun, but a little frivolous.
The true-life medical drama is less likely to bring awareness to a very rare autoimmune disorder than it is to be consumed as a low-rent imitator of Safe, Todd Haynes' 1995 parable.
The Salesman is a meticulously plotted moral puzzle that, once again, shows how great art can transcend the deeply restrained culture it springs from.
This big-budget action comedy is so sloppily written and utterly derivative that it may struggle to register in your mind even before end credits roll.
While it's a tonally uneven and sometimes implausibly scripted popcorn movie, Love Contractually would have been far less gratifying if not for its pair of very pleasant leads.
Yau does an impressive job of keeping the audience engaged amid the barrage of car crashes, shoot-outs and explosions.
Fukada's film sidesteps easy catharsis to stage a serious, and quite emotionally intense, inquiry into the unknown shades of human nature.
It'll likely take a diehard Hong fan to truly admire this dreamily scripted fare, lacking as it does the writer-director's usually rigorous musing on fate and perception.
movie_title: On the Beach at Night Alone (Bamui haebyun-eoseo honja) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The raw emotions of young love are captured in alternately ecstatic and frustrating fashion in Drowning Love, based on George Asakura's eponymous manga series.
Put aside your longing for a conventional narrative, and Tran's exquisite tone poem could yet prove to be one of the most beautifully poignant films you'll come across in some time.
MacLaine is the only reason this movie works.
An adequate homage to the comedic tradition immortalised by Mr Vampire (1985) and its sequels.
movie_title: Vampire Cleanup Department (Gao geung jing dou fu) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: It's a shame how the heavyweight cast and exotic European locations are wasted on such a derivative story.
Its corny display of nationalist pride aside, Wu's superior sequel to the laughably scripted Wolf Warrior should at least satisfy genre audiences with its slam-bang action.
It is this adult fairy tale's uninhibited embrace of love in all its euphoric glory that renders The Shape of Water such an unexpected delight.
Youth's conflicted narrative conveys the loss of innocence of its young characters fascinatingly.
The supernatural murder mystery is crammed so full with dazzling visuals and convoluted exposition that viewers are advised to surrender to this fever dream - or give up entirely.
For all the shape-shifting antics and giant fantasy creatures that it throws at the audience, Dunjia is only ever as fun as its characters get.
This hand-drawn animated feature by first-time directors Christian Desmares and Franck Ekinci is a steampunk marvel that will enchant both kids and adults with its high-concept premise.
movie_title: April and the Extraordinary World (Avril et le monde truqué) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: While far from being coherent, actress-turned director Sandra Ng's first feature does boast enough scenes of inspired hilarity to offset its less effective moments.
This time-travelling romance by Hsieh Chun-yi strikes an unexpectedly poignant chord beneath its teen comedy facade.
The White Girl is at once a self-proclaimed love letter to Hong Kong and an inadvertent middle finger to the art of sensible screenwriting.
[It] is ultimately more memorable for the chilling performances of its trio of actresses than for its story, which turns into a spectacle of family dysfunction and moral depravity.
movie_title: The Bold, the Corrupt, and the Beautiful (2017)

movie_review_blurb: While [Chrissie] Chau has given one of her most delicate performances to date, it is [Joyce] Cheng who steals the show with a heart-melting display of joy and compassion.
Tightly paced and at times overly melodramatic, Woo's film is a ridiculous but very enjoyable action thriller.
Few genre fans should feel short-changed by Yip's brutal action showcase.
It's just too bad that this waterlogged thriller is as technically impressive as it is narratively dubious.
Singer-actress Stephy Tang has never commanded the screen to quite the extent she does in this karate-themed character drama.
Dealer/Healer is by turns a violent action movie, a buddy comedy, a cheesy romance and even a terminal disease drama - and never finds the right tone for this schizophrenic mix.
The world of high finance makes an awkward crossover into the realm of soft-core sex romp with this curious dud from producer Ng Kin-hung.
The extreme measures by which Japanese politicians and bureaucrats rise through the ranks are ruthlessly satirised in this hilariously over-the-top high-school electoral drama.
movie_title: Teiichi: Battle of Supreme High (Teiichi no kuni) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: While it doesn't tell the most entertaining of stories, the meandering drama does slowly reveal itself to be a powerful statement on suicide prevention.
Chasing the Dragon will be remembered more as a Donnie Yen showcase than a Crippled Ho biopic.
Fireworks merely proves an ill-advised endeavour to tweak the original drama's musings on early adolescent desire and small quirks of luck into a full-on fantasy romance.
movie_title: Fireworks, Should We See It from the Side or the Bottom? (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Revenge plots don't get more contrived and illogical than they do in this stylish yet unashamedly superficial homage to the spaghetti western subgenre.
Although The Tag-Along 2 is short of creative scares, the film qualifies as more than passable entertainment with its tightly woven storylines and strong performances.
movie_title: The Tag-Along 2 (Hong yi xiao nu hai 2) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A mellow look at the tragic ends of several veterans of the criminal underworld, Colour of the Game ... veers towards the violent fatalism that colours much of Johnnie To's work.
The increasingly absurd societal values of post-handover Hong Kong receive rollicking parody treatment in The Sinking City: Capsule Odyssey, a vibrant and furiously funny comedy-thriller.
[The film] does manage to blend romantic comedy, sport film tropes and ensemble human drama into a pleasant if mostly unsurprising whole.
A thoroughly engaging drama that is peppered with both improbably dark humour and pungent attempts at social commentary.
Regular viewers of serial killer dramas - from Se7en to all those Death Note movies - may feel like they've seen it all before.
movie_title: The Liquidator (Xinli Zui Zhi Chengshi Zhi Guang) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: My Sassy Girl star Cha Tae-hyun plays an inadvertent Cupid in this fantasy melodrama, which merely treats its farfetched body-swapping premise as a convenient [narrative] device.
All those thrilling set-pieces may leave one feeling a little hollow inside; but for action film buffs, Christmas has come early.
This post-Holocaust drama, while admittedly quite engrossing to watch, can't avoid coming across as overly streamlined to offer easy catharsis for a mainstream audience.
Never Gone will likely struggle to get the audience on the side of its infuriatingly fickle heroine despite an endearing turn by Crystal Liu.
There's no doubt Trine Dyrholm - named best actress at the 2016 Berlin Film Festival for her emotionally intense portrayal of Anna - owns the movie's best moments.
It'd be very hard to think of a more pointless reboot than writer-director Jeff Lau Chun-wai's A Chinese Odyssey Part Three.
At a time when fears of political inference in the ICAC's role as a guardian of rule of law in Hong Kong are growing, S Storm is not even good propaganda.
Neal Wu paints a sensitive portrait of the strains of a long-distance relationship, and the film offers an unexpectedly bleak account of how people can grow apart.
Erased's fragmented and convoluted narrative may give viewers the impression it is a patiently staged, grippingly told psychological mystery, but they soon discover what an illogical mess it is.
Toho's 29th entry in the Godzilla franchise may prove too talky for some, but still manages to pay loving homage to the lumbering anti-hero of Ishiro Honda's 1954 classic.
Bi Gan's art-house gem is a narrative experiment which intuitively bridges social realism and magic realism to tell a story of great emotional resonance.
Benny Chan's best film in years - a Chinese wuxia epic with obvious echoes to classic spaghetti Western films and Akira Kurosawa's samurai dramas like Seven Samurai and Yojimbo.
Bittersweet should enchant foodies - although the film's tendency to pass gay stereotypes as humour may ruffle the feathers of more sensitive viewers.
Less a harrowing survival tale than a sweet-natured talking-animal cartoon for young children. ... This is pleasant but entirely frivolous fare.
The best condition to consume this wacky action fantasy - not that you should feel obliged to - is intoxicated.
Audiences from any culture should be able to learn from some of the potentially world-changing ideas paraded in this informative feature.
Bounty Hunters is a Chinese-Korean espionage comedy that intermittently amuses but never comes across as being remotely plausible.
A slice-of-life drama in which very little happens, After the Storm derives great emotional resonance from the subtlest indications of family ties - or lack thereof.
movie_title: After the Storm (Umi yori mo mada fukaku) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A minor work by a master craftsman, Johnnie To's Three tells a haphazardly scripted and weirdly paced story with intermittent flashes of technical brilliance.
Cold War 2 is competently plotted, tautly edited and superbly acted across the board. This is a political thriller that deserves the billing.
It says much about the colourful characters, thrilling action and inventive visual effects that Chen Sicheng's odd-couple caper never gets tedious over its 135-minute duration.

While its high-concept story touches on everything from assisted suicide and parental absence, to the emptiness of material wealth, this very dark film is, at its core, a conventional romantic comedy.
A genre mishmash that goes from exorcism drama to gangster comedy to zombie horror to supernatural romance. ... Nick Cheung has obviously done enough to set himself up for a sequel.
You're not going to hear people talking plot twists or modern spins about this umpteenth take on Johanna Spyri's classic children's story. ... Handsomely crafted, if uncompromisingly old-fashioned.
Its narrative makes little sense, but the film is so entertaining audiences will overlook its ludicrous plotting and identify with the protagonists.
This is that rare bromance movie in which the lads are less connected via women and drugs than by their intense, cerebral pursuits.
While the film eventually settles on Kurosawa's favourite themes of familial breakdown and the evocative sway of evil, it is the queasy ambience that will stay with you long after it's all over.
If Watkins has done anything well, it's that he never pauses the action to consider the ridiculousness of it all.
This lurid and disorienting story of an old man out for revenge is a Memento-like narrative puzzle enhanced by the immense presence of Christopher Plummer.
A relationship parable for the digital age, Perfect Strangers pits our deceitful natures against our dependence on smartphones, to mostly engaging effect.
This lushly coloured romantic fable is a bit like the pantomime cousin of Wong's 2046, in which a lovelorn Tony Leung also philosophises in frequent voice-over about the fate of those around him.
A thrilling but sometimes illogical piece of pulp entertainment that is crafted with impressive style.
movie_title: Death Note: Light Up the New World (Desu nôto: Light Up the New World) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: [It] begins as an endearing comedy about the psychology of romance, before switching tone and morphing into a laborious will-she-won't-she melodrama with few surprises to offer.
Masahiro Motoki makes it all a joy to watch, lending a complex touch of humanity to an unlikeable role that's more involving than it has presumably any right to be.
Portman's conviction in the material oozes from this deeply poetic debut.
movie_title: A Tale of Love and Darkness (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Sword Master is easily one of the best Chinese-language remakes in recent times.
A melancholy drama that unfolds at a slow-burning pace, Midi Z's visually engrossing film is elevated by reserved yet indelible turns by Kai Ko and Wu Ke-xi.
There's an alarming discrepancy between the Ringo Lam movies we love and the mediocre efforts that he's been producing since the Hong Kong film legend returned to directing.
A Kafkaesque tale about the Chinese bureaucracy's indifference to the people's legal rights.
Night's Tightrope offers everything from vengeful schoolgirls and ghastly suicides to a relentlessly gloomy view of Japanese society to satisfy the fans of crime-fiction author Kanae Minato.
While [the film] is never less than watchable, it's hard to shake the impression that Tsui [Hark] has partly ditched - or maybe failed to replicate - [Stephen] Chow's irreverent sense of humour.
movie_title: Journey to the West: The Demons Strike Back (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A slow-burning drama on the paranoia and distrust inherent in human relationships.
