A far superior film in terms of the quality on every level, but one that suffers from the weaker source material.
movie_title: The Chronicles of Narnia: Prince Caspian (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A ridiculous effort that fails to raise the blood pressure, and the poor quality of the film makes it a late night Cinemax guilty pleasure at best.
The Happening quickly deteriorates into the worst movie of M. Night Shyamalan's career... and that's saying something.
The timing of this film's release before Father's Day couldn't be more perfect, because anyone with an older father should be able to find some resonance with Morrison's personal story.
movie_title: When Did You Last See Your Father? (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Not that there aren't some great laughs, but this is far from the laugh-a-minute yuck-fest some might expect.
Another dull indie road movie that doesn't really go anywhere ... little more than a vanity project that wastes most of its better-than-average cast.
[DreamWorks Animation] has finally found their successor to the "Shrek" mantle in the hapless hero known as Po the Panda.
At times on par with the first Spider-Man, some of the original movie's problems are replaced by new ones, but none that completely ruin the enjoyment every time the Hulk comes out to 'SMASH!!!'
Like Mr. and Mrs. Smith without the action or The Break-Up with less depth--if that's even possible...
Younger girls will probably love Kit's antics and their parents won't find it too painful an experience, but it's still only a serviceable and fairly mediocre family film at best.
Beautifully realized by Sarah Gavron, who fills Nazneen's story with gorgeous visuals and traditional music, creating a film that's dramatic, romantic and even erotic at times.
Offensive, revolting and jawdropingly awful from beginning to end, a complete and total piece of Singularly Horrid Infantile Trash (TM).
I challenge anyone to stifle the snickers and not laugh a lot during this hilarious action-packed take on the '60s show.

An impressive feat on every level as Yauch brings an unbridled passion to shining a spotlight on some of the country's finest young basketball players in a way that can be appreciated by anyone and everyone.
A fun look at Vegas that imbues the seediness of the setting with a sense of innocence and warmth that might take some by surprise.

While his film's historical accuracy might sometimes be questionable, Bodrov has created a spectacular film filled with all-natural beauty from the realistic locations, one that brings forth the man within the fabled barbarian
Only excels when it treads on familiar Mamet territory; ultimately suffers from the ridiculous amount of characters and a convoluted plot.
Helen Hunt proves herself to be a highly capable filmmaker with this charming and mostly enjoyable dramedy that sometimes achieves its desired blend of humor and pathos, but not always.
Easily the best Marvel Comics based movie yet -- Favreau, Downey and company have really nailed this one!
A bit silly and predictable at times, but if you've been a long time fan of Tautou, you'll definitely want to see this.
The presence of Simon Pegg and Dylan Moran elevates what might have been merely a pleasant, harmless but ultimately forgettable romantic comedy.
Ultimately, it's a satisfying character study, even if it ends much like far too many Romanian movies without a real conclusion or resolution.
A deeply satisfying and entertaining film that will appeal just as much to guys as their ladies.
The film is 90 minutes that feel like a lifetime as nothing really happens ... disappointing at best and extremely aggravating at worst.

From the strange and implausible premise to the low-brow humor that dips into the Farrelly Brothers well at its lowest, this silly misguided comedy serves even less purpose than it does strong laughs.
A truly remarkable film that will have a deep emotional impact on anyone who watches it, even if you don't always immediately understand what is going on or where things are going.
It's a shame this movie wasn't made 20 to 30 years ago when Scorsese or the Stones were at their prime.

For adults, a grueling exercise in patience and endurance, especially in watching actors that we know can do better lowering themselves to try to mold themselves into some fictitious kid-friendly formula.
Not quite on par with something like The Descent but close enough to not make you feel as if you've been ripped off.
Far too much of a mixed bag to be completely effective, but allows for some fun and unexpected moments and solid performances.
A seriously misguided effort in attempting to explore what might lead a normally quiet and intelligent university student to lose control and go on a shooting spree.
Possibly the worst movie this year... or at least we can hope so.
Combines dark cynical humor with a moving relationship drama that never goes where you might expect.
Sadly, the subject matter might not make this the kind of movie that anyone would rush out to see, but it's a successful effort at informing while entertaining.
movie_title: Where in the World Is Osama Bin Laden? (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Gorgeous, haunting and thought-provoking ... a solid sophomore effort from Perelman despite its potentially frustrating pace.
Finding humor in situations we've all been through, and a few that only haunt our worst nightmares, Jason Segel and Nick Stoller make their mark in the Apatow-verse with a very funny date movie.
The filmmakers' intentions are kept deliberately vague but it's a surprisingly entertaining and informative doc that at least tries to address the debate over 'intelligent design' from another angle.
If you like zombies and you like strippers, than this movie has them both ... and that's about the only good thing that can be said about this awful waste of time.
There's something magical about [Fey and Poehler's] on-screen chemistry that we haven't seen since the days of Lucille Ball and Vivian Vance.
[Lelouch] masterfully switches tone without missing a beat and has truly created a masterpiece that can only get better the more times it's watched.
A gorgeous and harrowing film made by a master craftsman at the top of his game that probably won't hold much interest ... light entertainment, this is not.

A fine counterpart to Good Night, and Good Luck and a unique amalgam of talking heads and theatrics, the story of Dalton Trumbo and how he and his family dealt with being blacklisted is an amazing one.
The most effective scene is Chang's brilliant time-lapsed filming of the Yangtze River rising and engulfing the embankment.
Easily the funniest movie since Superbad and a more than satisfying sequel.
movie_title: Harold & Kumar Escape from Guantanamo Bay (2008)

movie_review_blurb: This boring, obvious and overly stylish cat-and-mouse thriller offers fewer thrills than a 'Tom and Jerry' cartoon.
An incredibly entertaining and satisfying action flick well worth the wait to finally see these two martial arts masters work together.
The R-rated action movie we've all been waiting for and Wesley Gibson is the hero we all want to be.

Not just a vast improvement over its predecessor, but the quality on almost every level is almost night and day with a stronger story and some of the most mind-blowing creature and FX work we've seen this summer.
Another great departure for Smith to put his charm and popularity to the test, offering more than a few solid laughs within an original superhero premise.
An average doc that far too often turns into a showcase for Roberts' burgeoning career as a rapper, something that often takes away from its potential as a real human and emotional story.
As much as the word 'vapid' is thrown around in the movie, it's also the perfect adjective to describe it. There are much better comedies out there right now to waste time on this one.
A thought-provoking addition to the current wave of real world political thrillers.
Like a futuristic remake of "XXX" no one ever asked for, this atrociously lame and redundant sci-fi flick may be the dullest action movie of the year.
Combining the imaginative visuals of Jeunet and Greenaway with the quirky characterizations of Kaurismaki ... a sumptuous feast of delicious food and sexy women.
movie_title: I Served the King of England (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A striking film but certainly more of one that grows on you rather than one that's immediately compelling.
Dull, predictable and unoriginal ... the main character is so annoyingly silly it's hard to put up with him for an entire movie.
A somber and haunting personal film told with the scope of The Godfather trilogy that's sure to leave a lasting impression on anyone who sees it.

Such a different movie from the Americana Chris Smith has covered in his previous films ... but it's a refreshing departure that gives us a different glimpse at the people of India than we've seen in common Bollywood fare.
Despite its slow pace and excessive length, it's still a striking debut from the [first-time] filmmaker that thrives on the simplicity of the characters and storytelling.
If Italians had their own term for 'schmaltzy', this awful, derivative and painfully cringeworthy piece of steaming crap would be the most loathsome example of such an adjective.
I expect the cast, particularly Beckinsale, and Lurie's script to get a lot of attention in the next few months.
This sweet inspirational story while familiar at times, keeps you thoroughly entertained by mixing healthy doses of humor into the real world drama.
There really isn't very much tension or the scares some might hope for ... the movie's last ten minutes try to overcompensate with lots of action after nearly 90 minutes of rather mundane mindgames.
An ambitious directorial debut from Irish actor Stuart Townsend that does an impressive job recreating the 1999 protests that accompanied the World Trade Organization's arrival in Seattle.

Trying to address important and serious social issues in this violent world rather than just creating something sensationalistic or exploitative gives Elite Squad an edge over normal police thrillers.

Both a departure and a welcome return to form for Wang as an indie auteur, a beautiful and incredibly moving story of real life relationships that exudes subtlety and self-control in a refreshing way.
movie_title: A Thousand Years of Good Prayers (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Sweet and heart-warming without being overly saccharine and smart without forcing one's brain to work too hard ... one of those rare feel-good comedies that actually makes you feel good.
A refreshing departure from the normal 'soldier's story' movies we've seen in recent years.
A ten hanky movie that ends up being just enough to make a nice noose for yourself after sitting through such an inexcusably downer ending.
Take one or two good ideas and add a lot of political thriller clichés and you end up with a disappointingly predictable action movie that doesn't necessarily deliver on the promised goods.
If nothing else, at least Lee can feel some degree of satisfaction knowing he's made a movie about as ineffective and incoherent as Clint Eastwood's Flag of our Fathers.
One can only assume that 'the blind leading the blind' best describes the decision to adapt this novel in such an abysmal manner.

A sweet story of young love on the streets of New York thrives on the chemistry between its two young stars, but is marred by the needlessly low-brow comedy added to try to create comedy that appeals to a larger (i.e. dumber) audience.

A fairly satisfying story of an underdog taking on the corporations that anyone can get behind, although it rarely feels like something so cinematic you might feel the need to rush to see it in theaters.
Might never be viewed as light entertainment, but the strong performances and ideas make it a satisfying film, one that you can ponder and discuss, as well as a powerful tribute to our troops.
A worthwhile addition to a genre that's been driven into the ground by weaker filmmakers who know where to rent the costumes, but don't understand the importance of storytelling.
Stanton and Pixar have achieved a new plateau in their craft, creating what's destined to be a beloved classic, right up there with the likes of Snow White, Bambi and Cinderella ...

Exactly what you might expect, a mindless action flick that allows you to cheer as people get slaughtered while racing around in armored cars ... anyone expecting anything [else] is obviously in the wrong movie.
You might leave the theatre wondering whose minds were more twisted and demented, those who wrote this movie, or your own?
Another fine addition to Gibney's filmography that successfully achieves its purposes, despite the extended tangent into the '72 election that almost derails it.
movie_title: Gonzo: The Life and Work of Hunter S. Thompson (2008)

movie_review_blurb: This Hollywood-level suspense thriller never goes where you expect it to go, but often gets bogged down in over-exposition as the plot thickens... and thicken... and thickens...
movie_title: Ne le Dis à Personne (Tell No One) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A mediocre effort that never really goes anywhere and never really pays off, trying too hard to be funny without delivering on the premises introduced over the course of the movie.

Daring and uncompromisingly different from previous incarnations of Batman, Nolan hasn't redefined the superhero genre as much as created an unforgettable piece of crime fiction within the context of that realm.
There are so few family films that can really appeal to everyone in the family, and this is an amazing adventure for both kids ... and adults who refuse to grow up.
movie_title: Journey to the Center of the Earth (2008)

movie_review_blurb: The presence of Cuba Gooding Jr. in this odd little indie comedy should set off early alarm bells.
Worthwhile for bringing these war games to light, but the filmmakers probably could have cut together their footage with narration and graphics to make it more interesting.

Maybe watching three older women prancing around in tight spandex singing ABBA is someone's idea of a good time, but I wouldn't want to be stuck in a room with those people for more than 90 minutes ever again.
Performed live, the haunting material finds new life ... Schnabel has created an incredibly artistic experience out of the concert with many moments that will give you goosebumps.
A fairly inconsistent effort assembled in a slipshod manner that doesn't do much to help one understand where this British gangster is coming from.
The influences for this poorly-made mock documentary are fairly obvious and if Lucas Akoskin was even 1/10th as funny as Sacha Baron Cohen, this movie might have worked.
If this movie doesn't make you laugh, you might want to give up on comedy altogether.
Is to the country's troubled economy what An Inconvenient Truth was to global warming ... it's extremely effective at getting its message across.
Could have been a lot worse, but should have been much better ... it's a movie you can watch once and be entertained, but it probably could never sustain multiple viewings like the best summer fare.
movie_title: The Mummy: Tomb of the Dragon Emperor (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Sweet, sentimental and funny in a warm and fuzzy way, even if it's somewhat predictable and few of the actors seem very Jewish.
Invariably, you may find yourself stopping to wonder whether what you just laughed at was actually funny, and that's a good way to kill any comedy right there.
A gorgeous looking film with a wry and clever script and a talented cast giving stellar performances, but one that suffers greatly from the painstakingly slow pace.
Not nearly as dramatic or visually captivating as last year's Control ... it does offer an interesting piece of the puzzle from the L.A. hardcore scene that hasn't been explored.
Since it's fairly obvious where things are going, it's somewhat of a waste of time when all's said and done ... unless you're REALLY into wine.

Probably could have cut out 15 to 20 minutes without losing anything, but if you're even remotely interested in this fascinating and enigmatic artist or the influence she's had on the world of rock, then you might want to check it out.
One of the most amazing cinematic experiences and achievements in terms of recreating a single event in history in the most comprehensive way.
It's the funniest movie of the year by far, one that can be watched repeatedly to gain more insight into its unmatched brilliance.

The movie is certainly flawed, but if you're able to suspend disbelief for the spiritual premise and can appreciate quiet little character-driven films where not much happens, you can do worse than this innocent and often lovely film.

May be a better-than-average Saturday morning cartoon, but as a theatrical feature, it has limited appeal to young kids and the few diehard fans who'll be able to overlook some of the silliness inherent in the story.
Another intriguing take on affairs of the heart from the master of the artform with some solid performances, most notably from Javier Bardem and Rebecca Hall.
A great cast, solid writing, some poppy head-bopping tunes and a story full of warmth and laughs often makes up for its sometimes predictable high concept plot.
For those in the Red States anxiously awaiting a political comedy just for you, here comes an extremely erratic and disjointed attempt at mixing comedy with a message movie that fails on both counts.
Entertaining fun [but] flawed in its overuse of Hollywood cliches and trickery that makes it predictable and less believable.
An endearing kids' adventure like the kind of movies Disney used to make in the '70s and Amblin made in the '80s.
movie_title: The Water Horse: Legend of the Deep (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A mostly dull and nonsensical attempt at a revenge thriller that trips and falls flat on its face far too many times to stand up to some of [Assayas'] stronger work.
Anyone who's ever been a fan of the Clash or Strummer's music should be fascinated by this comprehensive look at his eccentric life.
movie_title: Joe Strummer: The Future Is Unwritten (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The only thing that saves it from being a Lifetime movie is Cusack's ever-present charm and personality.
Takes a more direct approach to its politics but should have gone just a bit further if it really wanted to leave any sort of lasting impression.
An interesting though sometimes infuriating exercise from the veteran director that (as usual) goes just that little bit too far.
Hopeless romantics shouldn't have problems forgiving some of the foibles and faux pas made in the telling of the story.
movie_title: Love in the Time of Cholera (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A remarkably faithful adaptation of King's novella ... destined to be considered among the classic King horror adaptations.
Doesn't take long for the movie to reveal itself as an extremely contrived and predictable movie that tries too hard to tug on the heartstrings.
Another tragically banal step backwards in black filmmaking that looks to keep it from ever being taken seriously.
Frank Langella and Lili Taylor give great performances in what is essentially another painfully slow and bland digitally-shot indie drama.
A masterpiece of music, words and images that should get even the staunchest Dylan-haters interested in learning more about the man.
With better actors in the two main roles, this movie would probably have been great, but with Christensen and Alba, it's just okay.
Combining the poor choice of Will Smith in the lead with some of the worst CG work since Van Helsing, this dog makes the recent The Invasion come across like a masterpiece.

This masterpiece of production design and world-building might take some time to get into, but once past the confusing premise, it's worthy of plunking down another $7 to 12 to find out what happens next.
A well-crafted directorial debut that does a worthy job getting one thinking about those who have been the most affected by the war.
A genuinely touching crowd-pleaser and a real treat.
It's not quite clear why Venditti thought the film's annoying teen with ADD would make an interesting subject.
Brings Khaled Hosseini's epic vision to gorgeous life [and] leaves an equally lasting impression on viewers as the novel did with readers.
An extreme departure for P.T. Anderson, this violent and jarring oil epic is an achievement in cinematic storytelling that's hard to ignore.
Most people seeing this movie might wonder what Queen Latifah did to convince Terrence Howard to take on what will surely be his worst role of the year.
This grisly, grim and ghoulish gothic tale of vengeance is a thoroughly entertaining gore-filled experience, whether you're a fan of musicals or not.
movie_title: Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Even fans of the romantic comedy genre might have trouble suspending disbelief for this ridiculous bit of fluff that rarely knows whether it wants to be a serious drama about grieving or a light comedy about finding love.
The genius of Jake Kasdan's fourth and best film lies in the fact that it starts out as a very faithful spoof of Walk the Line but then slowly evolves into something much cooler.
movie_title: Walk Hard: The Dewey Cox Story (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Unquestionably one of the most amazing films dealing with man's battle against nature since Kevin Macdonald's Touching the Void
This too-cool-for-school Singles wannabe could have been great, but it never really goes anywhere due to its poor execution
It pulls you into Burton's world with its stunning performances and visuals.
movie_title: Sweeney Todd: The Demon Barber of Fleet Street (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Frankly, there's a way to get a message across and this sort of talking heads doc by numbers isn't it.
Seinfeld has completely dumbed-down his normal clever wit in order to appeal to younger kids; they're probably the only ones who might enjoy this.
An utterly charming crowd-pleasing comedy that adds another impressive performance to Steve Carell's resume.
Like a quirky poor man's version of The World According to Garp or Forrest Gump, it's hard to believe that it's actually based on the true story of a real person.
A tragically atrocious roadblock in the momentum Baumbach established with his previous movie, neither recapturing any of that magic nor paving any new ground.
Fessenden's best film and a huge turning point for him as a filmmaker, promising even stronger work to come.
Half of me hoped it would end with someone saying, 'Maybe we shouldn't form a Jane Austen Book Club after all' ... That would have been a much better happy ending.
Way too long and could have easily been trimmed by a good half hour, but it turns a new corner in [Sean Penn's] career as a filmmaker
Not nearly as dumb as the previous movie, but still fairly dull despite a few impressive action sequences.
Somewhat funny, but in strange and subtle ways, even by Anderson's standards.
Takes forever to get anywhere and the ridiculous ending doesn't make it worth the journey.
So sickeningly adorable and sweet that you'll be barfing sugarcubes long before the halfway point. The fact that they can stretch this idea into a movie longer than 90 minutes boggles the mind.
A fairly conservative and mundane character drama that doesn't offer any true proof of the joy and wonders of love promised by the title.
The open-endedness of the film makes for a rather unsatisfying non-conclusion to the story ... but like the best documentaries, it leaves you asking questions without trying to answer them for you.
A pleasant surprise with a high concept premise that allows for funnier situations and characters than some of Christopher Guest's last few offerings.
If you've ever been a fan of Cobain's music and want to learn what made him tick, this film is an amazing experience that's not to be missed.
Comes across like a 2-hour wedding video done by the world's worst cameraman with a few overly dramatic moments shoehorned in to allow the cast to flex their acting muscles.
The material is often too bizarre and esoteric for ordinary people to be able to relate to any of it.
While obviously important to those who made the film, [it] probably won't hold that much interest to anyone not directly involved with the story.
An entertaining, masterfully-crafted crime flick even if it isn't altogether original or groundbreaking compared to Ridley Scott's classic films.
An old school character-driven police drama that comes from the heart of a filmmaker who's clearly in complete sync with his cast and crew.
Commendable for its daring, unconventional vision of vampires, but its erratic pacing makes it a jarring experience that's hard to adjust to.
This riveting thriller may prove to be one of the most surprising debuts in a lucrative new filmmaking career for Ben Affleck.
To say that this low-fi indie movie is strange would be doing a disservice to quirky movies that thrive on their strangeness, rather than just being strange for the sake of spicing things up.
An emotionally-draining yet uplifting film about grief and redemption that should put Danish filmmaker Susanne Bier on America's radar.
movie_title: Things We Lost in the Fire (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Conventional in its storytelling and far less effective for the effort, but [Ruffalo's] performance often overshadows his Oscar-nominated castmates.
Anyone interested in politics and the conflict in the Mid-East should be able to enjoy this fascinating and informative portrait of a former president.
Doesn't seem to have very much plot or purpose, besides being an overly sweet and cute love letter to New York City, but the writing and storytelling just aren't there.
An amazing man and an amazing film.
movie_title: Pete Seeger: The Power of Song (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Marc Levin's biggest coup was actually finding Barnes and having him tell his story in his own words, which is ultimately the most interesting part of the movie
While this '70s comedy remake isn't a complete return to form for Peter and Bobby Farrelly, it's certainly a step back in the right direction for the pioneers of raunch.
Ultimately, the film does work as an inspirational tale even if it requires way too much effort and patience on the viewer's part before it gets there.
Satrapi is an interesting woman who clearly has a distinctive way of telling her story, which is what makes this film such a uniquely joyous experience.
A sporadically enjoyable no-brainer dramedy with a very simple premise that allows Nicholson or Freeman to coast through it without having to do much heavy hitting.
Vaughn's ambitious dream project offers more than just a look at four budding stand-up comics, but a look at our country from a very unique perspective as well.
movie_title: Vince Vaughn's Wild West Comedy Show: 30 Days & 30 Nights - Hollywood to the Heartland (2008)

movie_review_blurb: If Brooks' attempts to replicate the magic of About a Boy weren't obvious by the end credits, the Badly Drawn Boy song will drive the point home.
[The] combination of creature effects, action and believable situations is what ultimately puts the movie on par with the first couple 'Harry Potter' movies.
Michel Joelsas, the young actor who carries the film, is quite a find ... a fun and charming film.
movie_title: The Year My Parents Went on Vacation (O Ano em Que Meus Pais Saíram de Férias) (2006)

movie_review_blurb: An impressive feat as a vehicle for Doug Liman to pull out the stops with some of the most jaw-dropping stunts shot in some of the most amazing locations on earth.
Not as quirky as Gondry's previous movies but not quite mainstream either. [It] has enough heart in the end to make up for the fact that it isn't nearly as funny as its premise might suggest.
Mainly interesting for its premise and noteworthy for the main performance. [Not] nearly as deserving of accolades as many of the foreign language films that were ignored by the Academy.
This reprehensible effort is not only an embarrassment to Duke, but to everyone involved ... the offensively homophobic message behind this movie is not the only thing that makes it truly awful.
This isn't the definitive post-apocalyptic gore-fest some might hope for, and is more memorable for its cast of talented Atlanta-based actors ... than the talent of the three filmmakers.
A competently-made action-thriller but nothing particularly ground-breaking once it casually discards its pretense of being told from multiple points of view.
Semi-Pro joins Anchorman and Elf as one of Ferrell's funnier efforts.
A tragic waste of time and talent in every sense of the word.
It's hard to fault the filmmakers, because given the premise, it could have been much MUCH worse.
In the hands of a more competent director, Peter Morgan's strong script might have been turned into something more memorable.
A brilliant piece of filmmaking in the way it contrasts the beauty of Rio de Janeiro with the violence that affects the lives of the teens living in the city's favelas.
On par with Little Children in terms of the writing and performances, including one of Kate Beckinsale's shining moments.
Kids will probably appreciate it more than their parents, but those with a twisted sense of humor should get a few laughs out of Chow's oddest film yet.
All over the place in tone, never knowing if it wants to be a relationship comedy, a serious drama or a Hitchcock murder thriller.
If this film really epitomizes the way that teens talk and act ... then I seriously fear for the future of this country.
Owes more to Eastenders than The Italian Job with its mostly implausible piece of fiction disguising itself as a true crime story.
Cleverly written and brilliantly made ... the type of classy and tasteful British crime-drama that Caine has long been associated with.
An atrocious waste of a perfectly good CGI budget ... at least the Geico commercials make an effort to get the historical accuracy right
As much as Never Back Down tries to be The Fist and the Furious, it's really just a load of Raging Bullsh*t.
An amazing look back at a time in history when many people weren't alive, and it's a commendable and often impressive effort all around.
You can't help but be impressed by how many great bands played through [the club] before it shut its doors, just days before 9/11.
movie_title: Wetlands Preserved: The Story of an Activist Rock Club (2005)

movie_review_blurb: This look at the Mexican immigrant experience offers a few new ideas to the currently hot topic , but it's hard not to feel like we've seen this sort of story too many times in recent years.
However one can fault the execution, there's something ironic about its sweet message about accepting one's own faults.
A comedy that's surprisingly low on genuine laughs ... a trite, tamed and toned-down version of Apatow's high school formula with little of the pop or pizzazz of his other recent movies.
Jenkins' overly clever and stylish but ultimately shoddy and boring debut is mostly an awful waste of time.
If you're a fan of watching poker on television and inventive comedy than The Grand is an entertaining experience that delivers on its premise.
Falls quite short of its mark, mostly due to the poor casting as well as a deathly slow pace that far too often veers away from [the film's] greatest strength, which is the music.
An uninventive, unexciting and ultimately ineffective follow-up ... We can only hope that the sub-title means that this moneymaking farce is finally over.
Only slightly better than Chapter 27, it's questionable whether even the most morbidly curious John Lennon fan might have any interest in sitting through nearly two hours of this creepy lunatic.
With so much pointless violence for the sake of violence and a terrible non-sensical ending, this film is a grueling and pointless exercise that never fully delivers on its premise.
Doesn't pretend to be something more than a fun movie for women, as it offers a lighter look at romance and relationships without ever getting preachy or anti-male.
Hopefully, Allen has finally gotten the UK out of his system with his latest substandard film.
If you haven't already questioned the current government administration about some of their actions and tactics than this movie should be the last nail in that coffin.
Somewhat surprising that it's not nearly as awful as it could have been, but tragic to watch Diane Keaton's career continue its path into embarrassing roles that undermine her acting talent.
Worthwhile only for the scale of the destruction and the sheer audacity of its marketing campaign.
Sadly, it's a classic example of why some novels just don't translate well when adapted to the screen.
This entertaining and often moving documentary should help even the youngest of viewer get in touch with their own mortality and make it clear that life doesn't have to end at 60.
If In Bruges doesn't end up being the funniest and most quotable movies of the year, then it should be very close.
This has nothing to offer that we haven't seen before, making it one of those winter offerings that will be long forgotten by the summer.
Whenever you may think you know where things are going, Anderson throws a number of clever and unexpected twists that keeps you on your toes.
Has enough funny moments and original ideas that it's genuinely enjoyable based on the strength of its script and cast alone.
Aside from a few amusing scenes, it mostly comes across as a dry exercise, and the ending is so grim that much of the earlier charm might be forgotten.
Brett Simon's clever high school noir debut is more Heathers than John Hughes
movie_title: Assassination of a High School President (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A wonderfully refreshing and original film; this may be John Malkovich's best role and performance, maybe of his career.
The worthwhile attempts at creating realistic character dynamics and situations within a very specific era in New York is notable for sure.
A blatantly derivative serial killer thriller that proceeds to tick off every single cliché of the genre ... has nothing to offer beyond what we've already seen before.

Might be hard for those not conditioned to the generally cynical tone of Palahniuk's work to get very far, although it's much easier to swallow (no pun intended) due to the winning performances from Rockwell and Huston.
Those looking for an innovative new take on the prison genre should be pleased with the latest from this talented filmmaker.

The unique use of character dynamics combined with Blackburn's keen visual sense makes it a thinking person's horror flick that surpasses its genre by introducing a viable new cinematic voice and vision.
Unquestionably one of the worst movies Maria Bello has ever done ... this isn't just bad, but 'Tideland bad.'
[A] generally charming, funny and sweet movie that's far more accessible than past efforts [from the Duplass Brothers].
Someone else should have seen the obvious hurdle of making a horror movie that relies solely on Jessica Alba's acting abilities.
A great script and one of the more innovative indie comedies in recent memory.

Never tries to go too far below the surface, instead taking a snide and cynical approach to the meet-cute romantic comedy, filling it with all of the most obvious clichés and stereotypes in its desperate attempt for yucks.
movie_title: How to Lose Friends & Alienate People (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Push barely measures up to even the worst moments on "Heroes," and it makes 20th Century Fox's weaker superhero efforts look much better.
If nothing else, it's two hours of fun, unadulterated entertainment like the kind only Guy Ritchie can deliver ... requires a small amount of patience before its second half pay-off.
Darwin came up with some interesting theories about life but didn't have an interesting enough life to have made a movie about it.
An amusing film (albeit in spurts)... (although) Armando Iannucci's In the Loop is a hard act to follow for any politically-tinged comedy.
movie_title: The Men Who Stare at Goats (2009)

movie_review_blurb: An okay film with a funny premise that offers enough laughs to excuse the weaker direction.
A fairly standard and straight-forward biopic, but Sheen just has a way of personifying these public figures [and it's] another role perfectly suited for him.
A head-turning performance by Clive Owen and a similar breakthrough from Emma Booth ... an incredibly powerful and moving film.
Fits perfectly next to Gilliam's earlier films, and more often than not, his distinctive humor and the visuals help the movie overcome any of the weaker moments.
An impressive character piece that explores important themes ... as well as embellishing aspects of the original story that have never been fleshed out so elaborately.
Really pulls you in and sticks with you ... an incredibly strong piece of dramatic storytelling.
Another derivative gore-filled shocker that goes for laughs by paying homage to the low-budget video nasties of the '70s and '80s ... ridiculously sensationalistic and over-the-top
Will surely allow you to see John Krasinski in a different light, both as a filmmaker and as a dramatic actor.
Michael Moore fans should be able to appreciate what he does with this serious subject matter, while still keeping the movie entertaining and funny.
Surely Isaac Asimov, Philip K. Dick and Stan Winston must be tossing in their grave for what all their creative and innovative ideas have wrought.
Who knows what Von Trier was trying to achieve with the movie--some sort of catharsis, possibly?--but it's doubtful anyone will want to sit through it a second time to figure it out.
A refreshing new spin on the zombie flick, one with humor and heart, but also a great introduction to an innovative and talented new filmmaker.
Kubrick's A Clockwork Orange is an easy in for those looking for comparisons in terms of tone and mood and style.
The Yes Men Fix the World definitely shows they're one step closer to achieving their goal.
movie_title: The Yes Men Fix the World (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Offers nothing new to the tropical vacation comedy ... not even the funniest bits from the commercials really stack up to much of the cast's weakest work to date.
Few people who walk out of this movie will be able to forget Carey Mulligan's Jenny ... finds many layers in the way it explores the world at that time.
Jonze has produced a gorgeous $80 million Muppet Movie in the shape of an art film that will bore kids as much as it will depress adults.
Strong performances by Gerard Butler and Jamie Foxx drive this smart, sharp thriller that will keep you guessing with shocks and surprises at every turn.

The well-choreographed five-minute chase sequence offers more excitement than the rest of the movie combined. By then, it's far too late to forget the boredom suffered over the course of the rest of what's essentially a competent but dull and highly unnec
A futuristic take on "Pinocchio"... a competently-made animated adventure that probably will wow kids more than it will keep adults entertained for more than a few minutes.
It's fairly obvious Paul Weitz is trying to mimic the style of Tim Burton ... it's hard not to immediately fault the movie for failing to achieve the same impeccable blend of dark humor and wonder.
movie_title: Cirque du Freak: The Vampire's Assistant (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Not nearly as painful to get through as the Weinsteins' bastardization of Tom Yum Goong but those looking for more of the innovative modern-day action that made the original Ong Bak such a breath of fresh air in a somewhat tired genre might
By no means the perfect biopic, but one that covers a lot of ground in telling Amelia Earhart's story. The amount of research that went into (it) is fairly impressive.
Duffy is a smart filmmaker who knows what his mostly male fanbase will want to see in a sequel, while also wearing most of his obvious influences on his sleeve.
movie_title: The Boondock Saints II: All Saints Day (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Drew Barrymore has successfully directed a generally fun roller derby movie that never loses sight that the main character's journey should always be kept front and center.
A fine example of how a talented filmmaker can tackle a horror sub-genre in a way that's stylistically reverential but also original in its own way.
Storywise, it leaves a lot to be desired ... has many tonal and pacing problems, mainly because like the source material, it's all handled very seriously.
Shows the very growth and evolution that proves [Reitman] is a filmmaker who will be with us, making quality films that leave us deeply moved, for a very long time.
Clearly a new low for the genre as well as a career low for Columbus.
Hits every emotional nail in the head so perfectly ... you'll not be able to walk away from this movie at least not somewhat more enlightened than when you walked in.
It's just more of the same formulaic relationship poppycock that needs to have its mouth washed out with soap.
G-Force is not completely awful although it dips its toes into the easy territory of potty humor too many times to be forgiven.
Some of the finest comedy dialogue you'll hear this year, as Iannucci and his team have created sharp, snarky insults and comebacks.
It's clear that Sommers really gets the appeal of G.I. Joe to its fanbase, although far too often, the movie veers into territory that seems more like advertising for the cool vehicles and playsets,
movie_title: G.I. Joe: The Rise of Cobra (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Too long, too bland and never really pays off in the way one might hope with such a strong premise and cast.
The seamless blending of reality and fiction makes Paper Heart such an intriguing addition to the mockumentary genre, especially in light of all the TV reality dating shows.
You're either on board with what Twohy was trying to achieve here or not. Unfortunately, suspension of disbelief only can go so far.
A thoughtful and thought-provoking drama about what it takes for two people to overcome all the obstacles put in their path of staying together.
Could have been better if it had remained focused on the main character rather than trying to show off a variety of filmmaking styles with a lot of flashy CG FX-driven action.
The type of glorious filmmaking and storytelling that should appeal to everyone ... a wonderful and magical film that should be seen and enjoyed as a family.
Extremely clever, another piece of truly original fiction storytelling from the Coens, showing their brilliance at delivering subtle realism while keeping audiences entertained.
The sickest and most disturbing movie you'll see this year, extremely effective on every level without cowtowing to the overused formulas that have become standard in modern horror.
If you didn't have a chance to see it on stage, Spike Lee's movie really is the next best thing to being there.
A deeply fascinating movie ... you'll probably never be able to look at commercials and ads the same way again.
Watching WWII through the eyes of Quentin Tarantino is infinitely more fun than the real thing; the results are unforgettable.
Comedies like I Love You, Beth Cooper and My Life in Ruins have already set a very low bar for Fox ... Post Grad still finds room to lower that bar even further.
The most creative, timely and relevant doc of the year.
A more accurate and representative title might have been "Remaking Woodstock" because that's clearly what Lee set out to do.
Death's design finally catches up with itself and brutally kills a once-clever but now sadly predictable horror premise.
Mike Judge proves once again that few can top him when it comes to making cathartic social commentary about the working class.
Neveldine & Taylor have finally attained a level of crazy previously only displayed in Richard Kelly's Southland Tales.
Dumb, boring and predictable, rarely ever exceeding its TV movie esthetic and leading to the most ridiculous last-minute twist.
For someone claiming to be 'No Impact Man,' Beavan's efforts at reaching this lofty goal does in fact leave a very big impact on the viewer.
This historical film has to be seen for the glorious way it takes you back through time, making you feel as if you are part of Disney's entourage.
[A] meeting of musical minds that should thrill lovers of rock music, allowing this movie to easily fit on the shelf along with the rest of their records and CDs.
It's hard not to feel like this is little more than an interim piece in the overall story, presumably leading to something much bigger next time around.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Half-Blood Prince (2009)

movie_review_blurb: An abysmal waste of time and talent, a movie that takes a weak premise that could barely sustain a short homemade movie.
By the time it's over, you'll have to be a real Scrooge yourself to not have at least a little bit of the Christmas spirit instilled into you.
Confirms beyond a shadow of a doubt that Andrea Arnold's previous film Red Road was no fluke.
Plummer is just fantastic overall, and easily the best reason to sit through the film's two-hour running time.
Like a cross between The Road Warrior and "Deadwood" ... a generic post-Apocalypse movie with a few cool action scenes and a mostly ridiculous premise.
Makes it abundantly clear what a worthwhile endeavor curing disease can be; why anyone thought making a movie about such an achievement is another matter altogether.
About as bad as it looks, it will continuously test the tolerance and patience of any grown-up trying to endure it for the sake of trying to keep their kids entertained.
An incredibly moving experience to watch the struggles everyone went through, all framed by the protest songs of the time and what they represented to those in the trenches.

While it's hard to give the movie a whole-hearted recommendation, Legion is better than it should have been due to Stewart's attempts to NOT make it into just another high concept video game existing merely to set up a franchise.
Such an inventive and quirky film, it's hard to ignore what a distinctive voice Rhodes brings to indie comedy. Casting Buscemi in this role couldn't be more perfect.
A documentary that is at times reminiscent of Man on Wire and The Fog of War both in tone and filmmaking prowess.
movie_title: Most Dangerous Man in America: Daniel Ellsberg and the Pentagon Papers (2009)

movie_review_blurb: A top-notch thriller ... a well-crafted addition to a genre that has made a refreshing and welcome comeback in recent years.
Frozen is horrifying and brutal at times but without ever losing sight of important things like creating characters you really care about whether they live or die.
A terrific and well-realized first film, one that allows you into a world that very few outsiders have a chance to see and allows you to marvel at the storytelling skills of these two filmmakers.
Predictable as hell but delivering exactly what's advertised ... the rapport between Adams and Goode is often enough to keep this movie from totally sinking into its own formula-driven plot.
A strong crime-thriller on par with some of the films from the Coen Brothers, one that keeps you captivated with every twist and development.
A fascinating film, but for every interesting idea explored, there are just as many that don't seem to have as much relevance; the film is never focused enough to be wholly effective.
Who knows how many people know who Aebi is or about his selfless efforts, but it's inspiring to watch and Martina Egl has done a good job finding an inventively artistic way of telling his story.
Feels like a filmmaker more concerned with making this grand-looking epic and less concerned with keeping modern horror lovers as riveted to the screen as the original did back in its day.
Any potential for depth or intelligence has been sucked out by the very holiday the film attempts to glorify. The two hours watching this movie was no fairy tale.
Audiard has created another masterpiece, almost like his 'Godfather' trilogy if it were done over the course of one movie.
A fascinating indictment of how legislation and politics can be abused in a way that quite literally misses the bigger picture.
People who enjoy high fantasy like Carroll's classic work are more than happy to experience the insanity, but don't necessarily want to be driven insane themselves.
Brooklyn's Finest is a movie that could easily have gone horribly wrong if handled differently, but Antoine Fuqua is clearly a filmmaker at the top of his game.
Director Bong continues to be on par with Park Chan-wook, Kim Ki-Duk and other (Korean filmmakers) in terms of pushing the envelope in what can be done with storytelling on film.
If you have any interest whatsoever in writing a screenplay or trying to get a gig writing in Hollywood, this is a must-see film and a great companion to the book.
Its attempt at introducing 'Bourne'-style action into a real war setting is always on the precipice of utterly failing as a concept.
Has a lot of spirit and heart and actually quite sweet, but it tries to shoehorn too many ideas into one movie and not all of them work.
What might have been a fairly standard buddy comedy is elevated by a hilariously irreverent performance by Travolta and Morel's knack for creating exciting action pieces.
Consistently an entertaining and fascinating film that lifts the veil of secrecy to help us get closer to Jackson in ways that may have never been possible if he was still with us.
Successfully shows another side of society that feels foreign and unfamiliar at first, but one that's infinitely more interesting when put into context of our own lives.
An enjoyable look into one man's emotional journey even if it doesn't offer anything that new or indispensable in the grand scheme of things.

Olatunde Osunsnmi has created something incredibly original that can be debated and discussed endlessly regardless of whether you accept everything in his film as real or faked or a little bit of both.
As hard as the subject of incest and rape and abuse can be, it's a truly inspirational tale of overcoming the odds and never losing sight of your dreams.
movie_title: Precious: Based on the Novel Push by Sapphire (2009)

movie_review_blurb: There's very little meat on the bones of this movie that's little more than an extended 'Twilight Zone' episode at best and a Stephen King TV movie at worst.

A grim but gripping film that foresees doom and gloom, not just for the economy but for the entire country as a whole; one can decide for themselves whether or not [Michael Ruppert's] claims are valid.
Anderson's first foray into animation is far from fantastic ... his attempt to stay true to his gut while maintaining the integrity of Dahl's storytelling is a losing battle.
Particularly effective in showcasing the good Kunstler did for so many people and that tends to overpower all the bad stuff for which the majority probably remember Kunstler for later in his life.

All the outright silliness can be quite entertaining, but it's unsatisfying to watch a movie spend so much time developing characters you can't possibly care about as you wait for Emmerich to throw in the next wave of destruction.
Perfectly harmless fun ... the unwieldy number of characters keeps it from ever being something more than a movie for 40-something women looking to relive their teeny bopper years.
A fine bookend to Katheryn Bigelow's The Hurt Locker, showing another side of how the war at home can be just as rigorous as the one abroad.
Hard not to be impressed by the spectacular way Woo gives Western audiences an Asian history lesson that's thoroughly entertaining at the same time.
George Clooney is amazing in this even though he wasn't even born at the time it was made!
Alternates between grueling amounts of bad dialogue and silly humor for the teen set; except for a few moments involving the werewolves and the Volturi, it's fairly dismissible drivel.
In any other world, this would be getting a DVD or Syfy-only release, and Jacobson's talents would be better utilized directing Playboy Channel interstitials.
An action film that only works as long as there are ninjas on-screen slicing and dicing each other, and not so much when anyone opens their mouth and speaks.
Maguire delivers a dynamic performance unlike anything else we've seen from him...the movie might have been overwrought with grief in the hands of another director.
Has many sweet moments, but tends to veer into territory that's overly sentimental and saccharine.
A strong high concept heist thriller, sometimes hindered by the predictability of the genre and it's marketing but regularly salvaged by the movie's strong direction and the quality of the cast.
A beautiful-looking film, very poignant and moving, showing Ford to be a real filmmaker and not some flash in the pan trying his hand at a new medium.
Michael Clarke Duncan steals every single scene ... a very different role for the actor played so over-the-top that you can't help but be impressed and amazed.
Jeff Bridges realizing one of his most memorable film characters in years with a performance you won't quickly forget.
Can easily sit on anyone's DVD/Blu-ray shelf alongside Aliens and The Abyss further bolstering Cameron's already impressive film legacy.
Always fully aware it need not involve big words or ideas to offer light entertaining fare even if there's only so far you can take such a predictable premise.
movie_title: Did You Hear About the Morgans? (2009)

movie_review_blurb: When a movie with such a high pedigree feels so uninspired, you have to wonder whether there's any hope whatsoever for the romantic comedy genre.
Masterfully crafted by Guy Ritchie, this refreshing take on Sir Arthur Conan Doyle's sleuth is a great vehicle for Downey to create another distinctively eccentric character.
This quirky dark comedy offers you 90 minutes of [Michael Cera] not just doing what he does best but also showing that he has a few new tricks up his sleeve.
That rare art form of documentary verité, Castain-Taylor's camera acts as a silent observer showing the rigorous trip these men have taken for many years.
An all-around warm and entertaining film ... has a romanticism that we haven't seen very much from Linklater in recent years.
Strange but wonderful ... up there with some of Leigh's best movies, driven by riveting performances from Sally Hawkins and Eddie Marsan.
Shows a new level of filmmaking incompetence previously only seen in the films of Dr. Uwe Boll. It is just plain awful
Seems destined to join classic concert films like Woodstock and Gimme Shelter in the musical archives for its ability to capture the feel of the times and really make you feel like you were there.
Gus Van Sant's return to mainstream filmmaking [is] one of the more fascinating political biopics in recent memory.
A disjointed attempt at covering far too many angles and artists to make for a cohesive film ... this isn't the movie that'll get these musicians the respect they deserve.
Ron Howard has taken a great play and made it even better, perfectly preserving the performances by Langella and Sheen that made Peter Morgan's work so special.
Bad writing, worse acting and violence that redefines the word 'excessive' makes it clear that The Punisher is one Marvel character that probably should stay in the comic books.
One could have made a much stronger movie with a cast this good, one that wasn't so erratic and driven by such obvious and formulaic holiday silliness.
Anything good that can be said about this movie tends to be hindered by the ugly animation, which pales in comparison to anything else being done in the field right now.
Williams is fascinating to watch on screen ... but a strong performance does not necessarily an entertaining movie make, and there seems to be little point or purpose to this.
There's a realism to this story we don't often see in crime dramas, and that can only have come from someone who actually lived through it themselves.
Despite the generally weak acting, this modern remake is as effective and thoughtful at capturing the global zeitgeist and how the world today might react to an alien invasion as the original.
movie_title: The Day the Earth Stood Still (2008)

movie_review_blurb: A generally enjoyable but problematic departure for Eastwood which works best during its lighter moments but gets too dark while trying to create heightened tension and drama.
Another dog of a comedy, lame even in comparison to what Carrey's done in the past, and its tiresome premise doesn't do much to help the matter.
The results look nice, but there's little way to get past its intriguing but impenetrable (and unmarketable) premise.
The epic scope of the filmmaking gives you newfound appreciation for what a visionary filmmaker can achieve when given the chance to make films without compromise.
Just another innocuous character dramedy that might have been handled better if done independently.
A wonderfully romantic movie that you don't have to be in your 40's or older to appreciate and enjoy.
Meryl Streep is absolutely the least interesting thing about this inventive doc that takes an unprecedented look at the staging of a high-profile theater production.
Who on earth seriously wants to watch an entire movie of Kate and Leo squabbling as their marriage implodes?
Riveting and unforgettable, this intense drama really pulls you in and holds you with a terrific script and four unforgettable Oscar-worthy performances.
Marred by hammy overacting and horrendous writing by a filmmaker who clearly doesn't share Eisner's charming sense of humor.
Just one long ridiculous string of moviemaking cliches that prevents the film from having any of the desired impact.
You're likely to leave this movie wondering what you've just watched, as if you've been abused worse than the poor kidnapped girl.
There's great potential to be a classic Vegas indie drama ala Swingers or The Cooler though it's only 60% its way to getting there.
Any intelligence gets lost in an unsatisfying ending that doesn't justify the brain cells lost while getting there.
The amazing visuals and sound design (make) the movie so riveting, but its ability to let Rockwell shine with such a brilliant and rounded performance will probably be appreciated more.
Shows Jenkins to be an innovative and original voice to indie filmmaking, one certainly worth watching if he can deliver a second effort as enjoyable as this debut.
The charm of Manchevski's film clearly lies in its ability to embrace its eccentricities and pull together a number of disparate ideas into what's generally a satisfying thriller.
Bedtime Stories isn't Sandler's best movie, nor is it his worst; it's just perfectly harmless fun that the kids will probably love just a little bit more than their parents.
One of those rare examples of a high concept thriller where the elements come together in a way that delivers something far more original and appealing than one might imagine.
[It] could never be deemed a 'good movie' but it's one of those bad movies so entertaining and fun it's hard to fully condemn it.
Essentially, a CW take on Anne Rice, catering to the gooey-eyed fans of Meyer's novels and their unrealistic romantic expectations.
As disturbing as it is compelling, Ridley Scott has outdone himself with his first modern-day political thriller, delivering his strongest movie since Black Hawk Down.

Even without reading the book, one can easily deduce how this adaptation will explore every single manipulative trick in the book to tug at the heartstrings of women whose emotions are easily manipulated.

As relaxing as it may be to watch the Morning Light floating idly at sea with glorious sunsets setting behind it, it doesn't make for a particularly entertaining movie and it's certainly not something that will inspire anyone to get into sailing as a spor
Excellent performances by Brolin, Cromwell and others get lost within a generally dull piece of political fantasy fiction trying to sell itself as an entertaining biopic.
As raunchy as you'd expect from an R-rated teen sex comedy, but surprisingly clever and even sweet at times.
An embarrassment to a genre that's already delivered some of the worst movies of the last ten years.
A simply-made yet entertaining doc that has a similar appeal as Alexander Payne's Election while following in the vein of docs like American Teen and Spellbound.
Most of it seems like pointless goofing around, offering lots of filth and very little semblance of wisdom.
Suffers from its lack of focus by trying to create an overly complex story that would probably have been just as interesting if it were kept simpler ... and shorter.
As hard as it must have been to screw up a Joe Carnahan script, the fact that Gavin O'Connor is no Martin Scorsese or Michael Mann is blatantly obvious from this weak effort.
One of the most intriguing character studies in recent memory; a dialogue heavy drama that never gets dull and will leave you drained from the amount of emotions explored.
The thoughts and emotions the movie stirs up in the viewer makes it one of the more powerful documentaries of the year.
movie_title: Stranded: I Have Come from a Plane That Crashed on the Mountains (2008)

movie_review_blurb: There are far worse ways of kicking yourself into the holiday spirit than this inventive variation on the Meet the Parents formula.
A lot of thought may have gone into constructing this intricate, remotely clever, but ultimately dour and depressing, directorial debut from Charlie Kaufman, but it probably wasn't worth the effort.
One of the most powerful and moving films this year, a personal film that perfectly captures the feelings of anger and loss that accompany a loved one's untimely death.
movie_title: Dear Zachary: A Letter to a Son About His Father (2008)

movie_review_blurb: One of the more comprehensive looks at bullfighting we've seen in this country.
The better than usual cast offers enough new twists to keep it from being just another Kevin Smith comedy.
movie_title: Zack and Miri Make a Porno (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Is this the funniest movie from Wain or anyone involved in the cast? No, probably not, but you should get enough laughs out of it that it shouldn't be completely written off as a loss.
If Jackson and the late Bernie Mac weren't chewing up the scenery in an incessant game of one-upmanship, this might have worked nearly as well (as The Blues Brothers).
Not quite on par with Life is Beautiful or Schindler's List but it's still a powerful film, and a more than worthy addition to the genre due to its unique perspective.
movie_title: The Boy in the Striped Pajamas (The Boy in the Striped Pyjamas) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Certainly in the future, depicted here so stylishly, Andrew Lloyd Webber is probably turning in his grave.
Daniel Craig has firmly ensconced himself as one of the definitive Bonds, one now fully updated for the 21st Century.
Clearly one of the best movies of the year, Slumdog Millionaire is a fine example of why we love to watch movies.
Essentially a vanity project, a budget Ocean's 11 for Davi and his pals to sing some doo-wop tunes and ham it up.

Those looking for a cheery family gathering for the holidays flick might want to look elsewhere. Those who enjoy quirky family dramas, beautifully written, performed and shot will be thrilled by Desplechin's latest.
movie_title: Un Conte de Noël (A Christmas Tale) (2008)

movie_review_blurb: Disney's strongest CG animated effort to date can be credited to the strength of a premise that mixes what's worked so well in earlier Disney animated films with a better awareness of what makes a movie entertaining both for kids and adults.

If you liked the previous four movies, there's little reason why you won't find at least a few things to enjoy in this one, but it's definitely getting to the point where it's dubious whether they can keep it going much longer...
You have to give Lynn Shelton a lot of credit for trying to explore a part of the male lifestyle that often deliberately goes unspoken.
Too derivative and laden with plot twists to be effective, it's hard to enjoy this cluttered remake knowing how much better the original movie is.
You can do far worse than this when it comes to a date movie, but knowing so much about how the opposite sex thinks will surely put a quick and sour end to date night.
movie_title: He's Just Not That Into You (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Carlos Cuarón proves his mettle as a director with an amusing and entertaining look at how fame (and soccer) can destroy the bonds of brotherhood.
One of the more unique romantic comedies since Garden State, one that's sweet and strange at the same time.
Remaining faithful to stronger source material makes Ron Howard and Tom Hanks' second Dan Brown adaptation a far superior effort in every possible way.
There's a true filmmaking force at work here; open-minded film enthusiasts should appreciate [Johnson's] charming and unique approach to the heist comedy
Fails because it doesn't really get you excited about the return of the franchise... and a lot of that comes down to the cheesy writing and bad acting.
An interesting character-based experiment by Soderbergh, one that's more fully-realized than some of his other recent ideas.
It never quite finds its comic footing, but kids will probably love it--they might even learn a thing or two.
movie_title: Night at the Museum 2: Battle of the Smithsonian (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Grueling, but mostly watchable. Funny? Not so much.
Better than at least 90% of the non-Pixar animated movies being produced, as well as a film experience that can be fully embraced for its originality of vision and tone.
This is truly masterful and glorious filmmaking that's guaranteed a spot in my Top 10 of the year.
Such a heartfelt inspirational story that one can fully understand why it seemed like such a worthwhile effort to capture the results of Stephenson's efforts on film.
Drag Me to Hell more than lives up to the hype surrounding the horror master's return to the genre.
Will be remembered for the unforgettable performance by Swinton that drives this inventive thriller.
Sometimes gets bogged down in its own weirdness, but a genuinely unique piece of horror filmmaking.
An amusing and incredibly strange experience that might have you laughing at the ballsiness of pulling something as crazy as this off.
May not be as exciting as some may hope for what is essentially a summer popcorn flick. What keeps it from being a complete loss is the strong character work from Washington and Gandolfini.
An important film, a fascinating and intelligent doc that's easily one of the best of the year. Could very well make a huge difference in how you decide what you put in your mouth.
Simple and effective with a quirky charm that's infectious due to the perfect pairing of Krasinski and Rudolph and the decidedly different approach Mendes has taken with the material.
Who knows why anyone thought a kid's movie about financial investing might be of interest to anyone of any age? Effortlessly hammers another nail into Eddie Murphy's credibility as a comic star.
A wonderful character study not only about the four main characters but also New York City itself and how it affects everyone who enters it.
Being directed by Michael Bay, you will probably go in expecting a lot of action and explosions ... but this is clearly the Bay of Pearl Harbor and Armageddon
A brilliantly realized character-driven thriller likely to leave a lasting impression and make you completely forget everything you thought you knew about the day-to-day lives of soldiers in Iraq.
Like an amalgam of every "ABC After-School Special" ever made ... makes most Lifetime Channel movies seem competent by comparison.

As technically flawless a film as we've come to expect from a master filmmaker like Michael Mann, but handled far more clinically than some might expect considering the subject matter and the summer release.

There's little question that the movie will most be remembered for its introduction of the luscious Louise Bourgouin. Fontaine has a way at bringing out her oozing sex appeal without the movie ever feeling exploitative.
movie_title: La Fille de Monaco (The Girl from Monaco) (2009)

movie_review_blurb: Even more insane and hysterical than Borat, Sacha Baron Cohen's hilarious follow-up is also far more coherent and effective at using shock factor to get you laughing.
Todd Phillips masterfully shows that the combination of unexpected ingredients can create a potent chemistry that elevates a simple premise.
Nothing more than an attempt to stroke the "Star Wars" fans ... they're probably the only ones who might appreciate what is generally a weak and unfunny movie.
So far, this is one of the best docs in terms of intelligence and craftsmanship this year.
For a comedy that doesn't require a lot of heavy thinking, it tries hard not to dumb things down too much, nor skimp on character or storytelling either.
A truly warm and wonderful film that work by using simpler storytelling to explore very deep human emotions.
Completely misses the point of what worked ... a relatively unsatisfying rehash of what's come before while barely moving the franchise past the overused cliches.
Smart, tense and effective ... an intelligent conspiracy thriller that takes its time setting things up, but delivers one of the most impressive set pieces of the year.
If Phoenix's transition from actor to rapper turns out to be true, this would make quite an intriguing swan song for sure.
As hard as this movie tries to 'bring it on', it probably should have left the cheerleading realm well enough alone ... one of the most blatantly sexist and homophobic comedies in some time.
Wajda has assembled a really amazing ensemble cast to realize an excellent script ... beautifully shot by Pawel Edelman with some truly gorgeous sequences.
The process for putting on a high-profile fashion show seems endlessly fascinating even if it's hard to find reason to care about Jay McCarroll as the film's central subject.
This politically-minded ensemble drama's obvious attempts at being Traffic or Crash barely gets out of the garage before it stalls in neutral.
Zack Snyder's attempt at being faithful to Alan Moore and Dave Gibbons' vision is ultimately the film's biggest fault since it makes the flaws in the original source material far more obvious.
Unlike most movies that deal with women's issues, this is one that can be enjoyed equally by guys rather than being so fueled by estrogen that it's unbearable.
Neither a conventional spy flick nor a traditional romantic comedy, Duplicity is a satisfying mix of the two that's as entertaining as it is thought-provoking
One of the few touchy-feely relationship comedies that will probably play as well or better with guys than it does with women.
Star Trek should quench all your Trekker geek desires, but make no mistake, this is still very much the same Star Trek, just with a younger cast and a lot more money thrown at it.

A welcome entry into the burgeoning horror-comedy field, blending its mad environmental science with a lot of fun laughs.
The best of the three movies due to the added complexities in its storytelling and the evolution and growth of the characters as a whole since the first movie.

A surprisingly strong addition to the high school comedy genre with more rounded characters and realistic situations than one normally gets.

movie_title: The King of Kong: A Fistful of Quarters (2007)

movie_review_blurb: The scenes between Hopkins and Gosling stand out in what is generally a bland, by-the-books crime drama that drags when Hopkins isn't on screen.
A truly universal comedy about relationships that's worth more than a few laughs regardless of your race, gender or marital status.
movie_title: I Think I Love My Wife (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A visually-stimulating real world take on "The Great Escape" that only suffers from a slower second act and a bit of silliness.
A thoroughly enjoyable and charming film that will strike a chord with anyone who's ever felt the need to get away from the strangling, constrictive strings of their mother's apron.

If Brightway's main contribution to Lapica's life was to convince him to take up filmmaking, they deserved to be shut down by the government.

While generally a well-made horror remake... fans will be chomping at the bit waiting for the slaughter to begin, and once it does, it has very little to offer beyond what John Carpenter did in the original movie.
Might have been accepted as a classic modern grindhouse flick if any of its inherent humor were even remotely intentional.
Diehard Western fans might appreciate it, but those unfamiliar or uncomfortable with the genre will admire it for the craftsmanship that Mangold et al bring to the table.

Silverman's fans will appreciate what she brings to the table, but it's not too believable that [she] would be interested in [Garlin's] wishy-washy character.
movie_title: I Want Someone to Eat Cheese With (2006)

movie_review_blurb: A gorgeous, powerful and moving film ... not only the best documentary of the year, but possibly one of the best films period.
movie_title: In the Shadow of the Moon (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Quickly gets bogged down in Anton Yelchin's tendency to be whiny and annoying in his attempts to be clever or cute.
Harder to adjust to the humor within the country's tragedy, but Shepard's talent and sensibilities as a filmmaker keeps things light and entertaining.
Starts to get interesting when the lead character learns how to use magic, but ultimately, the computer FX do little to counter the generally poor production values.
Hawke has some strong and worthwhile thoughts about love and relationships, but as a director, he's just not skilled enough to make his novel work as a movie.
An appallingly bad, mostly unwatchable embarrassment to everyone involved.
A brilliant debut by Gilroy, it takes its time to grab you but [then] keeps you riveted to the screen. No one should be surprised if it brings [Clooney] back to the Oscars.
Never lets up as it keeps piling on the scares and surprises, as it builds to a surprisingly poignant conclusion.
As close to perfection as you'll get for a movie dealing with a subject matter that might seem impossible to handle in an entertaining way.
movie_title: The Diving Bell and the Butterfly (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Shows how far SNL has fallen in its attempt to create original comedy; other times, it makes the Farrelly Brothers seem tasteful.
The slow pace and the fact that the title gives away the entire plot should only be a minor annoyance to those who love strong writing, powerful acting and great filmmaking.
movie_title: The Assassination of Jesse James by the Coward Robert Ford (2007)

movie_review_blurb: A film that must be seen by any true Joy Division fan, but also entertaining enough as an introduction to this influential band and its troubled singer.

Far lighter and easier to absorb than Thank You For Smoking even if it does sometimes try way too hard to be hip and quirky.
While this isn't a terrible movie, compared to A History of Violence or any of Cronenberg's earlier films, it's a huge disappointment.
A terrific return to form on a par with Fargo and other Coen classics.
A stunning, powerful sophomore effort from Joe Wright, likely to have as much impact on second viewing.
A crime drama on par with classics like the Coens' Fargo with intense drama in the vein of Todd Field's In the Bedroom.
movie_title: Before the Devil Knows You're Dead (2007)

movie_review_blurb: You have to appreciate the technical achievements even if the movie as a whole is not something that will stick with you for long.

movie_title: Harry Potter and the Order of the Phoenix (2007)

movie_review_blurb: Driven by a really smart script and strong performances by one of the most unlikely film pairings in many years.

There are enough decent moments in Burnt to eventually make it enjoyable.
An incredibly emotional film on many levels and a more than worthy conclusion to the series.
A joyous crowdpleasing experience that's both witty and sweet and way more than the 'chick flick' it sometimes pertains to be.
Fantastically fun and clever, surprisingly so at times.
As beautiful as it is boring, Angelina Jolie Pitt has successfully created a movie that she might want to watch... but no one else.
A gorgeous and sumptuous period love story that's a worthy addition to Todd Haynes' filmography.
A darn fine boxing movie that pays tribute to the Rocky legacy in a way that fans of those movies should thoroughly enjoy.
Those hoping to see an updated big screen version of Melville's Moby Dick are likely to be left wanting something more significant.
movie_title: In the Heart of the Sea (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The type of film that can only get better on multiple viewings.
When it comes down to it, the movie is still all about a mop.
Anyone who enjoys the other movies, particularly Episodes 4 through 6, should be perfectly satisfied with the direction of the franchise.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode VII - The Force Awakens (2015)

movie_review_blurb: It's hard to believe that despite having two equally funny women, Sisters fails to connect and feels like a let-down.
Further proves Tarantino to be a true original despite his constant homages to films of the past.
A competent but failed attempt at salvaging a fairly lame horror premise.
By the end of the film, you're likely to want to shoot Kevin Hart in the face yourself.
Feels slightly padded with unnecessary character moments which keep it from being nearly as effective as it could have been.
Norm of the North may be just fine for the youngest of kids [...] but for anyone over a certain age or IQ, it's likely to be fairly mind-numbing.
Derives the most laughs possible out of what is the simplest of holiday comedy concepts.
With humor that makes Bill & Ted seem intelligent, this sequel is pretty much garbage. We had to wait five years for this?
Fans of the original movie may be more forgiving of the weak storytelling and the awkward performances that make up this lackluster sequel.
movie_title: The Second Best Exotic Marigold Hotel (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Some aspects might be off-putting, but the actors and filmmakers handle the topic in a surprisingly tasteful way.
Blended isn't truly awful or unwatchable, but it's also not particularly groundbreaking, even by Sandler's standards.
The best action movie of the summer ... combining its innovative sci-fi premise with the type of high-gauged action James Cameron delivers so effortlessly.
movie_title: Live Die Repeat: Edge of Tomorrow (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A charming delight that's going to leave you wanting to form your own punk band on leaving the theater.
Might as well just be an extended episode of 'Family Guy' set in the West.
movie_title: A Million Ways to Die in the West (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A worthy successor to the first movie with exactly the right combination of jokes and action that it's not likely to disappoint too many people.

A wonderfully-made doc that's full of pleasant surprises and a terrific portrait of someone who has deliberately remained fairly hidden from the world at large while his clients have become huge stars.
movie_title: Supermensch: The Legend of Shep Gordon (2014)

movie_review_blurb: An effective tearjerker that benefits from its strong script and the presence of Woodley, who really shines in a more dramatic role.
