It's hard to warm up to a movie when you hate its central character and it's also frustrating when a comedy about stand-up goes out of its way to be so unfunny.
Those looking for something closer to a European film than the dramas we normally get from American filmmakers, should appreciate the cinematic experience Haggis has created.
Bong brings enough straight action to the mix that even those put off by the more bizarre characters should ultimately dig what he's done with the material.
Enough satisfying chemistry between its two leads as well as another terrific soundtrack, which makes it easier to overlook some of its less credible moments.
If you ever wanted to find out what drives someone like Roger Ebert's passion for film, essentially what makes a great film critic like him tick, then this is one of the year's must-see docs.
Anyone paying to see it in Brooklyn or anywhere else for that matter will probably leave the theater angrier than the film's title character.

There isn't a ton of reinventing the wheel in terms of demonic possession or the police procedural, but the combination of those two genres makes it far more satisfying than it might have been otherwise.
A brilliantly-realized successor to a solid franchise reboot.
movie_title: Dawn Of The Planet Of The Apes (2014)

movie_review_blurb: With a brilliant filmmaking experiment that works beyond belief, Linklater continues to prove himself as one of the strongest character-driven filmmakers out there.
A fantastic but far-too-short appearance by Rob Lowe and some well-timed quips by Rob Corddry are not enough for this high concept comedy to deliver on the promised laughs.
Magic in the Moonlight has Woody Allen's usual irrepressible charm that will appeal to those who have stuck with him through thick and thin.
Having one of the world's finest actors in a near-perfect role for him goes a long way to create a character and plot-driven film that pays the greatest homage to the author's work.
Luc Besson makes an entertaining but often inane sci-fi action movie that mainly works due to Scarlet Johansson's presence on screen.
Possibly one of the funniest (and strangest) Marvel movies yet, James Gunn and his cast deliver an infinitely entertaining space opera that's really something quite special.
A thoroughly entertaining film.
For everyone still trying to make the perfect modern romantic comedy, What If comes the closest thanks to brilliant writing and a terrific cast at the top of their game.
Despite how predictable and obvious this movie made itself, it still managed to win me over and resonate by the end.
It's hard to get excited about a movie based around such a bland premise that never ventures too far beyond the most obvious and expected places.
As enjoyable as the first movie was, its follow-up successfully evolves that formula into an equally enjoyable film.
The combination of demonic possession and the police procedural makes the film far more satisfying than it might have been otherwise.
Sachs goes for subdued subtlety and winds up with a beautiful and unforgettable film.
Neither the Brosnan charm nor the Thompson pedigree can save a movie that's embarrassing to all involved.
A joyful conclusion to the underrated series and a true coup for Klepisch that he was able to end the series on such a high.
No one involved with the making of this movie should be allowed to work again.
We have to assume, even hope, that a movie this bad will finally wring the death knell for found footage horror... but sadly we'd probably be wrong.
Two talented genre filmmakers to keep an eye on, especially if they're able to break away from far too familiar genre territory and try something even more different with their third movie.
I, Frankenstein isn't just a bad movie--it is an abysmally awful one. Someone in production should have realized it didn't work in the script phase and put a stop to it before it went this far.
These quote-unquote filmmakers have nothing to offer the world of comedy or film and I've given up trying to figure out why people keep giving them money.
Sometimes comes off as uneven due to a semi-convoluted plot, but the cast brings their all to the material and eventually, it does win you over.
Labor Day could have been a beautiful love story. It also could have been a tense thriller. Trying to be both makes it tonally tricky and not an easy movie to love.
The results are thoroughly entertaining and anyone who has ever played with the blocks or the recent video games will find something to enjoy.
If I read this screenplay, I'd probably immediately ban Dean and Herschel from Hollywood.
Plenty of moviegoers out there enjoy these sorts of films--usually at festivals--but I honestly have no idea what anyone else might get out of watching this.
Truly one of [Wes Anderson's] most inspired films, as much influenced by classic cinemas as it maintains his own sense of style and pace.
Jason Bateman's delivery and his direction turn the movie into something more thoughtful and entertaining than it might have been going by the initial set-up.
Owen and Binoche bring so much to the story as a whole that it's hard not to be won over once it gets past the rom-com cliches we've seen so many times before.
A very special film that transcends its origins; despite its simple premise, it's a story that could really only take place in Mumbai.
The movie is clearly more for the diehard fans and they likely will get more out of this experience than the mildly curious.
Never relies solely on its tasty-looking food to win over the audience ... and yet, it's probably the best 'foodie' movie since Ratatouille.
Neighbors succeeds at being more than your typical frat house movie, even if it's a strange mix of humor that might lose some along the way.

Gains huge points by working as a standalone movie set in the world of espionage and world politics, different enough from previous Marvel movies to be more accessible for non-comic fans than anything Marvel's done thus far.
You have to admit that Tom Berninger has captured something truly unique and unlike any other music documentary so far.
Shows off real filmmaking and storytelling skill on the part of Teplitzky and a different view of WWII than we've seen before.
Mostly uninspired and rarely even remotely entertaining, you'd be better off sticking with the original Rio... and by that, we mean the one in Brazil.
A movie as entertaining as some of Woody Allen's classics but also one with its own personality.
Any momentum is swallowed up by its failed attempts at being smarter than everyone in the room, which isn't exactly a good way to keep an audience invested.
It's disappointing that it never feels like anyone involved with this sequel has learned anything about what didn't work in previous Spider-Man movies.
There's a lot to enjoy in this latest attempt to bring everyone's favorite giant lizard back to the screen.
A perfectly fine follow-up to X-Men: First Class and a nice way to offer some closure for Bryan Singer's earlier X-men movies.
An epic spectacle filled with fantastic visuals that ultimately works as a worthy follow-up.
Beckinsale is fantastic and probably has the funniest and snarkiest lines in the movie. It's better than Stillman's last few movies.
A relatively worthy follow-up loses some luster from the time passed while still delivering the originality of Miller's visuals and Rodriguez's flair for action.
movie_title: Frank Miller's Sin City: A Dame to Kill For (2014)

movie_review_blurb: One of the best prison dramas you're likely to see in some time, but the real stand-out is the introduction of Jack O'Connell
Hilarious, but it's probably going to get us nuked.
Avoids the typical bombast of the normal crime thriller, instead focusing its efforts at being a densely-scripted character study.
Fails to convey the material in a particularly creative or inventive way with Waltz's constant scenery-chewing detracting from any insight the story tries to offer.
Easily one of the most important and relevant films of the year.
Maintains the snarkiness of Mark Millar's writing, while creating something on a much grander scale.
A Most Violent Year is Chandor's take on The Godfather or Scarface, though it's not quite as thrilling or memorable as those classics.
It tends to drag in setting up what may be one of the most unsatisfying and aggravating plot twists in recent memory.
This time around, the only thing getting taken is your money.
Hard as it tries, The Wedding Ringer is spectacularly unfunny.
Fans of previous submarine thrillers should appreciate the tense nail-biter that Macdonald has created.
A grueling experience to sit through if you're not in on the central joke and Rauch's character.
Another comedy that tries too hard for laughs and ends up with a batting average below 50%.
Chris Rock never loses sight of the laughs for his most personal film yet.
Not a particularly mainstream film, but it's certainly one that will appeal to the arthouse crowd who appreciates character-based storytelling.
The amount of laughs Patrick Brice is able to generate from such a simple idea and on such a small budget makes one think that he's due for a breakout.
It's so nice to have this fantastic filmmaking couple back and regaining their stride with such a different film for them.
Baumbach and Gerwig came up with the simplest of concepts and then threw in as many ideas as possible rather than trying to do things that might enhance the overall story.
Doesn't really offer anything unique or special that we haven't seen before, basically squandering its talented stars.
There aren't a ton of significant moments as it essentially rolls along and follows their journey to find out if Polly can get pregnant.
Will have a significant impact on anyone who watches it, regardless of whether they've been personally affected by cancer.
movie_title: Me and Earl and the Dying Girl (2015)

movie_review_blurb: Swanberg has created a lovely film that it's hard to find anything to not like about it, but it also never tries to be anything more than what sets it out to be.
A grim and depressing movie that's painfully dull, making it hard to recommend it even for fans of Silverman who want to see her stretch her dramatic acting muscles.
Such a strong piece that I would not even be remotely surprised if this is being talked about at year's end, come awards time.
A perfectly pleasant mix of humor and drama that will remind you how much Lily Tomlin is missed as a regular fixture in movies.
The Seinfeld of this year's Sundance, basically a movie with a lot of talking about nothing.
The Hobbit and 'Game of Thrones' both have done this form of the fantasy genre much better in recent years.
A thought-provoking experience that never feels bogged down in its dialogue.
Make no mistake that the film has issues, but it also has some fun action scenes and ultimately one can see Brosnan doing more with the character in the planned sequel.
Reese Witherspoon and the unconventional way Strayed's story is told goes a long way to create a far more lasting experience.
Another grand spectacle that does a fine job wrapping things up without offering nearly as many of the memorable moments of its predecessor.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Battle of the Five Armies (2014)

movie_review_blurb: Despite a strong cast, it's obvious where the problems lie: a weak script and a director working beyond his ability to make the movie work dramatically.
Shawn Levy's cast often makes up for the routineness of the film's overused premise.
movie_title: This Is Where I Leave You (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A perfectly respectable crime-drama that's only hindered by the fact it feels redundant to a genre that's already become fairly oversaturated.
Has such a good heart that you leave the theater smiling, which is not something we get very often nowadays.
movie_title: Hector And The Search For Happiness (2014)

movie_review_blurb: A beautiful and inspirational story, and a real filmmaking coup for Curran which should be getting a far more high-profile release than it's being given.
A refreshing change from other musical biopics as it shows other sides to the rock legend that we haven't had a chance to see before.
movie_title: Jimi: All Is by My Side (2014)

movie_review_blurb: What may be one of Jason Schwartzman's funniest roles to date.
An ambitious look at a very specific time that works better than other similar attempts.
A forgettable non-event ... almost as aggravating as David Cronenberg's A Dangerous Method.
For those who expect cinematic mastery from everything David Fincher does, this doesn't seem like anything special compared to his high watermarks.
Another fine step forward for Jason Reitman as a filmmaker, although for some, the film's message may be a little on-point.
Few movies can achieve the highest benchmark of 'perfection,' and movies like Whiplash only come along once in a blue moon.
Jack O'Connell's performance and the fantastic work done by Jolie and her team make this a far more effective story than one might expect.
P.T. Anderson's most uninspired work to date and mostly a worthless waste of time.
Quite an achievement for director David Ayer in creating something far more expansive and cinematic than some of his earlier films.
Corny, dumb and predictable and rife with clichés, it's Dawson's Crap.
Shows another side to Snowden and the reasons for what he did in a fairly unedited fashion and that's largely what makes it the perfect coda to Snowden's story.
Nolan's love letter to space travel and the exploration of the stars may require some patience, but it offers an incredible emotional payoff along with its visual spectacle.
Absolutely intense, a fantastic debut by Dan Gilroy with Gyllenhaal giving an unforgettable performance that shows him achieving the next level as an actor.
Definitely a movie to see for true fans of British music, as it shows another layer of the punk and post-punk music scene that should be appreciated.
A brilliant and beautiful film that gives us a more personal and intimate look at this amazing genius of a man than we've ever seen before.
The slow pace won't be for everyone, but watching three actors give such riveting performances in the telling of such a fascinating character piece more than makes up for it.
Prince-Blythewood's attempt to create authenticity in a story set within the music business is elevated by having solid actors like Gugu Mbatha-Raw and Nate Parker to bolster it.
A disappointing follow-up to 'Catching Fire.' You're left feeling as if you've only watched half a movie without the same feeling of anticipation to see what happens next.
A lazy and uninspired attempt that barely captures or recreates why the first movie was so hilarious.
A riveting and emotional historical piece that bolsters one of the best performances of the year by Benedict Cumberbatch.
May be hard to wrap one's head around, but it's easily one of the most thought-provoking films of the past ten years, maybe more.
Offers very few new scares, mainly because it's so haunted by the ghosts of far better horror movies.
With the added layer of humor that comes with switching genders, Neighbors 2 ends up offering even more laughs than the original movie.
Alice ends up being nothing more than another needless tinkering of the Lewis Carroll mythos that's grueling to sit through at its worst-which is most of it.
An exceedingly warm and wonderful family drama from filmmaker Marc Webb.
Shot! is an absolutely essential doc for anyone interested in the amazing era of rock music produced during the 1970s.
movie_title: SHOT!: The Psycho-Spiritual Mantra of Rock (2017)

movie_review_blurb: An embarrassing, unfunny movie that leaves a bad blemish on the late careers of its stars.
The fluid mix of genres and tones helps make Their Finest better than many other period films of its ilk.
Another gorgeous film from Gray, The Lost City of Z is a great step forward in his career.
There has never been a movie about this subject matter handled in such an honest, personal and funny way.
Clumsily wedges a romantic triangle into the gritty story of the Armenian genocide ... never really gives you much reason to care about the characters.
An intensive look inside the way one of the country's most prestigious newspapers works.
A distinctive approach to movie storytelling and keeps you invested, mainly because Malek is such a compelling actor.
Marc Myers' innovative look at a serial killer as a high school outcast is a welcome twist on the genre.
There's also little question that the movie is frequently saved by offering another joyously entertaining performance by Christopher Plummer.
May be one of this year's most important and significant documentaries.
Overall, it's a fairly sweet and enjoyable film.
Laura Poitras offers a worthwhile look at WikiLeaks founder Julian Assange that somehow still feels half-finished.
Scott has effectively created a satisfying hybrid of Alien, Prometheus and even James Cameron's Aliens.
A very weak high concept thriller that gets worse the further it goes into its god awful premise.
Such a fun and funny movie about a long-time friendship that's put to the test through a road trip.
Disturbing and jarring ... but masterfully directed and acted.
A really pleasant and joyous film that definitely has a Bridget Jones quality to it.
The most obvious of humor and weakest of plots lead this road comedy based on Jeff Kinney's popular books down a dead end.
movie_title: Diary Of A Wimpy Kid: The Long Haul (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A weak, uninspired thriller, offering a frustrating and implausible twist instead of anything in the way of tension.
A fairly comprehensive and thorough portrait of a band whose legacy has far surpassed its drug-tinged hippie roots.
movie_title: Long Strange Trip: The Untold Story of The Grateful Dead (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Dead Men Tell No Tales is flawed, but it's still better than Marshall's film and the weirdness that overpowered and eventually ruined Verbinski's original trilogy.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: Dead Men Tell No Tales (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Jenkins (and Gadot) particularly excel in the action scenes, because when Wonder Woman first runs across the battlefields in her costume, you are immediately won over.
Captain Underpants' unquenchable desire to make kids laugh is ultimately what wins you over with its charm.
movie_title: Captain Underpants: The First Epic Movie (Captain Underpants) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Often scarier for what it doesn't say or show, which may also make it somewhat frustrating, since you're never sure exactly what's happening either.
A fairly standard, thinly plotted martial-arts film that purports to elevate women in that arena, but instead demeans them with weak, clichéd storytelling.
Ultimately, The Mummy isn't absolutely terrible... there's a lot of potential here that's been squandered by including Cruise and Crowe.
Fans of the original comics should appreciate how faithful it remains to them. It's a very pretty movie that pulls you into this futuristic world.
A contemplative Malick-like drama that leans heavily on its Iceland locations and the genuine chemistry between its two young actors.
The movie tends to fluctuate between being corny, sappy, and outright ridiculous.
Rings does little to improve upon a tired horror idea that's been done better by other filmmakers, making it aggravatingly redundant.
In the end, this latest "Rings" sequel is just inexcusably bad.
This is a far more fun and family-friendly superhero universe than what we normally get.
If you loved the original movie, you might not care so much about being given warmed-over seconds. Otherwise, this Wick has burned itself out.
The actors are so good that it doesn't even seem awkward when the film gives us a romantic angle between Nicholson's Sophie and the Japanese visitor.
A perfectly harmless family film that's about as challenging and interesting as Saturday morning television fare, and yet, better than expected.
Takes its sweet time before audiences can connect to it in the way the filmmaker intended, but ultimately the emotional content of the last act wins you over.
Hugh Jackman's last Wolverine story ends on a grim, gritty and ultra-violent note that wins points both for being cinematic and for being so different.
Peele takes the concept behind Guess Who's Coming to Dinner? to its furthest, most genre extreme.
If you're a fan of genre films, especially things like Danny Boyle's 28 Days Later, then this is definitely a movie you'll want to check out.
movie_title: The Girl With All the Gifts (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Poorly conceived and executed, it doesn't even feel like something that can be laughed about when it shows up on cable... which will probably be very soon.
An outlandish, overly complicated premise that's likely to confound the kiddies while it tries hard to get laughs from their parents.
Kris Avedisian's undeniably quirky charm in the title role helps steer this indie buddy comedy away from the usual clichés.
A popcorn movie that's only good as long as you still have popcorn left in your tub, and is quickly forgotten after you've run out.
One of Freundlich's career best, just an amazing achievement in creating a movie that keeps you on edge...
A brilliant must-watch documentary whether you're Jewish or a fan of comedy and how/why it does or doesn't work.
Works well as a movie meant to provoke thought and discussion with a capitol 'P.'
No, the main duo isn't the problem as much as it is the bad writing and a lot of the cast around them.
An interesting character study and a nice book-end to the original Trainspotting.
An absolutely fantastic film from Ozon ... easily Ozon's most striking and solid films in years.
An amusing show-slash-movie, with the caveat being that you really need to be able to endure Zahedi's nerdy and neurotic persona to be able to fully appreciate his work.
A welcome addition to the genre, although it is slower and more grounded in reality than the science fiction movies to which modern audiences have become accustomed.
Jessica Chastain and director Niki Caro bring a tenderness to The Zookeeper's Wife, but it's hurt by erratic pacing.
Wilson is a fine showcase for the talented Woody Harrelson to create another character who, at least at first, is mostly likable for being so unlikable.
It's a convoluted mess that zig-zags all over the map, but there are enough jokes that connect to keep you along for the ride.
An important message ... buried under platitudes, sermons and a saccharine score that endlessly plucks at the heart strings.
Moronic lowbrow stoner humor and two of the most annoying characters ever put onscreen make this a grueling experience.
Despite treading far-too-familiar territory, The Hunter's Prayer is a surprisingly solid action thriller that should appeal to fans of Luc Besson's earlier movies.
By the finale, there's way too much happening on screen, to the point where no one will be able to figure out what they're watching.
Darkest Hour showcases a performance by Gary Oldman that is so good, you'll often forget you're watching an actor working from a script.
The Disaster Artist comes off a lot like Ed Wood or even American Splendor, as it feels like there's always multiple layers to what Franco is doing.
Friend Request is either the funniest bad horror movie ever made or, more likely, just a bad movie that was never meant to be a comedy.
A twisty redneck genre flick that partially thrives on its odd stoner humor, then loses something as it shifts to something far darker.
A fascinating doc just being able to see how things really work within the police department compared to what we see in press conferences and through the media.
A welcome return to form for Dayton and Faris
[C.K.] has made the type of masterful picture that might put him into serious consideration as a filmmaker...
It's a decent character piece for Washington to break away from that same cocksure role we've seen him play so many times before
A decent concert film but also a touching tribute to Eddie Vedder's childhood love for the Chicago Cubs, which should make it a favorite among Pearl Jam and Cubs fans alike.
Last Flag Flying is a comedy with a lower case "c," so if you're expecting a lot of big laughs from this story about a man mourning the death of his son, you should probably adjust your expectations.
Having such freedom and such an illustrious cast makes The Meyerowitz Stories one of Baumbach's best movies so far.
A decent, highly informational doc that takes a lighter look at a subject some might take far more seriously than others.
Antonio Banderas hams it up in this dumber than dumb action-comedy that always reaches for the lowest hanging fruit for laughs.
Wonderstruck is probably the biggest disappointment in Todd Haynes' entire career. How one can go from the masterpiece that was Carol or any of his other films to this is mindboggling.
It's the type of action movie that just feels dated and not in a fun way either.
Neither Allen's best movie nor his worst, although it's probably a stronger than his last few, mainly due to Winslet's fabulousness.
Won't be the comeback Schwarzenegger fans may be hoping for, but there are enough funny moments in Killam's directorial debut to augur a promising future in film comedy.
Betts proves herself to be a fantastic storyteller ... Intense and riveting dramatic storytelling we rarely get to see in any given year.
Won't be for everyone, and some people are going to absolutely loathe it, but it's a lovely artistic character exploration that is quite compelling when you're willing to go along for the ride.
A faithful adaptation of a classic manga that drags at times but offers enough exciting moments at others to make it worthwhile.
movie_title: Blade of the Immortal (Mugen no jûnin) (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The embarrassment a few fine, august actors have to go through in the name of 'comedy' is lost on a movie that never warrants a single laugh.
A triumph by Rees as a filmmaker, showing she can handle a wide range of characters and settings to create a cohesive story.
A mishmash of decent action scenes smooshed into a weak revenge-thriller premise that only comes together towards the end.
While not horrible, [it] feels like such a wasted opportunity to end on a high note rather than merely petering away.
There's certainly good to be found in the story Winchester is trying to tell, but it's hard to believe it can possibly satisfy both the casual horror buff and the more diehard supernatural purist.
A film about growth and recovery, about finding your way in life after the loss of a loved one and simply one of the best films I've seen this year so far.
With nothing particularly new or revelatory to offer, Haze is a terrible, pointless movie.
Demetrius Shipp Jr. gives it his all with an impressive performance that's far more than just an impression.
Good luck understanding how any of this might appeal to modern moviegoers. It isn't awful, but it's needlessly convoluted and dull, dull, dull.
After a summer full of disappointing sequels, it shouldn't be too much of a surprise that we're getting yet another.
Ripped is not a good film, yet it's also a movie that's difficult to completely hate.
Loads of fun, Baby Driver gives a great ride.
A grand entry into more straightforward American genre film-mixing by Wright, while still maintaining all the things we've loved about his previous movies.
I'm going to end this review on some sort of hyperbolic pull quote that will look good on Twitter and/or RottenTomatoes that can be used in the film's marketing.
movie_title: War for the Planet of the Apes (2017)

movie_review_blurb: The best-realized Spider-Man movie in terms of making the character current with what's been done with Marvel Studios' other movies...
An intriguing exploration of fate vs. circumstance and coincidence that ends up being far better than it should be, but only if it's not taken too seriously.
A mind-numbing premise that's often embarrassing to its illustrious cast.
Like The Fifth Element, this will grow on people with time ... meant more for discerning moviegoers with strange taste and sensibilities.
movie_title: Valerian and the City of a Thousand Planets (2017)

movie_review_blurb: A serious drama about something with which many soldiers have to contend, needlessly diluted by a terrible crime thriller premise.
It seems content at being just another Saturday Night Live short.
Never goes far enough to truly scare anyone. Even easy-to-please teens might wish for their time back.
A prime candidate for worst movie of the year.
A beautiful film documenting some of the most groundbreaking rock music of the '70s and the major contribution Mick Ronson offered well beyond being "Bowie's guitar player."
movie_title: Beside Bowie: The Mick Ronson Story (2017)

movie_review_blurb: There's so much to absorb and appreciate in this movie that one viewing just might not be enough.

One thing Power mostly gets right is that he spends enough time with both the predators and their victims, separately, so that you start to care for the latter even if you don't fully understand the motivations of the former.
A suitably punky, fast-paced doc that may be long and overly talky but is undeniably comprehensive.
movie_title: Turn It Around: The Story of East Bay Punk (2017)

movie_review_blurb: Fans of John Wick and Kill Bill should generally be impressed with what director Jung has done to put a twist on the typical revenge thriller.
Lowlife features a lot of amazing new talent that's likely to make this a popular cult hit.
Takes filmmaking incompetence to a whole new level.
This bona-fide grindhouse film constantly goes for violent and gory shock value, yet manages to connect more through its hilarious female characters.
An erratic but emotional adaptation of Jeannette Wallis' memoir.
The Safdie Brothers box well outside their weight class with this abrasive crime-thriller.
An above-average, obscenity-laden buddy comedy that mostly excels due to the brilliant comic pairing of Ryan Reynolds and Samuel L. Jackson.
Aspects of the film recalls the early work of Damien Chazelle. If Jasper can continue to deliver on this level, his career may wind up being just as impressive.
A brilliantly made film, unlike anything else out there, and it teaches a valuable lesson about what the penal system's cycle of violence can do to an honest man.
Mopey and pretentious, just like the real Morrissey, but lacking the music that made his work with The Smiths so influential.
While it may not be the best-constructed rock doc [...] Who the F**k is still a satisfyingly quick 77-minute film.
movie_title: Who The F**k Is That Guy? The Fabulous Journey of Michael Alago (2017)

movie_review_blurb: To create something so epic while also maintaining itself as a small and intimate film is something that's difficult to accomplish. Somehow Schlesinger is able to pull off that feat.
M. Night Shyamalan's thrilling and satisfying return to form showcases an entertaining, multi-faceted role for James McAvoy.
Probably best seen with a rowdy theater reacting every time the spirit's name is uttered.
Li Lu's bland road movie is barely salvaged by the talents of its star, Agnes Bruckner.
movie_title: There Is a New World Somewhere (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The weaker characters and generally weak plot keep it from being one of the better comic book movies.
An even more relatable story of real-world people and the troubles in which we frequently find ourselves.
A wonderful surprise.
Dull at times but otherwise fine, this fantasy remake tends to excel from the realism instilled into its animated title character.
Won't be for everyone, but if nothing else, you'll never look at your groceries the same way again.
Mel Gibson makes a brilliant return to the revenge-thriller genre with a surprisingly strong effort.
Imperium is a stark character drama that's more disconcerting for its subject matter than its actual storytelling.
Equally clever and charming, and ultimately a pretty good date movie in its own right.
The type of edge-of-your seat thrills promised by its commercials, but also takes you into far darker territory than anticipated.
With stunning photorealistic animation but poor storytelling, this action movie is meant solely to interest fans of the videogame franchise.
One of the most enjoyable films of the year.
A moving and inspirational story of strength and perseverance in the face of tremendous adversity.
One of the more intriguing German films that sadly won't get nearly as much attention here as it deserves.
movie_title: The People vs. Fritz Bauer (Der Staat Gegen Fritz Bauer) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: A very accessible and relatable movie about family and how one family pulls together to try to fight against adversity with love and laughs.
As funny as it ends up being, it's also quite thought-provoking, because it makes you think about whether you're satisfied with your own relationships
This unnecessary sequel to the Russian animated film loses all sense of coherence long before any of its annoyingly talky animals ever get to the moon.
movie_title: Space Dogs: Adventure to the Moon (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It's more than a little ironic that a film called Complete Unknown will leave you scratching your head about what you just watched.
The sequel to the Danish comedy duo's breakout hit fails to find the same degree of laughs.
Chris Reading's attempt at a lower-budget space thriller suffers as much from its lack of originality as it does from its weak cast and script.
A distinctly authentic-feeling coming-of-age story that introduces a bright new visionary filmmaker in Justin Tipping.
A solid script and cast and a fantastic ending battle helps Antoine Fuqua's first Western stand out despite being rather conventional.
Filmmaker J.A. Bayona goes three for three with A Monster Calls, a movie more steeped in fantasy and fairy tale than his previous one.
A cerebral and emotionally resonant examination of language through the genre of science fiction.
With nothing new to add to the "Blair Witch" mythos, this is one found footage movie that should have been left lost in the woods.
Peter Berg's masterful disaster flick will shake you up with its accuracy.
... A pleasant enough experience in which you should easily be able to find someone or something to relate to in it.
Chazelle creates something absolutely unforgettable. Few people will be able to see this movie only once.
The film is quite hilarious and on par with Tarantino's recent work.
Scares come easily from a fairly simple idea in this impressive horror debut from director David Sandberg.
An oppressive onslaught of noises and colors, occasionally punctuated by a joke.
Well-rounded portrait of a talented celebrity DJ, whose potential was taken away by drug addiction.
movie_title: As I AM: The Life and Times of DJ AM (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The film also captures the ups and downs of the band that sometimes felt like they were cursed.
movie_title: The Damned: Don't You Wish That We Were Dead (2015)

movie_review_blurb: The Lonely Island at their best and a brilliantly clever successor to This is Spinal Tap.
If you're a serious horror fan, then you absolutely must add The Wailing to your must-see list this year.
Guns N' Roses rocker's inane babbling does little to enhance this tedious doc.
movie_title: It's So Easy and Other Lies (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Mark Strong deserves better material than this.
As with the best popcorn flicks, Out of the Shadows offers plenty of mindless entertainment and mind-numbing silliness...
movie_title: Teenage Mutant Ninja Turtles: Out of the Shadows (2016)

movie_review_blurb: The ghost busters of The Conjuring 2 are scary good.
Probably good enough that if you liked the first movie, you'll want to check this one out as well.
A Norwegian history lesson that offers very little of interest for American audiences, unless they're really into skiing.
Seems to talk down to all but the youngest of children, making it grueling for adults to find anything to keep them invested.
Unsettling enough to make you think twice about what might be in the room with you when the lights go out.
Needless to say Swiss Army Man isn't going to be for everyone.
A wonderful slice of New Zealand-bred humor that should have a far wider appeal than Waititi's previous films.
The Shallows isn't bad as much-needed escapist summer fun
It's not nearly as good as it should be with the pedigree of filmmaker and star involved.
If nothing else, Emmerich's return to familiar territory shows his evolution as a filmmaker well in-tune with what it takes to keep mass audiences entertained.
A B-grade action movie filled with racist, homophobic and sexist humor, knowing its audience is likely to eat it up.
Our Kind of Traitor tries to sell itself as a classic British espionage thriller, but with spy work this boring, this isn't our kind of movie.
After three disturbingly violent films, this may be a concept that deserves to be purged.
Fairly harmless and innocuous, but also only as funny as your tolerance for the overuse of Borg's idiotic shenanigans.
It's clearly the talent Mortensen has for bringing out the best in the young cast that makes the film one that should find a good number of fans.
A surprisingly fun summer comedy and icing on the (wedding) cake for fans of the raunchiest of humor.
movie_title: Mike and Dave Need Wedding Dates (2016)

movie_review_blurb: At best, The Dog Lover is like a bad Hallmark Channel or Lifetime movie, so bland and vanilla it would be inhumane to canines to call it a "dog" of a movie.
Morath's film, while incredibly informative, is also entertaining enough to not make you feel like you've been handed a written test in PhysEd.
As with many supermodels, The Neon Demon is gorgeous to the eye but ultimately quite vacant and shallow.
Sleepless isn't bad for making the Vegas PD seem corrupt, as much as it is bad for making them look incompetent and clueless.
Simply one of the best historic musical docs you're likely to see.
movie_title: The Beatles: Eight Days a Week - The Touring Years (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It feel more like you're watching real lives and events rather than a big bombastic movie with lots of overwrought drama.
Zack Whedon's missing person thriller starts out slow but showcases fine acting by Aaron Paul and his irresistible chemistry with Annabelle Wallis.
Chemistry between the talented Alden Ehrenreich and Lily Collins tends to overshadow Warren Beatty's Howard Hughes in Rules Don't Apply.
In a year already full of crappy sequels, Bad Santa 2 is the lump of coal we really didn't need this Christmas.
If you enjoy slightly awkward romance during wartime, Allied is worth a fling.
You'll try your best to hold back the tears, only to find yourself incapable of not being thoroughly moved by Saroo's journey.
Jessica Chastain gives an amazing performance as a woman you don't immediately like and have trouble rooting for but whom really drives what makes the film so good.
Not for the squeamish and even those with strong stomachs may find themselves getting bored at times.
A must-see doc for fans of New York noise bands, but maybe a little too precious for anyone who never made it out to the Williamsburg venue Death By Audio.
movie_title: Goodnight Brooklyn: The Story of Death by Audio (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Canadian/Chinese director Johnny Ma has made a sensational debut.
A decent look into the tumultuous rock relationship that led to murder, but not particularly essential except to Sex Pistols completists.
movie_title: Sad Vacation: The Last Days of Sid and Nancy (2016)

movie_review_blurb: This inspirational story of three brilliant women is like a bright ray of hope breaking out from the pre-Civil Rights South.
Garth Jennings ("Son of Rambow") gives the humor in this comedy a very different sensibility.
Having a pop superstar like Timberlake in your voice cast, and deliberately not having him sing until near the end just seems like a waste of that talent.
End up being better than it probably deserves to be, but most of the time, that's because Hopkins can really do no wrong ... except in picking his movies.
Despite the strange direction the plot takes, this is a film that goes with old school traditional values in the vein of movies like Miracle on 34th Street and It's a Wonderful Life...
Ventures into some corny (yet sweet) territory in resolving its central conflict, but it throws enough laughs at the viewer that at least some of them land.
A slow-moving, heady twist on the space travel sci-fi subgenre that benefits more from Chris Pratt's dynamic range than Jennifer Lawrence's performance.
A somewhat silly premise leads to a lot of hilariously quirky animated musical fun.
For years we've heard moans that video-game movies are jinxed ... Assassin's Creed won't lift that curse.
In a world that seems to be getting worse with every passing minute, I, Daniel Blake is a sobering but inspiring pleasure - easily one of the best films of the year.
A harrowing but inspiring look at a deplorable act of terror that brought a number of brave individuals and a city together to find those responsible.

For a movie where so much occurs in the first 30 minutes, the pace still tends to drag and, at times, is as slow as hell. A lot of these problems can be attributed to Affleck's stilted screenplay that never quite finds the right tone.
This is clearly one franchise that's been fully drained of its blood.
Split is a thrilling return to form for M. Night Shyamalan that proves he still has many new tricks up his sleeve.
A genuinely ugly and misguided attempt at merging dark comedy with gore.
Detailed knowledge of the subject and a fine ensemble cast of characters makes for a compelling (albeit wholly fictional) financial thriller.
A deeply emotional film about loss that will probably have you crying by film's end.
If you're remotely interested in America's space program, this will be a fun movie to watch.
Ryan Patrick Bachand's breakthrough performance does a lot to show off the potential in Sam Kretchmar's debut.
A personalized love letter to [Iggy Pop and the Stooges] and a fitting tribute to their legacy.
Nowhere near a perfect movie but it navigates Roth's cloudy waters surprisingly well ... and there are moments that are absolutely heartbreaking.
First-time director Kelly Fremon Craig delivers a hilarious teen comedy with a truly original voice.
Far more enjoyable and entertaining than one might expect.
A pretty fantastic character study that really keeps you invested in the story and where it goes.
With The Queen of Katwe, Mira Nair really has created something quite special.
One of my biggest guilty pleasures of the year.
A drama that's as frustrating as it is innovative in its storytelling decisions.
Adam Driver makes the perfect Jim Jarmusch proxy in Paterson, the indie filmmaker's most accessible work.
20th Century Women is a brilliantly insightful portrait of an extended family told from the perspective of 1979.
Godzilla ... lumbers through Tokyo in a far less natural way than the days when an actor in a rubber suit stomped on models.
An impressive edge-of-your-seat thriller set within a fantastic outdoors environment.
Ben Affleck's action-thriller is plagued by muddled and convoluted storytelling, and a general lack of action.
DreamWorks Animation's karaoke musical has the flimsiest of plots and silliest of premises, yet it still finds a way to pay off.
A gorgeous animated tale of love, family and art set during Japan's Edo period.
An absolutely terrifying account that keeps you fairly caught up in what essentially was just 96 minutes of terror.
Rebecca Hall gives an absolutely indelible performance.

When it comes to making films that work as much for the sake of artistic expression as for capturing a moment in history, there's little question Jackie might be one of the finest pieces of cinematic storytelling we see this year.
If there's nothing else to be gained from Lee's latest, at least it confirms his amazing instinct for finding talent.
Offers some easy scares and cheesy fun, but if nothing else, it gets points for not losing sight of its characters amidst those scares.

With all the action movies that have come before, it's tough to make car chases and fist fights seem original and exciting, but fortunately, there's enough of a story to keep things interesting even when you might feel a sense of déjà vu.
If for some reason you're undecided or thinking of voting for a third party candidate or just don't feel like going out to vote for anyone, then you should at least try to catch Moore's new movie.
A startlingly intimate portrait of enigmatic X Japan drummer Yoshiki that goes far beyond the typical rock doc.
Isn't as unwatchable as other similar movies, but it's still pretty deplorable and offensive.
Absolutely gorgeous, with so much attention paid to every visual detail from the costumes to the mansion's many rooms.
Won't be for everyone, but those who have stuck through Howard and Hanks' previous Dan Brown adaptations should find enough thrills to keep them interested in solving the mystery.
An inspiring look at a brave young girl taking on her tribe's male-dominated eagle-hunting traditions.
Kelly Reichardt has finally made her Seinfeld-esque movie about nothing.
Not a terrible movie as much as a redundant one since we've already seen much of the source material and most of that does it better than this mostly ripped-off cliché fest.
While this is going to be a polarizing and divisive film, it's one that people will talk about after seeing it, almost as if it was made as an experiment itself.
A beautiful film marred by a weak script that tries to dive headlong down the Hitchcock rabbit hole without offering any of the tension or suspense that might have made it a worthwhile journey.
Aacts as a time capsule of New York of that era ... being able to see all of this crazy originality unfolding chronologically really makes this a very special film.
Joe Wright continues to prove himself as one of the more innovative filmmakers working today.
Better than the two previous sequels in large part due to the inspiration Kevin Williamson found to return to Woodsboro without ignoring everything that's happened since the last movie.
What could and should have been an unforgettable historic drama gets a bit lost along the way due to convoluted storytelling and a number of questionable directorial decisions.
The filmmakers' adherence to standard nature doc formula can probably be forgiven due to solid storytelling and filmmaking.
The results are absolutely hilarious, maybe even funnier than Super Size Me
movie_title: POM Wonderful Presents: The Greatest Movie Ever Sold (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The fact it works as well as it does is a strong testament both to the source material and to those involved with bringing it to the screen.
Takashi Miike's masterwork, the type of grand filmmaking we've always come to expect from him and the film that should get him taken more seriously among cinephiles and mainstream movie fans alike.
If you liked any of the previous movies, you should be even more thrilled by what they've done this time around with a lot more at play here in terms of storytelling.
The fact they've found a way into the comic material without being precious about it leaves you immediately wanting to see more of all the characters.

Even those who aren't as fanatical should be able to appreciate the enthusiasm and energy people are willing to put into something they love and hate as much as they do George Lucas' 'Star Wars' movies.
Not particularly funny nor memorable, but at least [it] has a few saving graces due to a solid cast and doesn't leave you feeling like you wasted your time.
Making comparisons to the work of Wes Anderson is a little too obvious, but Winkler definitely has a talent for creating strong believable characters and dialogue.
Rarely gets beyond its simplistic plot and Kate Hudson's ridiculous character.
You have to assume the title is meant to be ironic since the one thing 'Passion Play' lacks more than anything else is passion.
Simply put, An Invisible Sign is one of the worst movies we've seen in a very, very long time.
Whether you're looking for an easy laugh or a rioutously funny comedy, Bridesmaids will have you in tears.
Like a Chinese Schindler's List, it's not an easy film to watch, but it's an important story that needs to be told and remembered.
Anyone who's ever hit a low in their own lives can find inspiration in how Will Ferrell's character overcomes obstacles and pulls himself up from rock bottom.
Woody Allen's latest venture takes him into new territory and moving locations has inspired him to deliver one of his strongest premises in years.
It's admirable how a movie with so many obvious influences and references can offer an experience that still feels like its own thing.
Only true fans will be able to get excited about watching essentially the same thing we've seen three times before.
movie_title: Pirates of the Caribbean: On Stranger Tides (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The master filmmaker takes one step further into another plane of creative cinematic storytelling.
A valiant enough first effort, but {Sean} Kirkpatrick has a long way to go before he achieves even Mean Streets-level Scorsese.
One of those welcome sequels that lives up to the promise of its predecessor; fans of the original movie should enjoy how it builds nicely upon the set-up.
Essentially, it's Ocean's 12 ... if a monkey stole the movie.
Not knowing whether to be a comedy or a drama and often failing at both, there's very little to recommend about this downer of a movie.
Fans of the movies should appreciate how Matthew Vaughn has established characters they love in a unique setting with a strong cast and set pieces as big and impressive as the other movies.

A highly entertaining film that exudes all the warmth of Tom McCarthy's previous films but also has a sense of comic pace and timing that should allow it far greater appeal to a wider array of audiences.
Snyder's craziest ride yet and his most ambitious film to date ... the action ultimately wins out over the actual story.

For better or worse, Red State just doesn't have the elements we expect from a Kevin Smith movie, and horror fans will feel especially ripped off with how little the film resembles anything that may be deemed conventional horror.
A genre film that literally pulls no punches that will thrill fans of Tarantino and Rodriguez's recent revenge movies-- true "grindhouse" through and through.
Works perfectly as a situational comedy vehicle for Paul Rudd with all the warmth of an indie yet also the type of easy-to-digest premise that should appeal to a wide range of audiences.
There have been better movies set in the financial world, but for a rather contained ensemble drama, it generally works, though it's no Inside Job
A movie that will make you laugh and cry in equal proportions and it signals the arrival of another terrific second generation filmmaker.
Just not a very strong take on the bank-robbing comedy we've seen so many times before.
The nature of the genre gives The Details tonal issues that ultimately, it's able to overcome.
Any hopes that three movies may have improved Dito Montiel as a filmmaker probably should have been left at the door of the Eccles Theater.
Despite its potential, it adheres too closely to formula and is driven by stunted dialogue as well as a cast that aren't up to the material.
Offers enough hearty laughs to at least be considered a guilty pleasure, even if it still sticks far too close to formula that's worked for Sandler before.
We can't say enough great things about this terrific debut and how well it plays even on repeat viewings when you know where things are going.
A fairly decent action flick with the type of car chases and exploits one might expect from a Joel Silver Joint.
James Wan's most effective film as a director and one of the scariest and creepiest movies in some time.
Leaves you wanting to see what happens next to the characters, and that almost makes up for the film's earlier cheesiness, but not quite.
There's very little that sets it apart from superior comedies that have done a better job portraying real people as the dirty-minded beings we all are.
Those looking for a journey into the darker side of human nature that's on par with some of the best serial killer thrillers should be significantly impressed with the results.
Its abuse of nostalgia is more frustrating than entertaining and the same can be said for Dan Fogler.
Clear proof that a great director can work in any genre and medium and produce great results.
The umpteenth take on Brontë's novel takes a unique gothic approach, but the results are grim at times and dull at others.
A fun and entertaining take on the genre.
Some may surprised at what a smart film came from the director of so many stupid comedies.
What is an otherwise decent war movie is marred by unforgivably bad writing and even worse acting.
Quite deep and affecting on many levels with a premise that never gets dull or predictable or feels gimmicky.
Having so much talent involved in making a comedy that's not particularly funny is quite disappointing.
A deeply moving film on many levels that wears its love for '60s music on its sleeve for what is ultimately a solid family drama.
A solid L.A. crime story that once again proves McConaughey as a leading actor to be reckoned with.
A sublime bit of filmmaking that explores faith and history without the pandering that often comes with the former and the Hollywood clichés that normally comes with the latter.
One of the more impressive debuts we've seen in some time, a hypnotic and haunting film that pulls you into its story and keeps your attention while maintaining a steady intensity.
Super 8 thrives on nostalgia and Abrams' admiration for all things Spielberg, but the results are as aggravating as they are satisfying.
A troubling but inspiring David vs. Goliath story that's probably one of the better films to explore the current ecological problems with a more personal touch.
An incredibly unique look at Iran through the eyes of two young women trapped in a society that doesn't allow them to express their individuality.
Helen Mirren and Jessica Chastain give such fantastic performances in their respective timelines, it works quite well in terms of drama and suspense.
[Joffe] isn't nearly as strong a director as he is a writer and he's unable to realize such an intricate story in a way that's even remotely satisfying.
First-time filmmakers Gregory and Huyck have assembled a fantastic cast who do an amazing job selling this fairly simple comedy premise and making every scene count.
A terrific sleeper doc that somehow finds a way of pulling you into its investigation and makes you wonder about what drives people to do the things they do.
movie_title: Resurrect Dead: The Mystery of the Toynbee Tiles (2011)

movie_review_blurb: The music and cast really drive Sfar's debut in a way that will make you immediately want to learn more about Gainsbourg.
A brilliantly executed film that succeeds both as a family drama and one of the most exciting sports films you're likely to see this year.
A powerful 'what if?' that leaves you reeling from the implications that something like this could very well happen exactly as depicted.
May not feel quite like the classic baseball movie others have achieved, but it's certainly pleasant enough to be enjoyable even by non-sports fans.
The slow pace and eclectic tone might take some adjusting to, but there's no denying that Drive is absolutely brilliant filmmaking.
The brilliant cast Clooney has assembled are delivering some of their finest work in telling this story.
Rises above its difficult subject matter to create a movie that's warm and poignant but incredibly funny as well.
Sturgess is great, Hathaway is less so, and ultimately, the more enjoyable high points don't do enough to make up for a lot of serious lulls.
Gets away from what we've come to expect from the filmmaker who started out by making some of the most disturbing genre films.
Jeff Nichols has arrived, proving he has what it takes to deliver on far bigger ideas than his indie roots have shown so far.
Things are established well in the first half, but it's disappointing when it becomes too reverential to its predecessor and fails to avoid the traps that plagued it.
Has the same mix of lightness and depth of Payne's past films even if the material doesn't feel nearly as strong.
Once again proves Polley's talents both for writing riveting dialogue and for being able to get unforgettable performances from her actors.
Jennifer Westfeldt once again proves she has a way of examining aspects of everyday life that can be appreciated even by those not in that same situation.
Shelton's clearly found her legging in order to create something that stays true to her indie ethics, while also creating something that can be accessible to wider audiences.
A powerful second film from Moverman, one that could probably find itself an audience beyond the arthouse crowd.
The type of lazy storytelling we've come to expect from actual studio movies with not a particularly fulfilling way to end the movie
Drake Doremus has arrived and he's creating a new cinematic language that makes Like Crazy unlike any other movie you're likely to see this year.
Trying to get audiences to root for whether fish will swim upstream is often an easier task than getting them to care about whether the two leads will hook up.
A fairly simple and straight-forward competition comedy that's much more entertaining and endearing than one might imagine from the premise.
One is likely to leave Stillman's movie feeling somewhat disenchanted that it only partially delivers on the long wait for his return.
Considering how great it looks, it's a shame the odd choices Almodovar makes in telling the story turn it into one of his first big misses in a long time.
Mills delivers another film full of poise and poignancy that's emotionally-devastating, but also an enjoyable experience.
It's always great that movies like this can be made for so little money, but when the results are so dull and derivative, the only real question is "Why bother?"
The fantastic performances make it a real winner of a movie, one that entertains and moves you regardless of gender, age or race.
Infinitely funny and entertaining, but also ending on a coda of sadness, one that leaves you wondering how much of the real Steve Coogan and Rob Brydon are on display here?
The access Rossi gets is quite incredible as is his ability to edit nearly a year's worth of footage into a tight and cohesive film.
movie_title: Page One: Inside the New York Times (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Fails on so many levels, both as a movie and as a comics adaptation, that it's easily one of the bigger disappointments of the summer.
Despite gags that fall flat and potty humor going for easy laughs from the kids, Mr. Popper's Penguins offers generally enjoyable and harmless family fun.
A New York City boy-meets-girl story may be something we've seen many times before and often better, but Wiesen brings something unique to the mix.
Likely to be one of the funniest concert docs you're likely to see and not just for what's happening on-stage.
By no means terrible or unbearable, though it's slightly disappointing after the brilliance of Kasdan's previous movie.
Michael Bay has essentially created his 'Star Wars prequels' for a new generation, and that is not a compliment.
Project Nim will be considered amongst the best docs of the year and another brilliant piece of work from Marsh.
You'll definitely leave the movie hoping [A Tribe Called Quest] will work out their differences to make more music together sometime in the future.
movie_title: Beats Rhymes & Life: The Travels of a Tribe Called Quest (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Like The Hangover, the genius of Horrible Bosses lies in the fact it takes the simplest of concepts and builds upon it with hilarious non-stop laughs.
Attack the Block is quite a brilliant debut by Joe Cornish, the type of fun genre flick that we just don't see that often anymore.
Easily the most shocking and disturbing movie in the series and if they choose to finally end things here, they would be ending things on a high note.
Not even particularly funny or entertaining, it's as if they tried too hard to make a movie that appeals to everybody, but instead wound up with a movie that will appeal to nobody.
A far more light-hearted approach than some of Morris' other recent work but just as layered and thorough in terms of getting to the heart of a story and leaving you thinking afterwards.
If you are looking for a way to quickly bond with your younger kids, this truly is a wonderful hour of entertainment that will leave you smiling.
A fairly decent drama about a little-known part of French history that may be a little melodramatic at times but offers solid storytelling.
A Little Help could have used a lot of help, but it's doubtful that would have saved it from being one of the most incompetent movies we've seen this year.
The perfect casting of Evans as well as the original approach to the action ultimately makes up for some of the annoying changes from the source material.
A boring and tame movie that fails to work either as comedy or as romantic drama.
Might not be the rousing sci-fi action movie some might expect, but there's more than enough fun summer entertainment to make it worthwhile, especially if you're a fan of Westerns.
A talented cast and a strong last act is ultimately what saves The Change-Up from being a dud, though you'll have to endure a lot of lazy gross-out humor before you get to that point.
Up there with some of the best franchise reboots; anyone seeing it, whether they're a fan of the previous movies or not, will leave it hoping it does well enough to warrant more.
movie_title: Rise of the Planet of the Apes (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Straddling the madness of Nicolas Refn or Lars von Trier and the low-fi production values of Joe Swanberg, Bellflower proves those two things don't necessarily coexist well within the same movie.
May not immediately feel like Gibney's most inspired doc compared to his more politically-tinted work, but a unique look at interesting times and people.
Like the Coen Brothers on speed, 30 Minutes or Less is an inspired update of the classic buddy action-comedy of the '80s and '90s
To say they've saved the best for last would be an understatement. It's a finale that's truly magical in every way, and easily the best Harry Potter movie yet.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 2 (2011)

movie_review_blurb: Solondz's most upbeat film since Welcome to the Dollhouse that doesn't make you feel like you need to take a long shower to clean off how ugly it makes you feel afterwards.
It seems unlikely anyone but Brendan Gleeson could pull off a character like Sgt. Gerry Boyle and keep the crowd on his side.
Doesn't really feel like one of Bier's better films even if it's still a very good film and better than so many other dramas that have tried to explore this type of subject matter.
Mindnumbingly boring and unfunny ... throws a bunch of things that wouldn't necessarily work together onto the screen hoping movie audiences are too dumb to care.
The results are a truly original doc and one of the year's best -- heartfelt and funny and thoroughly entertaining.
movie_title: Joan Rivers: A Piece Of Work (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Rises above the fact it's a remake and delivers the type of classic old school filmmaking we rarely see nowadays, delivering a solidly satisfying and entertaining experience.
Tries a bit too hard to cater to fans of the original show at times, but it's exactly the type of fun escapist entertainment we need this summer.
Visually and thematically compelling ... only marred by the languid pacing, but it's always better whenever Mikkelsen and Mouglalis are on screen together.

The Duplass Brothers have taken up the challenge to break through from indie obscurity to the mainstream without compromising their ideals or sacrificing the quality of their character-driven storytelling.
Winterbottom delves into Coen Brothers territory and delivers one of his best-looking movies as well as one that's far more cinematic than what we've normally seen from him.
Funnier and more poignant than the previous two Toy Story installments. Up there with WALL-E and Ratatouille as one of Pixar's best-realized films.
Gives Hollywood an excuse not to make more Westerns, just as it's bad for the future of graphic novel adaptations ... save your money and buy the trades.
The entertainment comes from how much fun it is watching [Cruise and Diaz] on screen together and that's what separates Knight and Day from previous attempts at mixing romance, comedy, and action.
If you're a fan of war movies, Restrepo puts you on the frontlines and impacts you in a way you won't soon forget what you've seen.
Not the worst movie any of the cast have done but far from their best work ... the sum of the parts rarely achieves anything as funny as Sandler might have done on his own.
There is a special place in hell for filmmakers who deliberately force audiences to endure a worse dog movie than both Marley & Me and The Shaggy Dog remake put together.

Falls somewhere directly between Court TV and VH-1 ... a fairly thorough portrait of [Spector] both as an eccentric but tormented artist and as an arrogant blowhard whose hubris may have been his undoing.
movie_title: The Agony and the Ecstasy of Phil Spector (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Nimród Antal's movie makes for a far more satisfying sequel than the weak 1990 follow-up or any of the "AVP" movies, maybe because it makes more of an effort to create the vibe and tension that worked so well in the original.

Nolan's most personal and daring film, "Inception" contains some of Nolan's most innovative ideas since "Memento." It's also his most successful movie in terms of being able to fully realize every nuance of such a rich concept.

So perfectly paced and quite well-made, but left open-ended for potential sequels rather than being concerned about telling a complete story, it's not nearly as successful as the movies that influenced it.
With very little to differentiate [itself] from dozens of other movies meant solely for young girls, Ramona and Beezus certainly shows potential to be a better movie than it is.
Just a brilliantly-realized look at this influential artist, and really the definitive word on why he had such an impact.

Significantly slower than Salt (obviously) and requires more patience and focus, but it's ultimately more satisfying in that Carion realizes the importance of establishing and developing the characters.
Another genius turn in Wright's career and filmography -- destined to become a beloved classic among the under-30 ADD generation.
May not resonate as soundly as Step Brothers or be as quotable as Anchorman, but it's certainly another one chalked up in the 'win' column for Ferrell and McKay.
A squandered opportunity to tell what may have been an interesting story.
Offers the quality storytelling of those '70s crime classics but with an edge that makes it feels far more contemporary than other films influenced by that era
Blakeson is a filmmaker to watch due to the masterful way he's created such a riveting twist-filled film out of such a simple premise.
Like a 2 1/2 hour infomercial about sharing your feelings that replaces any true emotions with some of the most ridiculous and useless spiritual rhetoric you're ever likely to hear.
A poignant human story deeply rooted in feelings we all can relate to even if we come from a more conventional family than this one.
Like the Gosford Park of bad acting, this is one throwback that should have been thrown back.
The welcome return of one of horror's more underrated filmmakers is marked by one of the most distinctive scientific horror films since Cronenberg made it fashionable during the '80s.
Infinitely fascinating for the way it lays out [its] puzzle pieces as well as the interesting local characters the filmmakers encounter on their way to learning the truth themselves.
Kids will absolutely adore and thrill to this adventure, but it will sneak up on grown-ups who will eventually be dazzled both by the beauty of the visuals and the masterful storytelling.
Every once in a while, a comedy comes along that's so outlandish and ridiculous you have to take notice ... the emphasis is on the first word of 'high concept.'
Watching Seyfried come into her own as an actress going toe-to-toe with a powerhouse like Julianne Moore is thoroughly satisfying.
A thoroughly entertaining and fun adventure that delivers exactly what is expected from a movie called 'Clash of the Titans,' nothing more or less.
You have to be impressed with the dedication the filmmakers had to covering as much of the story as they could at a time when it was very much in the public eye.
Fun and entertaining in all the ways a violent R-rated action flick should be, but its unfocused structure creates a lull that almost kills the movie.
By no means groundbreaking even by studio comedy standards, but like last year's The Proposal, the movie succeeds more based on its two leads than on its high concept material.
A funny and fascinating look at an underground art movement, and how easy it is for someone with questionable amounts of talent to suddenly become a star.
Some great scenes in there, but somewhat erratic and a little too derivative of the work of another filmmaker, Spain's Pedro Almodovar.
movie_title: The Secret in Their Eyes (El Secreto de Sus Ojos) (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Duchovny exudes charm and humor throughout, and he alone nearly makes up for material that's generally rather flat.
Serene and sublime, Oceans is the best nature doc since March of the Penguins -- kids will love it!
A fairly literal translation of the comics to the screen that isn't perfect but has enough funny moments to keep you involved with the characters.
A clever spin-off that allows the two actors who helped make Sarah Marshall so hilarious to flourish on their own ... certainly stands a good chance at being one of the funniest comedies this summer.
High expectations from the first movie may leave some wanting, but there's enough brilliance on display to leave you wanting more as well.

Bayer's stylish visual direction does little to detract from the fact this is essentially the same movie with far too many visual nods and little to differentiate it or set it apart from the original.
The combination of strong writing and note-perfect performances makes Mother and Child one of those unforgettable films that should be amongst the year's best.

If the inner workings of Washington, D.C. interest you, especially in terms of how politicians and lobbyists work the system to make money, Gibney's latest can be accepted as a fine addition to his filmography.
movie_title: Casino Jack And The United States Of Money (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Literally 80 minutes of footage of babies sans commentary ... acts as little more than a commercial for procreation.
[Ridley] Scott has created another masterful period piece of the highest caliber, one that gets your adrenaline pumping as it draws you into its story.
Curry's just an amazing filmmaker who knows exactly how to pace the movie so it isn't just talking heads ... one of the most riveting and insightful docs you're likely to see this year
A unique look at the conflict in the Middle East by putting it in the context of a competitive sports doc.
movie_title: After The Cup: Sons Of Sakhnin United (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Establishes a character on par with Austin Powers and does more than an adequate job transcending the pitfalls of prior movies based on "SNL" sketches.
Any attempt to create a magical fun adventure instead falls flat, ultimately turning into a convoluted mess that barely registers once the end credits roll.
movie_title: Prince of Persia: The Sands of Time (2010)

movie_review_blurb: Continues to be little more than the female equivalent to porn, a fashionable but unrealistic fairy tale with very little actual meat, but this time, it feels more like a cash grab.
The visuals are quite spectacular and like always, something worth marveling over as one tries to figure out how they were achieved.
Survival of the Dead is clear proof it's time for Romero to give up the zombie and MOVE ON.
In a genre that's become so devoid of originality, Tom Six's movie is the type of disturbing and disgusting gamechanger, much like the breakouts by Hooper, Cronenberg, Miike...
Proves Paddy Considine has a distinctive and singular vision as a filmmaker as if working with so many great filmmakers has rubbed off on him.
Quite momentous and on par with the works of Errol Morris and Michael Moore without ever feeling strictly political or losing sight of the humanity at the story's core.
Saying Akin's latest could have very well been made within the Hollywood studio system would not be a compliment.
Morning Glory is one of those rare mainstream comedies that's far better than it should be. It's a fun crowd-pleasing movie indeed.
Deathly Hallows - Part 1 isn't necessarily bad but it's more than a little disappointing.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Deathly Hallows - Part 1 (2010)

movie_review_blurb: One of those rare films that affects you in ways that might not be immediately apparent but that sticks with you long after it's finished.
About women standing up to The Man, the great big corporate beast who is constantly trying to save money by undermining their hard work.
Despite prominent pacing problems and an ending that goes on for too long, The Three Next Days works well as a character piece due to the solid performances by the cast.
A generic, sanitized version of Showgirls that blatantly plagiarizes dozens of far superior musicals.

Offers a warmth and familiarity that allows for easy entry as an inspirational tale of overcoming one's shortcomings, while also delivering a rich multi-layered experience that stands up to repeat viewings.
As masterfully-crafted as Black Swan is, it's still very much Natalie Portman's performance as a ballerina pushed to the very edges of sanity that makes the film absolutely unforgettable.
A raw and unadulterated comedy that finds true emotion within its characters and its humor from the fact that some of the craziest bits really happened.
David O. Russell's strongest film in years ... the movie's heart and soul lies in Christian Bale's performance and what his character brings to every one of his scenes.
Another painfully dull movie about an American in Europe hoping to capitalize on the looks and fame of its stars.
One of the few films that handles grief honestly and in an engaging way without ever going for any sort of sappy Hollywood clichés.

May not be the end-all be-all of global warming docs, although it does a fine job cutting through the rhetoric to ask questions and focus on facts rather than just trying to create fear in the viewer.
Considering how many great films have been influenced by Brooks' earlier work, it's hard to believe how badly this movie fails.
Embellishing Jack Abramoff's story with so much humor makes the film feel more like a political parody than a document of what really happened.
There's something clearly missing that makes you think this movie may have fared better if it was made three years ago... or not at all.
What could have been a moving tale of a father and daughter reconnecting instead comes off as an interminably boring and pretentious bit of "inside baseball"
Uninspired compared to previous efforts, making it fairly blatant the Coens should stick to their own original material.
Gulliver's Travels is just plain embarrassing in how ill-conceived it is, bad enough that it could easily signal the death of Black's career as a live action comedy star.
If Leigh were trying to make some sort of statement on life or aging or relationships or the current depressed climate in his country, it never quite materializes as effectively as planned.
Lacking any sort of energy and the weak premise at its core means there's very little anyone or anything could have been done to salvage it.
A fine debut that provides another piece to the enigmatic puzzle that is Romanian cinema.
movie_title: If I Want To Whistle, I Whistle (2011)

movie_review_blurb: An amazing film that really delivers on everything we expect from great cinema - a character unlike any we've seen before, and a beautiful and compelling way of telling his story.
A surprisingly funny and ingeniously clever take on superheroes ... The Green Hornet certainly sets the bar high for other superhero movies coming out this year.
Stirring and thought-provoking in a similar way as Black Swan, showing how far a flawed system drives one poor young woman merely trying to please her employers.
One of the best films we've seen in some time, an incredibly powerful film that unfolds in such unique and unexpected ways, it's not an experience easily forgotten or dismissed.
Groundbreaking and cutting edge filmmaking in terms of the production design and special FX, and the action scenes are some of the best you'll see this year.
A classic case of a decent cast trying to make the most out of bad material, but it brings nothing new to the 'urban comedy' than any of the worst Friday knock-offs.
Women may appreciate the message and sentiments expressed in Shange's words, but they would have been even more effective if incorporated into a stronger story.
Due Date may not be nearly as clever as The Hangover, but it's a fairly satisfying film on its own merits, a fun experience that's more than just an endless stream of jokes.
Creepy, disturbing fun... and very surprising in the way it handles the subject matter differently than how it's been handled in the past.
Quite engrossing, very much like a cross between Spielberg's Catch Me If You Can and a French 'Godfather'
Gorgeously shot with plenty of beautiful scenery to gush over, but mostly dull and disjointed, more "boredom-inducing" than Bourne.
Never fully justifies its expanded status nor does it feel like a movie that anyone's going to relish beyond one viewing, but far more satisfying and effective than The Expendables
Richet and Cassel's masterpiece, just a riveting story of a notorious criminal who keeps the viewer equally charmed and shocked by his actions.
Isn't quite as strong as Gone Baby Gone but it's still a solid sophomore effort with the heist sequences being well worth the price of admission.

Some people may appreciate its original take on a not particularly original premise ... others are likely to find it too tedious and depressing to put much thought into what the filmmakers were trying to accomplish.
As delightfully odd and quirky as you might expect from an actor like Philip Seymour Hoffman, but it also has a strange tone that's hard to put one's finger on.
Without a question, it's a movie every parent must see, because to them, it may be the most important movie of the year.
A brilliantly layered film ... another home run for Fincher and about as close to perfection one can hope for with such a complex tale.
A really innovative way to explore a potentially boring subject like economics in a way that mass audiences can understand and appreciate.
A truly memorable horror classic filled with the same degree of tension and emotion as the Swedish film.
