Has some problems with its pacing and tone especially when it switches gears in the second half, but Liman and his cast do a commendable enough job with difficult material.

Another fine example of Ferguson's ability to tackle a topic in a way that keeps you riveted to every single word, knowing full well how much better you'll be by knowing what you'll learn by paying attention.
Easily the worst movie of Craven's career and not even remotely scary or creepy or any of the things you expect from a good horror movie.
Absolutely brilliant work from Assayas, the most impressive film of his career, and quite an astounding career turn for Ramirez as well.
Another masterful benchmark in Clint Eastwood's illustrious career.
Ray Griggs takes the prize as the most annoying filmmaker to insert himself into his own movie ... and that INCLUDES 'Hollywood Leftist' Michael Moore.
Particularly disappointing following Korkakur's exceptional Icelandic work, and it leaves you wondering what whoever financed this movie was inhaling.
The perfect follow-up to "Jackass" if only because it's equally moronic, although in this case, it's not even remotely funny.
Extremely effective as its own movie but even more enjoyable when it connects together with the original, Paranormal Activity 2 is a movie that will satisfy the fans while offering a lot more layers.
Terrific performances elevate this inspirational courtroom/procedural drama above the standard Hollywood based on a true story fare.
If you're a fan of quality songwriting but haven't been exposed to Merritt's quirky and catchy tunes, you'll be suitably enamored by a film that's as charming and enjoyable as the band's music.
movie_title: Strange Powers: Stephin Merritt And The Magnetic Fields (2010)

movie_review_blurb: The combination of convoluted storytelling and often grueling-to-watch death traps will make you say, 'Thank God that's over!' ... and you may as well be referring to the entire franchise at this point.
'Hornet's Nest' wraps everything up in a nice bundle, even if it takes far too long to get going; the last two movies could have easily been condensed down into one stronger movie.
movie_title: The Girl Who Kicked the Hornet's Nest (2010)

movie_review_blurb: On par with Danny Boyle's milestone benchmarks, 127 Hours is a visually-stunning, visceral and emotional experience that makes it one of the year's best films.
A sweet and warm comedy that always brings its focus back to the laughs even when dealing with very real and serious relationship issues.
Fails to deliver an emotional impact, and that's mainly due to its schizophrenic nature. The results are a movie as disjointed as its title makes it sound.
If you're a fan of Helms or Reilly, neither of them disappoint, but with so many strong elements, we were hoping for something a bit more memorable.
May be one of the most patently incompetent action-thrillers we've seen in some time.
A better than average horror premise and some clever bits that are often enough to make up for the more obvious moments that foray into cliché territory.
Its premise fails to pull the viewer in because it goes off on too many tangents and the few twists are so obvious you immediately can figure out where it's heading.
One of those movies that may have looked better on paper and probably should have stayed there.
Explores interesting ideas within the world of psychiatry and pharmaceuticals by transplanting them into a classic thriller setting.
A great look at the history of [New York City] and a pivotal turning point when things changed so drastically.
There's nothing cool or sexy or thrilling about this lame attempt at a revenge thriller that deserves any attention beyond the DVD bin.
If you're looking for a fun and stylish old school action flick then you can probably do far worse than this.
As outrageous as the premise may seem, there's enough laughs to make up for the predictable road comedy formula we've seen so many times before.
A good way to ruin the 'Die Hard' franchise. Terrible.
movie_title: A Good Day To Die Hard (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Another attempt to adapt a young adult novel that fails to justify the adaptation.
An incredible human story filled with tension and drama that leaves you thinking in a way we rarely get from typical 'action movies' these days.
Mostly bland and often confusing, Phantom had potential to be a better movie.
Creative film storytelling at its finest and a truly unique coming-of-age tale.
Does a good job relaying the facts and why it's become so difficult to overcome the problems but also an incredibly emotional film.
There's only so much Mia Wasikowska navel-gazing anyone should be forced to bear.
The perfect blend of Frank L. Baum, Sam Raimi and Disney... and a movie that's as entertaining as the 1939 classic.
It eventually elevates itself above its genre, which can be fully attributed to Paul Weitz's knack for this type of material and the brilliant pairing of Tina Fey with Paul Rudd.
If you're a fan of the band and want to learn more about its relatively new frontman, then the film is a must-see.
Not particularly funny or clever, it often hits the lows of some of the worst Adam Sandler and Will Ferrell character comedies.
As edgy and in-your-face as Fight Club, Spring Breakers may be just as divisive.
A truly original character piece, hilariously funny and poignant, with enough humor and heart that more people will be able to relate to the characters than they'll care to admit.
Even with its share of tonal shifts, this is a fun follow-up to Lovers of Hate as Poyser shows he can work with a bigger budget and more ideas.
Upstream Color is cinema as art and it's the type of art that can lead to lots of conversations, presumably intelligent philosophical ones.
A study of relationships between men and women and how attraction and chemistry can get in the way of keeping a friendship platonic.
Has a couple of true revelatory moments, but the script could be better so that it didn't constantly have to rely on the music to drive the movie... and ultimately, save it.
There's probably an audience for Baytown Outlaws, but it's not one anyone might want to spend 90 minutes with in a movie theater.
The pace is slow at times, but the results are satisfying enough to want more.
It's quite astounding to see Way taking huge spills at some of his jumps only to get back on his board and try again.
A fantastic sophomore effort from Juan Bayona that reaches the emotional and filmmaking heights that Spielberg and Eastwood have been trying to achieve for years.
Radnor shows incredible growth both as a filmmaker and actor to create an incredibly clever and entertaining film that goes beyond the normal rom-com genre.
David O. Russell has turned Matthew Quick's novel into an easily accessible romantic comedy that pulls you in with its immediacy.
Not the fastest-moving action movie you'll see, but it remains true to the comics thanks to Karl Urban's spot-on portrayal of Dredd.
A fairly well-rounded film offering enough in terms of entertainment value to make up for any shortcomings.
Fairly obvious and predictable, it's just the type of safe and bland fare that should do very well among mainstream audiences.
Stephen Chbosky has created an intensely honest and personal look at high school friendships and first love, full of entertaining retro fun and deeply poignant moments.
movie_title: The Perks of Being a Wallflower (2012)

movie_review_blurb: An entertaining inspirational story about people making a difference that should at least get the viewer interested in exploring the realities in making change.
A near-perfect film, one of the must-experience films of the year and destined to be a classic.
There isn't a lot of new ground being broken in what ends up being a perfectly respectable action sequel and little more.
Offers enough seriously scary moments to feel somewhat fresh due to the way Derickson blends overused horror clichés with more original and disturbing visuals.
The Bond movie every James Bond fan, new or old, will want to see.
The filmmakers now realize they can just do the exact same thing for a fourth time and the fans will eat it up, even if it does nothing to move the overall story forward.
Much like the original Death at a Funeral, it offers enough huge physically-driven laughs that it makes up for some of the lazier storytelling decisions.
A beautifully touching true story that never feels like the typical biopic since it finds a way of instilling humor and charm into a delicate and often tragic situation.
Like an overly long perfume commercial, Anna Karenina is as stylishly extravagant as it is dull and pretentious.
Anthony Hopkins' thoroughly entertaining take on Hitchcock and his great scenes with Helen Mirren drive the movie enough that you should be able to enjoy it for that alone.
Powerful enough to leave you wondering whether the Catholic Church will ever stop protecting child molesters.
movie_title: Mea Maxima Culpa: Silence In The House Of God (2012)

movie_review_blurb: An excellent transition into film [for David Chase] even if it's likely to have a far more limited audience than "The Sopranos."
Could have easily been a movie just about the relationship between the President and the King of England--it would have been much better movie, even if it would still feel like one we've seen before.
Jacques Audiard continues to strive to make films so distinctively singular in their originality, no one in Hollywood would even consider remaking this.
movie_title: De rouille et d'os (Rust and Bone) (2012)

movie_review_blurb: May be one of the most worthless remakes in recent memory and this is coming from someone who didn't hate Len Wiseman's Total Recall.
Fans of vintage Scorsese, Tarantino and Guy Ritchie should appreciate Dominik's stylish character-driven gangster thriller.
Not quite on par with The Hurt Locker in terms of intensity or entertainment value, Zero Dark Thirty eventually finds its footing to become a film with real weight.
An Unexpected Journey may as well be The Phantom Menace and God help us all if the next two movies aren't better than this one.
The refreshingly simple storytelling and authentic small town feel makes it a very special film indeed.
Tom Hooper has created an unprecedented musical experience, a powerful and unforgettable showstopper of a film.
Zemeckis drives the drama with strong performances and enough moments that keep the overly long movie from turning into a complete snoozefest.
Not nearly as strong as Cianfrance's previous movie, but it comes across as an interesting dramatic storytelling experiment that ultimately pays off.
A better Die Hard movie than the most recent Die Hard, but it's hard to quantify its entertainment value due to how ridiculous the whole thing comes across.
Most of the high points involve its bigger action set pieces, but other parts just don't work as well because it never quite finds the right overall tone.
A fun and interesting twist on the travelogue sub-genre of horror ... far better than many horror movies with twice the budget.
Enough solid dramatic moments that make it far more interesting than the typical "found footage" movie.
Holofcener's best script to date and performances by Louis-Dreyfus and Gandolfini make it one of her most enjoyable films.
Those who dig what Metallica do will certainly appreciate what they and Antal have done to create a very different experience from other concert docs that have come out in recent years.
Will hold infinitely more interest for those already intrigued by Assange's activities than those trying to learn more about WikiLeaks and its origins.
Simply the most spectacular movie you'll see this year.
A worthy follow-up even if there's less creativity involved once the central premise is introduced.
movie_title: Cloudy with a Chance of Meatballs 2 (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Paul Greengrass has created another gripping thriller with clear intentions to create as realistic a portrayal of actual events as possible.
Brutal and relentless, it's hard to recommend 12 Years a Slave whole-heartedly even though it's incredibly well directed and acted across the board.
An entertaining blend of fantasy and science fiction ... it's not the perfect sequel but it gets pretty damn close.
More in line with About Schmidt than Sideways, Alexander Payne's latest is a warm and witty look at the relationship between fathers and sons...
Significantly better than the first movie ... leaving you breathlessly waiting for the next chapter.
Prisoners offers strong drama, suspense and intrigue within a crime thriller that constantly leaves you guessing where it's going.
Philomena is one of those movies that plasters a big smile on your face with its sense of warmth and the originality of its storytelling.
A few minor changes and another strong, rounded performance by Josh Brolin helps Spike Lee's remake overcome some of the problems inherent in revisiting known source material.
One of the Coen Brothers' more enigmatic offerings ... gets major points for the authentic folk music and an unforgettable committed performance by Oscar Isaac.
A solidly-directed thriller that could easily appeal to a wider audience than the arthouse crowd.
Other than some decent performances from Bale and Harrelson, this feels like it could have been executed better.
A welcome return to form for Peter Jackson that should help remind everyone why they loved 'The Lord of the Rings' trilogy so much.
movie_title: The Hobbit: The Desolation of Smaug (2013)

movie_review_blurb: A definite must-see for long-time Disney fans.
Enough quotable quips and laughs to enjoy the movie as a whole ... but when it goes off the rails and starts getting silly, it has a hard time recovering.
A brilliantly witty take on the world of the stock market that's on par with Scorsese classics like Goodfellas and Casino.
A solid effort from director Peter Berg in turning Marcus Luttrell's story into a edge-of-your-seat military thriller that never feels over-the-top or sensationalistic.
Like all relationships, it's a complicated film that's hard to love but impossible to hate, and though it gets better once it overcomes its painfully dull first hour, it still feels uneven at best.
A great introduction to the band as well as a great recap for the fans who have been there all along the way.
An absolute joy of a film and a masterpiece in terms of storytelling, Ben Stiller has become a serious director who seems like he's capable of doing anything.
movie_title: The Secret Life Of Walter Mitty (2013)

movie_review_blurb: Another dumb action movie with a couple of fun fight sequences, none of which make up for the weak cliché-filled story that tries too hard to be a serious drama.
Anderson has created another unmistakably unique work, an intriguing look at grassroots religion through the relationship between two men who couldn't seem more different.
An awe-inspiring story filled with nail-biting, fast-paced racing scenes ... right up there with some of Ron Howard's best films.
Just a beautiful film and a real crowd pleaser.
It's painfully obvious Stephenie Meyer is a one-trick pony and a trick like Twilight you can only really pull off once.
This political conspiracy thriller benefits from its strong script and cast, but an overabundance of satellite characters results in an erratic and disjointed effort.
The type of film that makes you ponder long and hard afterwards to appreciate what Antonio Campos was trying to achieve.
The movie tries to achieve something we've seen done so much better in the past without the level of writing necessary to make it work.
From any other director, Trance would be just fine, but coming from Danny Boyle after such a long gap, it's hard not to be disappointed by what is clearly weaker material.
Loach's best film since The Wind That Shakes the Barley.
A terrifically layered film that really leaves you thinking and wanting to talk about what you've just watched afterwards
A powerful and effective film that really gets across the tense situation in Northern Ireland in a way unlike any other movie
Seems far too clever to be a summer release--those who enjoy fun heist movies should appreciate how unique this one is from others.
Enough laughs and entertainment value you have to give them more than a little credit for what they're able to pull off and get away with.
An amazing group of women with stories that need to be heard and seen to be believed.
It's not Pixar's most innovative or clever movie by any means, but it ultimately delivers in terms of offering something to entertain everyone.
Motors along at such a slow pace it hardly earns its moniker of 'thriller,' often keeping any real tension at an aggravating minimum.
Plays with scale in ways that allows it to feel like a big movie at times but it also has enough intimate moments to keep sight of the fact that it's a character piece.
An uninspired formula comedy that wastes every iota of that talent on a movie genre that should have been retired at least five years ago.
Shows how a fairly simple concept and plot can be transformed by a master filmmaker into literally one of the most entertaining and fun movies of the summer.
The best comic book movie of the summer and one that rarely feels like a comic book movie.
Maybe fashioning it as a trilogy with "Shaun" and "Hot Fuzz" wasn't a great idea since it leads to comparisons it can't possibly live up to being such a different movie.
For a film that starts as a 'fish out of water' comedy, it's not that funny, instead feeling more disjointed and all over the place in terms of tone and even dull at times.
An incredibly catchy attempt at a retro sex comedy ... while it does go a bit overboard with the raunch at times, it offers enough solid laughs to make it worthwhile.
You have to give Ponsoldt some credit for getting strong and naturalistic performances out of the entire cast.
A surprisingly fun action comedy that you can enjoy in the moment but also one that's likely to play just as well on repeat viewings.
There isn't a ton of heavy thinking involved with the high concept premise but it works better than one might expect.
Any attempt at heavy political commentary tends to get diluted by the film's desires to be accepted as a summer action movie.
So faithful to the comics that whether you like the movie or not may already be determined by whether or not they're to your taste.
While the filmmakers clearly did their homework on how to make a scary gorefest, they fail to give us something that feels particularly new or different.
Whether or not you agree with the characters' motivations, it's far too easy to understand how the world we currently live in can lead to something like this happening.
As much a curiosity as it is a boldly brilliant adaptation that captures the best moments of Mitchell's novel while improving upon the structure and enhancing the main themes.
Isn't a terrible movie, it's just a lot of fluff that serves very little purpose beyond 100 minutes of forgettable entertainment.
Works well as a character piece, mainly due to Ponsoldt's handling of the material and Winstead's memorable portrayal of an alcoholic trying to regain control.
Takes some time to find its footing, but its emotive equine star and a wonderful last act will ultimately win over even the chronically cynical.
Meryl Streep once again proves to be working on another plane than the actors around her.
Has some nice moments but overall is a failure in its exploration of the subject matter and it feels more exploitative than entertaining.
Far more than just the simple domestic drama it pretends to be, filled with subliminally veiled statements that add up to something with far more layers and levels.
Bruce Wilkinson, the film's late writer and executive producer, is more than likely turning in his own grave.
An incredibly powerful film that will inform anyone who doesn't realize the huge contribution Belafonte has made to making the world a better place.
Evans proves he's the real deal with impressive visuals and fast-paced setpieces on par with Guy Ritchie, Park Chan-wook and Quentin Tarantino.
It feels like a wasted effort that such a strong filmmaker would needlessly water down a serious topic for easier consumption like this.
The type of heavy drama that might not necessarily play for mass audiences but the skill of filmmaking and talented cast should bring the film some critical prestige.
It's hard to fully appreciate [the film] just for Lynskey's performance, which is often it's one saving grace.
A strong drama that may seem simple at first, but it's likely to leave you wondering whether what you watched was real or whether the various stories were all just layers of fiction.
As disturbing as it is, it's even moreso when you realize it's based on true events.

With a fun group of characters and cool set pieces that take advantage of the IMAX format, it always manages to entertain despite the rather lazy central plot that may have been more effective say 25 years ago.
A textbook study on how to do horror in a way that offers scares and surprises at every turn.
If you're looking to watch Daniel Radcliffe walk around a house and aren't necessarily looking for a deep or scary movie, than maybe this is for you.
Only works as long as you're willing to overlook some of the obvious discrepancies in the use of its format and feel it's a story worth telling regardless.
The historic storyline is far better done than the present day one, which ultimately leads to half a decent movie and another half that's almost unbearable.
Those looking for a relatively enjoyable spy film with some solid action sequences probably won't be too disappointed with the by-the-books nature of Safe House.
An incredibly beautiful story that uses animation to truly push boundaries in what types of stories can be told in the format.
An insulting mess that expects the IQ and taste of all women to be so easy to manipulate they'll accept or laugh at anything if it involves men humiliating themselves on their behalf.
There's a fine line between jarring and unwatchable that Ghost Rider Spirit of Vengeance gleefully straddles which might make one wonder who exactly was meant to enjoy this experience.
There is absolute brilliance at work here both in the way Weitz tells Nick Flynn's story and how he gets such fantastic performances out of De Niro and Dano.

Feel free to formulate your own greater meaning to Free Fire if you wish. I think it's just a shoot-em-up with a gimmick. Luckily, it's got enough action and humor to remain entertaining almost all the way through.
The Lobster is not for everybody. But if you're adventurous and patient, there are ample rewards to be had.
It reminds us repeatedly of how fragile civilization was in the Old West.
If this sounds like standard disaster movie stuff, it is, but Berg keeps it brisk and crisp.
Days of Future Past was a doozy. Apocalypse... not so much.

Southside With You isn't just a crystal ball look at history in the making. It's fun to peek into the past and figure out how Barack and Michelle became who they are today, but these characters also exude a timeless, universal appeal.
The Light Between Oceans is a tearjerker that plays like an extra long Lifetime TV movie with a Grade A cast.
Hands of Stone has feet in concrete.
If you're a fan of indie films, comedy, improv comedy, and/or well-textured ensemble acting, then go see Don't Think Twice. Mike Birbiglia's latest is rich and rewarding.
Hell or High Water takes a story that's been told many times before and makes it feel vital.
Pete's Dragon is a nice little Disney film, and my use of the words "nice" and "little" is in no way intended to be dismissive.
It's a modest tale about the roles we play, told in an unusual fashion. There are rewards to be had here, if you're willing to meet the filmmaker halfway.
He was a troublemaker, and a visionary. Sometimes Frank Zappa's sneer made me angry. But his challenges made me better. He made a lot of us better.
movie_title: Eat That Question: Frank Zappa in His Own Words (2016)

movie_review_blurb: They're still delightfully awful, but not outrageous enough to watch.
The 2016 Ghostbusters is entertaining and funny. It never reaches the heights of the original, which is common with reboots.

You can laugh, wince, and squirm at Swiss Army Man. You can harvest the small truths, enjoy the lyrical moments...And when somebody asks you if you've seen any good movies lately, boy, will you have an interesting answer.

Mike and Dave are funny because Efron, DeVine, Kendrick and Plaza are pros. There are plenty of rude and crude moments in the movie, and I laughed a lot...I hit the wall about 20 minutes before the film ended, which isn't bad for a hard R comedy.
movie_title: Mike and Dave Need Wedding Dates (2016)

movie_review_blurb: It works in large part because of the swell cast.
Everybody Wants Some!! is a highly entertaining production that's easily as good as its title is bad.
Bad Moms is deeply flawed, but funny enough.
After nearly a year of hype, The Magnificent Seven has arrived and proven itself to be another entertaining if underwhelming remake of a well-regarded flick.
There are lots of nice moments and the cast is charming.
The Birth of a Nation may be a blend of indie sensibilities and Hollywood imagery, but it works.
Good, but not great
Kenneth Lonergan has crafted a film that speaks to the human condition without getting pretentious. Insight is rarely this accessible.
Jeff Nichols has made a fine, honest portrait of one couple's unwavering love, but he fails to present that portrait in a sufficiently rousing context. Shucks.
Want to know more about Ramanujan? Read one of the books about him, or check out the documentary on the man. Want a serviceable, but routine biopic? Look no further.
Instead of covering the standard biopic plot points, the film moves into lurid B movie territory.
I understand the appeal of vicarious brushes with death, I just don't share it.
When the big battle between two feuding factions of the Avengers finally happens, it's a doozy.
Hello My Name is Doris is a modest little comedy-drama that is beautifully cast. It's all about Sally Field and Max Greenfield. And trusting your instincts.
Despite its failings, there's a lot of magic in this movie.
It's funny, involving and touching in nice doses. Plus it stars Hailee Steinfeld and features our longtime pal Woody Harrelson. Kelly Fremon Craig has made a dandy directorial debut.
Amy Adams is spot on in the lead role, admirably keeping the story on track and not seizing a flashy scene for the consideration of Oscar voters. She does everything right.
A star is born in Sasha Lane, and you're invited to go with her into writer-director Arnold's mesmerizing (and mostly credible) tale of Dickensian life in Wal-Mart America.
The Accountant is entertaining junk.
A nice mix of bitter and sweet, with a strong cast.
movie_title: A Man Called Ove (En man som heter Ove) (2016)

movie_review_blurb: Certain Women isn't about resolutions. It's about how certain women interact, or try to, with certain others. Search for monolithic statements about men and women if you want, or just watch and listen to these particular individuals.
This is one of those films where knowing how it ends makes it better.
Simply an exercise in hyper-violent showboating, a nihilistically pure look at impurity.
Despite a few stylistic flourishes, the production is an earnest and straightforward account of what happened, with moments of naturalistic humor based on some major miscommunication.

Salgado has been called a voyeur of global pain. Does his work objectify suffering? Is it grief porn? Does the photographer overtly anesthetize human misery? I believe beauty and great pain can coexist without one trivializing the other.
As an action movie, it is an exercise in excess, albeit one with a knockout color scheme.
Reaches its goal with a skewed, satisfying closing scene.
What a treat it is to peep in on these clever, nasty people and their scandalous goings on.
Starts off as a spoof of the world of pornographic moviemaking, then smoothly turns into a gripping study of codependency.
Best film of 2001.
Fails to do more than colorfully skim the surface of its subject's life
A script so unrealistic that it could only take place in a parallel universe.
One of the most captivating failures of the year.
Just a lame cowboy movie that doesn't warrant your attention. Or mine.
Little more than an occasionally amusing, often maddening rip-off of old Woody Allen multirelationship films.
John Moore delivers exactly the movie you would expect from a director of a Sega ad.

Charming, inventive and witty
For some, the conversations will be like fingernails across a blackboard. For others, the discussions will be as involving as the visuals are lilting.
Offers a series of arresting visuals that play off the dramatic lighting and superb black and white photography.
A sweet, wispy little romantic comedy.
An exercise in quiet elegance and disarming earthiness.
Contains no great revelations, but a lot of outstanding performances.
Tackling a Barney-like kiddie-show icon in 2002 - how daring and timely! Where will you aim your bold comedic sword next, Mr. DeVito? Reaganomics?
Director David Fincher is on cruise control here, his ambition apparently sated by the knockout title sequence and jazzy camerawork.
The credits list the film as being "written and directed" by Paul W.S. Anderson. "Programmed by" would be a more accurate credit.
By the time the production reaches its third act, it is nothing but car crashes and shoot-outs.
The dynamic personalities of the characters more than compensate for any slight deficits in the laugh department.
Everything feels rushed. Instead of drinking in the futuristic wonders, we are shooed forward like tourists on a cut-rate package deal.
Serviceable entertainment; the kind of film one expects to see released in the early months of a new year.
Informative and thoughtful, presenting a pivotal battle with clarity and all of the people in the middle of it with reverence.
The feel bad movie of the winter.
A tightly constructed, chilling drama with welcome doses of gallows humor.
Extremely likable because it is so specific

Hopefully, even those who fail to accept the director's stylistic experiments will still appreciate the beautifully acted, disarming picture of youth and love.

Compared to most of the youth oriented fare released over the last few months, "40 Days and 40 Nights" shines

movie_review_blurb: Now here's something you don't see everyday: a movie title that matches the number of stars most critics are going to give to it.
Pixar continues to dazzle.
Wicked fun and another feather in the cap of Kevin Smith.
movie_title: Jay and Silent Bob Strike Back (2001)

movie_review_blurb: A dull, depressing exercise in amateurism from a filmmaker in serious decline.
A great goofy delight, a dandy mix of energetic performances, inspired sight gags and flat-out silliness.
The dreamiest Jesse James ever, looking less like a bandit and more like the grand prize in my sister's old 'Mystery Date' board game.
The movie is entertainingly bad.
Sets out to be a classic ghost story, but fails to grasp that special something that makes such films more than layers of mist.
This is a bumpy ride.
Gives us another chance to experience the skewed vision of Tim Burton.
The film offers no grand statements, just a clever idea and exceptional cast.
As a Hollywood satire, America's Sweethearts is toothless. As a romance, it is at best a minor pleasure.
Bright, busy and visually diverting, but not very much fun.

Witnessing De Niro, Norton, Brando and Bassett act in this film is like watching Mark McGwire and Sammy Sosa play softball. You're not sure why they're doing it, but you wouldn't miss the game for anything.
Despite the idiotic people, the absurd level of coincidence, the spotty special effects and the lazy ending, I still liked Jurassic Park III.
The filmmakers clearly realize they are making a formulaic, crowd-pleasing girl power movie and they know how to do it.
Rush Hour 2 isn't as good as the original, but it offers more than enough entertainment to warrant your time and money.
Surrounds a weird, funny and touching story with a knockout series of songs performed by an exceptional cast.
Jeepers Creepers may sputter in the last reel, but it still delivers enough style and scares to warrant a look by horror aficionados.
Inoffensive, but utterly generic, the baseball-related romantic comedy does little more than kill time.
For those who marvel at dinosaurs, this is an absolute must-see.
Plays as primarily an academic exercise, engaging the eyes, ears and intellect, but not the heart.
If you're the kind of person that questions the fantastic and expects a story to respect its own logic, then you should take some aspirin before seeing this movie.
The film is a silly, pretentious and generally entertaining yarn about the pissing war between a fallen leader and a wannabe.
While the film sags in spots, it is remarkably rich and robust, with a wealth of memorable performances.
Ups the fear factor by adding an anonymous figure, one that cannot be reasoned with, whose only goal is to get his hands on you.
A windy, moderately entertaining trifle. You could do a lot worse than "Bandits," but the filmmakers could have done much better.
These are frightening, uncertain times and there is something soothing about watching a movie and knowing exactly what is going to happen.
Those able to withstand the intensity and violence will be rewarded with solid acting by Ethan Hawke and a towering performance from Denzel Washington.
I found Bully absolutely riveting.
Purports to show the incalculable impact a mentor can have on a child, but offers a contradictory message through its depiction of the adult version of that child.
The story degenerates steadily and finally becomes just another horror show with a psycho chasing adolescents.

A minor pleasure, with a strong first half, a tepid second half and a hell of a performance from Mark Wahlberg.
Beneath the sappy music and formulaic story, the core of the film rang true.
The storyline gets buried by the filmmakers insistence on trying to be cruder than all the other gross-out comedies.
I suspect this is the kind of production that would have been funnier if the director had released the outtakes theatrically and used the film as a bonus feature on the DVD.
An ethical thriller about two men whose biggest enemy is not each other, but their unwillingness to take responsibility for their own actions.
The film loses steam whenever it shifts from the teen killers to the adult pair investigating the crime.
Locke is a great looking and sounding tale of a man's (misguided?) quest to do the right thing.

The Theory of Everything offers interesting characters and standout acting. I wish it had delved deeper into its characters, but for what it is -- a romance involving one of the great minds of humanity -- it's engaging and moving.
Hoffman is in fine form here and, despite a long murky stretch, the film works.
It's colorful and fun, a good, but not great Disney cartoon.
The Drop is an atmospheric crime story with fine performances, especially from star Tom Hardy. As for the plot - well, it keeps the characters busy.
The black and white images are beautifully composed, the classic "Academy" square screen ratio adds to the atmosphere and the music is sparse and effective.
Citizenfour deserves your attention.
I had a better time than I expected.

movie_review_blurb: Love is Strange is lovely, painful and universal.
I had more fun watching Guardians of the Galaxy than I've had in a long time.
I've been bullied and I've been a bully, and I don't enjoy watching it onscreen. I loved Whiplash, though.
More a character study than a thriller, Nightcrawler is well-acted and compelling.
Some may find it too outlandish, but it never fails to remain interesting.
Is Birdman an indictment of Hollywood for playing to the crowds? That would be odd coming from a movie stuffed with camera gimmicks, eye candy, dirty jokes and stunt casting.
Life Itself is an exceptional look at this exceptional man. Wouldn't it have been interesting to read Ebert's assessment of the film?
Rock's best work yet.
Writer-director Gillian Robespierre and star Jenny Slate team up to create a fine portrait of a twenty-something comedian dealing with life as a struggling performer in New York City.
Reeves is charismatic and kind of otherworldly, and the stunts are shot and presented clearly enough that you can tell what's going on. What else do you need?
Director Thomas Vinterberg crafts a handsome film, then lets the string section goo everything up.

[I] loved most of the exchanges between the characters. Appreciated the Avengers' attempts to avoid destruction in population centers. The action scenes were very exciting and clever, but I had trouble keeping up with the visuals.
Powerhouse dystopian chase film/thriller/political statement from Alfonso Cuarón.

It would've been nice to tell you Insurgent was surprisingly good. Or fun to rant and rave about how lousy it is. But no. It's just there, another middle installment of another teen-targeted post-apocalyptic series.
You don't have to be a Star Trek fan to enjoy this rollicking movie. J.J. Abrams' reboot of the 1966 TV space adventure series is fast-paced, action-packed and lots of fun.
The rich, dark production is the 25th directorial turn by Clint Eastwood and is perhaps his best work yet.
The movie pays off so well because it places you fully in the shoes of the men, from their fears and obsessions to their paranoia about virtually every Iraqi citizen they encounter.
Crash is the best film I've seen so far this year.
Danny Boyle and company have crafted a film that feels like a project of citizens of the world, not outsiders looking in.

No Country for Old Men is wide and dusty and terribly bleak. It's beautifully photographed and assembled, with great performances from its lead players and a number of welcome appearances by actors we haven't seen enough of lately.
One of the very best films of 2011.
The shocking violence is well-placed. The action scenes are always comprehensible -- no jump cut cheats here -- and the suspense will make you fidget in your seat. What a corker.

Even though the ending is well known, Affleck masterfully maintains the tension, tempering it with welcome laughs provided by two veteran filmmakers involved in the scheme (Alan Arkin and John Goodman).
12 Years a Slave is the clearest view of slavery I've seen onscreen.
The adaptation of John Green's best-selling young adult novel gets downright gloppy at times, even as Hazel and Augustus strive to remain brave and unsentimental. But it touched my heart and mind.
Joyeux Noel is a fascinating piece of work that manages to be moving without becoming maudlin.
We've got a movie about a futuristic city that doesn't spend much time in the futuristic city, instead focusing on a road trip/chase plot line with mostly uninteresting characters.
The film offers grand visuals, including a bizarre-beautiful key scene in a location I couldn't describe if I wanted to.

Moneyball looks like an underdog sports movie, but it veers away from the path usually followed by films of the genre. My suggestion is that you set aside any preconceptions and just go with the flow.
Too busy, with too many characters and too much going on. Still, the film retains enough charm to offset the excess.

movie_review_blurb: Most of the film is quite entertaining, mixing scares with welcome bits of humor, but the ending fizzles.
Lower your expectations. A lot. No, more than that.
Adam Sandler is an extremely likable man who knows his limitations and works within them.
Pulses with fascinating ideas, memorable images and thrilling action sequences.

Snappier than the first.
movie_title: Harry Potter and the Chamber of Secrets (2002)

A thoroughly enjoyable "B" Movie all trussed up in "A" Movie trappings.
Brash, funny, sexually frank and extremely smart.
Derailed by an idiotic, utterly needless plot gimmick.

A breezy romantic comedy that has the punch of a good sitcom, while offering exceptionally well-detailed characters.
Well, it's not as bad as the last one.
movie_title: Star Wars: Episode II - Attack of the Clones (2002)

movie_review_blurb: Powerful, disturbing, funny, thought provoking, moving and infuriating.

Better than Generations and Insurrection, but not as good as First Contact.

One thing's for sure. You won't see another documentary like this one.

Shaky in spots, but rewarding overall.
